PROCTEXT.PARA: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.
Motion (by Senator Durack)-by leave-agreed to:
That so much of the sessional orders be suspended as would prevent petitions lodged with the Clerk being presented this day.
The Deputy Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That we are concerned that an increasing number of Australian families are facing financial burdens beyond their capacity to meet.
2. That we are concerned that the amount of financial assistance being afforded to families is inadequate.
3. That there has been no increase in family allowances for most families for some years.
4. That family allowances in all instances have declined in real value since 1976.
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, will:
1. Ensure that there is an increase in family allowances in the 1982 Budget so that family allowances are at least restored to the real money value of their 1976 level;
2. Ensure that provision is made for the automatic and regular indexation of family allowances;
3. Ensure that proper consideration is given to the introduction of a Homemakers Allowance.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle (from 8,422 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of Australia, concerned about the high and increasing rate of divorce and family breakdown, convinced that the Family Law Act has weakened marriage by making divorce a trivial matter, the present Act paying scant regard to its own definition of marriage as a life-long union, and believing that the legal bond of marriage should be strengthened, humbly petition for the Family Law Act and the Marriage Act to be amended in order to:
(1) Reject any moves towards divorce by post
(2) Restore the former prohibition of marriages between close relatives by blood or marriage
(3) Protect the rights and welfare of aggrieved partners of a marriage who are threatened with being divorced against their will
(4) Ensure that in divorce judgements paramount attention be given to whatever course will best serve the welfare of dependent children of the marriage
(5) Encourage counselling towards reconciliation
(6) Restore objective tests to irretrievable breakdown of marriage in terms of: (i) intolerable behaviour; (ii) desertion for 2 years; (iii) separation for 3 years.
And we pray that you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our nation .

PETITION.TITLE: Pensioner Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:

That it is clearly apparent that Australian society is becoming more polarised- that the rich at home and abroad are becoming richer, profitting from Australia' s mineral wealth, whilst pensioners and the disadvantaged, some three million people, are becoming a race apart.

That, of necessity, the Federal Government take action that all Australians share the wealth of their country by the transfer of resources to income security, health care and housing. Therefore, your petitioners urge that:
1. All pensions and benefits be raised to at least 30 per cent of the National Average Male Earnings seasonally adjusted.
2. Removal of the means/income test on the Pensioner Health Benefit imposed by Federal legislation 1973.
Reintroduction of Medibank in so doing restore all Australians to equality of citizenship.

3. To alleviate Australia's shortage of housing stock within the capacity of people to pay (rental and ownership) the Federal Government immediately inject $ 200 million into State Housing Authorities, which will, in addition, alleviate unemployment.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Passport: Reissue
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That Mary Woodrow is a citizen of Australia. That the reissue of a passport to her has been refused. That this refusal prevents her access to the culture of her birth (Thailand) and to access to her mother and grandparents, therefore causing great hardship.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that a passport be issued to Mary Woodrow.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Employment of Early Childhood Consultant
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That citizens of South Australia are gravely concerned over a recent decision by the Commonwealth Public Service not to renew the employment of Miss Joan Fry with the Commonwealth Department of Education and to eliminate her position as Early Childhood Consultant and Assistant Secretary to the Educational Planning Group of that Department.

Since June 1976, Miss Fry has served the Department in the capacity of Early Childhood Consultant and Assistant Secretary to the Educational Planning Group of the Department of Education. Miss Fry is a distinguished early childhood educator whose contributions to education are widely recognised. During 1973 she served as chairman of the Australian Preschools Committee which produced a report ''Care and Education of Young Children'' known as the ''Fry Report''. The extensive nature and worth of her contributions to children's services were recognised when she was awarded an Order of the British Empire in 1981.

We believe that no useful purpose could be gained by terminating Miss Fry's appointment to the Educational Planning Group and, further, that Australia would be deprived of the services of a distinguished person, and that children's services would be adversely impacted by the elimination of the early childhood consultant position on the Educational Planning Group.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled , should take every step as necessary to ensure that the Australian Government retain the services of this distinguished early childhood educator and that the position of Early Childhood Consultant and Assistant Secretary to the Educational Planning Group of the Commonwealth Department of Education be maintained.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
(i) community based child care centres are widely recognised as beneficial to both parents and children.

(ii) the implementation of the recommendations contained in the Review of Children's Services Program (Spender Report) denies the expansion of community based child care centres and threatens existing centres.
(iii) such denial and threat is contrary to the expressed desires of parents.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
1. the recommendations of the Review of Children's Services Program (Spender Report) be rejected
2. the Government immediately instruct (through the Minister for Social Security) the Office of Child Care to reverse decisions to reject 500 applications for funding under the Child Care Act (1972)
3. the Minister for Social Security immediately request the Government to respond favourably to the expressed desires of parents for the provision of community based child care centres.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That a select committee, to be known as the Select Committee on the Electoral System, be appointed to inquire into and report upon all aspects of the conduct of elections for the Parliament of the Commonwealth and matters related thereto, including, without limiting the generality of the foregoing-
(a) public funding and disclosure of sources of funds;
(b) electoral advertising;
(c) franchise and registration of voters;
(d) voting systems;
(e) polling procedures;
(f) legislation governing, and operation of, the Australian Electoral Office;
(g) ballot paper format;
(h) media coverage; and
(i) electoral distribution procedures and systems.
(2) That provisions relating to the composition and powers of the Committee be contained in a subsequent resolution.
(3) That the date on which the Committee shall commence its inquiry be contained in a subsequent resolution.

DEBATE.TITLE: UNITED STATES OF AMERICA: ELECTRONIC EQUIPMENT IN AUSTRALIA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate is of the opinion that the appropriate Senate committee should call Dr Desmond Ball of the Strategic and Defence Studies Centre in Canberra to enable him to be questioned on the accuracy of his assertions that the United States national security agency operates highly sophisticated electronic equipment in Australia which is not subject to direction by the Australian Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate:
1. Notes the cynical and manipulative campaign by the South Australian Tonkin Government to survive by making South Australia part of the nuclear fuel cycle;

2. Notes that as part of this campaign for survival the Tonkin Government has initiated a campaign of deception on the benefits of the Roxby Downs mining project and on the dangers of the uranium industry;

3. Recognises that the Roxby Downs Indenture Bill commits the South Australian people to an outlay of more than $50m with a non-guaranteed return of 0.68 per cent per annum on outlaid capital expenditure;
4. Recognises that uranium mined at Roxby Downs will add to the world's enormous stockpile of nuclear weapons and high level nuclear waste;
5. Recognises that such an agreement displays the economic incompetence and social irresponsibility of the failing Tonkin Government;

6. Applauds the people of South Australia for their perceptiveness in rejecting the Roxby Downs campaign of the Government at the recent Mitcham by-election and as evidenced in the latest public opinion polls, which by their evidence of overwhelming Labor support in South Australia show that the Tonkin Government's campaign has been a total failure; and

7. Encourages all South Australians to demonstrate their opposition to the Roxby Downs Indenture Bill in all possible ways, commencing by attending the rally organised for Saturday, 29 May 1982, at 10.30 a.m.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DAIRY MANUFACTURING COMPANIES: ALLEGED MISUSE OF FUNDS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Durack, is almost a question with notice. I refer the Minister to a letter that I wrote to him, dated 26 May, in which the following questions appeared: 1. Senator Chaney told the Senate yesterday that the Minister for Primary Industry did not know of the misuse of funds by dairy manufacturers until last Wednesday. That being the case, did Mr Nixon comply with recommendation 8.7 of the Bowen guidelines by informing the Prime Minister or Acting Prime Minister that the matters raised a real or apparent conflict of interest for him? 2. Did the Prime Minister, if he was informed by Mr Nixon, comply with recommendation 8.7 (a) by arranging for another Minister to deal with the matter or giving explicit authorisation to Mr Nixon to proceed with it; (b) by recording the matter? 3. It was indicated at Question Time that the Minister for Primary Industry was obliged to hold shares in the Murray Goulburn dairy co-operative because he was a dairy farmer. Is he, in fact, still deriving his farm income from dairying or has he been involved for some time exclusively with beef cattle raising? 4. If he is no longer a dairy farmer, why does he continue to hold shares in a dairy co-operative with which his Department has dealings? 5. What steps have been taken to impose penalty interest payments on companies which have withheld Reserve Bank advances? 6. What is the period for which the misuse of advances of $11.7m, as indicated by the Australian Dairy Corporation on Monday, has occurred? 7. Are similar arrangements made by the Reserve Bank for other primary industries? 8. If so, what checks are made to see that the same abuses are not occurring?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answers to the series of questions which Senator Button has just asked, and of which he gave me notice yesterday, are as follows: As to whether Mr Nixon informed the Prime Minister or the Acting Prime Minister that the matters raised a real or apparent conflict of interest, he did not, for the following reasons. On 19 May Mr Nixon was advised of the present situation after the Australian Dairy Corporation investigations revealed the extent of the breaches. Immediately on receiving that advice Mr Nixon asked the Chairman of the Corporation, Mr Vawser, to return to Australia from London to deal with the matter personally. This is the only involvement that Mr Nixon has had with the ADC investigations. Mr Nixon has not been involved in any way in any decision making with regard to the question of certain dairy companies breaching ADC rules covering the provision of financial advances to those companies. The rules are laid down and administered by the ADC. It is the ADC that has detected these breaches and the ADC is quite properly following up with further investigations. The ADC has already taken action to ensure that all moneys so far found to be due for repayment, totalling $11.7m, either have been repaid or are properly accounted for. Mr Nixon expects to be kept fully informed of developments in the investigation by the ADC. Mr Nixon is well aware of recommendation 8.7 in the Bowen guidelines and will comply with them as circumstances may require. Question No. 2 does not arise, for the reasons given in answer to question No. 1 .

ANSWER.PARA: As to question No. 3, Mr Nixon is not involved exclusively with beef cattle raising; he is a dairy farmer and has also been a beef producer for many years. As to question No. 4, Mr Nixon and his family continue to hold 1,244 out of a total of nearly 18 1/2 million shares in the Murray Goulburn Co-op. because he continues to be a dairy farmer and supplies Murray Goulburn. For geographical reasons Mr Nixon has to supply Murray Goulburn and it is a policy of that co- operative to require regular suppliers also to be shareholders.

As to question No. 5, the ADC management is currently examining in detail the circumstances which have given rise to the situations which, prima facie, involve breaches of the Corporation's rules. At the same time, the ADC management is taking legal advice on the extent to which penalties can be enforced under the terms and conditions which apply to the ADC finance arrangements in relation to the purchase or loan of dairy products. Legal advice will be taken into account by the board of the ADC when it considers whether any penalties should apply. As to question No. 6, the ADC has advised that the amount of $11.7m was found to be immediately due to the ADC by the 10 companies nominated as a result of checks by ADC staff during the period 19 April to 21 May 1982. Further checks are being carried out as part of the Corporation's present investigations to ascertain the precise dates on which the breaches of the ADC terms and conditions occurred.

As to question No. 7, similar arrangements are made by the Rural Credits Department of the Reserve Bank for the Australian Egg Board, the Australian Honey Board, the Australian Canned Fruits Corporation and the Australian Wheat Board. As to question No. 8, the systems used by the abovementioned organisations are, as with the ADC, determined and supervised by each individual organisation. In the light of the situation regarding the ADC, other statutory authorities with similar systems are being asked to check their systems to ensure that similar situations have not occurred and cannot occur. However, it should be noted that all of these systems are subject to scrutiny by the Auditor -General.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. It relates to the Minister's answer to question No. 5, namely: What steps have been taken to impose penalty interest payments on companies which have withheld Reserve Bank funds? Is it not a fact that the Minister for Primary Industry is ultimately responsible for determining what penalty rates should apply and the level of those penalty rates ?

—As I have said, the Minister expects to be fully informed of the ADC investigations. As to what action should be taken, whether by the ADC or by him, that is a matter which has yet to be determined and which is the subject of legal consideration and advice. At the stage of its determination Senator Button 's question may apply.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. Recently I drew to the attention of the Minister for Administrative Services the matter of stolen trucks in Australia. My information, which came from a constituent who has spent many years working in the road transport industry, is that some 160 heavy road trucks were stolen and not recovered in Australia during the last three years. Some trucks that have been recovered indicated that the trucks are changed in such a professional way as to make them virtually unrecognisable to the original owner and that they are invariably resold in a different State from that in which they were stolen. My suggestion was that this could be the subject of discussions between State and Federal Ministers responsible for police. Can the Minister tell me the outcome of those discussions?

—Yes, I recall the attention of the Senate and the Government being drawn to the question of stolen trucks. We feel particularly indebted to Senator Thomas for bringing our attention to the fact that these trucks are sold across State borders. The Government has taken action on this matter. Indeed, I understand that as recently as a week or so ago the Minister was in discussion, through the Australian Police Ministers Council, with Mr Hinze from Queensland. There has been a reference from the Police Ministers Council to the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence. This co-operative body, which was recently announced and organised by the Federal Government, is proving its worth in terms of finding answers to the kinds of questions raised by Senator Thomas. As to any further information, I am unable to point out whether there has been any success in finding the culprits involved in these episodes. I will endeavour to obtain further information on the matter for Senator Thomas.

—While I do not expect the Minister representing the Minister for Health to have read the Manly Daily of last weekend, I wish to point out to him an article in it which states that valuable relics from the North Head quarantine station have disappeared over the years, with some of them ending up in private antique collections as far away as Western Australia. In view of this claim, and bearing in mind that the Federal Government will be handing over the land now occupied by the quarantine station to the New South Wales Government in the near future, why is the Federal Department of Health not co-operating with the National Parks and Wildlife Service of New South Wales by assisting it to make a survey of this area so that it can catalogue the artefacts and relics which are found there? Does the Minister not agree that such a survey is vitally necessary now, particularly when there is a distinct likelihood that the changeover will leave this section of North Head vacant for some time and thus susceptible to acts of vandalism?

—I do not know that the Department of Health is not co- operating, as suggested by Senator Sibraa. I would hope that the Department of Health would, as is its usual practice, co-operate fully in a matter of this kind that does involve it and a State department. I am aware of the negotiations that have gone on in relation to the North Head quarantine station, negotiations in which my colleague Mr MacKellar was vitally interested. As honourable senators will know, the area falls within his electorate of Warringah. If there are relics which are in danger and if they do need to be put on a register, that is something in which the new Minister for Health, who, as Senator Sibraa will know, represents the seat of Mackellar in the Warringah Shire, would want to have an interest. I will undertake to see that that matter is referred to him for his attention.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNIVERSITIES AND COLLEGES OF ADVANCED EDUCATION: AMALGAMATIONS

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Education confirm reports that the Commonwealth Government does not intend to insist on the still outstanding amalgamations of colleges of advanced education in Victoria and university and college amalgamations in New South Wales? How can the Government justify such an approach in the light of its insistence on the amalgamation of the James Cook University and the Townsville College of Advanced Education in Queensland?

—I am aware, as I think most honourable senators are, that the Government has been pursuing 30 amalgamations which are justified on sound educational grounds and that 24 of these 30 amalgamations are already in place. They include amalgamations in Senator Martin's State of Queensland. I am also aware that the Queensland Minister, recently, in letters which he sent to a number of parliamentarians has expressed concern that the Commonwealth may not intend to press ahead with the remaining six amalgamations. I am seeking an early opportunity to meet with the Minister of Education in Victoria and with the Minister for Education in New South Wales to discuss the remaining six amalgamations, all of which fall within those two States. It is essential that these amalgamations be settled to the satisfaction of the Commonwealth by the end of July of this year so that appropriate arrangements can be made by the end of this year. I advise Senator Martin that there have been no provisions for recurrent financial assistance for these institutions beyond December 1982. It is the intention of the Commonwealth that the amalgamations should proceed, as announced in the decision. In fact, action is now under way by me to put those amalgamations in place.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TAX REBATE SCHEME FOR HOME BUYERS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is it a fact that the Australian Taxation Office has criticised many tax concessions for their administrative complexity and expense? Will the Government's new mortgage interest tax rebate scheme for first home buyers be relatively expensive to administer, as it will require applicants to complete a full half-page of Form S?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I think I read the same Press comment this morning which has obviously prompted the question from Senator Ray. I would imagine that there are some concessions and deductions to target groups in the taxation system that are costly to administer. I did note the comment with regard to the mortgage interest relief. I do not know what to say in answer to what is implied by the question, other than to state what was stated by those who gave evidence, to the committee reviewing the matter yesterday, that a cost is involved in proceeding with concessions, deductions or other matters that are raised through the taxation system. Whether what is implied by Senator Ray is that he would like to see a flat tax with no concessions, target group deductions, rebates or whatever, I do not know. But I noted the comment that there is some complexity with regard to a particular one and that many of the deductions or schemes do have administrative costs. I am not aware of the relationship of those costs to the total tax collected. I can say only that the comments were noted. No doubt the committee which is reviewing the matter will make some response which would receive the attention of government in due course .

—Mr Deputy President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I may not have made myself clear enough. Will the Minister take up with the Treasurer the question of trying to evaluate how many cents in the dollar each of the tax concessions costs to administer so that the Senate and other people can make a judgment as to their worth?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — As I have said, I do not know whether it is possible to do that. I think the committee which is looking at the matters raised yesterday by those who gave evidence will no doubt make a report in due course which would, in the normal process, receive the Government's attention. Administrative costs may be one factor considered in looking at the operation of schemes or the policy related to them. But I do not know whether information on the individual cost of an individual deduction, rebate or concession within the taxation system would be readily available or whether the importance of such information would warrant the cost that might be involved in extracting it. However, as I have said, the committee concerned will report and the Government will react to that committee's recommendation.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Honourable senators may be aware of the land claim lodged over Beetaloo station, where one group of Aboriginals who we believe are already entitled to thousands of square miles of land is seeking to dispossess an Aboriginal family group which holds the Beetaloo station as a pastoral lease and which has held and worked the station for generations. My question of the Minister is: How is it that legal aid has been granted immediately to the Central Australian Aboriginal Congress, which, I understand, has some $250,000 in accumulated reserves, when it took over 12 months to obtain a grant of legal aid for the Bathern family of Beetaloo, which has no funds, and when one member of that family who has sought additional legal aid in his own right has not yet been granted assistance? Further, does the Minister believe that the Bathern family will have further difficulties in obtaining legal aid until such time as the land claim proceeds?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think part of Senator Kilgariff's question does not really fall within the administrative responsibility of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. It may not be possible for me to give an answer to that part of the question which relates to access to legal aid. But I would like to comment on the issue which has been raised by Senator Kilgariff's question. It is an unsatisfactory part of the working of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act that one group of Aboriginal people is able to lodge a land claim over a property held by another group of Aboriginal people. The situation at Beetaloo is one of the situations that have caused considerable distress. The other situation honourable senators might remember is the one which occurred in relation to the Borroloola land claim. Mr Steve Johnston has a holding on Vanderlin Island which has been subject to claim. That is one group of Aboriginals seeking to dispossess another Aboriginal land holder.

ANSWER.PARA: The negotiations which have been going on in relation to the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act have tried to take this, among other matters, on board. If it is possible to put in place a package of amendments, it is to be hoped that this is one thing that would be overcome. I can confirm that the Central Australian Aboriginal Congress is in receipt of large amounts of money for the various functions it carries out. It is one of the few organisations of that size in the centre of Australia. I regret that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs is not able to advise Senator Kilgariff on the rules which regulate access to legal aid in the Territory. That part of the question may have to be directed to another Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. What progress can she report in the inquiry into the Tehran embassy embezzlement raised by me three months ago? Has it been established that all files relating to this matter are still intact? Can she give an assessment as to when the inquiry will be finalised?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — It will be recalled that the Minister for Foreign Affairs asked me and my Department to conduct an investigation into the allegations made in regard to the Tehran embassy. I can report that the Department of Finance has now completed an interim report. It is interim in the sense that one of the people to be interviewed is on leave and is not able to be interviewed for a short time. That interim report has been written by the Department of Finance and I shall now forward that to Mr Street to see whether he wishes to refer the matter to the Australian Federal Police.

ANSWER.PARA: The report itself did not, to my knowledge, indicate that there was any lack of information on file. In fact, files going back to 1962 appear to have been checked by the Department of Finance. I am not aware of any gaps in files, but I could have that matter checked. However, the report, in its interim stage, is now ready for forwarding to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. If he feels that it is a matter for the Australian Federal Police to look at further or take any action, I assume that he would make that decision. But I think that within a short time some response will be able to be made to Senator Primmer.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FEDERATED LIQUOR AND ALLIED TRADES EMPLOYEES ASSOCIATION

TALK.START.PARA: —What action has the Attorney-General taken about the matter referred by me to him last week concerning the Victorian branch of the Federated Liquor and Allied Trades Employees Association and the admitted misappropriation of almost $10,000? Is the Attorney aware that today members of the Victorian fraud squad will be interviewing officers of the Victorian branch about the matter? Does this mean that the Attorney has referred the matter to the Victorian Police? Finally, has the Attorney-General had the accounts of the branch examined to see whether they comply with Part VIII AA, of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act and, if so, with what result?

—In answer to Senator Lewis's question generally, I can say that the papers that were referred to me by Senator Lewis are being examined by officers of my Department. No conclusions have yet been reached, except to the extent that it appeared likely that the papers would have to be referred to the Victorian Attorney-General for his consideration. I was not aware of the investigation to which Senator Lewis referred, which has apparently been initiated in Victoria and not as a result of any reference by me or my Department to the Victorian authorities.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ATOMIC BOMB TESTS: CONTRACTION OF CANCER

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I preface the question by drawing the Minister's attention to an article in this morning's edition of the Sydney Morning Herald, among other newspapers, which refers to the $32,500 compensation payment made to the widow of a man who died of cancer after working on aircraft used in atomic bomb tests in Australia in the 1950s. Is the Minister aware of the formal determination which stated, inter alia, that the death was the result of the contraction of a disease to which his employment was a contributing factor? Does the Minister agree that, if this is the case, there may be others whose deaths from cancer or whose contraction of that disease can be attributed to their duties, military or civilian, on the atomic test sites of Monte Bello, Emu Field and Maralinga, as well as those serving at Nagasaki and Hiroshima after the bombings? If he does agree that this may be the case, will he make available to the servicemen and the civilians concerned or their widows-I believe there are something like 200 in South Australia alone-the medical files, service records, radiation profiles and such other information as may be necessary for them to claim compensation?

—The first point to make is that the matter really is concerned with the Department of Defence rather than the Department of Veterans' Affairs. The operations at Maralinga and the other places that were mentioned by Senator Haines in her question in which personnel may or may not have been involved were not theatres of war which would therefore define my Department's interest in the matter. There would be some involvement for my Department, of course, in relation to those soldiers who were serving in Japan at the end of the Second World War. The honourable senator mentioned Hiroshima and Nagasaki. In that context my Department would be involved. The matter of the provision of any information would need to be referred to the Department of Defence, which would be in control of such records. I undertake to refer the whole of Senator Haine's question to that Department.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FOOTBALL MATCH BETWEEN THE SENATE AND THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, my question is directed to you. Are you aware that the more progressive members of the Senate who have discarded the yoke of colonialism have issued a challenge to the House of Representatives to play a game of Australian parliamentary rules football, which is an extension of super rules, on Friday, 20 August, at 11 a.m. at Football Park, Phillip, and that this challenge has been accepted by the Speaker on behalf of that other place? Can you say whether there is any truth in the rumour that Mr Speaker is proposing to ask Ron Barassi to perform the seemingly impossible task of coaching the House of Representatives team to a win on that day? Can you also inform the Senate whether negotiations are being conducted with 'Cowboy' Neale to secure his services as coach of the Senate side? Is it a fact that Senator Button has already commenced a rigorous secret training program to enable him to play full forward for the Senate team, no doubt wishing to emulate the famous Victorian 'Jacko' Jackson, and that Senator Chipp and Senator Teague are also engaged in similar exercises in the hope of attracting the attention of the Senate team selectors? Are you also aware that a secret donor has already undertaken to provide a unique perpetual trophy for what it is hoped will become an annual parliamentary event?

—It has been drawn to the President's attention and also to my attention that an Australian rules football game is to be played between the House of Representatives and the Senate at the Phillip Football Park on Friday, 20 August. The Senate selectors have taken the President into their confidence and I can report that to date they are very impressed with the overall talent that is available for the Senate team and the exceptional physical fitness of the prospective players. I am told by the spotters around this place that the players that are available are likely to be offered substantial rugby league contracts next year. I am told that our erstwhile colleague former Senator McAuliffe will have a roving eye over all the players on that day.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: GOVERNMENT INFORMATION UNIT: ACCESS TO PARLIAMENTARY LIBRARY FACILITIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, my question also is directed to you but I am afraid it deals with matters of sordid political sensitivity rather than of universal interest of the kind that has just been expressed by Senator Jessop. As a result of that sensitivity I appreciate that you may wish to refer the question to the President upon his return. I ask: Was it agreed at a meeting of the principal officers of the Parliamentary Library on 6 May 1982 that the Government Information Unit should be recognised as a client of the Parliamentary Library and should have access to the reference services of the Library and also to the general publications of the Legislative Research Service? Further, if it is the function of the Government Information Unit, as has been constantly claimed by the Government, simply to disseminate to the public information relating to the decisions and actions of the Government, on what conceivable basis did the principal officers consider that the GIU needed or deserved access to these already extraordinarily overburdened resources? Is one of the reasons that this kind of decision came to be made by the Library the fact that it clearly lacks direction from the top following the failure for 10 months now to appoint a new Librarian following the departure of Mr Weir? Is the central reason for that delay the failure of the Speaker to agree upon the candidate preferred by the other members of the selection panel with neither the Speaker nor the President being prepared to authorise the appointment of each other's candidate? Is the President aware of the mounting concern that this bizarre, almost Monty Python, situation in the Library is creating in many quarters? Does he recall the unanimous resolution in this place that the Library Committee be consulted on the appointment of the new Librarian? Will he do something to restore a degree of sanity in the administration of the Parliamentary Library?

—I am unaware of all of the matters raised by Senator Evans. I will ensure that they are drawn to the attention of the President. I will see whether an early reply can be provided to the honourable senator.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Construction whether the terms under which Tasmania's shipping freight equalisation scheme will be extended to air freight have been revised? The Minister will recall my supplementary question of 6 May when I queried whether the new scheme would operate only when the employees of the two major shipping companies operating in Tasmania had ceased to operate due to industrial disputation? Has this been clarified? If not, when is an announcement expected?

—I am afraid I have no further information on the matter raised by Senator Walters which, of course, was raised in this place about a fortnight ago. I need to refer the matter to the Minister to see whether I can obtain some further information. If I can do that before the close of business today, I will certainly make it known to the Senate.

—I refer the Minister for Social Security to the evidence of the Department of Social Security to the Public Accounts Committee where it was stated that between $40m and $45m is owed in overpayments and duplicate payments . How much does the Minister realistically expect to recover? How much of the overpayments accumulated during the years when the Department failed to send out review forms and people were unwittingly overpaid? What is the Department's policy towards those people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen a report of the evidence which was given by officers of my Department to the Public Accounts Committee. I think some of the public reports were somewhat misleading, because at least one newspaper report suggested that a large proportion of those overpayments was caused by administrative error, whereas a very small proportion is caused by administrative error. The main cause of overpayments is that people neglect to advise the Department of changes in income which would result in pension reduction. They are discovered some time after the event in the course of reviews initiated by my Department rather than by the client. The figure for actual adminstrative error is perhaps indicated by the volume of these payments which are written off. I think they would amount to a little over a million dollars a year which, in terms of the totality of the budget of my Department, is quite miniscule.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to recovery, I regret my lack of a photographic memory. I have a clear picture of the page that was put before me, but I have to say that I am guessing. My recollection is the figure is somewhere around an annual recovery rate of $16m to $17m. Part of the $45m referred to by the honourable senator in her question is a cumulative figure with carried forward overpayments being part of that total. The annual level of overpayments is around the $20m mark. A substantial proportion of that annual amount is recovered.

The reason for the carry forward is quite simple. Quite often the overpayment is caused because there has been some increase in income which leads to an entitlement to a lower rate of pension. Because reviews are not conducted on a weekly or a monthly basis but at less regular intervals, for reasons of not wanting to interfere unduly with people and the administrative burden, sometimes people are not able to repay immediately the amount which is sought to be recovered. We are usually dealing with pensioners and beneficiaries who are substantially reliant on the pension or benefit received. The normal method of recovery would be by way of a small weekly deduction. So there is a carry- forward situation and this means that repayments may be made over quite a lengthy period. Obviously cases vary considerably. There is a relatively small number of fraudulent cases. There are cases where people simply have not realised or have not got round to notifying us of some income variation. But we expect to recover a substantial proportion of overpayments and I think the figures show an increasing level of recovery year by year. That is in part probably because of the factor mentioned by the honourable senator, namely, the more regular reviews which are now conducted.

That whole answer is descriptive. I would not want to be held closely to the figures I have mentioned. I will check all the figures and let the honourable senator have a detailed reply. Should any of the figures I have put before the Senate be misleading in any substantial sense-and from the way Senator Grimes is poised in the starting blocks they may be-I will certainly bring to the attention of the Senate any change I would wish to mention.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources, relates to the uncertainties which have surrounded Australia's export industry since the expenditure review committee announced proposed cuts in export expansion grants and to the concern expressed to the Government by the Australian Chamber of Commerce Export Council on this matter. This concern, as I understand it, relates to any unilateral decision to reduce export incentives in Australia and not to any bilateral arrangements that might flow from the Prime Minister's initiatives in his recent world mission. Because Australia's economic progress is inextricably bound to its ability to hold its place as a trading nation, I ask: Firstly, will the Government confirm its commitment to Australia's many export traders through the continuation of the export development grant and the export expansion grant schemes; and secondly, what long term policies does the Government have to encourge exporters to seek long term business and to maintain Australia's viability as a trading nation?

—Senator Missen's question raises matters which are of considerable importance to large numbers of exporters in Australia. In order to ensure a very clear and accurate answer I will refer the question to the Minister for Trade and Resources and ask him to provide an early answer to the honourable senator.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DAIRY MANUFACTURING COMPANIES: ALLEGED MISUSE OF FUNDS

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. I refer to the Minister's answer on Tuesday when he said that the Australian Dairy Corporation was aware of the misuse of Reserve Bank funds on 19 April last but that the Minister was not informed until 19 May. Did the board of the Australian Dairy Corporation meet on 5 and 6 May? Was the misuse of funds reported at that meeting? Was the Government's board member, Mr Wallace, present at that meeting and, if so, why was Mr Nixon not told until 19 May?

—I have no information about the meetings of 5 and 6 May and hence , of course, as to who might have attended them. I will seek that information for the honourable senator and let him have an early reply.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Education. Will the Government soon be in a position to conclude considerations of the universities' and colleges' proposal for an integrated national superannuation scheme for all Australian academics? In particular, will direct provision be made for a continuum of pro rata benefits in respect of fractional appointments and in respect of early retirement so that these two procedures are of positive relief to the too immobile staff structures which prevent sufficient opportunity for new and younger persons to be appointed to our universities and colleges? Finally, will the superannuation scheme as a whole be so arranged that it may easily and reasonably become part of the even wider national superannuation plan , involving all occupations, which is currently being developed by Government members?

—I make no comment about a national superannuation scheme in general. The proposal which has been carefully worked up looks a most interesting proposal. It requires a series of Government decisions. In other words, the proposals which are now being worked on within my Department will need to go to the Government for decision. They have some budgetary implications . Therefore, it is not possible to promise Senator Teague an immediate or early announcement. However, I can say that the universities and colleges have been in some distress about the situation facing their present superannuation schemes. If this present proposal can be brought to fruition it might provide a significant advance on what has been available and what is presently available. The scheme which has been advanced-the Federation of Australian University Staff Associations and the college academics have had a major input into the scheme- looks promising. The Government hopes to be able to make an announcement on this matter before too long.
—I wish to ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister for Education give direct consideration to facilities for fractional appointments and pro rata early retirement?
—I will need to look at the scheme as proposed to see whether it covers those matters. If it does not, I will certainly give consideration to the points raised by Senator Teague.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DAIRY MANUFACTURING COMPANIES: ALLEGED MISUSE OF FUNDS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to his answer to my question earlier about the misuse of Reserve Bank advances to dairy companies. I refer in particular to his answer to my question No. 1 in which he said that the matter at this stage was strictly one for the Australian Dairy Corporation and, therefore, the Minister for Primary Industry was not obliged to inform the Prime Minister. Is it not true that Mr Nixon and his representatives on the Board of the Australian Dairy Corporation have been involved in a series of meetings with officers of the Dairy Corporation about this matter? Has the Minister in fact issued directives to the Corporation or to his representative on the Board of the Corporation? If he has done either of those things, does this not represent direct involvement by the Minister and require him, in terms of the Bowen guidelines, to inform the Prime Minister of the matter and of his possible conflict of interest?

—I do not have details of what discussions Mr Nixon may have had with officers of his Department in regard to this matter. I will refer Senator Button's question to him for further detailed answers. I draw the attention of honourable senators to the answer which I gave earlier which was a result of a discussion with Mr Nixon. I said that immediately on receiving advice that the Australian Dairy Corporation's investigation revealed breaches, Mr Nixon asked the Chairman of the Australian Dairy Corporation, Mr Vawser, to return to Australia to deal personally with the matter. Mr Nixon has not been involved in any way in decision making with regard to this question. As I have tried to emphasise, the matter is under investigation. It is under legal advice. What Mr Nixon's actual role might be as a result of those investigations and that advice is another matter. But at this stage that particular situation has not arisen. I think that there are difficulties. I have had the opportunity of having only a most cursory look at the legislation. I am not involved in the advice being obtained by the Australian Dairy Corporation, but I think legal matters have to be considered. I think it is appropriate that one should wait until those matters are fully investigated and that advice is obtained before questioning further what action Mr Nixon should take.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation aware that the charter of the old Department of Civil Aviation required the Department to assist and further general aviation in this country and that the Department of Transport had no such requirement imposed upon it? Will the new Department of Aviation protect the interests of and develop the general aviation sector instead of being obsessed with regular passenger transport and airline operations, which in any case are stable and predictable, and devote a reasonable part of its resources to what is by far and away the largest part of Australian aviation and which has nearly been driven out of business by a consistent policy of alternating harassment and neglect by the previous Department?

—A number of assertions in Senator MacGibbon's question demand specific attention from the Minister involved, and I will endeavour to obtain answers to them. There is a firm commitment on the part of the Government to the continuation and development of general aviation in this country and it has a very real interest in its future development. I will bring to the attention of the Minister all the concerns that Senator MacGibbon evidenced in his question. I will certainly bring forward to the Minister the suggestion that a charter be incorporated in the Department of Aviation's masthead and obtain some further information for Senator MacGibbon.

—Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. May I have an assurance from the Minister that there will be full negotiations with representatives of the general aviation sector on the many issues, such as the biennial flight renewal checks and the use of motor spirit in aircraft engines, that need resolution in the near future?

—The matters referred to by Senator MacGibbon are ongoing concerns of the Department. I will certainly draw those concerns to the attention of the Minister and ask him to take into account the further suggestions which Senator MacGibbon has made.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. Is it a fact that the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act was passed in 1981? Is it a fact that this Act has not yet been proclaimed and that, as a result, there is no legislation to prevent the dumping of hazardous chemicals in the seas around Australia? Why has there been a year's delay in proclaiming this Act? When will it be proclaimed?

—Like other senators, I recall the passage of that legislation through the Parliament. I am interested in Senator Childs's concern that it may not have been proclaimed. I think I will need to refer this matter to the new Minister for Home Affairs and Environment and get from him a detailed explanation for Senator Childs.

—Will the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry assure the Senate that the ban on steroid-type hormones which promote fast growth in livestock will not be lifted until all available evidence is examined and while there are any doubts about their long term effects on human or animal health?

—I will refer that question to Mr Nixon for consideration and reply to Senator Watson. My only knowledge about steroids is that they are used by athletes. I was not aware that they are also a serious problem in this area. I will certainly see that Senator Watson gets an early reply.

—My question is directed to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate and on the assumption that he has assumed the mantle of Minister for National Development and Energy. My question is one about which Senator Button, my leader, alerted Senator Sir John Carrick last week. How much has the Commonwealth spent on the construction of the Split Rock Dam in New South Wales? Will the Minister give an assurance that the Government will make annual allocations for the building of this dam? Finally, will these allocations continue without interruption until the dam is completed?
—I am very pleased that Opposition members are setting the precedent of giving some notice of questions to which they really want answers.
—Senator Teague will be upset.
—A splendid example of this occurred yesterday in Senator Ryan's case as well, so obviously a new spirit is emerging.
—Order! Will the Minister answer the question?

—I am very happy to do so, Mr Deputy President. In 1982-83 the Commonwealth has made $1.5m available to New South Wales towards the cost of approved work of the Split Rock Dam project in northern New South Wales to augment supplies in the Namoi Valley, mainly for cotton production. Information available to the Commonwealth indicates that only about $300,000 of that $1.5m allocated will be used mainly to upgrade an access road to the dam site and for design work on the dam structure. New South Wales has indicated that it does not intend to proceed further with the construction of the Split Rock Dam unless it has a firm commitment from the Commonwealth in relation to the completion of the project. However, the Commonwealth has undertaken to consider a long term commitment in the 1982-83 Budget discussions.

—Can the Minister for Finance advise the Senate what changes in the economic climate of Australia have brought about a recent drop in interest rates on bank loans? Can she indicate what effect the influx of overseas funds into Australia is having on the availability of money here?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The only interest rates on bank loans that have fallen recently are the rates on short term bank loans such as the rate at which the short term money market will buy bills of exchange accepted or endorsed by a bank. In recent weeks the fall in the short term bank lending rates has reflected a general fall in interest rates on the short term money market. The general fall in short term interest rates is due both to the passing of the period of heavy provisional and company tax payments and to the continuing strong inflow of capital from abroad. While resulting in a welcome addition to our foreign exchange reserves the strong capital inflows have added to the liquidity available to financial institutions and hence have added to the rate of monetary growth. The Government will continue to pursue its objective of restraining the growth of monetary aggregates, as is evidenced by the recent decision to adjust yields on Commonwealth bonds to fully competitive levels.

—I direct my question to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. Before the Senate rose on 6 May Senator Button asked Senator Carrick whether he would guarantee that the Government would honour its promise not to provide jobs for the boys when appointing the new ambassadors to Washington and Tokyo. Will the Minister confirm that the appointment of the former Leader of the Government in the Senate Mr Robert Cotton as ambassador to Washington will mean that 13 former Liberal Party members of parliament have now been given government appointments since the Fraser Government took office? Will he now give an assurance that the new ambassador to Japan will not be the fourteenth in this already long line of appointments for the favoured sons of the Liberal Party?

—I have better things to do-I think most honourable senators have, except Senator McLaren-than count up how many former Liberal members of parliament, as he says, have been appointed to some office. He raises the matter in connection with a recent report that former Senator Cotton may be appointed ambassador to Washington. I am aware that appointments to other ambassadorial positions have to be made from time to time, but no assurance of the type sought by Senator McLaren can be given. These appointments are made after consideration of the person best suited for the position. I do not believe that the Government should tie its hands in a way that Senator McLaren seeks.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Thomas Sen A.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. I refer to a newspaper article on page 1 of Tuesday's West Australian concerning the gaoling of two Pilbara union officials for non-payment of fines. The article said that the Trades and Labour Council called for protest strikes. Quoting the Secretary of the Trades and Labour Council, it stated:

QUESTION.PARA: the union movement would not tolerate the gaoling of officials involved in legitimate union activities.

Would the Minister not compare the so-called legitimate union activities with the famous 95 Theses by Martin Luther in 1517 when he opposed the granting of indulgences whereby monks financed the building of St Peter's Basilica in Rome by selling letters of absolution to sinners so that they considered themselves as having repented?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am in a fairly delicate position on this question. I get the newsletter of the United Order of Orangemen and the chances of my being able, as a Catholic, to answer a question on Martin Luther in this place are absolutely nil. The question is valuable in one respect alone. It suggests a way in which we might finance the new and permanent Parliament House. I would have thought that the sale of indulgences in this place which gave forgiveness for transgressions would probably give rise to payments of several hundred millions of dollars which would finance that building quite quickly.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Support aware that replacement driving sprockets for the Leopard tanks have recently been ordered from Germany in spite of the fact that these components can be made competitively and to a high standard at the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo? In view of the fact that the Falkland Islands conflict has demonstrated the importance of self-sufficiency in critical areas of defence equipment, will the Minister give an assurance that high-wearing and critical replacement parts for our defence equipment will be manufactured in Australia wherever possible?
—I will refer that question to the Minister for Defence Support and ask him to provide an early answer.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations to an article in this week's National Times concerning underspending by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations in its manpower training programs for young unemployed people. Is the Minister aware that for the first three-quarters of the 1981-82 financial year the number of people assisted by youth training schemes was running 30 per cent below Budget estimates? Can he tell the Senate why this has been allowed to happen at a time when youth employment is still hovering around the 20 per cent mark? Is it an indication that the Government intends to wind down some of these programs? If not, can the Minister give an assurance that the targets for 1982-83 will be increased accordingly to make up for any shortfalls in this financial year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will remember that in the field referred to by the honourable senator in his question there was a very considerable expansion of activities by the Commonwealth in the last Budget and considerable expansion of the amount of money made available. That expansion was somewhat obscured by the controversy over the one negative decision in that area, which was not to continue with the Community Youth Support Scheme. The considerable furore which followed that announcement tended to distract attention from the very positive approach which the Government had in the rest of its program for youth.

ANSWER.PARA: I have seen a note recently which I do not have with me but will try to get by the end of Question Time. I think that the problem is, in part, related to the expansion of activity. It is certainly not meant to be or should not be taken as any indication that the Government will be winding down the program. With regard to the request from Senator Foreman that we have some sort of make-up next year, the important thing is to have adequate financing for those people who will be available to benefit from the programs. In other words, I do not think one can set an arbitrary limit on the basis of some figure added on to what may not be spent if there is underspending this year. Rather, I say simply that I would expect the Minister whom I represent in this place to address his attention to those programs to see the extent to which there are people in the Australian community, particularly young people, who can benefit from them and ensure that there is adequate Budget provision to meet the demand which exists.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Prime Minister aware that every country that the Prime Minister has visited, and also Britain, has now accepted in principle the plan for economic world recovery that has been put by him?

—The plan that the Prime Minister took overseas with him represented a major initiative. I believe that yesterday even Senator Walsh said that he had to agree with it, so it is a plan that one would have expected to receive bipartisan support. Obviously it has been received with attention by those leaders to whom he has spoken. I have not had details of nor have I seen any report from the Prime Minister-there has not been an opportunity of doing so -so I cannot give Senator Walters a detailed answer. Certainly it appears from the reports that we have received that it was a very valuable and important initiative and, one hopes, will be productive in regard to the problems that it was addressing.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Did the Treasurer announce approximately two weeks ago that interest rates on Commonwealth bonds would rise by 1.4 per cent to 16.4 per cent? Will this, among other things, lead to further increases in interest rates on housing loans as has been reported? Will it increase the extreme hardship on families even further and bring about more family disruption? Will the Government urgently consider giving more funds to welfare agencies dealing with families which lose their homes, and which are doing a job that the Federal Government should be doing?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator's question ranges over the responsibilities of a couple of other Ministers also. Interest rates on housing loans will, of course, reflect market rates. However, I draw attention to the schemes that were introduced by the Government to assist those who have bought houses in recent years or will buy them in the near future, and are thus subjected to the payment of the present rates of interest. They are measures which the Government introduced in order to be of assistance. The question of assistance to welfare agencies, in the form of grants or by way of emergency assistance, falls more properly within the area of my colleague Senator Chaney. Again, a great deal of assistance is given by many of the family support projects and other projects that are developed through the Department of Social Security and through the giving of assistance to the States. The whole housing area was canvassed very widely at the time that we introduced those measures of assistance and changes to the Homes Savings Grant Scheme. Those schemes recognised the priority given by the Government to housing policy and to the granting of assistance when that is possible. We believe that these measures, combined with the extra funds released and made available through the banking system, have been of assistance. It is not denied that difficulties exist in regard to present housing market costs, in some States particularly, and in regard to high interest rates. Where we have been able to be of assistance we have taken the steps that were outlined a month or two ago.

—I take the opportunity of answering a question that was asked of me by Senator Martyr on Tuesday of this week. The question concerned operations of the Australian Federal Police. I undertook to refer the question to the Minister for Administrative Services and to obtain an answer to it. I am advised as follows: The Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police, Sir Colin Woods, has advised that the Federal Police have no evidence of any meetings between the former New South Wales Minister for Police, Mr Crabtree, and members of the New South Wales Police Force for the purposes implied in Senator Martyr's question, namely, the collection of bribery money from illegal gambling operations. The Commissioner has also advised that, except in respect of investigations of allegations against the former New South Wales Deputy Commissioner, Mr Allen, undertaken at the request of the former New South Wales Commissioner, Mr Lees, the Australian Federal Police have not mounted any operations directed against members of the New South Wales Police.
—I ask that the Minister table the document from which he quoted .
—I table the document.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DAIRY MANUFACTURING COMPANIES: ALLEGED MISUSE OF FUNDS

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time yesterday, Senator Georges asked whether I would make a statement today relating to advances of some $130,000 which the Australian Dairy Corporation had made to the Colac Dairying Company Ltd and the subsequent ADC request for repayment of those advances. Senator Georges also referred to statements attributed to Mr David Burston, General Manager of the company, concerning the matter. I believe that the best way to answer the honourable senator's questions would be to outline briefly the circumstances surrounding the matter as they have been advised to me.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Dairy Corporation has advised that the $130,000 was advanced to the Colac Dairying Company Ltd between September 1981 and November 1981 in respect of cheese produced by that company. The advance was subject to the usual condition that the product should not be sold or removed from store prior to repayment of the advance. The Colac Dairying Company Ltd subsequently sold the cheese to McMahon Dairy Products Pty Ltd. The ADC has been advised orally by both the Colac Dairying Company and McMahon Dairy Products Pty Ltd that a condition of the sale was that would reimburse the ADC with the advance money involved. When the ADC inspection on 18 May 1982 revealed that the cheese was no longer held in store by the Colac Dairying Company Ltd, the ADC sought immediate repayment of the advance. Reimbursement was received from McMahon Dairy Products Pty Ltd on 19 May 1982. As the ADC has not yet examined the Colac Dairying Company Ltd's sales records to determine the date or dates of the sales to McMahon Dairy Products Pty Ltd, I am not yet in a position to advise the Senate of the exact period in which repayment of the advance was due to the ADC.

At the end of Question Time yesterday, I provided the Senate with additional information in respect of Mr Peter Lever-Naylor and his involvement in the Nestle Company Australia Ltd when he was a member of the Board of the ADC. Subsequent to my providing that information, Senator Bolkus indicated that he did not think the information that I had provided was an adequate response. I have received further advice which I will now give to the Senate. If Senator Bolkus does not think that it is adequate, he might let me know in what particular aspect it is inadequate. The further advice is as follows: The Nestle Company did not receive any ADC advance on its production of whole milk powder during the period that Mr Peter Lever-Naylor was associated with that company. The advances by the ADC were made after Mr Peter Lever-Naylor retired as Manager, Production Division, of the Nestle Company on 30 June 1978. A subsidiary company of Nestle, the Girgarre Cheese Co. Pty Ltd, received ADC advances on leviable cheese production during the period when Mr Peter Lever- Naylor was employed by Nestle. The ADC has not detected any breaches of the conditions of the advances made to that company.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier in Question Time, Senator Giles asked me a question about repayments and I responded from memory. I think the answer I gave is broadly in line but I could assist the Senate by being a little more specific now that I have hard information. The overpayments raised by the Department of Social Security represent about 0.3 per cent of outlays on pensions and benefits. Overpayments waived due to office error form a small fraction-less than 1.5 per cent-of total overpayments and only 0.005 per cent of outlays. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table showing the overpayment details for the last three years.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The table read as follows-
Overpayment details for the last three years are:
$m
$m $m $m

Balance at 1 July 21.4 28.5 36.3 Overpayments raised 20.8 23.9 27.2 Recoveries 12.2 14.6 16.6 Amounts written off 1.5 1.5 1.9 Balance at 30 June 28.5 36.3 45.0 Recoveries as per cent of raisings 58 61 61

I merely wish to add that excess payments over the same period which were reported as being due to office error, such as a delay or omission on the part of an officer in effecting a variation advice and on which recovery was waived, amounted over the last three years to $306,000, $257,000 and $383,000 respectively. I would point out that total payments in these areas are in terms of many billions of dollars.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to respond to Senator Foreman who asked a question about employment and industrial relations programs and an article which had appeared concerning certain under spending by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations. Advice from the Department is that some of the expenditures are not running at the levels envisaged when estimates were originally made for 1981-82. However, for some items expenditures will be greater than original estimates although these are not referred to in the article. In relation to the School to Work Transition Program, the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations originally estimated $13m for transition allowance expenditure for 1981-82. This estimate was later revised to $10m, reflecting later and more precise knowledge of trainee numbers and entitlements .

ANSWER.PARA: While there may have been some shortfall in the numbers originally envisaged, the 36 per cent reduction mainly reflects the difficulty of making the initial estimate. The transition allowance applies not only to Commonwealth funded tertiary and further education transition courses but also to approved State funded courses, so precise estimating is not easy as DEIR cannot predict accurately State provisions. The revised estimate of $10m for the transition allowance represents approximately 13,000 trainees. Allowances had been provided for 9,000 as at the end of March 1982, which was on target. As far as program funds are concerned, estimated under spending for 1981-82 will be under 3 per cent. This is caused by recoveries from States of advances not spent in 1980, the first year of the program, when some programs took time to become established.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Mulvihill asked a question on 25 May concerning the vulnerability of whales in the battle zone in the South Atlantic. The question also contained some reference to Japan's capacity to hunt sperm whales . I have some information for the honourable senator. At the special meeting of the International Whaling Commission held on 24 and 25 March 1982 it was agreed by consensus that the question of 1982 sperm whale quotas should be reconsidered at the annual meeting to be held in July 1982. In the meantime, the scientific committee was asked to complete its review of sperm whale assessment. The effect on whales, if any, of the Falkland Islands hostilities is unknown. This is a matter of concern and is now before the Department.

—Earlier today Senator Childs asked me a question concerning the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act 1981. I have been able to get more information. The situation is more advanced than might have been inferred from Senator Childs's question. I am advised that administrative arrangements and regulations to be discussed with the States are currently being prepared to enable the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act to be brought into operation. It is currently planned that the Act will be brought into operation in June 1982, which is almost upon us, with the dumping convention being ratified in July 1982. A draft model State Bill prepared for consideration by the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General is being used as a basis for the States and the Northern Territory to implement the provisions of the dumping convention in the territorial sea adjacent to their coast through State or Territory legislation. When a State or the Northern Territory does not wish to enact separate legislation the Commonwealth Act will apply in the territorial sea adjacent to that State or Territory.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Questions have been raised with me in connection with an incident which occurred in the chamber yesterday afternoon in which the Chair requested the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Chipp, not to remain standing in a passageway talking with persons on the gallery side of the rail that divides the chamber from the senators' guests' gallery. Senator Chipp properly indicated that as no seating was available for advisers to the members of his party comparable with areas beside the members of the Ministry, the Opposition shadow Ministry and the major party Whips, arrangements had been authorised by the President for those advisors to sit in the gallery closest to the seats occupied by Senator Chipp and his colleagues and for that area to be reserved for them.

INTERJECT.PARA: As honourable senators are aware, Standing Order 402 provides that senators shall not stand in any of the passageways. In addition, all Presidents, in the exercise of their responsibilities to maintain order, have consistently called to order any senator attempting to speak to visitors in the galleries. The request from the Chair yesterday was based on those two factors. It appears to me that the special arrangements approved at the request of Senator Chipp have, perhaps unwittingly, given rise to the problem that arose yesterday insofar as it might be thought that the members of the Australian Democrats should be able to talk directly over the dividing rail to their advisers, in a fashion comparable to that by which Ministers, shadow Ministers and Whips talk to their advisers in the benches on my immediate right and left.

I believe that there is a sufficient distinction between the two situations inasmuch as the space set aside for the Democrats' advisers is, of necessity, in the senators' guests' gallery, which is open to and used by many visitors to the Senate, while the places on my right and left are exclusively set aside for the purposes of advisers. It is perhaps regrettable that this is so, but I draw the attention of honourable senators to the fact that, principally to overcome the problem which arose yesterday, a special door was cut in the dividing rail to provide direct and easy access for the Australian Democrat senators to the area set aside for their advisers. I understand that the special arrangements made by the President were referred to the leaders of the Government and the Opposition and to Senator Harradine for their consideration and this statement by me will now inform the Senate as a whole of those arrangements. They are no doubt less than perfect but I believe that they do provide an appropriate, workable solution to the problem which Senator Chipp originally raised.

In the light of the Standing Order, the practice of not permitting conversations between persons inside and outside the defined chamber area and the structural alterations referred to above, I trust that any repetition of yesterday's problem might be avoided by the co-operation of Australian Democrats senators in making use of the special access arrangements provided for them to talk with their advisers. I take this opportunity also of reminding all honourable senators that they should keep very much in mind Standing Order 402 that prohibits standing in passageways in the chamber. Because of the considerable interest this matter aroused yesterday I propose to discuss the matter with the President at the earliest opportunity. I inform the Senate also that I held a meeting this morning to discuss the matter with the temporary chairmen of committees, all of whom are required to occupy the chair from time to time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Last night during a debate Senator Walsh said that I had passionate objections to the proposed Federal crimes commission. I must say from the outset that I do not associate passion and politics. However, Mr Deputy President, with your indulgence-I will seek to be as brief as I can-I refer you to the only public or private comment I have made on this subject which was by way of a question directed to the Attorney- General (Senator Durack) on 6 May 1982. I am sorry that I have to read the question but it is the only way I can explain the position. I asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Is the Minister aware that very effective co-operative working arrangements have been developed between the States and the Commonwealth in the last two years through the Australian Police Ministers Council? Is he further aware that the Council has established the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence and is close to finalising agreement on a national police research unit?
