Inasmuch as no discussion or consultation took place with the States before the Prime Minister made his statement, is it his intention to set up a national crimes commission in consultation and co-operation with the State governments, which have considerable constitutional power in this area? Does he concede that the effectiveness of such a commission would be considerably diluted without proper Commonwealth-State consultation and co-operation?

Mr Deputy President, with respect I suggest to you that what I am proposing is that establishing such a crimes commission has a great deal of virtue providing it is set up in close and effective consultation with the States. If Senator Walsh so misrepresented the truth on this occasion, in my view that can be only a reflection on his integrity. I believe that the coalition partners, part of his own party and the public at large have already made their judgment about him and I do not intend to make a judgment. But it is not without significance to note that in 1977, when Senator Walsh headed the Australian Labor Party's Senate ticket in Western Australia, that party got the worst vote that it has ever had. Going back to 1944-I can show the statistics-the same thing applied.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator is exceeding the bounds of a personal explanation.

—I rise to a point of order, Mr Deputy President. Senator Crichton-Browne was given leave by the Senate to make a personal explanation, but he has transgressed considerably. He is beginning to make a speech. He is attacking other members of the Senate. I think that he should be called to order and should keep within the bounds of the Opposition's generosity.
—I have already asked Senator Crichton-Browne to confine his remarks to his personal explanation.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. I shall confine myself to your directions. I conclude simply by saying that I do not intend to indulge in the sort of mudslinging which is becoming a familiar pattern in respect of one personality in this chamber. I believe that that is the judgment that the community has made in the past and that it will make in the future about Senator Walsh.

—by leave-I do not have the relevant Hansard with me, and I may seek leave later to make a further explanation. At this stage I should just like to say that my judgment of Senator Crichton-Browne is endorsed by many members of his own party, including some of those who have sat in the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate, aware of the increasing cost, danger and ineffectiveness of arms and negotiations for disarmament development and the four freedoms of the Atlantic Charter, calls upon all nations to cease production and development of nuclear weapons and their delivery systems; negotiate treaty for comprehensive disarmament under enforceable world law, which should include:
disarmament of all nations to the level of armament required for internal security;
an international inspection organisation able to monitor disarmament and detect violations of the agreement using satellites and on-site inspection;
a world Peace Force able to enforce disarmament and prevent international aggression, members of which should be individually recruited;
an effective system of world courts and arbitration tribunals; and
a world development fund through which a fixed proportion of the resources made available through disarmament will be devoted to development in the poorest nations of the world.

Mr President,

On behalf of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, and pursuant to section 40 of the Aboriginal Development Commission Act 1980, I present the report and financial statements of the Commission for the year ended 30 June 1981, together with a copy of the report of the Auditor-General in respect of those financial statements.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND GOVERNMENT OPERATIONS

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Special Broadcasting Service Annual Reports

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, I present a report on the first and second annual reports of the Special Broadcasting Service.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —(11.31)-by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

Mr Deputy President, I speak very briefly to outline the Committee's report. The two annual reports which are the subject of our inquiry were referred to the Committee last year by Estimates Committee B. The tabling of both reports was considerably delayed and, in fact, at the time that the Estimates Committee reported to the Senate early in May of last year, the Special Broadcasting Service second annual report for 1979-80 had yet to be tabled. The report was subsequently tabled on 12 May 1981.

The Committee found that the SBS first annual report dealt with a period of 18 months, contrary to a legislative requirement that the Service report for each 12-month period of operations ending on 30 June. The decision to prepare an annual report for an amalgamated period was made by the SBS board. The Minister then responsible for SBS affairs apparently consented to this course of action. The Committee realises that the administrative pressure upon Ministers makes continual oversight of authorities difficult. Nonetheless, timely tabling of annual reports in accordance with the legislation governing an authority is the Minister's responsibility. The Committee has expressed its disappointment that the Minister did not ensure that the SBS report to the Parliament was made as required by statute.

The SBS plays an important role in communications and community relations in Australia. It is an example of a statutory authority whose performance and achievements are of interest to the Parliament and the community. The Committee therefore intends to note the timeliness of its future reports to the Parliament . I seek to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

I believe that it would be useful to everybody if, rather than tabling it, Senator Baume were invited to have it incorporated in Hansard.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Peter Baume

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to have the letter referred to incorporated in Hansard.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
The Honourable the Minister
for Aboriginal Affairs,
Parliament House,
Canberra, Australian Capital Territory 2600
Dear Sir
ABORIGINAL DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION

In compliance with section 41 (1) of the Aboriginal Development Commission Act 1980, the accounts and records of financial transactions and records relating to assets of, or in the custody of, the Commission have been inspected and audited for the year ended 30 June 1981.
On 1 July 1980 the Commission commenced operations with the following functions :
land acquisition (previously carried out by the Aboriginal Land Fund Commission )
housing loans and enterprise loans (previously carried out by the Aboriginal Loans Commission)
enterprise grants (previously carried out by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs).
From 1 July 1980 to mid September 1980 all payments, including salaries, were made through the Department of Aboriginal Affairs after which the Commission maintained its own accounts and records.

The first audit conducted to review and evaluate accounting systems and controls disclosed a number of unsatisfactory features. Representations to the Commission on 13 May 1981 indicated weaknesses including the absence of written instructions and procedures, no formal chart of accounts, limited internal audit and incomplete accounts for fixed assets, advances, investments and shares. The maintenance of accounts and records, and of personnel records, was not up to date nor, in some instances, accurate. In response the Commission advised some 6 months later on 9 November 1981 of remedial action taken or proposed with respect to the matters.

Because of the inadequacies revealed during the first audit, substantive detailed testing was undertaken during the course of the final audit so that reasonable assurance could be obtained that transactions were correctly recorded and that assets were adequately safeguarded. Draft financial statements were received on 9 November 1981 and necessary corrections were referred to the Commission by this office on 30 November 1981, 16 December 1981 and 5 January 1982. Signed financial statements were received on 26 February 1982.

My report on the financial statements of the Commission for the year ended 30 June 1981, in terms of section 40 (5) of the Act, together with a copy of the Statements, has been forwarded to you today under separate cover. It will be noted that my report outlines the unsatisfactory aspects of the keeping of the accounts and records during the financial year ended 30 June 1981 and thereafter and includes three qualifications:
Terms and Conditions of Employment

Following Public Service Board approval on 2 September 1980 to the terms and conditions of employment for persons engaged by the Commission under section 33 of the Act, three part-time employees were paid at rates in excess of that prescribed. The Commission advised that the officer in charge of the area at the time was unaware of the relevant Public Service employment provisions applicable . This situation has since been remedied.
Engagement of Consultants

The Commission did not obtain Public Service Board approval for the terms and conditions for engagement of consultants, as required by section 35 of the Act. The reason given by the Commission was a misunderstanding and/or misapprehension of the relevant Public Service-Engagement of Consultants Provisions. It has now sought retrospective approval from the Board.
Delegation to Invest Funds

Moneys of the Capital Fund were invested by officers who did not hold a delegation from the Commission under section 44 of the Act. The Commission acknowledged the observation and agreed that the General Manager's written endorsement was not obtained in these particular instances. It was pointed out by the Commission that all investments were made strictly in accordance with section 37 of the Act after due deliberation and consultation with the General Manager.
Yours Faithfully
K. F. Brigden Auditor-General

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON EDUCATION AND THE ARTS

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report 'Preparation for the Workforce': Government Response-Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable senators, I present a response by the Government to a report by the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts entitled ' Preparation for the Workforce'. Apart from paying a tribute to the Committee for the work it put into this report I seek leave to have the statement incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
The Report of the Senate Standing Committee entitled 'Preparation for the Workforce' was tabled in Parliament on 2 June 1981.

The Committee inquired into the effectiveness of Australian schools in preparing young people for the workforce, with particular emphasis on literacy and numeracy, and the Report made recommendations for action by Commonwealth and State authorities. The majority of the recommendations are, however, directed to the responsibilities of the States and the non-government schools.

In summarising its findings the Committee stated that a major part of its inquiry was concerned with an apparent mismatch between the education system and the students it produces and community expectations. The Committee formed the opinion that employers tend to see education in strict utilitarian terms and are not fully appreciative of the difficulties and uncertainties facing educators in preparing young people for contemporary society. The Committee was equally convinced that the schools have become insular in their views on what education is for and are not appreciative of the needs of industry and commerce.
The Committee considered that these misunderstandings can only be resolved by educators and industry representatives sitting down together and engaging in rational discussion.

Another major area of concern expressed by the Senate Committee was the view that an estimated 20 to 25 per cent of young people who leave Australian schools each year are educationally disadvantaged in basic literacy and numeracy skills and life role competencies. The Committee therefore focused on the need to increase the overall proficiency of primary school teachers.

As the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts has recognised, its recommendations require the attention of educationists and administrators at various levels. The proposals are directed at the Commonwealth and State administrations, non-government school authorities, the teacher education institutions, and the schools and their communities.

The Committee's Report raises and comments on a wide range of issues, most of which are of current concern and importance. It cannot be expected that there will be universal agreement with the committee's proposals; some concern controversial areas or look for solutions to difficult problems. However, I believe that the raising of these issues in such a direct and compact form has already had an impact in the education community and, now that the Government has had an opportunity to review the Committee's recommendations, I propose bringing them formally to the attention of the Australian Education Council and the non-government school authorities.

A number of the Committee's proposals cover similar ground to that of the report of the National Inquiry into Teacher Education (NITE) and the associated State Reports. Many of the recommendations in these reports are also essentially matters for the States and the teacher education institutions to consider. For its part, the Commonwealth is continuing in 1982 its extensive support for the in-service education of teachers through the programs of the Commonwealth Schools Commission.

The rest of this statement summarises the recommendations of the Committee under the sixteen areas for action which it identified. The Government's responses in respect of recommendations in each area are outlined.
1. Areas of Disagreement and Misunderstanding

The Committee recommended that Commonwealth and State Education Departments initiate debate and discussion at the educational regional level within schools and between schools and the community, particularly local employers, to resolve the disagreements and misunderstandings about the aims and functions of schooling.

Response: The Commonwealth accepts the importance of school-community consultation and in its own area of direct responsibility for education, the Australian Capital Territory, the Schools Authority and its schools are already required by an Ordinance to involve the community in decision-making.

The Commonwealth Schools Commission is also committed to involving parents actively in the school decision-making processes. The previous Minister approved $28,000 for a project to stimulate public and professional awareness of the report, ''Schooling for 15 and 16 Year Olds'', through seminars, workshops and school based activities organised by State and Commonwealth funded teacher education centres.

The Curriculum Development Centre commissioned a study on the school and the community, the report of which, ''The Curriculum and the Community'', was published in September 1981. With funding from the Commonwealth's Transition Program some States have introduced community awareness programs which are aimed at developing an understanding of issues in the transition from school to work among teachers, parents, employers and the community.

From its examination of the areas of disagreement and misunderstanding, the Senate Committee concluded that immediate and pressing problems in schools needed to be tackled as soon as possible in order to make a serious attempt at reducing the large numbers of educationally disadvantaged children. The Government, of course, is well aware of this problem, and it was to assist such school leavers and others that the Transition from School to Work Program was introduced in November 1979. Under the Transition Program the Commonwealth has funded programs in 1980-82 to develop improved services and techniques for identifying potential early school leavers, to expand school counsellor, vocational education and guidance services to provide more comprehensive assistance for students ''at risk'' and their parents, and funded the development of alternative courses in schools for potential early school leavers .
2. Teachers
The Committee recommended that greater attention be given to identifying teachers whose proficiency is inadequate.

If in-service training cannot remedy such deficiencies, education departments should require such teachers to take early retirement or alternative employment. To reconcile the responsibilities of bringing up a young family with those of teaching, provision should be made so that, where appropriate, young married teachers may be employed on a half-time basis and/or have one or more years leave without pay.

Response: The Commonwealth shares the view that the quality of teaching is a key factor in determining educational outcomes and maintaining that quality. The NITE Report recommended that greater attention be given to in-service education and projected that by 1985 new graduates would account for as little as 6% of the teaching force.

This recommendation is primarily for the States and non-government school authorities to consider. However, it is relevant to note that in at least two States consideration is now being given to introducing re-certification for all teachers at regular intervals.

On the question of provisions for young married teachers, discussion of the possibility of offering permanent part-time employment might extend to any male and female teachers, not just young married female teachers, particularly in view of the reduced demand for teachers.
3, 4, 5 Class Size, School Size and School Design

For the first two years of primary school, class sizes should be significantly smaller than for later years and all classes should be as small as practicable for the teaching of cognitive skills. Schools should introduce sub-school units in which children can identify and develop relationships and education authorities should establish upper limits for school sizes taking into account research in this matter. Teacher training programs should include practical courses specifically designed to improve teaching proficiency both in conventional classrooms and open-plan settings.

Response: These three recommendations are directed at policy decisions to be taken at the State and individual school or tertiary teacher training institution level. However, the Commonwealth accepts the merit of the objective that class sizes be as small as practicable for teaching and learning, consistent with available resources, and it agrees that all teachers during their training should gain the necessary skills and knowledge to teach in a variety of settings, including open-plan classrooms.
6 and 7. Teacher Training and Trainee Teacher Selection

Pre-service teacher training programs should include a compulsory core of studies including such elements as teaching techniques in English and Mathematics, diagnosis of specific learning difficulties and remediation methods , stucture and sequence in curriculum development, organisation and methods of teaching for conventional school rooms and open-plan and the uses and abuses of teaching aids. Teacher training institutions should specify the minimum standards they require trainees to achieve in the teaching of English expression and comprehension and in the teaching of Mathematics.

The Committee recommended that teacher training institutions take action during the selection of trainee teachers to ensure that all teacher trainees achieve minimum competence at Year 12 level in Mathematics and English and have non- academic and personal qualities relevant to teaching such as a sense of responsibility, motivation, resilience, self-discipline and compassion. Where trainees do not measure up in these respects, they should be required to withdraw from teacher training. Potential teacher trainees should be counselled on these requirements of training institutions.

Response: Because of the autonomy of tertiary institutions responsible for teacher education programs, it is a matter for individual institutions to adopt the recommendations and to implement appropriate programs.

The Commonwealth agrees with the general thrust of the recommendations relating to teacher training institutions, and endorses the view that pre-service teacher training courses should include teaching techniques designed to facilitate pupils' acquisition of literacy and numeracy skills. In the ACT many of the Committee's recommendations in this area are already incorporated in teacher education courses at the Canberra College of Advanced Education.

As far as the Senate Committee's recommendation concerning in-course assessment of the non-academic and personal qualities of trainees is concerned, the NITE Committee recognised the problems associated with selecting individuals with suitable personal qualities for entry into the teaching profession, but suggested that there may be certain disqualifying criteria which could be used to ensure that grossly unsuitable individuals are screened out during initial selection or are counselled out during the pre-service course. These criteria might relate, for example, to the qualities of emotional instability, inflexibility and unfavourable attitudes towards children, since these are deep- rooted qualities which do not readily change in late adolescence or adulthood. ( Par 8.21.) However, this is an area which is acknowledged by educators as difficult to measure and evaluate. The trainee teacher's experience in teaching practice, together with assessment and in-course counselling on a continuing basis, would seem to provide an appropriate form of practical preparation for the classroom.
8. Remediation

Teacher training colleges should ensure that all trainees complete courses in remedial teaching of Mathematics and English and acquire the ability to diagnose specific learning difficulties. Suitably qualified remedial specialist teachers should be appointed to schools with priority given to appointment in primary schools and, in particular, to the first two years of schooling. Specialist remedial teachers should be carefully selected and receive salaries commensurate with their qualifications and experience.

Response: The Commonwealth Schools Commission through its Services and Development Program has provided funds which can be used to train experienced teachers specifically in remedial techniques. However, the Government considers that it is desirable for all teachers to have a wide range of skills and an understanding of the techniques and methods of diagnosis and remediation.

Significant provision has been made at the Canberra College of Advanced Education in recent years for qualified practising teachers to undertake further specialist teacher training at the postgraduate diploma and master's degree levels. The ACT Schools Authority makes provision for remedial reading teachers in schools. It also allocates resources for English as a Second Language programs and for Slow Learner programs.
9. School Leadership and Morale

School principals, encountering difficulties in school management, should receive counselling and guidance. Where this is unsuccessful, the principal should be replaced or transferred to a new role appropriate to his skills or, where appropriate, be encouraged to accept early retirement.

Response: The Commonwealth Schools Commission in its 1982/84 triennal report has drawn attention to the urgent need to provide appropriate training for principals before they take up their appointments and for a regular development program thereafter. The Commission has approved in principle the allocation of $ 75,000 in 1982 from its projects of national significance to support a project related to the professional development of principals.
10. In-Service Training

The Committee recommended that Commonwealth and State Governments allocate special grants to schools for in-service training programs on a continuing basis . The priority should be workshops in methods of teaching English and Mathematics and diagnosis and treatment of learning difficulties. These courses should be available to all teachers but those identified in need of such training should be required to attend.

Response: While this is primarily the responsibility of the States and non- government schools, the Commonwealth will provide $17.5m within the programs of the Commonwealth Schools Commission for such purposes in 1982, including grants to education centres operated by teachers.
11. Teaching Aids

Against the background of uncertainty concerning effective use of teaching aids the Committee recommended instruction as part of teacher training in the use and selection of teaching aids, caution in the purchase and use of television as a teaching aid and evaluation by schools of their own stock of teaching aids in order to sell those that are ineffective and further reduce purchases so that equipment funds may be applied to more effective purchases.

Response: The Commonwealth notes the Senate Committee's recommendation, though it should be recognised that instruction in the use of teaching aids already forms part of most current teacher education programs. However, the recommendation raises matters which are essentially ones for State Education authorities, individual training institutions and schools to consider in assessing their own needs and priorities.
12. Core Curriculum

A core curriculum in literacy and numeracy should be introduced into all schools and implemented systematically to achieve continuity of teaching experiences through all years of schooling. The details of curriculum construction should be the responsibility of education departments and experimentation with school based curriculum restricted. National monitoring of literacy and numeracy standards should continue.

Response: It should be noted that the Curriculum Development Centre Core Curriculum which the Report wants introduced is not a specific syllabus, but rather an attempt to identify broad areas of knowledge and experience which could be included in the curriculum. Responsibilities in these areas in the States essentially rest with State and non-government school authorities.

In the ACT the Schools Authority is committed to school-based curriculum development which has been undertaken on a continuing basis as part of the normal government schools system since 1974. A comprehensive external review of the curriculum development procedures in the ACT for Years 11 and 12 was conducted in 1979 with positive findings. Refinement of procedures associated with school-based curriculum development (such as the provision of guidelines and example materials) in the ACT is currently under review.

The Commonwealth supports the recommendation to continue with the national monitoring of literacy and numeracy. At its meeting of 22-23 October 1981 the Australian Education Council reaffirmed its intention to continue sponsorship of a nationwide program to monitor performance of students. It decided that monitoring should take place at regular intervals. The Council will be making decisions at its June 1982 meeting on the form and frequency of the monitoring program taking account of the findings of the final report of the 1980 testing. Development of the diagnostic and achievement tests to be used by teachers at the classroom level will proceed and a report made on these to the June 1982 meeting.
13. Home Environment
Headmasters should be required to give priority to establishing closer involvement and understanding between parents and schools and public relations campaigns should be mounted to support this.

Response: This recommendation is essentially a matter for State authorities and schools themselves to implement. The concept of community involvement in schools is supported by the Government, and the Commonwealth Schools Commission has funded projects in which parent school interaction has been a key feature. It is also encouraged under the Transition Program.
14. Career Guidance and School Counsellors

Student counsellors and career guidance officers should be appointed to all secondary schools and such services introduced into schools as part of the education program. Action should be taken to expand training provisions for counsellors and guidance officers and to award them appropriate specialist qualifications and status within the teaching profession.

Response: The Commonwealth accepts the importance of adequate services being available in this area and it should be noted that the States have significantly increased the numbers of such officers in 1980-81 with funding from the Commonwealth Transition Program.

The Committee's recommendations that counsellors and guidance officers be appointed to all secondary schools, and that appropriate qualifications and status be awarded within the teaching profession, fall within State and non- government school responsibilities.

In the A.C.T. in-service courses in career education are provided by the Schools Authority and these include short industrial placement of teachers, courses and sessions with the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations, labour market seminars, regular meetings of career co-ordinators and other relevant courses. Teachers employed as counsellors in A.C.T. government schools are required to have completed at least the first year of a Master's degree in School Counselling.
15. Secondary School System

The Australian Education Council should urgently convene a conference of Commonwealth and State education departments to draw up plans for restructuring the secondary school system to provide curriculum structures directly serving school leavers with non-academic outcomes. In considering such a proposal particular attention should be given to Years 11 and 12 of secondary education being conducted in separate institutions.

Response: The Commonwealth would be happy for the AEC to sponsor such an activity. In his statement to Parliament of 4 June 1981 concerning the outcome of the Review of Opportunities for Youth, my predecessor indicated that the Commonwealth wished to accelerate the development of appropriate transition courses in secondary schools, with emphasis on basic changes in curricula relevant particularly to the needs of low achievers. However, the Commonwealth recognises the rights and responsibilities of the States in respect of structuring their school systems and would not seek to impose specific developments upon them.

The Senate Committee's wish that particular attention be given to having Years 11 and 12 conducted in separate high schools or colleges is already in operation in the Australian Capital Territory and in Tasmania. While the separate senior high school has advantages, no clear evidence is yet available to indicate that such schools better prepare students for entrance to the world of work or result in higher academic achievement. Many link courses and the less academic alternative courses now operating in the States which the Senate Committee saw as part of the restructuring of secondary education have been supported from the Commonwealth Transition Program.
16. Educational Research

Priority for educational research should be directed towards solving practical problems and findings translated into statements for policy development and practical propositions so that more effective use can be made of the research. Educational research should be more effectively co-ordinated.

Response: The Commonwealth accepts this recommendation and will continue to encourage the co-ordination of research through the Australian Education Council , and meetings of State and Commonwealth education researchers.
Conclusion

The Committee's major concern was to encourage closer links between industry and educators, and between schools, parents and the community in order to make what is offered and taught at schools more relevant both to the demands of working life and to the demands of modern society. The Committee has produced a thoughtful and constructive report which is producing a worthwhile contribution to the transition debate. I commend the Report to all who are interested in this important area of education.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night, before the adjournment debate, I was debating the extension of the bounty covered by the Fertilizers (Subsidy) Amendment Bill 1982. I turn again to the discussion held by the National Farmers Federation on this matter. It has been suggested that the overall effect of tariffs on the farming community in 1979-80 was $340m or 6 per cent of the total farm costs. On the basis of calculations of the Industries Assistance Commission, that protection adds 2.8c per kilometre to the cost of running a car and about $112m of that total cost can be attributed to the tariff on motor vehicles. Indeed, in Australia the motor vehicle industry and the clothing, footwear and textile industries are the main beneficiaries of the import tariff system. By way of example I point out that, in 1980, 387,400 people were employed in agriculture and associated service industries in Australia. The cost attributable to tariffs affecting primary industry if they had not been incurred and had been distributed by way of wages to those people instead, would have resulted in an average wage increase in the order of $900 a person.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1975-76-these figures have not been able to be updated-it was estimated that the cost of tariffs borne by farmers was $2.60 a sheep, $8 a head of cattle and $31.20 per tonne of grain. This is the sort of debilitating effect which the current tariff structure is having on primary producers today. It is important to note that the same effect, to a greater or lesser extent, would be spread right throughout the community. The underlying rationale behind tariffs is to protect Australian industries which might otherwise be disadvantaged by free competition from overseas.

I accept that, with the high prevailing wage rates and the unacceptable level of industrial unrest in Australia today, there are cost factors which are not necessarily imposed upon our competitors. However, recent history of this country shows that there has been a great temptation from many union leaders who know that, if they press firmly enough upon the employers for unrealistic wage increases through strike action, ultimately they will receive the unrealistic wage demands which they pursue. In many sectors of the secondary industry the employer knows that all he has to do to recoup his additional wage payout is to go cap in hand to the Federal Government for additional tariff levels which, of course, the users and the exporters in the end have to carry.

These additional burdens, of course, are placed upon the rest of the community and cause no pain to the employers. Need we go past the example of the recent case of the metal trades industry which, last December, negotiated an agreement which amounted to a 38-hour a week and a simultaneous $39 a week wage increase? Cynics might be tempted to ask how an industry such as the metal trades industry can on the one hand negotiate such a generous agreement and, on the other hand, ask for a continuation of government support by way of tariffs to enable it to compete on the domestic market. According to one report, that agreement amounts to a 22.5 per cent increase in costs for metal trades employers or, to put it another way, it amounts roughly to the same as the average rate of assistance which is presently rendered to the manufacturing sector by way of tariffs.

That does not sound to me like a path between what the Director of the Metal Trades Industry Association of Australia, Mr Albert Evans, called the economic capacity of the industry to sustain higher costs and the industrial reality of constant strikes and disruptions. It sounds to me like an industry caving in to union pressure. If it can afford that, surely it can afford to reduce its tariffs for the benefit of all other Australians and all other sectors of the Australian economy. The manufacturers, of course, are able to hide behind a tariff wall and pass on their costs to consumers without fear or threat of real competition. However, if the employer is an exporter, such as a farmer, who is unable to pass on his additional costs because he has to compete on an open world market and who knows that people buying his products are not concerned about his profits or additional costs but simply about what the market will bear , he must absorb all these additional costs himself.

Of course, added to this direct additional cost are wage demands and the like. The farmer is required personally to carry the further enormous burden of the weakness, selfishness, expediency and, in may cases, incompetence of some other employers who create these additional inbuilt costs in the community, often through unnecessary, unfair, unreasonable and improper agreements with unions. I accept that if Australian industries were able to compete effectively most of the benefits of tariff reductions would have to be ploughed back into plant and equipment and they would not necessarily be distributed on an ad hoc basis as undeserved wage increases. I remind the Senate of the Federal Government's policy statement in 1977 in its White Paper on manufacturing industry which said :

Australian manufacturing industry needs in the long-run to achieve a greater degree of specialisation, with less reliance on government assistance. As a long term objective the community will be best served by a manufacturing industry with a structure which requires minimum levels of government support.

In this case I stress manufacturing because that is the area which is receiving the most government support by way of tariffs and quotas. According to the 1980- 81 annual report of the IAC the average effective rate of assistance for the manufacturing sector as a whole in that year was 24 per cent. That same level of assistance was effectively rendered to the manufacturing sector in the two previous years, 1979-80 and 1978-79. Looking at individual industries, the clothing and footwear industries effectively received assistance in the order of 130 per cent, the motor vehicle industry effectively received 90 per cent and the textile industry effectively received 49 per cent. By comparison, the effective rate of assistance for agriculture in the years 1978-79 was 8 per cent , in 1979-80 it was 4 per cent and in 1980-81 it was one per cent.

I argue that it was the view of the Federal Government in that 1977 White Paper that, rather than increase the level of government aid to industry, whether it be primary or secondary, it should phase it out altogether or at least allow it to fall to very minimal standards.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the unemployment?

—I think that unemployment ought to be looked at in totally different terms. I am sure that if we restructure industry effectively and efficiently we will find that we can absorb a great many of the work force. I am not suggesting for a moment that we immediately dislocate industry because that would, in the short term, cause very real problems in terms of employment. The effect which a substantial reduction of tariffs on manufacturing will have on the Australian economy will be a forced restructuring whereby inefficient industries will disappear and the industries which are rendered more competitive will achieve greater growth. What will be the effect of that? In a freer trade situation the dollar can be devalued because the incentive for efficient industries to export will be greater and those developing industries will take up a greater share of the labour market. The farm sector would be the one to benefit from this change, and the mining sector, already beset by falling world commodity prices and ever increasing costs, would be another. They would be more competitive in the world scene, their input costs for imported equipment would be lower and their share of world markets and the price they can achieve would improve dramatically.

SPEECH.PARA: With the additional costs which farmers are being forced to bear due to the present tariff structure, a subsidy on fertilisers is essential to redress the imbalance. The Government cannot take away on the one hand without offering some measure of assistance on the other hand. The debates in the other place indicate that the Opposition seems to have some reservations about the extension of the provisions of this Bill to imported fertiliser as well as the local product. Yet the honourable member for Werriwa, Mr Kerin, expressed the fear that cheap superphosphate would be brought into Australia. In fact he cited Adelaide and Wallaroo Fertilizers Ltd which in 1981 produced 650,000 tonnes of single strength superphosphate and suggested that if one 20,000 tonne shipload of double superphosphate were imported it would comprise 40,000 tonnes of single phosphate or about 6 per cent of Adelaide and Wallaroo's annual production. It is not that simple, but perhaps I should quote an observation by the Industries Assistance Commission which is as follows:
AFL (Australian Fertilizers Ltd) stated that about eighty per cent of Australia 's fertilizer phosphorus is through single superphosphate . . .

There appears to be a strong trend away from the use of single superphosphate on crops in Victoria and Western Australia. It appears, therefore, that the proportion of the market for phosphate fertilizers that could be subject to import competition is increasing. In response to the draft report, the Electrolitic Zinc Company of Australasia Limited expressed concern that, if this occurred, imported high analysis fertilizers could pose a serious problem for local manufacturers because of the possibility for the substitution of these products for low analysis products . . .
I understand that to be a problem which the Opposition is envisaging. I quote further the IAC views of the validity of these fears. The IAC stated:

One of the reasons for the widespread use of single superphosphate in Australia , compared with other fertilizer using countries, is the widespread sulphur deficiencies in Australian soils . . . (but) single superphosphate has a much higher sulphur content than high analysis fertilizers.
Later the IAC concluded:

The Commission considers that the removal of fertilizer assistance, or its extension to imported phosphatic fertilizers, would not be likely to lead to a significant reduction in the local manufacture of these fertilizers.

I believe we should draw two conclusions from the IAC report. Firstly, removing the current 2 per cent import duty on fertilisers and extending the bounty to those fertilisers would have only a limited effect. Secondly, the removal of the subsidy completely would have only a minimal effect on overall fertiliser production and therefore, by implication, only minimal effect on the rate of usage. Fertiliser is a necessity in Australia and demand for it is relatively inelastic. Without the subsidy which we are discussing today farmers would have little choice but to face even higher costs. These subsidies recognise the fact that farmers are unduly burdened by the effects of tariffs which are designed to protect inefficient manufacturing industries. Bounties are one of the measures of redress available to farmers.

I give my unqualified support to this legislation. I hope that when the presently proposed period of extension for the bounty on phosphate and nitrogenous fertilisers expires in 1985 the need for the bounty will have largely been removed. I trust that by June 1985 the levels of assistance through high tariffs presently granted to often inefficient industries, which are placing heavy pressure on the agricultural industries, will be sufficiently reduced to allow primary industries to compete properly with their overseas competitiors on their own merits. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not want to cause any disturbance in the Senate, but I think the honourable senator was perilously close to reading his speech. I hope in future that he will have copious notes only.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, if I may have your indulgence for a moment, in fact I was not reading my speech. I referred to a great number of detailed statistics which from time to time are very difficult to recall. So I was required to refer to my notes on that basis. However, I take note of what you said.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The central intent of this piece of legislation, according to the second reading speech of the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume), is to 'ensure that farmers have adequate access to fertilisers at competitive prices'. I accept that that would be extremely useful and beneficial and I am sure it would have the support of this chamber. However, the legislation has had a rather chequered history. The Fertilizers ( Subsidy) Amendment Bill, in the form in which it was introduced merely extended the status quo of the bounty for a further three years to 1985. The Government introduced a range of amendments to that Bill, the main import of which was to allow that bounty to be changed to a subsidy, thereby to apply not only to locally produced fertilisers but also to imported fertilisers. This chamber and the other place have no quibble with the initial Bill. I am sure some honourable senators would like further assurances about that Bill but I think the original Bill would have no problem in having a speedy passage here.

SPEECH.PARA: The crux of the problem is the extension of the bounty, changing its nature to a subsidy and placing it on imports. The support for this move again raises some confusion. I refer to the differences between the draft report on phosphatic and nitrogenous fertilisers produced by the Industries Assistance Commission and its final report. The space between those reports led to a very interesting situation. The first recommendation of the final report stated:
Assistance, by means of bounty, be accorded the consumption of phosphatic fertilizers produced in Australia and sold for use in Australia.

The draft report omitted the words 'produced in Australia'. If one turns to the rest of the report to seek the argumentation for this change one finds that it becomes even more confusing. There does not seem to be in the report substantive arguments as to why the IAC changed its first recommendation. Indeed, it goes to some lengths to try to point out what little effect this would have on the manufacturing industry in Australia. Nevertheless, it makes a recommendation that it would be far better to retain the status quo and to phase out the bounty over three years. I certainly support that proposition. However, the Government, in its response in the second reading speech, did not address itself at all to that recommendation of the IAC. It did not state whether the Government would phase out the bounty over three years. The supporting argument given by the IAC was that, if the Government announced now that it intended to phase out that bounty, the industry in Australia could adjust. This seems an entirely proper and reasonable way for us to reduce some of our bounties and tariff barriers, that is, to allow the industry to adjust.

The Fertilizers (Subsidy) Amendment Bill does not give the industry that benefit. The arguments as to why the industry ought not to have that benefit really boiled down to the fact that the original intention of the bounty-this I accept as being the intention of the Act-was that it should be given solely to the consumer. The legislation makes it quite clear that it was not meant to be at any stage a protective measure for local industry. However, I think we all must agree that it eventually turned out to be a protective measure for local industry. The incidental protection that is involved in placing that bounty only on local products, as Senator Walsh pointed out most persuasively last night, has the effect of giving a protective incidence to local manufacturers. I do not believe that, while the Act has a particular intention, if spin-offs have another intention we can ignore them completely. We have to address ourselves to what may be the likely consequences for the local manufacturing industry of the development of a subsidy rather than a simple bounty. When we address ourselves to that question we immediately discover that there is a fair range of complications. I will go through some of those.

The first complication that needs to be raised, which was not addressed at all in the Minister's second reading speech, concerns Christmas Island, a dependency of Australia to which we have a particular responsibility. I think that most people would agree that it seems that in the short term Christmas Island will be mined out. It may very well be that its mining life will be no more than five to 10 years. This depends on whether there is a possibility of developing a successful economic operation in mining low yielding ores. Leaving that aside, I do not think that anybody is really giving the fertiliser industry of Christmas Island a terribly long life.

The Government, I believe, has a peculiar obligation to inform the legislature of its intentions in this regard. I refer to a comment that Senator Chaney made last night in answer to propositions by the Australian Democrats. He made what I thought was a cheap gibe about the possibility of our being in government and hence our ability to take unreal positions. Quite frankly, I was not elected to be a part of government; I was elected by the people of Queensland to be part of the Parliament and the Parliament's sole responsibility is in relation to legislation. I take that responsibility seriously. It is the one that I was elected to take and it is the one that I will pursue. I will not, in any way, accede to the Minister's implication that I could be totally irresponsible with my vote because I may or may not be in government. I believe that that is a proposition which casts aspersions on every member of an opposition, whether it consists of Liberal or Labor Party members. It implies that members of an opposition are able to take up totally irresponsible positions in relation to legislation before this House. I utterly and totally reject the implication against me and other members of my Party. When I cast my vote I cast it in as responsible a fashion as I can in relation to all the material that is available to me. If the Minister wishes to debate that matter further I will be quite happy to do so. I have been at great pains to discuss with the Minister our problems not only with this legislation but also with many other pieces of legislation. We have put a great deal of work into every piece of legislation that has come before this chamber.

As I said, the Minister made no comment on Christmas Island in his second reading speech. That is an omission that I hope he will address in his reply. The second problem concerns discussions that the Government has undertaken with the Government of the Republic of Nauru. Again, I believe that we have statutory obligations to accept certain amounts of fertiliser from the Republic of Nauru. In addition to that, we have certain moral obligations to the republics that are in our neighbourhood. I refer particularly to those of the Pacific. Nauru's economy is involved quite intricately with its fertiliser industry. I would be very interested in the Minister's response as to what discussions the Government had with the Government of the Republic of Nauru before this legislation was introduced into the House of Representatives and what assurances our Government was able to give to the Government of Nauru. Failing any discussions, what does the Government believe are its obligations to the Republic of Nauru? I believe that we must foster close and continuing links with the countries in our region.

The third problem, which I believe to be of crucial significance to this Bill, is the failure of the Government to lock into place any anti-dumping legislation as is contained in the Act governing nitrogenous fertilisers. Clause 6 of the Nitrogenous Fertilizers Subsidy Act 1966, a parallel Act, addresses quite extensively the issue of when subsidies will not be paid. The intent of that clause is that Australia not be involved in promoting dumping within the agricultural community of the world. I believe that in the long term interests of our agricultural community we must avoid at all costs the adoption of inconsistent positions-for instance, by criticising the European Economic Community for engaging in dumping in valuable markets that we wish to develop in South East Asia and then ourselves being a party to possible support of dumping operations on the part of the United States. In that regard I hope that the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) will respond concerning the precarious position of the phosphatic fertiliser industry in that country, and in Florida in particular. On Monday of this week yet another three major plants in the United States closed down completely. Undoubtedly there is a glut on world markets and, I believe quite rightly, the farmers, the consumers of fertiliser in this country, wish to take some advantage of lower world prices. But I wonder whether, in seeking that quite legitimate end the farmers may very well neglect their own long term interests which may be tied up more closely with those of our own producers than they may have recognised in their submissions to honourable senators.

I turn to the Government's intention, in relation to the protection tariff debate, possibly to isolate one industry, fertiliser manufacturing. Why has the Government chosen at this time to take in regard to this industry the particular stance that it has? I support totally the types of propositions that have been put to me and to other senators by the National Farmers Federation in relation to the development within this country of some coherent, cohesive, rational policy on tariff reductions-that, indeed, putting into place such a policy will do far more for our rural industries than will any tinkering with subsidies or bounties. I agree totally-I believe the point has been made by other senators also-that our rural industries, in comparison with manufacturing industries, are not in any way supported, in regard to type and development, although seemingly, it is the settled view of the community that they are.

Maybe it is just the settled view of the newspapers. I believe that all of the evidence confirms that the rural industries of this country are not supported to anywhere near the extent that our manufacturing industries are supported. Whether one accepts the general proposition of the Industries Assistance Commission that the difference in that regard is of the order of 2 per cent and 24 per cent, or whether one agrees with the recent comments of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) that those figures are exaggerated-I notice that he did not say they were totally incorrect-I believe the margin between effective support for our rural industries and that for our manufacturing industries is very wide indeed. We must address constantly the problem of assisting our rural industries to be competitive in the world market. The world market is a very simple market in that in almost every other country rural production is heavily subsidised by one means or another. In this regard, in the National Farmers Federation Newsletter of May 1982, Mr Davidson, its President, is reported to have said:

It is clearly established that high levels of protection to some manufacturing industries add to the cost of farm inputs, reduce the international competitiveness of Australian rural exports, limit the development of new export markets and completely undermine Australia's case for reduced protectionism in other countries such as the EEC . . .

I concur with those comments. One has only to point to the problem with farm machinery in Australia to see that the Government's attitude is causing enormous problems for rural industry. Many other examples can be cited.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think 'The Modest Farmer' would agree with you too.
—I think he might. Mr Davidson said further:

SPEECH.PARA: The NFF will not relent in its long-term policies to effect moderate, progressive reduction in protection.

I believe that accords totally with the propositions that Senator Siddons has put forward time and time again on behalf of the Australian Democrats in seeking long term indicative planning in this country so that we may settle on the direction in which we are heading. Mr Davidson said further:
In simple terms, the Government cannot expect the rural sector to accept reductions in assistance when assistance to other sectors is being maintained . . .

In two areas-the motor car manufacturing industry and the clothing and textiles industry-the Government has recently found its way clear to make massive decisions, but it has apparently not been able to make similar decisions which would benefit farmers. This measure has the problems that I have enunciated- those with regard to Christmas Island and Nauru and the long term interests of the rural sector, which are linked inextricably with the Government's overall policy on tariff reduction. A further problem concerns whether the Government at any stage will make any announcements, following the IAC's recommendation to phase out the bounty. I believe that if the Government had introduced the original legislation, had agreed with the IAC on a phasing-out operation and at the same time had pointed to the other changes that it would make, either in monetary policy with regard to the value of the dollar or in other assistance for the rural industry, such a package would have made much more sense than does the one-off, ad hoc proposition that we have before us.

Finally, I believe that the Government has an obligation, which it has not fulfilled to date, to explain to the legislature the particular items that I have raised. It is excessively difficult for people in this chamber to vote for Government legislation unless the Government is willing to enter into a comprehensive debate on it and thus permit sufficient understanding of its intentions in associated areas to enable honourable senators to cast a responsible vote on the issues. I await the Minister's reply to my comments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because of the legislative program we must get through this day I will not delay the Senate much further. Obviously, had there been any chance of the amendments made to the Fertilizers (Subsidy) Amendment Bill 1982 in the House of Representatives being extracted in the Senate, it would have warranted a more detailed speech and approach. As I understand the current situation, it is not the majority wish in the Senate for those amendments to be deleted, since that could well lead to the passage of the Bill being deferred until August. I make my position very clear. I regard the action of the House of Representatives in amending the Bill at the instigation of the Government as an insult to this chamber. The House of Representatives knew full well that the Bill would expire on 30 June. The Government, which instigated the amendments to its own Bill in the House of Representatives knew it and also knew that the House of Representatives, would be in recess when the Senate was considering those amendments. It therefore placed us in a position of having a gun at our heads. It was a case of: 'If you do not pass this legislation you will delay the payment of the bounty'. If Government senators believe that to be a proper situation, let them say so. In my view it denies to this chamber its rightful role as a House of review. Effectively it cuts off that role.

SPEECH.PARA: If the National Farmers Federation or any bureaucrat tries to accuse the Opposition, the Australian Democrats or me of tampering with the bounty, they stand condemned. It has been this chamber's role of review that has saved the farmer time and again. I would be prepared to travel the length and breadth of Tasmania to speak to my contacts in the rural industry to make known my views on this matter. Yesterday Mr David Trebeck, Deputy Director of the National Farmers Federation, in his address entitled 'Superphosphate Hypocrisy and Frustration', said about the debate in this Senate:

The whole sorry saga is due to culminate today when the Senate votes on the legislation. It all hinges on whether the Democrats decide to support the ALP and defeat the Bill. If such outrageous and hypocritical action is successful, it will mean that the bounty as a whole will expire on 30 June, given that the House of Representatives is not likely to be reconvened before then to consider the Senate's action.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is this idiot's name?

—The gentleman concerned is Mr David Trebeck. That sort of statement by a bureaucrat surely does not represent the viewpoint of the rural community. He is virtually telling the Opposition, the Democrats and me that we should not exercise our rightful review function. I say to him that I intend to exercise that rightful review function. If I had my way I would take out of the Bill the amendments that were inserted by the House of Representatives in order to show the House of Representatives that we are intent on giving legislation its proper review when it comes to this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of honourable senators have made a number of points on these matters. I will not canvass those, but certain questions arise which have not been answered. They include: The question of the long term effect on the farmers of Australia if the Government's proposal to extend the bounty to imports is adopted. We have not heard what effect this would have in the long term. It has been suggested to us by the lobbyists that there is some short term benefit but the long term benefit has not been suggested. What will be the long term effect on the trace elements in the Australian soil if, for example, farmers opt for triple superphosphate instead of single superphosphate? That is another question to which the Government appears not to have addressed itself. If it has addressed itself to that problem, then it has not confided in the Senate or the House of Representatives. What would be the effect on manufacturers if the bounty were extended to imports? That has not properly been determined nor could it properly be determined in the short period between the time when the Government decided to amend its own legislation in the House of Representatives and the time when the legislation was introduced here. It has been suggested that a number of Australian manufacturers are on a knife edge. It has been suggested, for example, that the Duchess mine in Queensland was operating on a knife edge basis and that it has been resurrected only in the last 18 months or so. What effect will the legislation have on that mine's operations? What effect will it have, for example, on the Electrolytic Zinc Co. of Australia Ltd in Tasmania? If it means that that company's operations are no longer viable, I ask the Government to tell me how the asset will be disposed of by the company. These are the sorts of considerations that should have taken place but obviously have not been given to the effects of the amendments made by the Government in the House of Representatives.

What will happen to the workers of Christmas Island? Has the Government given consideration to its guarantee to the manufacturer on Christmas Island which in turn has given a guarantee to the Australian National Line that it will subsidise the shortfall in the carrying of phosphate from Christmas Island? When ANL took over the ships of the British Phosphate Commission, a guarantee was given by the manufacturer, backed up by the Australian Government. Has the Government considered the effect on the Treasury of having to subsidise ANL even further to the extent guaranteed by that undertaking given by British Phosphate at the time? What will be the add-on effect of that further subsidy in respect of ANL operations in coastal Australia, including its operations from the mainland to Tasmania? These are the sorts of things about which we have heard nothing from the Government but which are of vital importance if we in this chamber are effectively to discharge our role as a House of review. Allegations have been made that the manufacturers in Australia are not passing on the full benefit of the bounty. They are very serious allegations, given the provisions of section 7 of the Phosphate Fertilizers Bounty Act, which states:

Where the Minister is not satisfied that the prices being charged by a producer to purchasers in respect of the sale of bountiable products, or fertiliser mixtures, produced by him at registered premises are such as to pass on to the purchasers the full benefit of the bounty in respect of the bountiable products, or the bountiable products used in the fertiliser mixtures, as the case may be, the Minister may direct that bounty shall not be paid to the producer.

As we all know, the Department does keep a check on the matter. I understand the proposition that various factors could substantiate the allegations but they have not been brought to the fore at present. If they exist, which I doubt, let those who are making the allegations against the manufacturers come forward with the proof. I am sure that it would be in the interests of the manufacturers and indeed the farmers themselves if some investigation could be made of these allegations. One of the statements by Mr Trebeck in his address yesterday was:

Let me say at the outset that NFF has lobbied this matter, in support of the proposed extension to imports, more intensively than any single issue I can recall in recent memory (broad protection matters such as motor vehicles aside).
That appeared on the front page of his statement. Yet in conclusion he talked of the bounty as being rather symbolic. He said:
It remains symbolic.

I wonder what benefit has come out of these lobbying efforts by the National Farmers Federation which have been more intensive than on any single issue. I have supported the superphosphate bounty and I have been accused of thereby helping the big farmers. What the National Farmers Federation has done in its lobbying to date is to raise the question of whether the bounty ought to continue to apply. That is the danger which occurs when this type of lobbying goes on. If such outrageous and hypocritical action is successful-my name was not mentioned in the accusations but the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats were mentioned-I intend to engage in a bit of outrageous and hypocritical action by, as a senator, exercising my role of the review of legislation that comes from the House of Representatives. I would have voted to extract the clauses if that course had been available to us in the Senate by means of a majority vote, but I understand that is not the situation at present. That would have thrown the onus back on the Government to put its own house in order. The Government would have come back to us in August with a reasoned submission rather than something that it has dreamed up off the top of its head and amended in the House of Representatives. Of course, the second best thing would be to defer consideration of this measure until August. The onus would then be on the Government to say that it does intend to support the continuance of the bounty, which I have supported against a lot of criticism in this chamber for a considerable number of years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have enjoyed the four or five speeches which have been made on the Fertilizers ( Subsidy) Amendment Bill. No doubt I have been educated by them. The debates have circulated around the quite different propositions which various members of the Senate seem to think are the critical points of the Bill. I was relieved to find that Senator Macklin, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, did make a concession on a point which I think is rather central and that is that the intent of this legislation is to help farmers. That seems to have been largely lost in the general debate around here. I acknowledge and thank him for that although I do not believe that the rest of his contribution really took that worthy sentiment into account.

SPEECH.PARA: The second area of debate that the Bill has produced is the need for protection of phosphate manufacturers in Australia. Quite clearly that is burning deep in the heart of Senator Harradine. Obviously some honourable senators have a deep concern about the possible effects on phosphate manufacturers. They are not consoled by the rather soothing words of the Industries Assistance Commission over a period of years that this is a competitive industry, an industry which has various advantages and which is able to face up to international competition . There is a second quite separate element of the debate which involves the protection of phosphate manufacturers. We had a third area of debate which concerned the whole question of protection generally. I believe the contribution of Senator Walsh and indeed the basic contribution of Senator Macklin revolved around their attitudes to protection policy generally. Both of them are, at heart, free traders. Both of them find artificial interference with the markets offensive. They find offensive the distortion of the markets, which is so often the result of tariffs and subsidies. They brought their concerns very much into the open in their contributions to the debate. That question provided a third and quite separate strand of argument. The fourth quite separate strand was that we have to protect the interests of the Christmas Island workers. Within the last half hour or so of the debate we even got a mention of Nauru.

There was a fifth and, I think, rather more offensive strand of the argument which related to the fact that whilst we can all get up in here and say whatever we like about whoever we like in terms as base and as vile as we like, if somebody has the cheek to put a strong view to us that person is damned. I did not know that one could manage to squeeze into the word 'bureaucrat' such contempt and loathing. I must say that it reminded me of the way people use the word 'scab' around here. 'Bureaucrat' is not really a term of offence. Quite frankly, if Mr David Trebeck or anybody else wants to put strong views about what we do in this place I suggest that they are entitled to do so.

The use of unseemly language in this place is not infrequent, including language about people who are not in a position to defend themselves. I am not very impressed by those elements of the debate which say: 'How dare the farmers, through the National Farmers Federation, use strong language about us'. I receive a great deal of strong language in the communications which come to me in the range of duties that I adopt on behalf of the Government. I do not find it pleasant but also I do not feel it is desirable to indicate that the use of that language is something which will colour my judgment on the issues with which I am called to deal. I do not say: 'How dare you say that I might be regarded as a hypocrite or whatever'. I simply suggest that we should get back to the substance of the Bill.

As I said before, the basic substance of the Bill is that we should provide some assistance for farmers through the payment of a fertiliser bounty which will now become-if this Bill is passed-a fertiliser subsidy. We have had a deal of academic argument about whether there should be any form of assistance. I remember part of the contribution of Senator Walsh where he used words to the effect that there was no case for transferring income from taxpayers to farmers, particularly wealthy farmers. That was the part of his argument which was really against there being any form of assistance in this area at all. As a matter of pure logic and as a matter of a principle which would be applied in a world where principles were applied equally across the board, I think that Senator Walsh is quite correct. There would be no logic in transferring taxpayers' money to farmers in a system where transfers against farmers were not taking place.

But it has been admitted in the debate and it is part of the IAC report that, in fact, there are transfers which are inimical to the economic interests of farmers. There are very heavily subsidised sections of Australian industry which cost farmers dearly. Part of the conclusion which is brought out by the IAC and, I think, adequately explained by it-it is surely generally understood in this chamber-is that what has been described in this debate as the diminishing assistance provided to farmers through this subsidy, or bounty as it is at present, is but a tiny offset to the disadvantages of one of the few sectors of Australian industry which genuinely in many cases trades internationally on a free market or on a market which is loaded against it.

Senator Crichton-Browne, speaking in support of the Government, put views which were particularly related to Western Australia and talked about the problems and the costs of inputs in that part of Western Australia. I acknowledge those arguments. But, to my mind, the really strong point is that, given a scheme of assistance to industry generally which is weighted in favour of manufacturing industry, it is hard to gainsay that there should be some continuing provision of assistance to farmers. I suppose that reality is reflected in the fact that all parties in this chamber and even independents are paying at least lip- service to the proposition that the bounty should continue.

I will now deal with the other strands of debate which were part of it and which appear to be central to the fact that a group of honourable senators is determined to delay this legislation notwithstanding the break which that will involve in the provision of bounty assistance. The protection of phosphate manufacturers is a point which has been made by a number of speakers. I can do very little more than refer the Senate to the various pronouncements of the IAC which has examined this proposition over a period of years. In 1976-which is some time ago now but it is interesting to see the consistency-we find the IAC saying that:
The Commission is aware that its recommendation for payment of bounty on imports--
That is, of course, the proposition before us now-

and for the sale of phosphate rock from Christmas Island at commercial prices will remove protection presently available to Australian fertiliser manufacturers. It sees such removal as being consistent with the recommendations in its report of 21 August 1975 on Superphosphate Production that assistance be not accorded to the production of superphosphates. If removal exposes the fertiliser manufacturers to damaging competition, the appropriate course would be a further examination of the question of assistance for their industry.
I will quote only briefly from the Commission's more recent report of 26 February 1982. The IAC said:

Given the advantages of locally produced single superphosphate, the minimal protection currently afforded manufacturers of nitrogenous fertilisers and the low price elasticity of demand for fertilisers, the Commission considers that removal of fertiliser assistance, or its extension to imported phosphatic fertilisers, would not be likely to lead to a significant reduction in the local manufacture of these fertilisers. Even if this reduction could be shown to be significant, it has not been demonstrated that fertiliser manufacture should be shielded from import competition or that consumption assistance is an appropriate means of achieving this.
In other words, that is the expert advice which is available from the independent IAC to the Government. It suggests that there is something of an over-emphasis on the problems of manufacturers.

Another point for consideration is that, if the world market is so difficult, it remains true that Australian manufacturers have access to other sources of rock. If there is such a deep and abiding problem that problem is not merely one which relates to the import of finished fertilisers. It is presumably a problem which can also arise with respect to the importation of the rock which is presently imported, in the main, from Nauru or Christmas Island. So, there is no answer to the longer term problems of the manufacturers with respect to international competition in the propositions which have been put forward by those who are opposing this Bill.

I suggest that in this country we have an established system of providing temporary and long term assistance for those industries which need it. It is a system which I think people such as Senator Walsh and Senator Macklin would suggest usually results in over-protection of many sections of Australian industry. They are not arms of government action which are open to the accusation of inadequate protection. Rather, the accusations from those honourable senators at least are usually the reverse. I suggest that the simple answer to the manufacturers' point is that this is legislation which looks to providing some compensating adjustment to the rural community. If, against the view of the IAC, there really is a significant risk to manufacturers, they should be seeking to use the mechanisms which are available to gain the protection that they say they require.

This Government takes the view that it should not make decisions on protection without reference to those authorities. That is a view which I would have thought would have the support of everyone in this chamber. Yet we have people wishing to move in a way which says: 'No, you do not need to do that. We have made our judgments. I live next door to EZ Industries and I know they might be in trouble. Therefore, we ought to be imposing protection by this'.

I think that second leg of argument has little or no weight. If it does have weight against the views of the IAC, it is a matter which should be subjected to references to either the Temporary Assistance Authority or the IAC. I suggest that that is the course manufacturers should follow. I believe that one or more of them are intending to or, in fact, have already set off along that course. The argument about protection generally is an argument which I believe we would properly address in debates which touch on broader sections of industry than this debate does. I do not believe that this bounty-to be a subsidy-is the vehicle which ought to be used to stress or to press upon the Parliament that we want, generally, a lower system of protection in Australia. It seems to me that the farmers of Australia are entitled to ask: 'Why us?'
