Protection for Christmas Island and Nauru is a matter which is, of course, of serious concern to the Commonwealth Government, but not because there are some mysterious contractual arrangements which seem to be in the mind of, I think, Senator Harradine. I advise him to address inquiries to the Government or to the Department of Primary Industry if he feels that there are some arrangements in place of which I am not aware. But the obligations that we have with respect to the administration of Christmas Island are clear. We, of course, have no similar obligations with respect to Nauru. The concerns which have been expressed about the future operations on Christmas Island are in that sense, the concerns of the Government as well. We have the responsibility for the administration of the Island and that responsibility is intimately linked with the operation of industry on the Island for the limited periods which remains. I stress that it is a limited period.

In light of the IAC report and in light of the Government's examination of the factors relevant to sourcing decisions by manufacturers, the Government is of the view that this legislation is of little relevance to the problems of Christmas Island. The future of phosphate rock production on Christmas Island will be influenced by a number of considerations which will have a much greater impact than will the proposed variation to the basis of fertiliser assistance payments. Again, I do not wish to delay the Senate unduly but I remind the Senate that the deposits on Christmas Island have an extremely limited life. We are looking at but a few years, even if all goes well with production on that Island. There are prospects of sales to other markets, including sales for lower grade rock. There is, of course, the internal influence of the exploitation of the Duchess deposit which can have a very considerable impact on the market for imported rock in Australia.

Christmas Island as an entity faces threats to its continuation which are acknowledged by the Government and which are the concern of the Government. We see the threat offered by this legislation as being minimal, if any threat does indeed exist. From the point of view of Christmas Island, the Government certainly does not see it as being necessary to change its approach to this legislation. I should like to make clear, however, that we are concerned with the long term future of the Island and, as is consistent with our responsibility to the Island community, we are trying to make sure that we plan the future of the Island in a way that protects the interests of the people of the Island.

We have commissioned a second report from Mr Sweetland dealing with the long term future of the Island. It has yet to be considered by the Government. I do not think it has been printed; it may be in the process of printing. It has certainly not yet been published. If, contrary to the Government's and the IAC's expectations, the changed arrangements which flowed from this Bill appeared to have some effects, those effects would be taken into account and would be part of the Government's consideration of what it should do with respect to the long term future of the Island. I can undertake that the Government would monitor the changing situation on Christmas Island very carefully. It is, of course, already doing that, and this legislation is certainly not seen by the Government as something which is threatening to the Christmas Islanders.

It has been foreshadowed that the attitude of at least some senators-indeed, it has been said that it is a majority of senators-would be that they would wish now to see this legislation delayed. I put it very warmly to the Senate that that is not a course which is to the advantage of anyone. It is clearly not to the advantage of the farmers of Australia, who I am sure, have no wish to see any break in the availability of the bounty on superphosphate. I do not believe that it is to the advantage of the phosphate manufacturers. But in any event, if an advantage is required for them, I put it very seriously to the chamber that it is an advantage which should be processed in the normal way through the Temporary Assistance Authority or the IAC, and that we should not regard this bounty or subsidy as being a protective tool.

I suggest to those senators who have a genuine concern about and interest in Christmas Island that it is the Government's judgment that this is a measure that will have a nil or, at worst, a marginal effect on the difficulties which Christmas Island already faces and that the Government will carefully monitor that situation and take into account any changes which occur as a result of this legislation and, indeed, the changes which occur because of larger factors that I mentioned earlier.

It is no satifaction to me that we are dealing with this legislation in the absence of the House of Representatives. That is a matter of fact. It is not a matter which has been in any sense planned by the Government. All honourable senators are aware of the way in which the program for this session has proceeded. But I want to take issue with Senator Harradine's suggestion that in some way the position is made different by the fact that the House of Representatives adopted Government amendments to the legislation before it was sent to this place. If one dispassionately and honestly looks at this situation, I think that one's attitude to the legislation should not be affected by the initial form in which it entered the House of Representatives. If it is objectionable to some senators in the form in which it now appears, presumably it would have been objectionable if it had been amended at the original time, before it was introduced into the House of Representatives. I ask any honourable senator who has that factor weighing on his or her mind to take into account the fact that it is really irrelevant to the merits of the Bill and does not go to the question of principle raised by Senator Harradine about the ability of the legislation to be dealt with here in the Senate.

In the interests of the farmers of Australia, I ask the Senate to give this legislation speedy passage. To fail to do so would almost certainly result in some hiatus in the payment of subsidy in a situation in which it is the unanimous view of this chamber that the subsidy should continue to be paid, and I think that that would be a matter for considerable regret. I commend the legislation to the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I claim to have been misrepresented, Mr Acting Deputy President, and I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rarely do this, but the Minister for Social Security ( Senator Chaney) suggested that I was averse in some way to some vigorous lobbying. I am not averse to vigorous lobbying. I am not even averse to having my actions described as outrageous or hypocritical if those actions are actions in respect of a particular issue. What I objected to was the implication of the National Farmers Federation that if this Senate chamber exercised its function of review in respect of this matter-the exercise of the function of review being the role of this chamber-that action would be outrageous and hypocritical. That was the imputation contained in the address by the gentleman that I mentioned from the National Farmers Federation. His statements indicated that if we did this, we would be responsible for having the bounty as a whole expiring on 30 June. I believe that that is an affront to the Senate and its role, and it is certainly counter-productive to the interests of the farming community of Australia.
—Thank you, Senator Harradine. I thought that you went fairly close to starting to debate the issue.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Chaney

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that Mr Trebeck has changed from being a bureaucrat to being a gentleman.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time. The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the second reading debate mention was made of the eleventh hour amendments introduced in the House of Representatives when this Bill was before that House. I add to that that the amendments were introduced on the last Wednesday on which that House sat. The Labor Party had received some information that amendments were to be introduced but the actual amendments were not known to John Kerin until the morning of the last Wednesday on which the House of Representatives sat. They were not known to me or to probably any other member of the Labor Party Caucus until John Kerin made his announcement at that Wednesday Caucus meeting.
—It was the second last day of the sitting.

—That is right. So in other words, because of the Government's actions, there was no opportunity for the Labor Party as a whole to consider the amendments that the Government introduced to its own legislation in the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.PARA: Two Committee stage amendments have been forecast. One is to be moved by me, the reasons for which I outlined last night. This morning Senator Chipp indicated that he intended to move a second amendment. The purpose of both amendments is related. It is to insulate the Australian industry against the quite violent cyclical swings in world prices. Senator Chipp's proposal is to insert into the Phosphate Fertilizers Bounty Act a clause identical to that which is already in the Nitrogenous Fertilizers Subsidy Act. It could be described as an anti-dumping clause. Senator Chaney has suggested that devices aimed at protecting Australian industry should not be inserted into the phosphatic fertiliser bill, but that obviously begs the question of why such a device is already in the Nitrogenous Fertilizers Subsidy Act, and why, if it is the Government's view that such provisions have no place in legislation on this matter, the Government has allowed that clause to remain in the Nitrogenous Fertilizers Subsidy Act.

A fact crucial to Senator Chipp's proposal is the present price of phosphatic and, I suppose, nitrogenous fertilizer in the United States. I have not been able to obtain information on that this morning. I have been told by the United States Embassy that, as far as the Embassy is concerned, it would not be possible to get such information in less than 24 hours. I do not want to take up too much time or explain why, but that information is critical to the operation of an anti-dumping provision because the crucial test is whether the f.o.b. price is lower than the American domestic price. We do know fairly accurately what the present f.o.b. price for triple superphosphate in the United States is. I am afraid I do not know at this stage what the American domestic price is. For that reason it is difficult, I suggest even impossible, to make an informed judgment about the amendment that has been foreshadowed by Senator Chipp.

For the reasons I stated last night, I believe there is a case for the provision of some insulation for the local industry against cyclical and quite violent price movements, even from the viewpoint of the consumers-that is, the farmers-because the industry has been price competitive over the long term and probably will be in the future. While the Australian industry under present conditions would certainly not be totally destroyed if it were faced with open competition from world suppliers-and I might add that the existing bounties do not, by a long way, close the gap between import prices and domestic prices for some types of fertilisers-equally there is no doubt that some of the industry's existing capacity would be phased out to the possible ultimate detriment of the Australian consumers.

I am not sure whether Senator Chipp's proposed amendment has been circulated but I have been given a copy of it. The substance of it is to insert into the Phosphate Fertilizers Bounty Act a clause identical to one in the Nitrogenous Fertilizers Subsidy Act. If either Senator Chipp's foreshadowed amendment or the one which I circulated last night were carried the legislation would be deferred until August because the House of Representatives is not sitting and I am sure the Government would have no intention of recalling it before the end of June just to deal with amendments which may be made to this Bill by the Senate. Therefore, no further delay would be incurred if the Senate moved at this stage to defer further consideration of the Bill until the Budget sitting. Reluctant though I am to expose myself to 12 weeks of intensive lobbying from the contestants on either side of this debate-and I am a little less reluctant to expose everybody else in the Senate to the same intensive lobbying-I move:
That the Committee report progress and ask for leave to sit again.

TALK.START.PARA: —I advise the Minister that the Standing Orders compel me to put Senator Walsh's motion without further discussion.
—I raise a point of order. If the Minister wishes, may he seek and be granted leave?
—I had thought that the requirement of the Standing Order was mandatory but the chamber is the master of its own destiny.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I thank the Committee for its indulgence. The Government obviously is opposed to the motion to report progress with the objective, as outlined by Senator Walsh, of obtaining the postponement of the consideration of this Bill until August. The reasons for that are not hard to understand. The effect of postponing consideration of the Bill will be to provide a break in the bounty arrangements which have applied to these fertilisers and that is certainly a long way from the wishes of the Government. It will be extremely disruptive to the marketing of fertilisers in Australia. There will be a period of considerable uncertainty. There will be a period of very great difficulty, I suspect, for manufacturers, for distributors and for the farming community generally. In other words, the honourable senators who have produced what I think are marginal arguments about marginal doubts, with their eyes open and anxious as they may be to avoid responsibility for this, are going to produce a series of negative results for sections of the community for which they all profess great concern and interest. I believe that the manufacturers are as unlikely to benefit from this move as any other section of the community, including the farmers. So I say to the Committee with very great earnestness that I think this is a very unfortunate move and one which will produce a whole series of unfortunate results. It is strongly opposed by the Government. It is seen as being against the interests of farmers, against the interests of manufacturers and distributors and against the interests of the community.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Walsh's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Progress reported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In light of the numbers as they fell in that division, and only in that light, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Committee be given leave to sit again on the next day of sitting.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS LICENCE FEES BILL 1982RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS (MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS) BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 18 May, on motion by Senator Peter Baume:
That the Bills be now read a first time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speeches in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS LICENCE FEES BILL 1982

This Bill and the Radio Communications (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 1982 which I will introduce soon, vary the basis on which Radiocommunication Licence Fees are charged. The intent of these Bills is to allow for radiocommunications licence fees to be determined on a basis other than solely the recovery of the costs of administering the radio spectrum. In future regulations made under the Radiocommunications Licence Fees Bill 1982 would set out the fees applicable. A present licence fees are determined by Regulations made under the Wireless Telegraphy Act 1905.

This Bill also includes a provision to ensure that all Commonwealth and Territory authorities are required to pay fees. In addition it further provides for transitional arrangements to exempt licencees who have already paid licence fees under the Wireless Telegraphy Act 1905 from payment of fees under the new Bill, in respect of the grant or renewal of licences during the period 1 July 1981 to the date of commencement of these measures.

Other matters connected with the implementation of these measures are included in a Radiocommunications (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 1982. Honourable Senators will be aware that Section 55 of the Constitution requires no matter other than the imposition of taxation can be validly dealt with in a tax Act.

The costs of providing radio frequency management services relate, among other factors, to the amount of spectrum space needed to accommodate the service, whether the service is in a valuable part of the spectrum, the service's potential to interfere with other services and the power allocated. Each assignment complicates the task succeeding assignments as there is less spectrum available for allocation.

All these factors were taken into account when setting radio-communication licence fees for 1981-82. As this financial year was the first year when full cost recovery was implemented, there was an overall increase in most categories of fees of the order of 12 per cent. However some categories of licences increased by much greater percentages as these categories of licences were previously charged at levels well below the costs associated with them. The licencees, in some cases, faced increases in fees of the order of many thousands of dollars. The television industry was particularly affected due to its extensive use of wide-band fixed links.

These fixed links are essential to the operation of many stations, especially to those stations serving a viewing population spread over a wide area. The links are used to distribute programs to remote transmitters and for studio to transmitter links. These facilities were established at great capital cost at a time when the licence fees for these radiocommunciations links ranged from $40 to around $300. Accordingly, the cost of a radiocommunication licence for these links was very low in comparison to the costs involved in establishing and maintaining them.

In 1981-82, with the implementation of full cost recovery in the radio frequency management area, the cost of licencing these links increased dramatically with the fee liability of two stations now exceeding $30,000. Most other existing licence fee categories were not affected to the same extent as the fees paid by them in previous years were relatively close to the cost recovery related fees introduced in 1981-82.

The Government's attention has been drawn to the problems that these increases have caused some licencees and, following reconsideration of the matter, the Government has decided that some adjustment in fees in necessary.

The Government remains firmly committed to full cost recovery in the area of radio frequency management but acknowledges that a period of phasing in of these fees is appropriate and that the measures should be retrospective to 1 July 1981 .

The Government has been advised that it would be appropriate for its objectives to be achieved by the introduction of legislation providing for the imposition of licence fees as taxes, with the actual levels of fees being established in Regulations made under the new legislation. Accordingly, licence fees would cease to be prescribed in the Wireless Telegraphy Regulations made under the Wireless Telegraphy Act 1905.

In introducing these Bills, I wish to make three things clear. First, the Bills do not indicate an intention on the part of the Government to immediately and substantially increase radiocommunications licence fees. The appropriate levels of these fees will be determined by the Government in the light of all relevant factors. Second, the fees to be imposed by these measures do not apply to normal television and broadcasting receivers. Third, commercial television and radio stations are licensed under separate legislation in respect of their broadcasting activities, i.e., transmissions intended for reception by the general public. Fees imposed under this legislation will not apply to those activities. Radiocommunications licence fees apply to the transmission and reception of private and business radiocommunciations conducted via two way radios and microwave links.
I commend this Bill to the Senate.
RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS (MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS) BILL 1982

As I have mentioned previously, the Radiocommunications (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 1982 implements measures that could not be included in the Radiocommunications Licence Fees Bill 1982 because of Constitutional requirements.

The Bill amends the Wireless Telegraphy Act 1905 by omitting from it the existing provisions relating to the payment of fees for the grant or renewal of licences, as these are now provided for in the Radiocommunications Licence Fees Bill 1982. It also authorises fees to be prescribed for other matters relating to the administration of the Wireless Telegraphy Act 1905.
Provision has also been made for any fees already paid to be refunded or offset against future payments if they are greater than fees payable under the new legislation.

In addition, the Bill repeals that part of the Overseas Telecommunications Act 1946 which exempts the Overseas Telecommunications Commission (Australia) from the payment of licence fees. Consequently the Commission will be required to pay radiocommunications licence fees for its use of the spectrum.
I commend this Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Radiocommunications Licence Fees Bill and the Radiocommunications (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill take the fee charging power out of the Wireless Telegraphy Act 1905 and apply to two-way radio and microwave links. Firstly, the Opposition does not oppose the legislation, but has some qualifications about it. I want to indicate some of those qualifications. The first qualification we had has now been resolved. We wondered why this legislation was necessary. It appears that there has been legal advice to the effect that there has always been some doubt about the power to impose fees under the Wireless Telegraphy Act, although it is interesting that the power to impose those fees has never been challenged. I understand that, for 1981-82, the decision to base fees on the user-pays principle was made for the first time on the basis of full recovery costs-that is, the cost of the Radio Frequency Management Division-and administration was apportioned to licensees. Previously charges had been based on a per link basis without regard to the width or spectrum space taken up by the link. Under the new scale this was taken into account, with the result that the wide links, mainly television stations, incurred a huge increase-for example, a few hundred dollars to many thousands of dollars. The note of the former Minister for Communications, Mr Sinclair, refers to a sum of $30,000 or sums exceeding $30, 000. As a result of this change there was something of an outcry from the industry. I am sure that most honourable senators have received letters from stations, particularly regional stations, relating to this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: As a result, the Government decided to phase in the increases. But there was no legal means under the Wireless Telegraphy Act whereby fees could be remitted. As a result, a new Bill giving these powers, retrospective to July 1981, was brought forward. I make the point that it is something of an inconsistency for this Government to be so willing to apply retrospectivity to give tax back to aggrieved licensees. That contrasts with the Government's unwillingness to collect tax retrospectively. I refer, of course, to action which could have been taken to collect tax retrospectively in relation to tax avoidance schemes. I make no criticism of the reasons which have been advanced by the Government, which are straightforward; but there is that inconsistency, which one is not unused to in observing the Government from this side of the chamber.

The new Bills make provision for a tax for spectrum space. Thus the nexus between fees and costs of administration that previously applied-I am not sure whether legally required or required by policy-is now being broken. The second reading speech of the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) confirms this . The point is that any future government could tax users of the spectrum. The capital value of spectrum space has been the subject of lengthy academic and other arguments over many years. It is very difficult to set the value of the radio spectrum. There is no free market in that spectrum and it is hard to estimate. I remember appearing before the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal not so long ago to give evidence to the cable television inquiry. One member of the Tribunal hazarded what I can only regard as an informed guess about the cost of spectrum space in relation to a metropolitan television station. Some of the figures, which are estimates, are very high in value.

It could be that even if a tax were set at market rates on capital value it could be a very high figure. There would be no necessary reason to set it at such a level. In fact, it could be set at a quite arbitrary level. I think that is something which the industry, particularly the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations, is concerned about. It has made representations to various honourable senators about the matter. I think the point is worth drawing attention to. I do not know whether the presence of television interests here in Canberra yesterday was in any way related to that question. But it is a matter which I am sure will always attract the attention of the heavies in the industry, and the Department of Communications, which is sometimes described in the industry as the Department of FACTS and FARB, may well have had some inquiries about this legislation as recently as yesterday.

A number of comments could be made about the open-ended nature of this issue. But I just flag attention to it as something which is of concern in the industry . I just want to commend from our point of view the idea that in principle there should be a proper return in respect of the use of spectrum space but that the tax imposed should bear a proper relationship to ability to pay and to the incidence of other taxes which bear on companies involved in the television industry and, indeed, companies across the board. I suppose it is fair to say that, while being mildly critical, we commend the phasing-in decision. However, at the same time, we point to the inconsistency in the Government's attitude to retrospectivity which is quite apparent in this legislation. The television industry, of course, with that detachment which comes from having no responsibility other than to itself, is sometimes very critical of the Department of Communications. The industry says that the user-pays principle is not applicable because it should not have to bear the costs of the bureaucracy. I guess all honourable senators would have heard this argument. But that is something which I do not think anybody in government or opposition can seriously accede to because if this activity is to be on a proper business footing with the use paying it is important that the Radio Frequency Management Division, which provides the services, be the appropriate beneficiary.

I would like to raise one general question which relates to the wider aspects of communications policy. Perhaps there should be a general policy on the use of the radio spectrum and perhaps it is time an inquiry was conducted into the economies particularly of the television industry and into the economies of the use in that spectrum. We have had a plethora of inquiries which involve the communications area-the Davidson Committee of Inquiry into Telecommunications Services in Australia, the various inquiries before the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal in respect of which all these matters are relevant and the inquiry in which lead the satellite proceeding under a totally separate authority. I believe this is a further example of ad hockery and inconsistency in Government policy. I make what I hope is the constructive suggestion that the value of the spectrum and the economies of the industry could well be closely examined by government, and perhaps the Department is the appropriate authority to do that.

We began by querying why these Bills were necessary. I think we now understand why the Bills are necessary on legal grounds. But I would also raise a further question as to why they are absolutely necessary at this stage as urgent matters when we are consistently told that a complete revamping of the Wireless Telegraphy Act is under way. I do not know whether that is so. I hope that in any reply that the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) makes he confirms whether that is so or not. I think it is high time that such a revamping took place.

I think there are three major points of objection to the legislation. They do not lead us to opposing the legislation; nonetheless we think they are worth making. They indicate at least a degree of poor consultation on the provisions of this legislation. The real crux of the matter and the matter which hurts the industry most is the scale of the new fees which have been imposed and in respect of which there have been a number of complaints. However, as I understand it under the legislation, there will be no real information about the scale of fees until the regulations are prescribed. In respect of some situations the fees, particularly those for television stations, are to be phased in over three years.

I have made the point that we do not really know on what basis these fees are assessed in relation to the values of the fixed channels or the capacity of the licencees to pay. That is a very important question. I suppose concessions of the type introduced not so long ago for the bigger television stations can be made. Those sorts of matters are in a sense open-ended and make the legislation a bit open-ended. We tried to assess all the criticisms which were made by the industry. We regard them as important. But in our final judgment we do not think they justify us opposing this legislation. In saying that we do not oppose it. We hope that in the future there will be some much clearer understanding and much more specific information available about what is intended in relation to the Wireless Telegraphy Act, what is intended by way of some legislation on fees and what is intended by way of answering the questions of how fees will be assessed in terms of the capacity to pay. I think there is probably plenty of capacity at the moment but that may not always be so. This is something about which the industry might be concerned for the future. With qualifications, we indicate that we do not oppose the legislation. This is a fairly technical and complex matter. I wanted only to put on record my comments, which really amount to qualifications.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Button has quite properly pointed to the reasons for this legislation. I think he referred to the possibility under pre-existing arrangements of High Court challenges being levelled with respect to fees charged for radio communication. I agree with the principle of the Radiocommunications Licence Fees Bill. The Bill did not seem to me to be objectionable when I first looked at it except perhaps to the degree that it is unusual for taxation measures to be dealt with by regulation. That would be one of my concerns.

SPEECH.PARA: After the Bill had passed through the House of Representatives, I was alerted to the concerns of the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations. The Federation is concerned that although there has been general consultation in principle there has been no specific consultation with the industry on the Bill. Its concern focuses on a number of matters-firstly, an apparent lack of consultation between the Department of Communications and FACTS when the Bill was being drafted; secondly, a question about the legalities of altering the way fees are to be collected in the future; and thirdly, a lack of definition and guidelines in the Bill as to how the fees are to be formulated and applied. All honourable senators would have received a telex from FACTS pointing out some of its concerns about this matter. Prior to my receiving this telex I had conversations with Mr Frank Waldron who is the planning engineer of FACTS. I asked him for more specific details than were outlined in the telex that we received. As all honourable senators have received copies of this telex I think it is appropriate that I seek leave to incorporate it in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Senate AA62326
FACTS AA21542
For urgent attention of all Senators
I believe it is important that you be aware that FACTS remains adamantly opposed to the licence fees Bills currently awaiting passage through the Senate.

I refer to the Radiocommunications Licence Fees Bill 1982 and the Radiocommunications (Miscellaneous Provisions) Licence Fees Bill 1982 which were pushed through the lower house at 10.00 p.m. last Thursday.

These Bills were introduced without any prior consultation which we regard as a most serious omission due to the fact that the proposals change a long established licence fee system into a new concept, a form of direct taxation.

Our opposition centres on the lack of positive definition in the Bills, a deficiency that could lead to the most serious consequences for a whole host of radio spectrum users, not only the broadcasters and Telecom, but all the public service organisations, such as mobile rescue groups on sea and land.
It is essential that the Bills contain positive guidelines for the achievement of fair and equitable licence fees-That this must not be left to the process of regulation outside the Parliament.

We urge you to recognise the most serious nature of this proposed legislation in its public affect and that the Bills' passage through the Senate must be delayed to allow for a proper examination of the ramifications of problems to which we have only briefly referred.
Regards
David Morgan
Acting Federal Director
Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations
FACTS AA21542*
Senate AA62326

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Mr Waldron informed me that the major worry of FACTS was about clause 8 of the Bill. In the explanatory memorandum clause 8 is described as providing for fees to be payable as ascertained by regulations. It went on to explain:

SPEECH.PARA: This means that the scale of fees and other associated matters, including concessions, may be set by regulation, allowing for flexible and adaptive fee practices.

FACTS was extremely concerned with the fact that there was no indication in the legislation of the way in which fees were to be ascertained in accordance with regulations referred to in clause 8 of the Bill. It believes that the Bills should have contained positive guidelines for fair and equitable licence fees. I have a letter from FACTS which provides further elaboration on the telex we received, together with a letter that FACTS received from the previous Minister for Communications, Mr Sinclair. I seek leave to incorporate those two documents in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
David Morgan
General Manager &
Deputy Federal Director
Senator D. S. Jessop,
Senator for South Australia,
Parliament House,
Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
Dear Senator,
RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS LICENCE FEESBILLS 1982
Further to our telex to all Senators dated 14th May, 1982 and your discussions with Frank Waldron on 18th May, 1982, I would like to confirm the Federation's position.
FACTS is adamantly opposed to the Licence Fees Bills in the form in which they were introduced into the Senate on 18th May, 1982.

In the Radiocommunications Licence Fees Bill 1982 Clause 4, Interpretation, provides that 'fee' (when used in the Act) means 'a fee that is by way of or in the nature of a tax' and in Section 6 Licence Fees provides, so far as relevant, that where a licence (i.e. a licence referred to in Section 5 of the W & T Act, 1905 [See Clause 4 of the Bill]) is granted or renewed, 'there is payable to the Commonwealth by the person to whom the licence is granted or the person who holds the licence that is renewed, as the case may be, a fee in respect of the licence'. Clause 8 of the Bill provides that the fees payable under Clause 6 are to be ascertained in accordance with the Regulations. The Bill then deals with other matters incidental to the imposition of the licence fee-time for payment, reduced fees and exemptions and the like. The Bill also contains a regulation making power in Clause 13.
FACTS is extremely concerned that there is no indication as to the manner in which the Fees are to be ascertained in accordance with regulations made under Clause 8 of the Bill.

We confirm our view that we regard a Taxing Act which provides for the tax which it imposes to be fixed in accordance with regulations to be an unsatisfactory Act and contrary to the general approach taken by Parliament to Taxing Acts. In support of this we refer to the following passage from judgment of Fullagar J. Re Dymond ([1959] 101 C.L.R. 11 at page 18).

'By reason of the provisions of Section 55 (of the Constitution) it has been the invariable practice since the establishment of the Commonwealth, when parliament has proposed to levy a tax on any subject of taxation, to pursue that object by means of two separate Acts, the one of which actually imposes the tax and fixes the rate of tax, and the other of which provides for the incidence, assessment, and collection, of the tax and for a variety of incidental matters'. (Our interpolation.)

FACTS believes that the bills should contain positive guidelines for fair and equitable licence fees and we urge you to recognise the most serious nature of this proposed legislation in its current form. We believe the Bills passage through the Senate should be delayed to allow for a proper examination of the ramifications of problems to which we have briefly referred.

Once again I must stress that the industry had no consultation concerning this legislation. We were aware that the former Minister for Communications, the Rt Hon. Ian Sinclair, MP, did intend to provide for some concessional Radiocommunications Licence Fees for 1981/1982, but no detail of the legislation was sighted. (Attached is his letter of 14th April, which refers.) We regard this as a serious omission particularly as the proposals changed a long established licence fee system into a form of direct taxation.

Should you or any of your colleagues wish to seek clarification of any of the issues we have raised in this letter or to any other issues which you consider relevant, the Federation would be pleased to provide such information.
Yours faithfully,
DAVID MORGAN Acting Federal Director
Minister FC Deputy Leader of the National Country Party Leader of the House
14 April 1982 Mr J. Malone
Federal Director
Federation of Australian Commercial
Television Stations
13th Floor
447 Kent Street
Sydney, N.S.W. 2000
Dear Mr Malone

You sent me a telex regarding radiocommunications licence fees payable by commercial television stations for broadband links. Several of your member stations also made representations to me on this matter.

As you are aware I have given very careful consideration to the points that have been raised both by FACTS, the individual stations and the Members of Parliament who have also written to me on their behalf. I referred the matter to the Government because of the policy implications for the user-pays principle and I am now able to inform you of the outcome.

It was decided that legislation is to be prepared to provide for a concessional radiocommunication licence fee for certain commercial television stations. If this legislation is passed by Parliament it will be effective from 1 July 1981.
The first proposed concession will apply to:
those commercial television stations whose licence fees payable under the Television Stations Licence Fee (TSLF) Act for the 1981-82 financial year are less than $25,000; and/or
those stations which were licensed to operate more than 12 radio relay links on 1 July 1981.

The concession consists of a phasing in over three years of radiocommunications licence fees in such a way that these stations are required to pay 25 per cent of the scheduled fee in 1981-82, 50 per cent of the scheduled fee in 1982-83 and 75 per cent of the scheduled fee in 1983-84. After that time the concession will cease and the scheduled fee applies.

Secondly, the Government also decided that in those cases where the licence fees payable under the TSLF Act are less than radiocommunications licence fees, the scheduled Wireless Telegraphy Act fee is to be limited to the TSLF Act fee. This further concession is to be on-going, subject to approval by Parliament.

The rise of fees for 1981-82 was, as you are aware, due to application of the user-pays principle to radio frequency management. Full costs are being recovered for the first time in this activity in 1981-82. The Government is committed to this principle but, in the cases where the proposed concessions are applicable, is recognising that there is merit in phasing in fees where the rise in a single year might adversely affect the stations concerned.

Unfortunately, the necessity to raise fees for outdoor broadcast units was overlooked in assessment of fees for this year. To implement the user-pays principle, these fees should be substantially more than they are now. Perhaps you would discuss reasonable phasing in arrangements with my Department in order to begin this process in the 1982-83 year.

In my reply to representations from your member stations I have advised them that I would inform you as soon as the Government's decision on this matter became available and I would therefore appreciate it if you would inform your members accordingly.
Yours sincerely Ian Sinclair

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. It is interesting that, at the same time as FACTS expressed concern about the operation of clause 8 of the Bill, the seventh report of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills drew attention to the same clause. I should like to quote from the seventh report of that Committee which Senator Missen chairs. When referring to clause 8, it stated:

SPEECH.PARA: These clauses enable the fees that are to be imposed by the Bill to be fixed by regulation. No indications are included relating to the amount of fees that may be imposed. While the Wireless Telegraphy Act 1905, under which radiocommunications licence fees were previously imposed, made like provision, the Committee draws the clauses to the attention of the Senate under principle 1 (a) (iii), in that they might be regarded as inappropriately delegating legislative power.

As a result of my discussions with FACTS, I believed that these matters should have been cleared up before the legislation was debated in this chamber. Therefore, I had discussions with the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) and officers of the Department of Communications and I put that view to them. I must say how much I appreciate the co-operation of Senator Peter Baume who represents the Minister for Communications in this place and the officers who attended that original consultation in Senator Baume's office. Subsequently, Mr Lansdown, the head of the Department of Communications and his deputy, Mr Payne also talked to me about the problem. I was able to arrange for them to have discussions with Mr David Morgan and Mr Waldron of FACTS. I am pleased to say that on Tuesday of this week when Mr Neil Brown, the new Minister for Communications, was in Canberra I was able to talk to him and arrange for these gentlemen to have further discussions with him.

As a result of these discussions I believe that the matter has now been resolved as much as possible as far as FACTS is concerned. I believe I am correct in saying that whilst FACTS has a general knowledge of what the Department is doing in this area the industry recognises that as this is a taxation measure it was not appropriate that it should have a detailed knowledge of what was included in the legislation. I further understand that as a result of these discussions with the Minister FACTS is confident that an undertaking has been given by the Minister who also recognises the concern of the industry. He has undertaken that in future full consultation will be carried out with respect to future fee structures. No doubt Senator Peter Baume will elaborate on this in his reply. I agree with Senator Button that this matter deserves far more intensive examination. I suggest that some sort of inquiry ought to be made as to the way in which the Government should go in future to ensure that this particular matter is dealt with more specifically. In my view it is preferable that it should be dealt with under an Act that ought to be far more extensive than the Bill before the Senate at the present time. I support the principle of the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will support the Radiocommunication Licence Fees Bill. We have arrived at that position only quite recently. When we first saw the proposed legislation we were very concerned about it. We believe it carries far reaching consequences and breaks new ground which this Senate should be very concerned about. As Senator Jessop has pointed out, the Bill effectively changes the radiocommunications licence fee from a simple charging of a fee to the charging of a tax. What is more, as Senator Jessop pointed out, there is no indication in the Bill of the level of taxation to be charged. Therefore, we have a Bill before us which is allowing taxation by regulation. Our initial suspicion, I believe, can readily be seen to be justifiable. The Australian Democrats were wondering whether in fact the Government was trying to get at the Democrats and at this Senate because as we all know a taxation Bill cannot be amended in this place. It can be accepted or rejected but it cannot be amended.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill gives the Government an open cheque to charge taxation at a level it sees fit and by regulation. We conducted considerable investigation into this matter. We discovered that in a High Court case recently a group of pathologists challenged the validity of a fee on the basis that it was in fact a tax. Although that fee at that time was only $10 the High Court agreed in that particular case that the charge was not a fee but a tax. For that reason there has always been, I think, on the Government's part a sneaking suspicion that the Wireless Telegraphy Act of 1905 could be unconstitutional. We go along with that view.

TALK.START.PARA: —It certainly heightened our concentration, didn't it, Senator?

—Yes. The consequences, nevertheless, are these: A whole variety of fees currently is charged by regulation. Presumably, the Government eventually will address itself to all these various fees that have been charged by regulation and we can expect the introduction of a whole series of Bills in the Senate which will do what this Bill does, that is, to change the charging of fees to a tax. We were also concerned-previous speakers alluded to this point- that there had not been any consultation with the industry. I believe this is a very serious matter. We would have opposed the Bill or delayed it on that basis alone if it were not for the information we have received that consultations have been held now between the industry and the Government. The industry is satisfied that it has come to an understanding with the Government about the basis on which these fees or taxes-one can call them what one likes-will be charged to the industry. On the assurance from the industry that a problem no longer exists and that there is accord between the Government and the industry the Australian Democrats are prepared to support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank honourable senators for the support they have given to this package of legislation, the Radiocommunications Licence Fees Bill and the Radiocommunications (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill which apply to radiocommunications licences. The legislation, as honourable senators indicated, establishes the fees as taxes to put them beyond any question of legal challenge . It will provide for them to be phased in and, as honourable senators said with some critical comment, for this to be done by regulation. The Bills remove the legal nexus between fees and costs and therefore remove another likelihood of legal challenge.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall refer briefly to the question of the charges being made by regulation. I remind honourable senators, as they would know, that regulations would be required to be tabled in the Parliament and would be disallowable in the usual way. In fact it would be wrong to imagine that the oversight or control by the Parliament of the level of fees would not be present. It would, of course, require a majority of honourable senators or honourable members in another place for that to happen, but there has been no intention that this should pass from parliamentary oversight.

The regulations to be implemented under the Radiocommunications Licence Fees Bill will confer benefits; they will assist smaller television stations which have been severely affected by the large rises in radiocommunications licence fees because of their program distribution links. It will enable these stations to adjust to the new fee levels without any impact on the level of services delivered to their viewers. The likely effect on viewers concerned the Government. The majority of these stations, as honourable senators will realise, are located in areas of limited television coverage, and the Government has considered the maintenance of these amenities to be of vital importance. We also believe that the measures also give further effect to the Government's principle of making public authorities accountable for their use of what are scarce public resources. These authorities will bear their full share of the burden of the administration of the radio frequency spectrum.

Senator Button asked a question relating to a matter to which I think Senator Siddons alluded. I can advise honourable senators that a complete review of the Wireless Telegraphy Act is approaching completion. It has been under way for some time. However, it will not deal with fees. The current Bills may need to be modified later in order to apply to the new Bill should the Wireless Telegraphy Act need some kind of review. This brings me to the question raised by Senator Jessop and mentioned by Senator Siddons; that is the concerns of industry. It is true that once these concerns were made known we sought to establish a series of consultations to see whether there was a chance of understanding and accommodating them. The method of determining radiocommunications licence fees was raised, and the principal factors which are taken into account in this matter are: Firstly, the effective power radiating into the spectrum; secondly, the band width actually occupied by the signal or reserved for the signal if it is not used continuously; thirdly, the space over which the signal is effectively radiated and detectable; fourthly, the time the spectrum is occupied by the signal, and that may be continuous; fifthly, the potential for interference to other users; and, finally, the sensitivity to interference from other users.

It is necessary to divide spectrum users into a number of classes to minimise administrative costs and to facilitate the prescription of licence fees. This involves grouping together a large number of users with basically similar, but maybe not identical, characteristics. It is not feasible to prescribe a fee for individual cases. In the Government's opinion, it is not practicable to relate the payment of fees to a precise formula which can be reflected in legislation. That is one of the difficulties which the Government faced when preparing this legislation. To attempt to do so would involve administrative procedures and costs out of all proportion to the revenue collected or the benefits to be gained. The net effect might therefore be an overall further increase in fees. The various categories of major users will be consulted with respect to these matters before the final form of the regulations is reached and before any changes to the form of those regulations are made in future. I think that goes a long way to meeting some of the concerns expressed by the industry and the question of consultation raised by several senators.

The proportion of radiocommunications licence fees attributed to each class therefore represents the Government's best estimate of the fees appropriate to each class. It is a generally accepted principle that the burden of taxation should fall as equally as practicable on the community. It would be inconsistent with that principle for a government to seek to disadvantage a certain group by imposing a higher rate of tax on that group. Exemptions and concessions are granted to very limited categories of users when those exemptions and concessions are considered to be in the public interest for the purpose of supporting a desirable public service. I set out some examples earlier. I remind honourable senators that regulations imposing radiocommunications licence fees will be subject to parliamentary scrutiny and disallowance by either House. Furthermore, public scrutiny of taxing measures is of such importance that the Government will examine the feasibility of having fee scales set out in Acts of Parliament rather than in regulations. Although I have identified the difficulties in doing that by legislative means, the Government has undertaken to give futher consideration to that matter in view of the concerns that have been expressed.

The licence fees are reviewed on an annual basis, usually taking effect at the beginning of the financial year. The present fees are currently under review. However, I refer honourable senators to my second reading speech in which I said that these Bills do not indicate an intention on the part of the Government to increase immediately and substantially radiocommunications licence fees. Having given those assurances in relation to the matters which have been raised, I commend the Bills to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without amendment, requests or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: HOME DEPOSIT ASSISTANCE BILL 1982HOMES SAVINGS GRANT ACTS AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 6 May, on motion by Senator Durack:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Home Deposit Assistance Bill and the Homes Savings Grant Acts Amendment Bill relate to the housing package which arose out of a statement made by the Treasurer, Mr Howard, on 18 March this year . I remind the Senate that both Mr Howard and the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) are on the public record as saying that they would not take any steps which would change the Homes Savings Grant Scheme throughout the life of this Budget year, 1981-82. The Home Deposit Assistance Bill replaces the existing Homes Savings Grant Scheme with the Home Deposit Assistance Scheme. The Opposition has consistently criticised the Government for the way in which the Homes Savings Grant Scheme operated. Whilst we concede that a great number of people did benefit as a result of that Scheme, it did not help housing in the area in which help was needed most.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation is one of a number of potentially expedient and ad hoc gimmicks announced by the Treasurer on the eve of the Victorian State election to address the housing crisis as it affected the Victorian Government. Of course the question affected not only the Victorian Government. It was an issue about which there was considerable concern in all States. It might be well to recall the flurry of announcements and activity from the former Victorian Minister of Housing, Mr Kennett, who placed large advertisements in newspapers and who made a number of criticisms of the Government's failure to recognise the housing crisis in this country. One should also recall the Federal Government's spokesman on housing at the time, who did not respond to such advertisements until such time as the then Premier of Victoria, Mr Thompson, made a public statement criticising the Fraser Government for its lack of concern about the problems of housing in Victoria. Of course the Government then came forth with this legislation which, on the last day of this session, we are dealing with. Honourable senators will be well aware that the electors saw through the duplicity, the gimmickry and the propaganda of those proposals as they related to the political situation in Victoria at that time. We well recall that the Victorian electors gave the Thompson administration and Mr Kennett the biggest kick in the pants that the Victorian Liberals have ever had and gave the Australian Labor Party in Victoria the greatest majority it has ever been able to win from the electors in that State.

Of course the result showed that the Victorian electors were not fooled in any sense by the approach of the Liberal-National Country Party Government. They responded favourably to the Labor Party's approach which is philosophically different from that of this Government. That difference is based on an attitude that we have of stimulating the building sector, of dampening down interest rates and providing greater support for public housing. That, of course, is the linchpin of the Labor Party's approach to the housing crisis in our country.

Labor's policies contrast very clearly with those of the Liberal Party. Since 1975-since the Fraser Government came to power-one sector of the community that can clearly be shown to be in a state of continual decline is the housing sector . There has been a great decline in the number of houses built and a decline in confidence in the industry. The housing sector has suffered greatly as a result of the economic policies pursued by the Fraser Government. Rising interest rates , the low availability of the rental housing market, greatly reduced building activity and the dropping levels of home ownership all show, very clearly, that the consistent policy followed by the Labor Party, by its spokesman on housing in the other place, Mr Uren, and by me here is borne out in statistics which show that housing has moved into an area similar to that of unemployment and is a major social problem.

The Government's housing problems have been dominated only by expediency. If the pressure mounts up an ad hoc decision is made and the Government must respond as it did in respect to Mr Thompson's plea. The measures which were brought forward by the Treasurer on 18 March have we believe failed to relieve the problem facing existing and intending home buyers. They barely address the serious problems faced by tenants in the private rental market. One does not have to do more than state that that it is a fact of life to indicate the tremendous problem that faces people who are forced into the rental market in this country.

This legislation will do nothing to reduce the growing problem of homelessness which is at an all time high. It is almost as high as it was in the immediate post-war years. It will do nothing to reduce the number of families-now 99,000 people-who are on the lists of State housing commissions or housing authorities lists as requiring public housing assistance. The measures include a further one per cent rise in the housing loan interest rates charged by savings banks. That should be added to the record of this Government, which has presided over the banks and provided them with the need to make loans, and presided over the highest interest rate hikes in Australia's history. That is not something of which any government ought to be proud. We cannot derive any pleasure from that. To some extent it is brought about by the economic policies followed by the Fraser Administration and by the direct budgetary attitudes towards the States responsibility for public housing. If honourable senators look at interest rates they will see that we are not gilding the lily. We are referring precisely to this major problem of interest rates. In March 1980-just a few weeks over two years ago-the interest rate charged by savings banks on housing loans was only 9 .5 per cent. It is now 13.5 per cent, an increase in real terms of 4 per cent but in actual terms it represents a 42 per cent increase in interest rates over those two years. The effect of the interest rate rise is to exclude-this demonstrates the serious effect of the Government's economic policies-a growing number of people from access to home ownership. In 1980, we said that there were signs that the level of home ownership in Australia was declining.

In 1978, the Australian Bureau of Statistics provided us with figures. It estimated that the level of home ownership in Australia was 73.8 per cent of the population. In 1980-two years later-the Bureau revealed that this estimate was down to 71.9 per cent. Therefore over two years there has been a drop of almost 2 per cent in home ownership in this country. As a result, pressures on State housing authorities and the rental market have increased. Each time interest rates rise intending home buyers have to find a larger deposit in order to gain access to home ownership. Or, as happens in so many cases, people have to resort to the burden of a large second mortgage. Everybody in this country knows what that means. People who have a second mortgage today are paying an interest rate of anything between 20 per cent and 24 per cent. That represents an unbelievable increase in the commitment carried by people who are attempting to buy their accommodation. The overtight monetary policy, which has been pursued by the Fraser Government, has led to rising interest rates.

This Government has widened the deposit gap required to be met by first home buyers. For example, on 18 March this year the Treasurer announced a rise in savings bank interest rates from 12.5 per cent to 13.5 per cent. I remind the Senate that the Government has not yet indicated that that will be the peak. It has suggested that another one per cent increase is in the pipeline. The maximum permissible borrowings from a savings bank for a person on average weekly earnings fell by $2,341, from $36,249 at 12.5 per cent interest rate to $33,908 at a 13.5 per cent interest rate. Therefore on the one hand this new proposal increases the maximum basic benefit-arising from the legislation that the Senate is asked to approve-by some $500, that is, from $2,000 to $2,500. However it reduces by $2,341 the amount that a person on average weekly earnings gets as a loan from a bank. As we know there is not a great number of people in our country who are on average weekly earnings. In fact in excess of 66 per cent of Australian people earn less than average weekly earnings.

The 42 per cent rise in interest rates under this Government means that the maximum first mortgage loan able to be borrowed by an intending home owner, who receives average weekly earnings, has been reduced by $11,330 for those who borrow from savings banks and $7,896 for those who borrow from building societies. In the same period the Government has raised the maximum amount of a homes savings grant, which is now described as an assistance grant, by $500-that is, from $2,000 to $2,500. That is the record of this Government in recent years . In fact, in the last two years the Government has effectively reduced the borrowing right from a savings bank of a person on average weekly earnings by $ 11,330. All it has given that person in return is $500. That is hardly adequate compensation for the policies that have been followed glibly, quietly and often vocally by the Commonwealth Government in opposition to its counterparts in the State area. The new Home Deposit Assistance Scheme will be, we recognise, of some use to a few people. The Opposition does not quibble with that conclusion. However, we believe that it is inadequate and does not address the major home finance problems that I have stressed today. Therefore, it is the Opposition's intention to seek support for the following amendment. I move:

At end of motion, add: ', but the Senate is of the opinion that the Bill should provide a more effective form of assistance which will reduce the deposit requirement of first home buyers by permitting larger first mortgage borrowings from savings banks and building societies'.

We say that the overriding problem with the scheme is its isolation from an integrated set of measures, which any government worth its salt should take, giving stability to the availability and price of housing finance and to housing industry activity generally. The scheme was announced in the context of a further rise in interest rates. Of course, that must be seen as a panic measure designed to assist a political problem in Victoria. The Government persists in suggesting that this legislation will somehow redress that problem. Of course, we know that interest rates will be driven up still further. We can expect any time after Parliament rises that interest rates will be officially allowed to rise. With further interest rate hikes the scheme projected on 18 March will become even less effective. In fact, as has been said by the Labor Party's spokesman on housing, Mr Uren, it will be shown to be quite meaningless in solving the housing problems in our country.

We need a scheme to assist first home buyers. We are pledged to that; it is our policy. It must fit into a set of policies to stabilise the flow of funds for housing at an affordable level to those who are in a position to provide their own accommodation. We need a commitment by a Federal Government to no further rises in housing interest rates. Surely that is not beyond the ability of any government that claims to represent the Australian people. But this Government is not prepared to make housing the social priority it deserves to be and which the Australian people demand it to be so that more and more of them will have an opportunity to solve their accommodation problems personally. This Government is not prepared to use its powers to control the assets of financial institutions to a sufficient extent to gain a stable flow of funds into the housing sector which would obviate the need for further interest rate rises to attract deposits .

It is rather strange that the Government should take the view that the housing industry is not an important sector for the generation of economic activity. It is a sector which takes up the slack in employment and which plays a part in alleviating the social problem of housing. It ought to be the cornerstone of any meaningful economic program. If this happened, it would obviate the need for further interest rate rises in order to attract deposits. From that perspective the Labor Party seeks to amend the Bill in the form I have moved. We see the need for a more effective home ownership scheme to be provided as an option to the Home Deposit Assistance Scheme so that those who are not helped by this scheme will not be left unaided. The Labor Party's proposal in this regard cannot be put forward in an ad hoc or piecemeal fashion. We are not in the game of gimmicks in the area of housing because we recognise that accommodation or shelter is one of the early requirements of any family situation. The problem is too serious and far-reaching for gimmickry or ad hoc decisions. Any decisions should be part of an overall planned approach to solving the housing problems in our country.

We need to upgrade and expand public sector housing because of the changes in our economic activities and in their geographical location as a result of more emphasis being placed on resource development and perhaps less on manufacturing. Therefore, we require a very strong public housing sector to meet the needs of people who move from one location to another, to provide homes at a reasonable rental. We make no apology for saying that we need a scheme to assist people who have to be mobile in order to take up employment opportunities. We need a scheme which will assist intending first home buyers to become home owners. We need a scheme which protects existing home purchasers from the growing mortgage burden. It has to be acknowledged that a great number of people are suffering grave hardships today as a result of the increase in interest rates. Their disposable income is being reduced to an alarming degree, forcing them into a new era of poverty and distress and affecting the whole level of economic activity in which they would otherwise be involved, and by that I mean consumer demand.

We need to stabilise the availability and price of housing finance. That is where this Government has failed dismally. Certainly, we need to stabilise the housing industry's capacity and activity. That is the view of the housing industry itself, including the Housing Industry Association and those people involved in the building societies. This is the Labor Party's approach to the housing crisis. It is the sort of approach that we believe gained acceptance in the Victorian elections recently. The Bill before us, therefore, does not come anywhere near these goals. It is inadequate, piecemeal and ad hoc. It is not the way to approach one of the most pressing problems before us today. That is why we have moved our amendment.

I have subsequently been advised that Senator Harradine proposes to move an amendment to our proposition, which seeks, as I understand it, to provide an overhang position between the old, phased out Homes Savings Grant Scheme and the Home Deposit Assistance Scheme. I have sought some advice on this proposed amendment from the appropriate people in my party. We do not necessarily agree with all that Senator Harradine has said about this problem, but there seems to be a grey area where those who have been saving under the old scheme may be placed at a disadvantage with respect to the new scheme. Therefore, Senator Harradine's proposal is acceptable to the Labor Party insofar as it would at least give an option to those who have been attracted previously to the Homes Savings Grant Scheme. The option would be to decide whether to remain with that scheme during the interim period or to go to the new scheme. We believe, and accept, that the new scheme has some advantages over the old Homes Savings Grant Scheme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The two Bills that we are debating today, the Home Deposit Assistance Bill and the Homes Savings Grant Acts Amendment Bill , form the rest of the Government's new housing package which was announced in March of this year. I recall saying at the time that I thought that the package was a sort of curate's egg package in that it was good in parts and woefully lacking in others. I also said at the time, and repeat, that I believe the Government should be given the benefit of the doubt as far as intentions are concerned. I believe that it recognised the anomalies and inequities operating under the existing system and set out to help the many thousands of families in the community-the sorts of families mentioned already by Senator Gietzelt-who find it increasingly difficult to buy or build a home in Australia, whether for the first time or not. Unfortunately, the end result of the housing package, taken as a whole, does not achieve the laudable objectives that I believe the Government had in mind in instigating it.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bills set out to do a number of things: Firstly, to revamp the old Homes Savings Grant Scheme which, as I have said, was clearly inadequate; secondly, to eliminate the nine-month waiting period and abolish the value limit of the home to be purchased; thirdly, to place a means test on eligibility for the grant so that the maximum grant would go to families whose income in the previous 12 months had been less than 130 per cent of average weekly earnings. A sliding scale was there to apply so that the grant cut out when earnings reached 150 per cent of average weekly earnings. Fourthly, it increased the basic value of the grant from $2,000 to $2,500 and added a further child bonus of $500 for a family with one child and $1,000 for a family with two or more children. I point out that this bonus is available to any family which qualifies for the basic homes savings grant to a level of at least $10, so in many ways, for families which qualify for even the smallest part of the basic grant, this child bonus is the most valuable part of the scheme. Fifthly, it sets out to reduce the savings requirement for a maximum grant to a dollar for dollar basis over a two-year period instead of the previous basis of $1 to $3 savings over a three-year period.

As I indicated when the package was first brought forward, and as I said again at the beginning of my remarks today, the Australian Democrats support the principle behind the Bills. We are pleased that the Government recognises that so many couples are finding great difficulty in bridging the deposit gap and is also prepared to recognise that the old scheme, despite its being the subject of a number of amendments which increased the value limit on the particular house and so on, failed in effect to solve the problem.

We are also happy to accept the need for a means test in order that the money available for the scheme-some $88m in 1982-will be directed to those who need it most. Finally, we are pleased to see that the Government has extended the amount available to families which can qualify for the grant. Nevertheless, I must repeat that we have distinct reservations about the real value of the new package and some specific criticisms, almost all of which arise out of not the contents of these Bills, or even what is left out of them, but the sweetheart agreement between the Government and the banks as an inducement to the banks to face what I believe is their moral responsibility to Australians who are not members of the wealthy investor class-a class which seems in the last few years to have taken over as far as the banks' interest is concerned, if the Senate will pardon the pun. Our specific criticisms are these--

TALK.START.PARA: —If the Senate notices the pun.
—I am sorry if it is a little over your head, Senator; go back to sleep.
—I am working on it; you are helping.

—That is something for which you are getting a good return. By simultaneously allowing the banks to lift interest rates on home loans by one percentage point, the Government has ensured that the Bills are aimed at, and will benefit most, the very limited group of people who are relatively affluent. In these straitened times of rising prices, tight money and high interest rates, only the relatively affluent-the middle class in regular employment-can afford even to think about buying a house. Whatever the intention of these Bills, the increase of one percentage point in home loan interest rates means effectively that the Bills will not assist those who need to be helped most.

SPEECH.PARA: Rises in interest rates effectively reduce the maximum amounts that banks and lending institutions will lend. Banks and other financial institutions that lend money for housing calculate lending ceilings by referring to the applicant's gross wage. The amount that they lend varies according to the institution. It usually involves repayments of from 25 per cent to 30 per cent of the gross wage or salary. With a hike in interest rates of the order of one percentage point, or any increase for that matter, repayments increase. In fact, a fairly good rule of thumb these days is that for every one percentage point increase in interest rates on an average home loan requirement, monthly repayments rise by 8 per cent. Effectively, the interest rate increase is likely to reduce the amount that the bank will lend in the first place.

According to my calculations-I am open to correction as always, being a fair and reasonable sort of person-a one percentage point increase in interest rates on an average home loan effectively reduces by some $2,000 the amount available for lending. Therefore, those home buyers who are lucky enough to qualify for the grant in the first place will see the effective sum that they need for their home eaten up by increased interest rates. Effectively, they are chasing their tails. Thus the Bills, because of the sweetheart arrangement arrived at between the Government and the banks, give on the one hand but, on the other, take away more or less the same amount of money.

The family bonus looks good enough on paper-$500 for one dependent child and $1 ,000 for two or more children. However, as anybody who knows young couples trying to buy a home will confirm, very few couples with children-in particular young children-can afford to bridge the deposit gap. We have reached in Australia a situation in which a couple who wish to buy or build a home must do so before they begin their family. It takes two incomes, over at least a two or three year period, to enable a couple to acquire the cash that they need. Therefore, those who are looking for this kind of assistance are not families with children; they are those with no children, so the benefit is largely illusory.

The package serves predominantly to accentuate existing divisions and inequities in the housing sector. One could say that the rich get richer and the poor get to live in tents. Furthermore, as Senator Gietzelt pointed out, it scoots over the whole question of welfare housing. In the interests of getting through the business of the Senate as quickly as possible I do not intend to canvass the issue again. Also, the package provides limited, if any, assistance to the low income earner. It does nothing to help the predicament of people in the rental market. The one percentage point interest rate rise is certain to flow through to that market and people in that area stand to lose most from the Government's package. As property investors find it increasingly difficult to make a reasonable living from rental housing, vis-a-vis other forms of investment, they are forced to increase rents. Since there are no tax rebates or grants to aid struggling tenants, the problem is compounded. Low vacancy rates reflect the problem of the housing market.
