The figures of the Real Estate Institute of Australia for March 1981 and March 1982 show that in Adelaide, for instance, the availability level of rental housing fell from 1.3 per cent to 0.6 per cent. That halving is similarly reflected in most other States and Territories, although Perth and Canberra seem to be a little better off than the other capital cities. The Adelaide figures are particularly poor. They are the lowest ever recorded in Adelaide, where a 3 per cent rate is generally considered to indicate a reasonable balance between supply and demand. Inevitably, pressure on the rental accommodation forces up rents. Hence, those trying to save for a house deposit suffer yet again.

I repeat that the package is aimed at the wrong area, taking into account the one per cent interest rise that was allowed to banks. I believe that it is treating the symptoms of the problem rather than the basic cause. I venture to say that this is becoming something of a habit of the present Government which appears to be rather addicted to ad hockery and status quo conservatism. I suspect that if it continues meekly to patch up the cracks as they appear in the legislation and in the system it will find the whole edifice will come tumbling down around its ears. The whole thing boils down to the fact that there is really only one section of the Australian community which stands to gain from the Treasurer's package and the one per cent interest rate rise; that is, the banking community.

It is interesting to compare figures relating to rises in average weekly earnings, interest rate movements and banking profits for the decade 1971-80. Average weekly earnings in the period jumped by 187 per cent-from $89.80 in June 1971 to $257.90 in June 1980. Home interest rates rose from approximately 6 1/4 per cent-that figure can be only an approximation since different lending organisations lent at marginally different amounts-in June 1971 to approximately 12 1/2 per cent in December 1981. That represented a jump of 100 per cent. As far as banking profits are concerned, the combined net profits of savings and trading banks rose from $64.5m in 1971 to $465.3m in 1980-a staggering 621 per cent increase. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table of banking profit increases. I indicated to the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) that I intended to do so and showed him the table.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. On the other hand, because of the rises in interest rates, repayment rates increased by an equally interesting figure. Monthly repayment rates on an average loan in 1971 were approximately $44. By 1980 repayment rates per month on an average loan in that year had risen to $322 -an increase of 632 per cent and a figure which I point out is remarkably close to the percentage rise in bank profits over the same period. As I have said, the Australian Democrats support the intention of the Bills. It is unfortunate that the trade-off to the banks will negate most of the potential good inherent in the legislation. I wish to take a few moments to discuss the amendment which the Australian Labor Party has moved and the amendment which I understand Senator Harradine will move in the Committee stage. The Australian Labor Party has moved to the motion for the second reading the following amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of motion, add: 'but the Senate is of the opinion that the Bill should provide a more effective form of assistance which will reduce the deposit requirement of first home buyers by permitting larger first mortgate borrowings from savings banks and building societies.'

The Australian Democrats have no quarrel with that. It is again a motherhood statement, although I believe that a large number of the problems would be solved if we returned to the days when banks were expected to lend a certain percentage to home loan borrowers and the interest rates on those home loans were kept low. The banks keep bleating that they were artificially low but the system seemed to work for 81 years and I cannot understand why all of a sudden it has ceased to be a workable proposition. I have a funny feeling that it coincides with the incursion of foreign banking interests into this country.

I do not propose to discuss Senator Harradine's amendment at the moment. I will consider it during the Committee stage when I have seen in more detail what Senator Harradine intends to move. I understand that he is concerned that some people will be disadvantaged by the change in legislation proposed by the Government and that the inclusion of the average weekly earnings provision in the new legislation may deprive some people of a grant that they would otherwise have got. I for one do not necessarily share that view, but I will not take up any more of the Senate's time at this stage. I will turn my attention to the matter during the Committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the amendment moved by Senator Gietzelt. I am also concerned that this legislation does not do enough to help lessen the burden on Australian householders. Over the last two years we have witnessed an explosion in interest rates, with the interest rate charged by savings banks on housing loans increasing from 9.5 per cent in March 1980 to 13.5 per cent. This represents a 4 per cent increase in interest rates in just two years. To an average family with a first mortgage of around $30,000, this has meant an increase in repayments of something like 28 per cent. To people who have borrowed this amount from a building society, it has meant an increase in monthly repayments from around $290 a month to nearly $370 a month, depending upon the State in which they live. All of this has come about at a time when this Government's economic policies have caused massive increases in indirect taxes, health insurance costs and State and local government charges. There is not a single household in this country that has not been hit recently by rising food bills, hospital charges, electricity and gas bills, water rates and council rates.

SPEECH.PARA: In view of these problems, we on this side of the chamber eagerly awaited the statement by the Treasurer, Mr Howard, on 18 March in the hope that it would provide significant and lasting relief for existing home buyers. Unfortunately, we were disappointed. The Home Deposit Assistance Bill, which arose out of that statement, does not go anywhere near far enough towards easing the tremendous burden which is falling on most working and middle class families in Australia. Although we concede that it contains some good proposals, there are still many people who will not benefit from the new scheme and many others who will be worse off.

For a start, an integral part of the Treasurer's statement on 18 March was the reference to an immediate increase of one per cent in interest rates for savings bank home loans. This has already flowed through to building societies and inflicted even more financial hardship on existing home buyers. Therefore, it is quite obvious that this legislation will only add fuel to the interest rate explosion in this country. Every time interest rates rise by one percentage point 9,000 families are denied access to home ownership because of the widening of the deposit gap.

As Senator Gietzelt pointed out, the increase of one percentage point in interest rates on savings bank home loans meant in effect that the maximum amount that could be borrowed by a person on average weekly earnings fell by $2, 300. From this it is easy to see that the $500 increase in the maximum grant is totally ineffective. In effect it means that, as a direct result of these measures, the deposit gap has been widened by something like $1,800, making it even more difficult for young couples to purchase their own home. As a result many of these people will be forced to resort to second mortgages and to pay interest rates in the vicinity of 20 per cent. Quite clearly, the measures contained in these Bills will not relieve the burden for either existing or potential home buyers and they will certainly not relieve the problems being faced by tenants, especially those in the private rental sector. The measures will not help many thousands of families now waiting on public housing commission lists throughout Australia.

However, as I said before, there are some positive aspects of the new scheme. One of these is that the nine-month waiting period for assistance which applied under the old scheme has been reduced. This means there will be more instant relief for home buyers at a time when they need it most. Another aspect relates to the eligibility criteria, which have been relaxed for de facto married couples and other couples who have jointly purchased a house. However, overall these measures do not go far enough. They were conceived very hastily during the run-up to the Victorian election for cheap political purposes which, as it turned out, did not pay off anyway. They will provide no real lasting relief for most of Australia's home buyers.

The fact of the matter is that this Government has no real concern for home buyers. This can be seen by the way in which it has directed funds away from the housing sector since it came to power. For instance, the proportion of total Budget outlays on housing has fallen from 2.6 per cent in 1975-76 to as low as 0 .9 per cent in 1980-81. In real terms there has been a 59 per cent cut in Budget outlays on housing between 1975-76 and 1981-82. During the same period real expenditure on defence has increased by 28 per cent and expenditure on industry assistance has increased by 58 per cent. All this is happening when queues for public housing in this country are increasing at an unprecedented rate. We regularly hear Ministers of the Government in this chamber boasting about the level of home ownership in Australia. Only last week, during the debate on the Supply Bills, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) claimed very proudly that 72 per cent of home ownership in Australia is in private hands. What he omitted to say was that in the last three years home ownership in Australia has actually fallen from 73 per cent to 71.9 per cent. That is a quite significant reduction and is a direct result of this Government's economic policies, which are preventing many thousands of Australians from owning their own home.

Every time interest rates rise more and more Australian home buyers are pushed closer to the edge. In fact, many have already been forced to sell their homes and move to rental accommodation. This has happened simply because of the Treasurer's determination to slow down the growth in the money supply. His manic desire to bring down the rate of inflation through tight monetary policies has inflicted a lot of unnecessary hardship upon Australian families. I believe that the Australian people deserve more than just some hastily conceived scheme designed purely to win votes at elections. I believe the Australian people are sick and tired of having the wool pulled over their eyes by this tired old conservative Government. The only way of providing any lasting relief for Australian home buyers is for this Government to change its economic policies. There is no point in this Government providing these sorts of schemes if it does not intend to stop pursuing tight monetary policies. The longer the Government keeps restricting the growth in the money supply the longer the Australian people will have to endure high interest rates.

The fact that this new scheme was accompanied by an increase of one percentage point in interest rates has made it almost totally ineffective. The only way to relieve the burden on Australian home buyers is to attack the problem on a much broader scale. The pressure on interest rates will be relieved only through a gradual easing of the money supply. Until the Government realises this there certainly will not be any significant and lasting relief for any home buyers. Instead we will see even more home buyers forced into selling their properties and even more potential home buyers unable to raise the money they need because of the widening deposit gap. What we need right now is some positive intervention by this Government to stop interest rate rises. We need some genuine concern by the Ministers of this Government for the needs of home buyers in Australia. I support the amendment moved by Senator Gietzelt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Home Deposit Assistance Bill 1982 and the Homes Savings Grant Acts Amendment Bill 1982. The Homes Savings Grant Acts Amendment Bill brings to an end the Homes Savings Grant Scheme which has been in operation in various forms since the early 1970s. The object is to replace that scheme with a new Home Deposit Assistance Scheme which is a refinement and an improvement upon the scheme which applied previously. I think there is general agreement on that. There seems to be agreement from the Opposition-both from Mr Uren, the Opposition spokesman on these matters, and from Senator Gietzelt, who represents him in this place-and from the Australian Democrats that a number of features of the new system are advantageous.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this Home Deposit Assistance Bill is, of course, to encourage people to save towards home ownership, to supplement their savings by a grant at the time of home purchase and to provide maximum help to single income and low income families. Whilst there does not seem to be any disagreement with those principles in the Bill, the debate has really centred on related matters in the housing field about which honourable senators have concerns. In that context, I simply stress that this Bill is but one part of the Government's approach to housing. It does not encompass the Government's approach to welfare housing and to the very real challenges in that area. Indeed, it does not encompass the totality of our assistance in the promotion of home ownership; it is but one brick in the wall.

The new housing package which was announced earlier this year on 18 March by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) contained a number of elements. I will touch briefly on them to indicate to those who might be interested in this debate that they should not look to this Bill or to this debate for the totality of policies which affect this very important area. Part of the package was a measure which received some criticism. It received most criticism from Senator Haines who spoke on behalf of the Australian Democrats. It was the arrangement which was made with the banks at the time the package was announced. That arrangement with the banks had an unpopular side to it because contemporaneous with that arrangement was the increase in interest rates of one per cent. I stress that the proposals we are bringing forward and, indeed, the package are not the cause of that one per cent interest rate rise. The cause of that one per cent interest rate rise was simply the greater competition for funds which exists in the Australian community, the higher levels of interest rates which apply and the higher levels of interest rates which savers are able to obtain from a variety of saving sources in the community.

It was the lament of Senator Haines that in the old days the banks had money to lend for housing which they do not appear to have now. I think that is fairly simply explained by the fact that there has been a change in the patterns of the savings of individual Australians. Fewer individual Australians are now prepared to leave their savings in relatively low interest bearing accounts. The sources of finance for housing funds have, therefore come under considerable pressure. If the banks and other organisations which lend money for home loans are precluded from competing for money in the market-place, quite clearly money will not be available for lending for home loans. It is a difficult matter but I suggest that those honourable senators who have doubts might, when talking to their constituents, canvass with them the changes in those constituents' savings habits. It is now a matter of people shopping around to see where they will get maximum interest. The smallest savers now have access to the same money market as that which has traditionally been the preserve of large savers and this has meant a general overall shift in the levels of interest rates in the community. It is no longer true that the poorer people in the community who are lending do so at a substantial detriment as compared with those who are better off.

The important, positive element in the package with the banks was that the banks agreed that they would make available an additional $400m for housing loans. In other words, in return for the banks being permitted to get into a more competitive position for funds they agreed to ensure that greater funds be made available for this important area. At the same time the Government announced a tax rebate on home loan interest for recent buyers of first homes. That is an important measure to aid that group of home buyers who are most likely to be feeling the strains of increased interest rates. It is, of course, true that the generality of home buyers who have not yet paid off their houses have seen their interest rates rise and feel that that is a strain. But it is also true that those who have purchased their homes in very recent times at recent price levels are likely to have a substantial element of that purchase price borrowed. They are the ones who are most likely to be affected by the increase in interest rates. The Government's taxation measures are squarely aimed at assisting those who are most likely to need the assistance.

I refer to the complaints by Senator Gietzelt and Senator Haines about the fact that nothing has been done about the welfare side of housing. I can point to the further element of the package, the mortgage and rent relief scheme, which involves our entering into negotiations with the States on the form of that scheme. But the Commonwealth has made a commitment that moneys be made available for a mortgage and rent relief scheme on the basis that the States will contribute dollar for dollar. That will require some working out because some forms of mortgage and rent relief schemes already apply in the States. Clearly there will be a need to tie in any Commonwealth activities in this area with existing arrangements to ensure that the total package is one which will best serve those who need assistance.

We have before us one element of a package of measures meant to assist home buyers in Australia. This is an important measure. It is meant to contribute to the maintenance of the traditionally high proportion of home ownership which we have in this country, a proportion which, at 72 per cent-that is the last figure I have-I do not think can be compared with anywhere else in the world. I commend the legislation to the Senate. I believe it will be beneficial and that it should be passed without delay.

I should perhaps touch on one other point which was made by Senator Haines. She was concerned about the fact that the family bonus was a positive aspect but that it was unlikely to benefit very many people. My advice is that under the old Homes Savings Grant Scheme 30 per cent of recipients under the scheme received the family bonus. One could anticipate a reasonable proportion of the beneficiaries under this scheme being poeple who have already started their families. I will not go through the detail. The second reading speech sets out well the detail of the measure. I have tried to respond in a broad sense to the concerns expressed by honourable senators in this debate. I do so acknowledging that in the total package of policies for which the Commonwealth is responsible, be it in the taxation field, be it grants for mortgage or rent relief or be it in the very important area of the capital grants and loans for welfare housing which are the subject of quite separate deliberations and legislation, we need to make sure that the totality of that package meets the needs in this important area.

I can understand those honourable senators who expressed concern about what they see as a diversion of resources from home building to resource development or to other forms of private investment. I can say only that, as in all things, it is a matter of balance. It is no use being concerned about the lack of employment and the lack of investment leading to employment and not being concerned about housing. By the same token, there has always been a very high proportion of investment by Australians in housing. It has probably been necessary to see some small shift of emphasis. But I give the commitment that the Government will continue to see a high proportion of private home ownership as a very important part of Australian society. We will be watching these policies carefully to see that the trend of increasing private home ownership which has occurred since the Second World War will continue.
Question put:
That words proposed to be added (Senator Gietzelt's amendment) be added.

DIVISION.DATA.PARA: (The Deputy President-Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland)

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I deal with the Home Deposit Assistance Bill 1982 and indicate that I wish to place on record my appreciation of the action of the former Minister for Housing and Construction, Mr Tom McVeigh, in including in the legislation a provision which enables the family bonus to be paid in respect of unborn children. Previously, of course, the situation was that unless the child was actually born the payment of the bonus was not available to the applicant-namely, the parent of that child. It is very heartening to see the action of Mr McVeigh in recognising the fact that there is a responsibility and an eligibility in respect of unborn children so far as the bonus is concerned under the Act. I turn now to the amendments that have been circulated and which seek to amend the Homes Savings Grant Acts Amendment Bill. I seek leave to move all of the amendments at once.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 2, clause 4, proposed new sub-section (1D), after 'after', insert 'the day which occurs 90 days after'.
(2) Page 2, clause 8, proposed new section 53A, sub-section (1), after 'is later than', insert 'the day which occurs 90 days after'.
(3) Page 2, clause 8, proposed new section 53A, sub-section (2), paragraph (a), after 'day', insert 'first'.

As first circulated the amendments read '180 days', but after discussions I have now agreed to change the period to 90 days. The purpose of the amendments is to overcome a situation which was highlighted by Neil O'Reilly in an article in the Sun-Herald on 23 May 1982. Perhaps I can detain the Senate briefly by referring to that article which was headed 'Two-week deadline for homes grant' and which stated:

Couples who want a Federal Government home-savings grant will need to have signed a contract for purchase of a home within two weeks. This is when the current home savings grant scheme ends to make way for the Government's new home deposit assistance scheme. Those eligible for the old home-savings grants will not necessarily qualify for the new scheme-thus the urgency for last-minute applications. The new home deposit assistance scheme legislation will receive Royal Assent in about two weeks. Those eligible for the old home-savings grant will have to sign a contract for the purchase of their dwelling by the day the legislation receives Royal Assent. They will have another month after this to lodge their applications. The Federal Government is anticipating a late rush of applications.

There is the situation which is giving us concern. I have had representations about this matter. I have particularly in mind constituents who are a single income family with two children. The husband is a trademan and he has been working overtime for the last 12 months in order to get sufficient money to put down on a home. He has been saving over a period of three years in anticipation of an entitlement under the Homes Savings Grant Scheme. He will not be eligible for assistance under the new scheme. In order to become eligible, he would immediately have to seek to purchase a home. He would have to sign the contract before the day on which the legislation implementing this new scheme receives royal assent. This is a disconcerting feature of the legislation which I believe requires sympathetic consideration from members of this chamber and members of the Government.

The Home Deposit Assistance Scheme is in fact, as has been outlined by the Minister, meant to replace the Homes Savings Grant Scheme. I accept that that is the Government's policy and I accept that there are some meritorious arguments in favour of that policy. There are some improvements. The savings period is now two years compared with three years under the old scheme. The ratio between savings and the amount of the grant is one to one, not three to one. The maximum amount of assistance is $2,500, not $2,000. There is also the family bonus, to which I have already referred, which applies to the birth of a child within 11 months of entering a contract to purchase. They are, of course, improvements. That is why I am not seeking at all to amend the Home Deposit Assistance Scheme. That Bill can go through and receive royal assent and that new scheme can be put in place.

But a radical change does come about as no grant will be payable where combined taxable income exceeds a figure approximately 155 per cent of average weekly earnings. Obviously many people who would have been eligible under the old scheme will be ineligible under the new scheme. Their number must be legion. there must be quite a number of people-I know of two who have contacted me-who will fall between the two schemes. That is a matter of real concern. Under the old scheme, the savings period was three years. So there could be many couples who for some period were saving in reasonable expectation of receiving a grant under the Homes Savings Grant Scheme.

The legislation provides for a transitional period in which applications can be made, that is to say from 18 March 1982, until the scheme receives royal assent. The royal assent deadline appears in the Homes Savings Grant Acts Amendment Bill . If we pass that Bill today as it stands, royal assent will be inevitable and it will probably be given next week. In other words, this chamber really cannot fiddle with the reference to royal assent but it can legitimately qualify the link to the royal assent by inserting a stated period in which applications can be made.

As the House of Representatives is not sitting, the Homes Savings Grant Acts Amendment Bill, if amended, would not become operative. The practical effect would be to leave the existing homes savings grant legislation as it stands and to allow the Home Deposit Assistance Bill to come into being. The two schemes would co-exist. The leeway period would remain until the amended Homes Savings Grant Acts Amendment Bill is considered by the House of Representatives.

So far as the existing leeway is concerned, under the Homes Savings Grant Acts Amendment Bill eligibility ceases where the contract is made after the Home Deposit Assistance Bill receives royal assent. Applications for assistance will be accepted until one month after that time. There is a distinction here. People have to sign the contract before the date of royal assent but they can make an application up to one month after the date of royal assent. The Home Deposit Assistance Bill applies from 18 March 1982. The two schemes, side by side, are to run until royal assent is given for the Home Deposit Assistance Bill. The practical leeway therefore is only until the granting of royal assent which, as I said, is only next week. I really feel that, if honourable senators consider this matter, they will recognise that that leeway is just too short. People who have been saving for almost three years are faced immediately with the prospect of racing out over the next weekend and signing a contract for the purchase of a house. I happen to have a home on the market, so it is good for me if they race out and buy my place. Can I give the address? No, I had better not! People will have to race out over this weekend and sign a contract for the purchase of a house if they are not going to be eligible under the new scheme. To my mind, that is an unreasonable expectation. People just cannot sort it all out in such a short period.

All I am asking this chamber to do really is to make special provisions in this respect. I did propose a leeway of 180 days but, after discussions with my colleagues in the Australian Democrats, I have reduced that to 90 days, which is only three months. I think that is a reasonable time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Three months from the date the Bill goes back to the House of Representatives.
—No, three months from the date of royal assent.
—It cannot have royal assent until it has been back to the House of Representatives.
—All right, perhaps you can work out some particular scheme.
—Six months.
—I can see what the Minister is getting at. If some suitable wording were suggested, I would try to accommodate him. But we were thinking of a period of three months.
—Seven days after royal assent in that case.

—I suppose that is a point. We are in a situation in which we thought three months would be a reasonable period. Originally I thought six months, but three months would be a reasonable period in which to enable people to consider their position and officers in the Department to undertake the publicity campaign that the Minister has said the Department will be undertaking . As soon as the publicity hits the deck, the people will have three months in which to have a look at the scheme. I have moved my amendments along those lines .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I indicated in my speech in the second reading debate, the Australian Democrats are not opposed in principle to what is contained in these Bills. Our complaints about the housing package that the Government initiated in March of this year are with the arrangements that were made with the banks to allow them an extra one per cent increase in interest rates. I have no objection to the means test. I support it in principle. I support the extension of the amount of assistance. I do not want to turn this speech into another second reading speech. I wish simply to say that we have no objection. It is not my intention to support Senator Harradine's amendments regardless of what he said about conversations with some of his colleagues from my Party.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that I support the principle of a means test, I do not believe that I can then turn around and support the suggestion that we have this strange overlapping sort of scheme for the benefit of a few people who have not been made aware of the fact that this plan has been in progress since 18 March. By the time the legislation receives royal assent, considerable publicity will have been given to the plan over a period of two and a half months. I can see no particular benefit accruing from Senator Harradine's amendments, whether the time is extended to 180 days or 90 days. It is inevitable when a new scheme is introduced that many people are helped by it and some people are not. I received letters regularly in my office whenever the Government raised the allowable value of a house because people had just signed contracts that were slightly above the limit and therefore did not qualify. They discovered that, as from the next day, they would have qualified. Unfortunately there was no retrospectivity in the scheme. It is unfortunate that some people suffer. I accept the emotion and the rhetoric Senator Harradine put into his speech in support of his amendment but I, for one, will not support that amendment, particularly in view of the money that the Government has spent on advertising the pending scheme, the fact that it is likely to cost somewhere around $25m to $30m extra, and that the imposition of a means test is a reasonable sort of amendment and principle to accept.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It might help the debate if I indicate the Government's position before everybody fully commits himself or herself. I thank Senator Haines for supporting the Bills in their present form. Of course, in this situation, as in any other situation, where there is a change of eligibility there will be a cut-off point and there is a potential for someone to miss out. Every change involves that possibility. We have a proposal before us which has been described generally in the Senate as a positive one. The changes have general support. The significant limitation which is imposed is that people with certain levels of income will no longer be eligible. In other words, the new system is geared more squarely to provide a greater level of assistance to people whose incomes are less. The provisions applying for the balance of this financial year will allow for a full grant for people with incomes of $363 or less a week with partial grants allowable for incomes between $363 and $417 a week. The estimated income limits which will apply after 30 June-these are estimates because the figures are not yet finalised but will be over the next few weeks-are between $416 and $477 a week. In other words, people earning incomes up to $416 will receive the full grant and those receiving incomes between $416 and $477 will receive partial grants.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth is aware that in any transition period there are difficulties. We did indulge in quite extensive advertising in this area. In fact, we were subject to some criticism in this place because some State elections were due at the time and it was thought that the Government should not be indulging in election advertising. I mention that merely to remind honourable senators that the fact of the advertising was certainly very well known and understood. The advertising which appeared in all major newspapers and main provincial newspapers pointed out that it was planned to end the old scheme in a few months and that until then an application may be made under either scheme according to eligibility. That point was clearly made. But, most importantly, at that early stage telephone numbers for inquiries were very prominently advertised. So I think people who are in that--

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you say 'the provincial Press'?
—In the provincial Press as well, yes. So there has been an opportunity for people to make inquiries. It is not a matter of this Bill suddenly appearing in the Senate and sneaking up on home buyers.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not enter the debate on the basis that there are no problems for individuals at the cut-off point. Of course I understand that there can be. But, whenever there are changes, whether it be to the income tax legislation or to a State stamp duty applicable to home transactions-that sort of thing occurs from time to time; we all know that stamp duty has become an important source of revenue-those charges alter the financial position of people who might have been anticipating a transaction of the sort we are dealing with here, namely, a home purchase. Wherever the point is drawn somebody will be able to say: 'Well, if it had just been kept going for another week or another month or whatever I would have had an opportunity to benefit from the old scheme which is now gone'. The fact is that for some months now it has been a matter of public record that the scheme would come to an end and that entitlement under the old scheme would stop .

The significant point in not extending this scheme further, from the Government 's point of view, is that the period of overlap is costly. I do not want to labour the point. The fact is that the Government, after looking at the home buying situation, allocated additional funds notwithstanding the tight financial position-all honourable senators know this-because of the blow-out. We found additional money to pay out the backlog of claims under the old scheme. So, there has been a very significant acceleration of payments and considerable additional funds have been allocated. We have done that knowing that we had forward commitments for the new scheme. If further changes are introduced then, once again, the legislature is saying to the Executive: 'Look, the parameters of your Budget can be stretched, as far as we are concerned, just that bit further' .

I ask honourable senators to bear in mind the series of points which I have tried to make as quickly as possible: That any cut-off point gives rise to the possibility that some people will be just outside the cut-off point no matter where it is drawn; that this scheme was coming to an end and that this was known and was advertised as long ago as 20 March; and that, notwithstanding the tight financial circumstances, additional funds have already been pushed into this program. I ask the Senate, in the interests of fairness to the Government, which has the difficult job of trying to put these things together, to not further extend this scheme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has taken on board the views of the Opposition about the weaknesses in the old Homes Saving Grant Scheme. It has provided, as Senator Haines suggested, a means test application in respect of the Home Deposit Assistance Scheme. We are grateful for that because it is an improvement, as I said in my speech in the debate on the motion for the second reading. The second reading speech of the former Minister for Housing and Construction indicated the difficulties to which Senator Harradine has referred. There will be problems of communication. The Government has accepted that some people will be disadvantaged. It is not the Senate's fault that the House of Representatives is not sitting so that if we passed this amendment now the House of Representatives could deal with it tonight. It is not our fault that the Fraser administration has gone on holidays while we are sitting here a fortnight after the House of Representatives has risen, fulfilling our obligations to the Australian people.

SPEECH.PARA: In his second reading speech on the Homes Savings Grant Acts Amendment Bill 1982 the former Minister said:

. . . the Government recognises the difficulty people living in remote areas might experience in obtaining the necessary application documents. Accordingly the Bill provides that a written notification within that month of an intention to apply will be accepted provided a formal application is lodged within one further month.
We are talking about Australia. Australia is a large continent. It has people scattered all over it. The second reading speech continues:

People who enter into a contract before the new scheme receives Royal Assent and who, as a result of the operation of the means test, may not be eligible under the new scheme, will have . . . to apply under the Home Savings Grant Scheme.
In other words, they have an option of remaining within the confines of the old Homes Savings Grant Scheme. The second reading speech continued:
They should lodge their application as promptly as possible and certainly within one month of the Royal Assent to the new scheme.

Is it unreasonable, as Senator Harradine pointed out, that we want to extend that one month period to a three month period? If the House of Representatives realises that we have a valid desire to improve the legislation-I think that is part of our obligation as a house of review-then nothing is wrong with finding a formula that meets that point of view. When the Minister commended the Bill to the Senate he said:
The Government will publicise the cut-off date widely and I strongly urge people who have bought their first home and who have not yet lodged an application to do so promptly.

So the Government recognises that there are people in that grey area. Surely it is accepted. We have seen the establishment of press relations offices, a Government Information Unit and Lord knows what. The amount of money devoted to public relations has been increased very extensively so that the Government can communicate with the Australian people about its legislation and its services. Obviously it did so because it feels it is not reaching the people.

The Government admits it is going to have difficulty in relating the new legislation and the options involved to the people who might be affected. I do not care whether it involves only one person, 50 persons or 500 persons; I do not think that we, as legislators, should take any steps that disenfranchise or in any way disadvantage any persons who honestly seek the grant. The Homes Savings Grant Scheme has been in operation for a number of years. Many people have entered a savings scheme in the belief that they were going to qualify for the grant. I just doubt whether the Government can validly say as is set out in the document I have before me that a certain month is the cut-off point. The Government says that it must change legislation from time to time and that such problems are just too bad.

I am not suggesting that Senator Chaney is necessarily taking a hard line view or that he is not sympathetic and compassionate to the view that Senator Harradine has put forward. All I am looking for is a formula that will resolve this difficulty and give us a breathing space so that nobody will be adversely affected by changes that have taken place. I am not concerned about the funding of this measure. There was a waiting time of, I think, some nine months and I was pleased to hear the Minister say that sufficient funds have been set aside to make up that leeway or lag. Surely we are talking about only a small number of people and a small amount of funds. After all, if the purpose is to help people it is our obligation to find the means to do that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I intervene only because I think there is a degree of cross purpose in the debate. I would like to clarify the matter because what I have to say may lead to a higher degree of unanimity. A lot of what Senator Gietzelt has been talking about relates to the problem of the period within which an application can be made. But in fact the reason I have difficulty with Senator Harradine's proposal is that Senator Harradine is not merely concerned with the period within which application can be made; he is concerned with the period of eligibility. So his proposal in fact involves an extension of eligibility. In other words, the period within which one can buy a house and qualify under the old scheme would be extended under Senator Harradine's amendment. I certainly will be doing everything I can to ensure that those who are eligible have their attention drawn to the scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: The previous Minister for Housing and Construction sent out 20,000 personal letters to lending institutions and so forth. We have advertising planned. As far as the application point is concerned, which was really the main thrust of the remarks made by Senator Gietzelt during the Committee stage of this debate, we will do our best to deal with that by making sure that the matters are drawn to people's attention. Eligibility raises a quite different question and that is whether we extend a non-income tested scheme another 90 days so that it runs contemporaneously with the income tested scheme. For the benefit of the Opposition, I refer to some of Mr Uren's comments in the House of Representatives. He really was critical of the Government's proposal to extend non-means tested and non-income tested assistance to home buyers through tax arrangements. I ask the Opposition to consider a couple of passages from Mr Uren 's speech as a basis of not supporting the amendment which has been put forward. Mr Uren said:
. . . The family home tax rebate scheme really means a subsidy of approximately $100m in a full year to that wealthy section of home purchasers--
I stress these words-
Who earn in excess of 150 per cent of average weekly earnings.
So Mr Uren picked 150 per cent of average weekly earnings as the income level above which to classify people as wealthy and not warranting assistance under that scheme. Mr Uren went on to say:
. . . instead of helping the people who really need help, he--
That is the Treasurer (Mr Howard)-
again serves it up to the wealthy.

I repeat those criticisms that Mr Uren made of the Government because it is a bit inconsistent for the Opposition to be making criticism of us in relation to the tax rebate and then to be saying that we really ought to be running our non- means tested Homes Savings Grant Scheme for another 90 days because it is not fair if people miss out. The fact is that during that 90 days assistance will be available to people who have incomes of up to 135 per cent of average weekly earnings, and partial assistance will be available for those on up to 155 per cent of average weekly earnings. We are not leaving home buyers without assistance; we are saying that that assistance should be focused on those people who are within those income limits. Mr Uren also said:

. . . The rebate is not targeted to those who need assistance most. On the basis of the 1980 home finance survey . . . 45 per cent of first home buyers had incomes in excess of 150 per cent of AWE. These upper income groups will be assisted by the rebate while deserving families on low incomes will get nothing.
Finally, Mr Uren said:

. . . this is nothing new for this Government because it has always taken resources away from the great bulk of the people on low incomes and transferred them either to wealthy individuals or to wealthy companies.

I have been a public exponent of trying to focus available assistance on need. I think this is one of those occasions when the Government has made a move which is significantly in that direction. I ask that we be supported and that the old non-directive system not be extended in the way that Senator Harradine has sought.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call Senator Mason, I thought that I detected a slight note of irritation a moment ago when I called the Minister for Social Security. It is the usual practice in Committee to call the Minister if it is thought by the Chair that the Minister can help straighten out the situation. That is why I called the Minister.
—I understand that. Since you raise the point, it was not that call but the previous call that I was interested in.
—Senator, that was because a member of your party previously had had a call.
—You cannot question the Chair and the Chair should not have to apologise.
—I did not raise the matter.
—I call Senator Mason.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like other Australian Democrats, I approve of the new Bill and the principles embodied in it. My cause for concern, as with Senator Harradine and certain other honourable senators who have spoken, is the transitional period. I think there is a difficulty in this regard which may not occur in some of the smaller cities in Australia but certainly does occur in Sydney where the time occupied in getting through the plans of a house and drawing up contracts is quite long. I take the excellent point made by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) that if 90 days were placed in the amendment at this stage that period would effectively be six months because the Bill could not be given royal assent until after it had been returned to the House of Representatives. I have an amendment to Senator Harradine's amendment which I have discussed with him, and I do not think he minds me saying that. I propose to move:

SPEECH.PARA: Where 90 days occurs, substitute seven days.

This would effectively bring the matter back to the three months which we are seeking. That, I think, would allow a period of 90 days, or something like that, to elapse before the Bill came into operation.

I must also reasonably declare here some sort of personal interest in this matter since a member of my family is affected by this situation. My knowledge of that situation, and others, convinces me that it is probably not possible in two months in the city of Sydney, and I suspect elsewhere, for persons who have saved conscientiously for the homes savings grant and who have tentative plans to complete their houses, to have the plans passed by a council-which they must do before they can have a contract with a builder-negotiate with builders on contracts and then sign a contract. That is almost impossible. I suspect that many thousands of people will be caught in just this dilemma.

I agree with the Minister that this plan should not be extended to the extent where people think they should benefit from it even if they have made no plans and we should go on indefinitely with extensions. But I think that those people who saved conscientiously over the years, who have plans and who have taken action in respect of the grant should not be deprived of that grant completely. It is for that reason that I support Senator Harradine's amendment, which I propose to amend to cover the point raised reasonably by the Minister.

As I said, it would be nearly impossible for people to go through the stages of getting their house to the stage where they can sign a contract with a builder. It is possible, and I think this is one of the unfortunate aspects of this situation, that on fairly harsh terms they could in fact get it done. But those terms would include rushing through the plans of their house, perhaps not doing what they wanted to do and accepting the first quote from a builder that came along. That would quite likely in the course of nature be a very disadvantageous one. So I suggest that the Government, by not agreeing to or considering this amendment, first, will push people of good faith into that position and, second, will make sure that a large number of plans to build which have been current over the last couple of months will be cancelled. It would not be terribly good for the building industry and it would not be good for Australia generally if that activity did not proceed. That is an element of this situation which must be taken into consideration.

The Minister for Social Security mentioned that there had been a wide pattern of advertising during the Victorian election and said this advertising was criticised. That election was held early in April. I suggest that it is unreasonable to expect everybody in Australia to read every advertisement which appears in the newspapers every day so that he will become immediately aware of everything that is advertised. It is probably only five or six weeks since people became aware of these advertisements. In many cases people became aware of them even later than that. That makes the situation in which these people are placed even more difficult for them. There is no question of wanting to give unfair advantages to people who are purely opportunistic and who want to get on the bandwagon with the old scheme. The amendment is designed, as I see it, to assist those people who have saved money, who have been prudent, who have persisted with the Homes Savings Grant Scheme in good faith, who have bought land, who have tentative plans ready and who were going to go ahead but who now find themselves, because of the nature of this Bill, in a situation in which it is not possible for them to proceed in time. On that basis, I have foreshadowed that I will move an amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before Senator Mason moves his amendment formally, I call the Minister for Social Security as I believe that he wishes to give further information to the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I may have misled the Committee. The amendments moved by Senator Harradine are amendments to the Homes Savings Grant Acts Amendment Bill 1982. As I understand it, the Home Deposit Assistance Bill 1982 is to pass unamended. In fact, the period of 90 days would apply once royal assent is given to the Home Deposit Assistance Bill. So something I said by way of interjection was incorrect. The only complication is that we would then need to get the Homes Savings Grant Acts Amendment Bill through the Parliament at a later stage. That is something which the Government cannot guarantee because it is in the hands of the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I should like to make a couple of brief comments. There is no need to go through the procedures which Senator Mason has outlined to sign a contract for the purchase of a house. One can sign a contract for the purchase of a house without having approvals or anything else. Very often that is something which is done by the builder pursuant to the signing of the contract. Very often the builder makes the arrangements for plans, lodges them and seeks the necessary approval. The signing of a contract is the determinant for a grant under this legislation. I think the difficulties that Senator Mason is concerned about are somewhat exaggerated in his mind. I do not mean that in any offensive sense. I think the difficulties are not as great as he has presented to the Committee. Entering into a firm contract for a house is something which does not necessarily occur at the end of the sort of process which Senator Mason has outlined.

The other point I wish to raise is that more than two months have passed since 18 March. People will have up to two months after the proclamation within which to apply for a grant. Advertisements were published earlier. There has been a great amount of publicity by Mr McVeigh, the former Minister for Housing and Construction, with respect to people such as real estate agents and those in banks who are active in this field. If this legislation is passed a substantial advertising campaign will be conducted. I ask the Committee to pass this legislation in the form it has been put before it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enter this debate because I have sympathy with the amendments. It now appears necessary that we should examine whether either House of Parliament should rise before the other has completed its business. I think we ought to take a look at that matter in future. If the Senate finds it necessary to sit, the House of Representatives should be available to consider any decision made by the Senate. If that does not occur, we will be constantly under pressure to pass legislation which needs to be amended and which the Senate might otherwise amend but will not because the House of Representatives is not sitting.

SPEECH.PARA: I return to the amendments for which I have sympathy in spite of the points which the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) has made concerning eligibility. This involves an area of great need on the part of those who are seeking not to buy a luxury item but to purchase a home. The Government, by its policies, has raised the expectations of a great number of people who will now be disadvantaged in spite of the fact that there has been an advertising campaign and that further advice will be given. I think a great number of people who do not deserve to be disadvantaged will be disadvantaged. I should like to mention why I think they should be disadvantaged.

The penalties which are imposed on people seeking homes now and the costs of borrowing money are substantial. I put to the Minister a variation of his comments to the chamber concerning high interest rates. The high interest rates which exist in the community do not exist because of a change in the pattern of savings and a change in the attitude of those people who have some funds in savings organisations. The problems that high interest rates cause the people whom we are trying to assist are problems of the Government's own making. The Government has taken a dangerous course. It endeavoured to soak up liquidity by lifting the bond rate by 1.4 per cent only recently. This led to a further upward thrust of interest rates. That deliberate policy taken by the Government lifted interest rates.

A further problem has been caused by the deregulation of interest rates. This also was a Government decision. Deregulation of interest rates has thrown the market place into disorder. There are many institutions in Australia chasing funds. I refer in particular to building societies and credit unions. They are now up against fairly savage and sophisticated competition from banks and other financial institutions which are offering interest rates as high as 17.5 per cent. That, of course, has forced the building societies-many of them are small institutions-to chase funds in the market place by also lifting their interest rates. I have not included the credit unions in that. In Australia a great number of financial institutions are chasing funds and forcing interest rates up , to the disadvantage of the home purchaser. That is why we need this legislation. The need is so great and the disadvantage is so great that we ought to be accepting the type of amendment which has been proposed, even though it may cost the Government millions of dollars. I put it to the Government that the rise in interest rates is not due to a change in the pattern of savings. Interest rates have been forced up by deliberate Government policy. The Minister for Social Security is attempting to stop me. I point out that if I do not make these comments now I will make them during the third reading stage.

I should like to conclude my remarks by saying that we should be very careful about allowing financial institutions to go into the market place to seek the funds which they desperately need. If they do not have the funds they cannot operate. A building society that does not receive funds cannot carry out its functions. A credit union that does not receive funds cannot carry out its functions. These organisations have to compete with the banks which, under deregulation, can now advertise what I think are excessive interest rates. Who are the most disadvantaged? The most disadvantaged are those people whom we are trying to assist by this legislation.

I warn the Government that, as the economic pressure starts to bite, some of these financial institutions may go to the wall. The responsibility will be on the Government's head. Some institutions may be those whose prime purpose is to provide home loans. They are able to do that now only with the greatest difficulty because the banks are not interested to the same extent, nor is their prime purpose lending for housing as it is with building societies. I put it to the Committee that building societies in this country are facing a great difficulty in carrying out their worthwhile purpose. I ask the Minister to consider all these matters, relax a little and accept the amendment and the further eligibility even though it might cost more. I advise him and the Government to deal with the prime cause of the problem-high interest rates. Interest rates are the responsibility of the Government and no one else.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I acknowledge the correctness of your response to my somewhat inaudible interjection concerning your call, for which I apologise. You were perfectly in the right and I was in the wrong. Beyond that, I shall comment on the remarks made by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney). I cannot understand how he can publicly encourage young people to sign a firm contract with a builder without knowing what they would build, without the plans being passed by the local council and without the closest and tightest specifications being provided for the structure . I suggest with all respect to the Minister that that would be a very dangerous thing for young people to do and would force them into an even more invidious situation than I had imagined. If this cut-off point failure will force young people into that position we will cause chaos for many hundreds or thousands of people. I do not know of a single reason why a person should sign a firm contract with a builder to construct a dwelling or any other structure without knowing exactly what it was and without having it covered by fully approved plans and specifications. I reiterate that under normal circumstances in Sydney- even if people started on 18 March, the actual day of this announcement-it would not be possible to get that done by the end of this month.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's view is that only a few people would be involved in this scheme. I think that there would be many more than the Government believes.
—It will be $10m to $20m worth.

—I thought the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) indicated that he felt that there would not be very many; that when there is a changeover there are always a few. Quite a few would be involved. My concern is that this is not analogous to a change in stamp duty regulations or in taxation laws; this refers to what is normally a once only major decision taken by a couple to buy their home. If a couple slave their guts out over a period and find themselves falling between the two stools only because the leeway is not sufficient, I think we should give those people sympathetic consideration.

SPEECH.PARA: I have one example very much in mind. There is no profit for me in raising this matter. In fact, from a personal point of view, given my own circumstances of selling a house, I ought to vote for the legislation as it is to force everybody out on to the market this weekend to buy a home. That is what they have to do. The Minister cannot deny that. If this legislation goes through as it is at present there will be no 2 1/2 months leeway-I think there must be some misunderstanding somewhere-and prospective purchasers must go out this weekend and buy a house.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or sign a building contract.

—That is right. They must sign a contract this weekend or before the legislation receives the royal assent. Of course they have a month after that time in which to make their application but they must sign a contract before the royal assent is given, say, next week. This is a matter which I should have thought would have concerned honourable senators opposite. If they do not vote for my amendments now they will certainly get a lot of queries in the future about its stand. I have only two or perhaps three cases to cite. In the third case it may be possible for something to be done. One of the cases concerns a single income family. A tradesman who has been working overtime will be ineligible.
—Because of his high income.

—Yes, because of his high income over the last year. He felt that there would be a benefit. He now finds that there will be no benefit unless he charges out this weekend and buys a home. I will let the case rest at this point. I thank the Minister for clarifying the point in respect of the Home Deposit Assistance Bill. There is absolutely no intention of amending that Bill in any shape or form. I believe that 90 days is a reasonable period. By that time the House of Representatives will be in session again and can determine the issue once and for all and send the Bill back to us.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Harradine's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.
