SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity of the first reading stage of these money Bills to raise a matter which, I think, must be brought before the Parliament at this stage before we commence the recess. It relates to Australia's obligations to its citizens who are abroad and who may have a problem with the laws of other countries. I raise this matter, coincidentally, on the same day that a man named William Sinclair, who was convicted in a Thailand court, is free, for the first time in three and a half years, to return to Australia, having had an appeal upheld. Having been found innocent of a heroin charge William Sinclair is reported in today's Age as saying that he blames the Australian Government for the three and a half years he spent in prison. Regardless of whether that statement is accurate, it is one important example of a question that has been unresolved for some five months, namely: What are the Australian Government's duties in respect of its citizens?

SPEECH.PARA: I first became involved with this question, through the Sinclair case, in January this year when the Australian Government refused to intervene with respect to his gaol sentence. At that time the Attorney-General, Senator Durack, wrote to the former Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Peacock, and said:

. . . when an Australian citizen becomes involved with a foreign legal system the Government will not attempt to interfere where the laws and procedures involved are applied without discrimination against Australians.

In other words provided the same laws-regardless of whether they conform in any way with our ideas of justice-are applied equally to Australian citizens we would not intervene at all. I then commented publicly that I did not believe the Government's attitude was adequate; I do not believe that it has been traditionally the view and policy of the Australian Government for many years; and I said that I intended to raise this matter in Parliament when it resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Drug peddling has put that in a new context.

—I will get to that matter. Drug peddling is no reason why we should ignore the rules of law in this country. I said that I would raise the matter before the Government members' law and government committee. I did that and after preparing a statement-which I believe is correct-of the policies which have been pursued by governments for many years, that document, containing a minor amendment, was referred to the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street). Some two months after that was done there is still no response from the Foreign Minister as to whether it is a correct statement. That statement sets out the circumstances under which I believe the Government has responsibilities. Because of the shortage of time I desire to incorporate in Hansard the statement headed 'Australia's obligations to its citizens abroad'.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
AUSTRALIA'S OBLIGATIONS TO ITS CITIZENS ABROAD

(1) On 6 January 1982, the Attorney-General, Senator Durack was reported as saying that when an Australian citizen becomes involved with a foreign legal system, the Government will not attempt to interfere where the laws and procedures involved are applied without discrimination against Australians. The Attorney-General, on 30 December 1981, had also written to Hon. Andrew Peacock relating to complaints about a particular trial of an Australian citizen in a foreign country in the following words:

'With regard to the conduct of the trial, the Australian Government has consistently taken the view that, when an Australian citizen becomes involved in normal judicial processes of another country, the Government will not attempt to interfere where the laws and procedures involved are applied without discrimination against Australians, notwithstanding that differences exist between the laws and procedures of that country and Australia.'

(2) The essence of these statements is that the Australian Government will never attempt to interfere in the case of an Australian citizen charged with offences in a foreign country, when the laws and procedures are applied without discrimination against Australians. In other words, provided the laws-no matter how unjust or offensive to the rule of law-are applied in the same form to Australians as to nationals of that country, the Australian Government will make no protest.

(3) These statements are not, and have never been, applied as Australian policy , and indeed there are many instances when Australian Governments have registered protests or made representations relating not only to the treatment of Australians abroad but even in the cases of citizens of that foreign country.

(4) The statement is altogether too extreme and unqualified. In normal cases against Australians in countries that respect the rule of law, provide opportunities for defendants to be effectively represented and to present their defences, then one would not expect the Australian Government to interfere, or make representations. But even in these cases the Australian Government would '' interfere'' in the sense that it would, through its Embassy, ensure that the Australian national was aware of his rights, had representation and communications with his relatives and advisers and, if imprisoned, would be given proper treatment including the provision of health needs.

(5) However, when we consider overseas nations operating under systems of law which do not accord with standards that would ordinarily be observed by civilised communities, or which are subject to manifest defects in administration, then the duty of the Australian Government to intervene on behalf of its nationals may often arise. For example, the fact Iran citizens may be given summary trial without semblance of justice, or may be executed, or stoned to death or have limbs cut off by way of punishment, is no reason why we should accept with equanimity the same treatment for Australians. Likewise, any Australian citizen accused of 'dissident' behaviour in the USSR (where such trials always lead to a conviction) may well lead to protest from the Australian Government, irrespective of the fact that USSR citizens are similarly treated.

The examples could be multiplied in many places. The Australian Government has protested on many occasions in these type of circumstances, both in relation to Australians and other persons. It has done so following the carriage of resolutions of the Parliament, representations from members of the Parliament, from Amnesty International, the International Commission of Jurists and from ordinary Australians.

(6) It follows that the Attorney-General's statement must at least be subject to a proviso that there are special obligations to Australian citizens abroad which will be dependent on the circumstances of each case and the legal procedures involved. In some cases the Government will have a duty to interfere in the interests of justice, to ensure, so far as is possible, application of the Rule of law, acceptable legal representation, communication with Australian diplomatic representatives and/or family of accused and, if imprisoned, health care.

(7) It is suggested that the Foreign Minister be asked to make a statement in the Parliament clarifying this matter and confirming the obligations of the Australian Government towards its nationals abroad.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the time I said that I did not believe the response which Senator Durack gave was good enough. I stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Government had to look at the material presented to the Thai court--
This was one example-
and see whether it was proper for them to supply evidence which would perhaps be inadmissible in Australia.
I further stated:

In the extraordinary legal systems that exist in some parts of the world we have a responsibility not only to our own citizens, but particularly to them, to ensure that we don't supply evidence that would not be acceptable under our own system or to our own obligations to international covenants.

I was concerned with the general question which arose. The Sinclair case is a good example of the difficulties that arise if we have the blunt idea that if in other countries the same laws apply to Australian citizens as to their nationals we will not intervene.

If I say only a few words about this case I will not do it justice. It has been done justice in a series of articles which Mr Garry Sturgess of the Age has written over a period of months. He has followed the case most diligently and one should read the whole of the series. However, I will summarise what happened in that case. A man, now aged 69 years, was convicted for possession of heroin 3 1/2 years ago and sentenced to 33 years' imprisonment. The evidence upon which he was convicted-it was referred to many times in the judgment of the Thai court of which I have a copy-consisted of statements made by a man named Edwin William Smith who is a prisoner in Australia. It was hearsay evidence. The court relied upon a statement; it did not have that witness before it. On the basis of that statement, which was supplied by Australian officials at our Embassy in Bangkok, Mr Sinclair was convicted. That evidence has since been totally discredited. Subsequently, prosecutions were taken in Australia against other people connected with the Sinclair case, including his son, on the same grounds. These people were charged in New South Wales and were acquitted. Some were acquitted by magistrates and some by Judge Muir in the District Court. According to an article in the Age about Edwin Smith, Judge Muir said:
He admits before this court and before the jury that he has deliberately given false evidence.
The article stated:
Edwin Smith, under examination in the District court, said that he had given false evidence because the police had promised him a pardon, and at other times a shortening of his sentence.

Very largely on the basis of that evidence William Sinclair was convicted. Subsequently, efforts were made through Mr Andrew Peacock and others to get the Australian Government to authenticate that evidence because the Thai court was not at first prepared to accept the evidence of the Australian court. Ultimately , the Australian Government did that. It proceeded late last year to authenticate the evidence. The Attorney-General (Senator Durack) then said:

Mr Sinclair requests that the Australian Government ensure that transcripts of certain proceedings before Australian courts are properly attested for use by the Thai court reviewing Mr Sinclair's father's conviction. I understand that the Department of Foreign Affairs is taking action to assist in this regard.

It did that and ultimately, in May of this year, the Thai court, on consideration of the further evidence, upheld the appeal. Although it fixed very high bail, which has since been obtained, Mr Sinclair was subsequently released and is now free to come back to Australia. The problem is that we meddled by providing evidence to the court in Thailand which turned out to be faulty. We have subsequently taken some action but, meanwhile, this man has spent 3 1/2 years in gaol.

I refer now to what was said in a speech on 25 November 1981 by the Australian Ambassador to Thailand, Mr Gordon Jockel, to the Australian-Thai Chamber of Commerce in which he outlined the constraints on specialist narcotics officers working in the Embassy. He is reported in the Age, which states:
He said embassy officers could not engage in police work, 'the performance of which is naturally within the sovereign jurisdiction of the appointed Thai agencies'.

'Nor would it be compatible with the immunities afforded these officers as members of the embassy for them to engage directly in operational work,' he said . The duties of the officers were carefully defined by directive. 'They work in a liaison capacity with their Thai counterparts. They exchange intelligence. They may consult on the timing and locations of operations. They may assist with interpretation in inquiries and interrogations. They may give evidence in Thai courts when it is appropriate to do so,' he said.

In this case the officers went much further than that. They supplied written evidence from Australia which led to a conviction. I think it is a matter of concern that we have officials who go beyond the duties which the Ambassador to Thailand indicated they should perform. The position is as I have set out in my statement. That statement has had the confirmation of the law and government committee of the Government parties. I hope that today the Acting Foreign Minister (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) will be able to say something about whether the statement is accurate.

In general, the statement that rules are applied equally to Australians as they are to locals is not good enough. It is too crude a statement altogether. It is not good enough to say that because laws, no matter how unjust or offensive to the rule of law, are applied in the same way to nationals of a country as to Australians, the Australian Government can make no protest. As I understand it, that policy has never been applied in Australia. I have checked these matters with people who ought to know. Even in normal cases with countries which observe the rule of law we expect our officials abroad to assist by making sure that Australian defendants are properly and effectively represented, that they have an opportunity to communicate with their relatives and advisers and that, if imprisoned, at least they are given proper treatment including health needs. But in other countries which do not accord with our standards of law and which accept evidence of a hearsay nature, or where there is no proper system of justice, we expect our protests to be heard. We constantly protest whether cases occur in the Soviet Union, Iran or Uganda. We often protest at the request of organisations in this country, such as Amnesty International, or at the request of our citizens. We expect that protests will be made in relation to not only Australian citizens but also the people of the country concerned.

Because we were dissatisfied with the proceedings in the Sinclair case this statement has been put to the Foreign Minister (Mr Street) for his comment. In Thailand, as I understand it, the law enables the Executive government to have a person accused in a drug case executed without trial. There does not have to be a trial. In the Sinclair case an enormous cost burden was placed on the relatives and friends of William Sinclair to ensure that he had a trial at all. We have to concern ourselves with the differences which occur in countries with that type of government.

TALK.START.PARA: —That would not apply to Hayward, I imagine.

—No, I am not talking about Hayward. I am talking about no one but William Sinclair who was found guilty. Other criticisms have also been made, one by the President of the Law Institute of Victoria, Mr Mat Walsh, who, at the time of his criticism in December, called on the Federal Government to consider drawing up guidelines to cover Australian officials asked to give evidence to foreign courts about Australian citizens. He said that the guidelines could limit the giving of evidence which would not be acceptable in Australian courts. He pointed out that in many of our embassies, including the one in Thailand, we have no specialised legal department or people knowledgeable in the laws that apply in those countries. So we have the problem that embassy officials are sometimes used to the detriment of Australian citizens.

SPEECH.PARA: As a representative of the International Commission of Jurists and one of its officers I could not fail to bring this matter to the notice of the Senate. As a representative and Vice-President of the Amnesty organisation's parliamentary wing-I note that Senator Coleman is in the chamber also-I constantly bring such matters to the attention of the Government of this country. We expect the Government to respond when people are not given proper trials abroad. We would be in dereliction of our duty if we did not draw these things to its attention. Our obligation to Australian citizens is surely just as great. One could say, in response to Senator Mulvihill's interjection, that in the case of heinous offences in other countries, such as drug offences with which we have no sympathy, if people are guilty they should suffer the penalty.

In the very serious cases we should be even more careful that there is a proper investigation, that the rules of evidence and so forth are applied and that people are dealt with properly. We have to be more vigilant in the serious cases . In our passports is a statement from the Governor-General which requests that the bearer be allowed to pass freely and that he or she be afforded every assistance and protection of which he or she may stand in need. One of those needs is the assistance of our representatives abroad. In recent times, I do not believe this has been brought sufficiently to the attention of the people concerned. I want to know from the Government whether the statement I have made is correct and whether the policies that I have outlined as being the Government 's remain such today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I intervene to respond in small measure to what Senator Missen has just said. Recently he referred the matter to me in my capacity as Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs. On 19 May, I sent to the Secretary of the Government Members Law and Government Committee an acknowledgment of the reference from that Committee on this subject. It was an interim reply stating that the matter had been taken up with the Attorney-General's Department and that the Department of Foreign Affairs would be writing to the Committee when the matter had been considered and a substantive reply could be given.

SPEECH.PARA: The letter from the Government Members Law and Government Committee raised some extremely complicated questions of international practice and law. I think one could gather as much from what has been said by Senator Missen today. The interim reply said that necessarily consultations would take place with the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) before a full reply to the letter could be prepared. Those consultations are taking place but, I repeat, the issues raised are extremely difficult and complicated. They involve questions of international law and practice. They cannot be answered simply and demand careful and thorough consideration. I assure Senator Missen and others who might be interested in the same subject that a more complete reply will be made available to the Committee and also to the Senate if thought fit. All efforts will be made to do that within a reasonable time.

As Senator Missen has referred to Mr William Sinclair, it is appropriate to say that the assistance given Mr Sinclair was considerable. On 18 January 1982 he acknowledged this by writing to express his appreciation, stating:
My sincere thanks for the kindly interest you have taken in my well-being.

I know that that does not address itself to the central point made by Senator Missen today, but the statement by the then Minister for Foreign Affairs to the House of Representatives on 26 May 1978 describes in some detail the services provided by the Government. It must be remembered that Australia provides consular services to its citizens overseas in accordance with established international practice and as provided for under the Vienna Convention on Consular Relations, to which Australia is a party. I believe we can say that the assistance available to Australians is at least equal to that provided by other countries to their citizens. A statement in 1978 by the then Minister for Foreign Affairs makes clear that it is an important consular duty to ensure that Australian citizens arrested overseas are treated with due process in accordance with the laws of the State where the offence may have occurred and that they receive the same benefits of the law which the foreign state affords its own subjects. The consular officers of the Australian Embassy in Bangkok paid considerable attention to the welfare of Mr Sinclair while he was in prison, as they do for other Australians in prison in Thailand and other countries. I understand that from the time of this arrest at least 32 visits were made to Mr Sinclair in prison. As well, there were 14 attendances at court hearings. This assistance was acknowledged by Mr Sinclair in letters that he wrote to the Consul in Bangkok. For example, on 9 December 1981 he wrote:
As for myself, I receive every possible assistance within the framework of the prison regulations.
As I have said, he also expressed his appreciation.

In the course of assisting Australians in gaol, Australian consular officials assist a broad range of welfare activities. They help with the delivery of mail, the transfer of funds, communication with the outside world, medical problems and other such matters. This work is carried out as part of the very broad- ranging responsibilities of the limited number of consular officers in each post . These include the giving of assistance to the many Australians travelling abroad who find themselves in difficulties for a whole range of reasons, as well as a number of formal functions such as performance of marriage, the registration of births and citizenship activities.

I make those points recognising that what Senator Missen has asked of the Government falls beyond that range of consular duties and raises the fundamental principles that he has brought forward. The Attorney-General's Department, in consultation with the Department of Foreign Affairs, is looking at these extremely difficult and complex questions, which involve international law. As soon as consideration can be given and some points resolved a complete reply will be given to the Government Members Law and Government Committee. I am sure that it will be made more widely available, if substantive changes take place, as compared with the position stated earlier by the Attorney-General and the Foreign Minister (Mr Street). I undertake that when such consideration has been given by the two departments concerned by the Foreign Minister and, if necessary , by the Attorney-General, further advice will be given the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer quite briefly to the matter raised by Senator Missen and to respond to it from the perspective of one who is a former Secretary of the parliamentary group of Amnesty International and is a current executive member of that group. The majority of its work, as is the case with Amnesty International generally, is to ensure that basic human rights are available to all. Of course, it is of great concern when it would appear, from evidence that has been given, that those human rights have been denied to an Australian in another country because of the judicial system that operates there. I will await with interest any further information that the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) may be able to provide. I hope that she will see fit at some stage to have a statement made in this chamber by the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) rather than merely pass it on to the Government Members Law and Government Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: The other matter that I wanted to raise today-I am conscious of the limitations on time-is perhaps the most important that could be raised in this decade. I refer to the second special session on disarmament which is being held in the United Nations in June. I believe that it would have been more appropriate for a full debate to take place regarding this matter, but this will be the last opportunity that one will have to discuss it before the Senate rises for the winter recess.

I believe the coming special session on disarmament to be the most important of any so far held. Perhaps it would be considered the last real chance for the world to divert itself from its present path which seems to be taking us daily closer to the possibility of a nuclear war on a global scale. I do not subscribe to the theory, expounded by some who should know better, that it is possible to have a limited nuclear war. The premise that one country can drop a nuclear bomb or a number of nuclear bombs on another without some form of retaliation is ludicrous. But as each day goes by we hear a number of reports that there are in high positions in other governments people who see that as a feasible proposition.

I am sure that every reasonably well informed member of the Senate and every reasonably well informed member of the Australian community are aware of the current situation which exists simply because rash and unthinking statements have been made and know that no government really wants to be seen as backing down. The biggest problem is to convince people that we are not entering upon a face saving operation. Also, I make it quite clear that I am not being any more or less critical of the United States than I am of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. I am simply making the point that to millions of people throughout the world the tragedy is that those super-powers cannot sit down to discuss the most important issue that may ever arise-the future of the world, or of mankind. We have seen a number of overtures made by both the United States of America and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics over the last few months. It appears that if one makes an overture the other has to reject it just because it was not its own proposal. I think that is a tragedy, one that we may live to regret.

I have spoken in this place before about the transference of funds and I want to touch on that matter again. Given that at the moment almost half of the world 's scientists are working either on the development of bigger and better more sophisticated weapons or directly or indirectly on military projects, given that governments are spending of the order of $1m a minute on the arms race, given that we already have enough nuclear arms to kill every human being 16 times over and given that two-thirds of the world's population lives in want and poverty, there is a great deal to be said about the transference of funds. On a world- wide basis, if the world spent 5 per cent of its military budgets on the means of food production and employed some of those specialists who are currently employed on military expenditures there would be no starving people. If the world spent 5 per cent of its military budgets on health care we could just about wipe out killer diseases. If the world spent 5 per cent of its military budgets on housing everyone could be housed. I am not saying that they would be housed in palatial mansions but at least there would be some form of shelter for everyone. If the world spent 5 per cent of its military budgets on education there would be no under-educated people in this world. That is the type of transference of funds about which I am talking.

I am also thinking of the spin-offs that governments and various nations would get from that transference of funds. Australia at the moment is suffering the effects of high inflation and high unemployment, as are most other Western countries. If we transfer funds to those productive areas we provide employment. We provide funds by way of taxation for governments to continue. So it is a spin -off that perhaps we should be looking at more seriously. Just as a matter of interest, I am not talking just about defence budgets. I am talking about military budgets. I think the distinction has to be made because one is totally different from the other. The budgets I am talking about-the military budgets- are those that are currently being spent on building up arms. They are totally unnecessary arms because we already have quite enough military equipment. We already have the capacity to destroy the world many times over and will only increase that capacity, although why anybody would want to be able to kill anybody more than once is beyond my comprehension.

We have a number of ever-growing stockpiles of nuclear weapons capable of that destruction. It is a fact, for instance, that there are now over 3 tonnes of explosive power for every man, woman and child on earth. Those stockpiles are increasing daily, both in number and sophistication. As the numbers grow and technology develops so, too, does the risk of war, either through mistake, miscalculation or even malfunction of control systems, not to mention the human factors such as the ambition, stubbornness, political intransigence or perhaps even mania of various people. I think it is sobering to reflect on Dr James Miller's speech in 1981 when he was secretary to the International Physicians for the Prevention of Nuclear War. He said that in 1977, an average year, 1,000 military people were removed from access to nuclear weapons because of drug usage.

Perhaps the most dangerous aspect of all is the growing psychological climate-a world-wide psychological climate, I might add-that suggests that a genuine nuclear war is inevitable in the future but that we can hope that whilst it will be unpleasant it will be, for some, a survivable experience. The best information available is that it will not be a survivable experience. It is simply recognised that some people will take longer to die than others. It is sometimes a little difficult, particularly in this place, not to become disheartened and to give up in the face of what we are increasingly being told that we have to acknowledge is inevitable. It is very easy to become cynical about such organisations as the United Nations. I would be the first to admit that there have been a number of occasions when I have felt disillusioned and discouraged about that organisation but it is all we have. It is the only avenue for a consensus of opinion which could lead-I stress, could lead-to world disarmament and to world peace. It is the only avenue we have whereby people can sit down and talk.

I think it is important that I have to remind people that the United Nations is a world organisation. It is not a world government. It can operate only if the people who subscribe to it recognise that they have a responsibility not only to agree to the treaties that are put up but also to make them work. It could be said that the United Nations lacks power. I would agree with that. Perhaps we should look at the organisation to see how we can strengthen its membership sot the that is no longer a fundamental weakness, and provide it with some teeth to enable it to do something. I believe that the United Nations can reflect the wishes of a global society. I believe also that world-wide public opinion can be expressed at this very important special session on disarmament.

In the last year we have seen demonstrations in every country in the world by millions of people, all marching for peace. In the week prior to Easter we saw those same demonstrations, those same marches, here in Australia. People marched in every State. The marches were not of the same magnitude as those in Bonn, Amsterdam or the United Kingdom. They were certainly not of the same magnitude as those in the United States. We have a much smaller population. I do believe, because of the size of our country, that we can make a comparison. Those people marched in their hundreds and thousands. They marched for one reason-to demonstrate to the Government that they are not prepared to be dragged along this road to destruction.

I believe that Australia could play a quite distinctive role at the special session. I believe that we can put forward positive proposals that can be accepted and, at least, lead to a situation where all sides can sit down, conciliate and talk about the problems tht they have with the arms race-how they can bring it to a halt, what they can do with their stockpiles of weapons, how they can make them safe so that the materials in them can be used for other things-and the transference of funds that I spoke about a little earlier so that we can see a world without any poverty.

Because it is such a special session I do not believe that Australia should even consider sending anybody less that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). I believe that it would be a mistake for someone of lesser importance to lead the Australian delegation. It is interesting that we saw the Prime Minister in Lusaka a few years ago posturing about something which could not be considered to be as important as a special session on disarmament. We have seen the recent display, his visits to overseas countries. One would have to admit that most of the visiting was done for reasons of domestic consumption and had nothing whatsoever to do with the terrible economic situation in which the world finds itself. Surely none of the meetings that he held with the leaders of any of those countries could be considered to be more important than the United Nations special session on disarmament. I believe that the Australian people expect him to be there, the people of the world want him to be there and that the people of this Parliament should insist that he go there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elstob Sen R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Senator Coleman, I wish to say something about peace. Peace is the ultimate quality of life. I believe war is the great thief of life. We cannot talk about peace unless we refer to our experiences in and fear of war. As I said, war is the great thief. Not only does war thieve people's lives, it is also the thief of the whole world in relation to such things as education and food. A quarter of the world's population goes hungry every night. One billion people are illiterate in this world. Much of this is caused by the amount which is spent on the war machine and wars. If man could live in peace in this world we would not recognise the world. We would have a quality of life which is unrecognisable from what we know now, or as past generations have seen it. It is essential not only for governments but also for people of the world to recognise and understand the dangers in the present situation. Removing the threat of a nuclear world war is the most urgent task at present. Mankind is confronted with a choice; we must either halt the arms race and proceed to disarmament or we face annihilation.

SPEECH.PARA: It is essential to understand just what the cost of war has been. Although I have only a short time in which to speak as this is the end of the parliamentary session before the winter recess, I wish to explain the cost to the world of past wars. World War I took twice as many men as all major wars which had occurred between 1790 and 1930. About 63 of every 100 servicemen who died came from the allied services. The number of civilian deaths which occurred in areas of actual war totalled about 5 million. Starvation, disease and exposure accounted for 80 of every 100 of these civilian deaths. Spanish flu, which some people blamed on the war, caused tens of millions of deaths.

World War I cost $US337 billion. Of that amount about, about $US186 billion was the direct cost of carrying on the war. The Allies spent about two-thirds of the money used to buy arms, food, ammunition and other war materials. During the first three years of the First World War the fighting nations spent about $US85, 000 every minute. That does not seem much today but in 1913 it was a tremendous amount. The world spends now $1m every minute just on preparation for war. None of the figures I have cited includes the additional loss to the economy of the suffering and the crippling, the billions of dollars needed to pay interest on war debts and the pensions paid to veterans and their families. About $8 of every $10 spent in the war came from borrowed money. We all know that this had to be paid back. We are still paying back war debts from the First World War.

In the Second World War, 62 million people died. Military action in the front line and civilian losses amounted to 57,542,000 people dead. Between 4.5 million and six million Jews were killed in that war. War is not only the great thief of life and everything around us; it also enables cruel, inhumane people in our society to perpetrate the greatest injustices on other people. It brings out the worst in men and women. People were killed through no fault of their own, simply because they wanted to follow a different religion. The great holocaust the Jewish population in Europe experienced in the Second World War was just unbelievable. Up to six million Jewish people died for no reason. They were tortured and shot. Everything despicable that one could imagine happened to them . But this behaviour does not stop at Germany. In every country there are people who, if they are allowed to be cruel and inhumane to other people, will be like that.

In latter time we have had the actions of Pol Pot in Kampuchea. He murdered over five million of his own people simply because they disagreed with his political views. They had other views, so he saw fit to butcher them. We also have the inhumanity which exists in South Africa because people have a different colour of skin. Some people there have no rights or very little rights. Without much ado they are gaoled and then thrown out of windows or many other despicable things happen to them. War is not just war. It brings out the worst in people. People should realise just how terrible war is. We must all get together and work out the ways of peace. If we can have peace we will have a better world and a world that will be meaningful and purposeful. Since World War II there have been 130 or so wars. Thirty million people have died. As I have said, many people have been butchered by Pol Pot. I repeat that 30 million people have perished since the Second World War in the 130 wars which have occurred mainly in Third World countries.

Today there is a conflict between Argentina and Britain. If one says anything against that war in the general community one is branded as a communist, a traitor or something else. This war really need not have happened. I could say that the British have done a magnificent job and that we should resist aggression. A great speech could be made on that. If one were on the Argentinian side one could make a speech saying that the Argentinians have rights, that the Falkland Islands were stolen from them and they have a right to get them back. A person living on the Falkland Islands could also make a great speech for his cause, saying that he has a right to live in freedom. All these things are correct. But eventually this war will have to be resolved around the conference table. In the meantime thousands of people-good, young, men and women-are dying for no reason. I predict that eventually Argentina will take over the Falkland Islands after agreements have been made through the United Nations by Britain and other countries. We will once again forget that many thousands of people's lives have been sacrificed for this cause. There is also the financial cost of the war. All the ships sunk and all the aeroplanes lost will have to be replaced because we simply cannot trust each other any longer. That is a great tragedy.

After the Second World War man was not satisfied. He had to go ahead and build bigger and better weapons. The atomic weapon had come into being. Today we have sufficient atomic weapons to eliminate all mankind ten times over. I do not know why that is necessary because we can only die once. Since the Second World War mankind has spent on the preparation of war, on the war machine, $6,000 billion. A staggering $500 billion was spent in 1980 alone. Today over $1m is spent every minute on defence. Yet the world faces starvation in many areas. One-quarter of the world's population will go to bed hungry tonight. One billion people live in ignorance because they are not educated. Yet 0.5 per cent of the amount spent on arms would pay for all the farm equipment needed to make the food deficient countries self-sufficient by 1990. Doctors also should be aware of what is going on. About $1 billion a day goes down the drain on the military costs when half of the world's population has no clean water, a quarter goes to bed hungry and 300 million people are unemployed. An investment equivalent to five hours of the world's military budget was enough to eradicate smallpox. That was a magnificent thing. We can eliminate all the disease and all the bad things in the world today.

As my time is limited, I must get back to the necessity of doing something about eliminating war. I believe that politicians will not be the ones who will stop war. Given what has happened in the past, I do not believe that we can really trust the politicians of this world to stop war. There will always be some excuse for them to wave the flag and beat the drum. The United Nations, churches or organisations such as that are not capable of stopping war. Even though they try in good faith, I do not believe it is possible for them to do so . The masses of people throughout this world are the only ones capable of bringing some sense to the politicians and the leaders of this world. It is only when the people take to the streets-not only in this country but also in every other country-and demand peace that a better world will be brought about.

I was amazed to read what Mr Fraser said when he was away. He launched a scathing attack on the international peace movement. He criticised churches and women's groups supporting recent big anti-nuclear protests. This will be going on. Anyone who really believes in peace will be called a communist, a betrayer of his country, disloyal, and all the other bad terms. In countries which have dictatorships, people will be gaoled, bashed and shot. But I believe that people in all types of countries will take to the streets and demand peace, under whatever type of government.

Much suffering will be caused. I believe that the Vietnam war was stopped because of people. This mad race to destruction by the world's powers, building bigger and better bombs, can be stopped only by people. I believe that the people of the world will stop this. I encourage people to do that. It is the only way in which we can survive. There is no other way that mankind can continue. We have left it to politicians and organisations for far too long. I believe that the people will have their say, and that we shall have a better world in which to live.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — I should like to use the opportunity presented by this first reading debate ro raise a voice of caution and of moderation in the emotional argument that is raging at present over the Falkland Islands with respect to equipment for the Australian defence forces. I certainly caution the Government on making an ad hoc reaction with respect to any major equipment purchases at present, particularly in responding to the intemperate claims by some of the past admirals who have been so vocal in the Press this week, with their calls for two or three carriers and an unbalanced force structure of that nature. It is rather as if we are moving back 20 or 30 years, instead of looking at the next 20 years, when the major equipment that we are buying now will be employed.

SPEECH.PARA: The argument is not on the level that something might be useful; it is on a matter of priority. We have limited resources in Australia. What we want in the defence forces of Australia, as I have said repeatedly in this chamber, is a deterrent capacity in the first instance and a capacity to provide for a flexible response to a wide variety of situations in which we may become involved and which we cannot foresee in detail at present.

The argument at present largely turns about HMS Invincible, or HMAS Australia as it will be in a few months time. I support both the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Minister for Defence (Mr Sinclair) when they make their statements regarding the use of this ship in Australian service as an anti- submarine platform. One can make a cogent case for the ship in that role. But it is an entirely different matter to be looking at fixed-wing aircraft and to move down the line of a major equipment involvement in amphibious warfare on the grounds of a wildly stated argument. The case must be developed, and there is a long way to go yet before the case is proven.

While on the subject of wild arguments, I am curious about the way in which the Australian Labor Party has suddenly discovered defence. After all these years, from the time under the tree of knowledge in Barcaldine, it has now discovered that defence is an issue. During the four years in which I have been in this chamber, I cannot recall one respectable or responsible speech from the Labor Party, in either House, on this subject. The only advice that I would give Mr Hayden for his next Press conference is that it is not a matter of saying to the Australian people what the ALP will do if it ever gets into government. The task for the Labor Party is to take some advice from the professionals in Australia and around the world, not to dream up a few policies in Caucus and then run matters that seem to have some support in the Press at the time. It is quite a serious business, and it is far more complex than the Labor Party realises.

Let me move back to the lessons of the Falkland Islands war. It is impossible for us yet to be able to look in any way at those in any completeness. The point I make this afternoon is that the lessons that we learn from that relate to weapons technology, not to geography. Yet so many people, some of them quite mature and experienced, have fallen into the trap of seeing the Falkland Islands war in relation to geography. They see it as being the next war that Australia will fight, or something similar to that, and from there they move on to seeing that we need exactly the same equipment as is required for the Falklands Islands operation. Nothing could be further from the truth. It is no more true for Australia to draw parallels out of the operations in the Falkland Islands, in one sense, than it is to say that Vietnam presaged the Falkland Islands war or that Korea presaged what happened in the Malaysian Emergency. Let us learn the immediate lessons from the Falkland Islands. There are a few which need to be reinforced now.

It is true that Australia has island responsibilities. One can think of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands and Christmas Island in the Indian Ocean, and the many islands in the South West Pacific area in which we have essential interests. But the important point is that our involvement there is quite different from Britain's involvement in the Falkland Islands in a whole variety of ways. The distances involved, though considerable, are considerably less than the distance of Port Stanley from London. The climatic conditions are different, and the whole political and military environment is quite different in the Pacific region from what is in the Falkland Islands.

Let us look quickly at the Cocos Islands. To me, there is probably no more important Australian possession than the Cocos Islands. It is very important to us from a defence point of view in relation to the Indian Ocean and to all our trade from Europe. If the Cocos Islands were threatened, would we really round up crews in Sydney, take three or four days to get some ships together, sail around the Australian coast and into the Indian Ocean-probably taking at least 10 days from the time that they slipped in Sydney-and then try an opposed landing? It took the British over seven weeks before they were in a position to do that in the Falklands. I wonder how many more weeks it would take us to mount a similar operation in the Cocos Islands. Of course we shall not do that.

My hope is that, if faced with a threat to the Cocos Islands, our intelligence services would be good enough to advise us in advance. When something was brewing, we could move in an element of the rapid deployment force from Townsville, maybe at brigade strength, and get the men on the ground in possession in advance of any trouble arising. It is possible by air movement to do the whole thing within 20 hours at the outside. If the runway on Cocos is seized, that just illustrates the importance to Australia of having a parachute brigade, which we do not have at present. This is something that we could have at very low cost, because some infantry battalions could be converted, maintained and equipped as parachute battalions at a cost of $2m a year per unit . Compared with the hundreds of millions of dollars involved in more sophisticated transport or fighting vehicles, for both the air force and the navy, that is a very cheap and very flexible weapons system.

I come to the point that prevention in these cases is very much better than cure, and not only prevention but also a reaction time is essential, because it saves both lives and money. I have no idea what the cost of the Falkland Islands operation is, but it is reported in today's Press that the Royal Navy now has 100 ships on station around the Falkland Islands. Taking a very conservative figure of $100m per ship, that is $10 billion, in ships, around those islands. Add to that the equipment with them and one has probably a figure of about $15 billion. That is a sum that Australia cannot afford. Putting it in perspective, the sort of force with which we might be faced, if the Cocos Islands were taken, could well number 4,000 or 5,000 men, the same force structure numerically as is in the Falkland Islands. Quite obviously, it would be beyond Australia to mount an operation that cost $10 billion or $15 billion on equipment.

One other great lesson that comes out of the Falkland Islands operation relates to a point that I have made repeatedly over the years in which I have been in this chamber. That is that we have been living for years in a missile age. In the past I have spoken-I shall not go into the subject in detail now-of the inability of the Royal Australian Navy to appreciate fully the potentialities of missile technology. The simple fact is that the initiative lies strongly with the attacker at present.

In relation to the Falklands Islands, it is premature to judge the missile war there. I must take this public opportunity to say that I have been misled insofar as the appreciations I have made, even though they were made very sanguinely, of the Royal Navy's missile capability. I really did believe it had a higher capability in the surface-to-air missile role than it seems to have; but we do not know the full story yet. One of the things that we do not know is whether those ships were fitted out with the weapons that they were designed to have. I have a suspicion that quite a large number of the ships that were lost were not fitted out in the way the designers intended them to be. If that is true, it is quite inexcusable. I think the proposition that Royal Navy ships and Royal Australian Navy ships be crewed with admirals, public servants and politicians is an excellent one.

There may also be inherent design limitations in the missile systems that the ships in the Falklands war have. It is one thing to test systems on the range. It is totally different to test them in operational conditions at war. Local conditions such as the environment, temperature and even the disposition of the ships themselves in a constricted waterway such as there is in the Falklands could have operated against the detection of incoming aircraft and the operational mode of the weapons. But they are all matters for a future debate and I do not wish to canvass them now.

The immediate lesson for us is the vulnerability of high value targets to missiles. It is absolutely irrelevant whether those targets are on land or at sea. In the Falklands dispute they happen to be at sea but they could just as well be on land. The Royal Navy has paid a tragic price in the Falklands, having lost at least five ships. Even if we accept the Royal Navy's figure of 50 or 60 Argentinian aircraft destroyed, it must be remembered that they are all old aircraft with only one pilot in each. I assume that the Royal Navy lost in one ship as many men as the whole of the Argentinian Air Force lost, without getting involved in an argument about the relative capital cost involved.

The final immediate lesson we draw from the operations in the Falklands in an immediate sense is the unpredictability of it all. We cannot foresee when our defence forces will be required. We must have an instant response capability, and that is particularly relevant to Australia because of our isolated geographic position. The full story has yet to be told. I do not doubt that many complex lessons are to be learned from it. But let us learn those immediate lessons that I have been talking about and for the longer term let us get our priorities right with respect to major equipment purchases bearing in mind the full story which will come out at a later date.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to use this first reading debate to speak on the state of the economy because, like many other Australians , I am concerned at the direction in which the Fraser Government's economic policies are taking this country. More importantly, I am concerned at the effect these policies are having on the tax paying wage and salary earners of Australia and the lack of compassion being shown by Ministers of this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Over the last nine months we have witnessed a massive slowing down of the Australian economy; so much so that the Treasurer (Mr Howard) had to revise the Budget's growth rate estimate from 3 1/2 per cent to somewhere between 2 per cent and 2 1/2 per cent. This recession which is gripping Australia is illustrated quite clearly by the latest production figures. Raw steel production is down by 15 1/2 per cent, pig iron production is down by 12 1/2 per cent and clay brick production is down by 9.4 per cent over the levels achieved in 1981. Even the Metal Trades Industry Association has predicted that 1982 and 1983 will be difficult years for the metal and engineering industries, as a direct result of lower levels of investment in those industries. In addition, we have recently seen the gloomy predictions of organisations like the Confederation of Australian Industry, the Bank of New South Wales and the National Bank of Australasia. Surveys conducted by these organisations have not only confirmed the severe downturn which has occurred in the Australian manufacturing sector but also they have revealed a tremendous amount of pessimism about the period ahead.

Of course, this Government has chosen to blame everything on the international economic scene and refuses to admit that its policies are in any way to blame. And yet, these are the very same people who said in 1975 that it was not good enough to put all the blame for the economic slowdown at that time on the international oil crisis which occurred in 1974. Another important indicator of the state of the economy is the level of retail sales, which is now increasing at a rate less than the rate of inflation. In other words, the real level of retail sales is declining as a direct result of this Goverment's economic policies. The reason for this is simply that ordinary Australians are just not able to cope with their day to day living expenses, which have snowballed in the last 18 months. Higher interest rates, higher State charges, higher local government rates, higher health insurance costs and higher sales taxes on a whole range of items have taken money out of the pockets and purses of 90 per cent of Australians. All this is a direct result of the restrictive monetary policies of the Fraser Government.

Now let us look at the logic, or should I say lack of it, behind these policies . As Mr Howard has told us so many times and as Senator Messner reminded us recently, this Government believes that the only way to cure inflation is to restrict the growth of the money supply. In other words, what it is saying is that the only way of curing inflation is to increase the level of unemployment because, let there be no mistake about it, this is what restricting the money supply is all about. That is why Great Britain under its warmonger Prime Minister, Mrs Thatcher, now has record unemployment and that is why unemployment in the United States of America under the command of its second rate ex-movie star President, Mr Reagan, has reached over 9 per cent.

Only last week, the Australian Bureau of Statisatics revealed that over one million Australians are now out of work. This consists of the 435,000 who are listed as officially unemployed and the other 619,000 people who the Bureau says want a job but have given up all hope of ever finding one. In other words, the true unemployment rate is somewhere around 16 per cent. The fact that official unemployment is now running at a level much higher than for the same period last year is due in no small way to the Fraser Government's economic policies. The way things are shaping up, I would not be surprised if we had an official unemployment rate in excess of 8 per cent or even as high as 9 per cent by February of next year with the actual rate, including the hidden unemployed, around 20 per cent.

Despite all this, the Government has not been able to reduce the rate of inflation very significantly at all. In fact, inflation has already burst back into double figures and it is approaching the 12 per cent mark largely because of the pressure of higher taxation and government induced price increases. So much for sound economic management, but I suppose this is the sort of thing we can expect from a man who says that you do not have to practice economics to be a Treasurer.

This Government's miserable record of economic management is perhaps best illustrated by measuring its achievements against the promises it made at the last election. In 1980, the Fraser Government promised to provide jobs for all, to reduce interest rates, reduce the tax burden, reduce inflation and maintain wage indexation. The facts are that since 1980, unemployment has increased, interest rates have increased, taxes, both direct and indirect, have increased, the inflation rate has increased and wage indexation has been abandoned. So much for Mr Fraser's election promises.

The result of all this has been that the ordinary working men and women of Australia are now struggling for survival and many have been forced to sell their homes because of the sky-rocketing cost of house mortgage repayments. Many others have just given up hope of ever owning their own home or even saving up enough money for a deposit on one. What's more, many families have had to stop buying meat and other food items which have now become luxuries for many households. One of the reasons this has happened of course is that personal income taxes have increased by over 22 per cent in the last 12 months. At the same time, the richest 10 per cent of the population, the millionaire friends of Mr Fraser and his Ministry, together with many large multinational corporations, are evading tax to the tune of $7,000m a year. The ordinary law-abiding taxpayers of this country are absolutely sick and tired of having to support these rich criminals. They simply cannot go on carrying this burden and paying out all of their salaries on day to day living costs.

I think it is very clear that the Ministers of this Government have absolutely no idea of what it is like to be forced to struggle for daily existence. They have no compassion at all for the plight of ordinary working and middle class Australians. This came across loud and clear last week when Senator Messner presented the Government's argument on the Supply Bills. This Government has the audacity to criticise trade unions for seeking higher wages for their members, while it never says a thing about the massive increases in the salaries of executives, doctors and lawyers, not to mention politicians! Who can blame workers for wanting more money in the present economic climate? Who can blame the 25 per cent of workers who have not had a pay increase since the end of wage indexation for wanting a pay increase? The fact is that unless something positive is done soon we will face massive social upheaval and unrest in this country.

We have to stop the likes of Fraser, Howard and Stone from ruining the economy and lowering the living standards of ordinary Australians. All is not all right as Senator Messner tried to tell us last week. It is a fact that the Fraser Government's economic policies have caused a massive increase in unemployment and a huge increase in the incidence of poverty in Australia. They have also caused a massive increase in the tax burden on those Australians lucky enough to have jobs and high interest rates have killed off the housing industry in this country and ruined the dream of many Australian families. This Government's economic policies have increased the gap between the rich and poor and day by day an increasing number of concerned Australians are learning not to trust this tired old Government with its tired old Ministers, saying the same tired old things. It is about time the Ministers of this Government stopped tripping overseas and visited some ordinary suburban homes in Australia and saw at first hand how people are struggling.

A number of things need to be done if we are to get rid of the excessive levels of unemployment, poverty and financial hardship in the community. Firstly, the Government must immediately provide income tax cuts to ease the strain on wage and salary earners and in so doing give a much needed boost to retail sales. This sort of stimulus could flow through the economy and help revitalise our ailing manufacturing industries. It needs to be a significant and lasting reduction in taxes and not just a carrot to be dangled in front of people as an election gimmick, as we have seen in the past. In addition to this, the Government should provide a boost in public works programs, which could also help to stimulate activity in the private sector, particularly in the building and construction sector which is at such a low ebb in most parts of Australia. At the same time there needs to be an easing of the money supply so that interest rates can be brought back to more reasonable levels. This would not only stimulate the home building industry but ease the financial burden for thousands of Australian home buyers. As a result of this there would be an added boost to retail sales with the resultant stimulus flowing through the economy and providing more employment opportunities.

Finally, we urgently need a return to a centralised wage fixing system so that some order can be brought back into the industrial relations scene. It is a fact that since wage indexation was abolished industrial disputation has increased dramatically. Between August and November 1981, 2.02 million working days were lost due to industrial disputes compared to 1.04 million for the same period in 1980. That is an increase of 100 per cent. The absence of a centralised wage fixing system has quite clearly created a more turbulent industrial relations climate. This free-for-all situation that has developed since July 1981 has severely disadvantaged those workers who belong to the less powerful unions and created a lot of unnecessary hardship and ill feeling in the community. These measures that I have just outlined may not solve all our problems but at least they would help get the economy back on the rails. They would certainly go a lot closer to revitalising the Australian economy than the present Government's policies ever will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to urge upon the Government reform of what is commonly called double taxation of dividends. I am not the first to urge reform in this area. Advice was given to the Government by the Asprey Taxation Review Committee in 1975 which, unfortunately, was not accepted. More recently, advice was given by the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System which reported in September last year. That advice recommended reform, which advice has not yet been accepted. In the Budget planning context I think it is time, again, to urge reform in this particularly important area. I was heartened when, on 26 August last year, the Australian reported that the Treasurer (Mr Howard) had hinted to the Australian Institute of Directors that double taxation of dividends would soon be abolished. The report stated that Mr Howard was expected to make the move once the Campbell inquiry had reported. The report continued:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it is not known which way the inquiry will jump on the issue, but if a recommendation to abolish is not forthcoming it is thought the Government will act independently.

It is, of course, now history that the Government does not have to act independently, but has the solace of being able to lean upon the most comprehensive report into the Australian financial system yet carried out. Demands for reform in this area of taxation have been forthcoming for a long time. They have come from the stock exchanges and from such organisations as the Australian Industries Development Association, from business and from academics. Australia has what is referred to in the literature as the classical system of company taxation, that is, the corporation and its shareholders are treated as separate entities for taxation purposes. Corporations are taxed at the flat rate , now 46 per cent, on their income whether distributed or not. That part of the income, so taxed, when distributed to shareholders as, say, dividends, is again taxed in the hands of the recipient at the recipient's marginal rate. Thus, the distributed income is said to have been taxed twice.

Arguments against the classical system of company taxation are that it is logically indefensible, that it creates both horizontal and vertical inequities, that it is non-neutral or, as Asprey says, it is inefficient in that it distorts the allocation of investment between the corporate sector and the non-corporate sector, that it encourages corporations to rely too heavily on debt financing and to retain too great a share of net corporate income and, finally, that it depresses the nation's rate of capital accumulation and economic growth.

It is necessary briefly to examine these criticisms. The argument that the classical system is logically indefensible arises from the view that, for taxation purposes at least, a corporation is a form of entity through which income is earned by shareholders in the form of dividends or retained earnings. In the American terminology, the corporation is a conduit through which earnings pass on their way to shareholders-what they refer to as the 'conduit theory'. As was said by Campbell: 'Ultimately all taxes fall on individuals'. Therefore, whilst the corporation may be a separate legal entity for some purposes, there is no sound reason why it should be so for taxation purposes. As was said by the Asprey Committee, it is necessary to go behind the veil of separate legal personality which the company enjoys and translate the tax formerly imposed on company income into a set of individual tax 'burdens'. Certainly when one assesses the impact of so-called double tax it is necessary to determine the total tax on the particular source of income-that is, aggregate corporation tax plus the personal tax on distributions. Why not then integrate for the purpose of assessing the tax?

The second and most important criticism is that of inequity. The system as we have it does not provide horizontal equity in that two persons with the same income may not necessarily pay the same tax. Persons paying marginal tax of 46 per cent or less will nearly always bear an effective combined company personal income tax rate higher than their marginal income tax rate. So two persons receiving the same income-say, one from a corporate investment and one from a partnership investment-may not pay the same tax from the fruits of their investment. It fails also on the ground of vertical equity in that, as incomes rise, the recipient does not pay directly proportionally more tax. Asprey found that the system 'substantially defeats the general progressivity of the income tax'.

The Campbell Committee more recently found that the degree of over-taxation- that over the marginal rate-diminishes as the shareholder's income rises. To the extent that progressivity lessens the system becomes regressive. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table from the Campbell report showing excess tax payable by shareholders under the present classical system of corporation tax at various salary levels.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The third criticism of our current system is that of its non-neutrality and in particular that it distorts the allocation of investment between the corporate sector and the non-corporate sector. An accepted objective of taxation policy is that the form in which a business is operated should not be influenced by taxation consequences. As was stated by Asprey the over-taxation of the profit entitlement of shareholders creates a bias against their doing business in corporate form, although the under-taxation of other shareholders creates the opposite bias. The bias against lower income investors in equity investments, and the declining presence of the individual in the equity market, is not regarded by the stock exchanges and others as a coincidence, it being suggested that taxation factors have influenced the trend. It is said that now only 4 per cent of Australians directly own equity shares. Campbell considers it important that all sectors of the community be given equal encouragement to participate directly as equity holders in companies and accepted that the system has discouraged low income investors from that direct participation.

SPEECH.PARA: Further, under the head of non-neutrality it is said that the classical system encourages corporations to rely too heavily on debt financing in that, in determining the taxation income of the company, interest on monies borrowed may be deducted but not for dividends paid on equity capital. As was recognised by Campbell, it may also give companies an incentive to adopt higher gearing ratios than might otherwise be deemed appropriate, at times exposing such companies to greater financial risk. To some extent, and in balance, is the bias in favour of retaining earnings, as undistributed profits will attract less tax. This in itself is an additional example of the non- neutrality of the classical system. I know it can be said that larger retained profit might normally be associated with greater ability to carry out investment programs; but, on the other hand, economists will argue that it is particularly important to encourage profitable investment rather than any investment. Therefore, finance should be made to flow towards those companies which are most profitable-that is often those which are able to pay highest dividends. This is distorted negatively by a lack of a capital tax and positively by Division 7 tax on underdistribution by private companies. With these various distortions and conflicting economic principles, it is not therefore surprising that Asprey concluded that neutrality is the best practical test.

Fourthly, and somewhat encompassing the previous mentioned criticisms, it is said that the system depresses the nation's rate of capital accumulation and economic growth. As was stated in a paper 'Reform of the Corporation Tax' by Geoffrey Board: 'Investors in general decide where to invest their capital on the basis of after tax rates of return'. Because the overall burden of taxation is higher on capital income generated in the corporate sector, investors are induced to allocate their capital to non-corporate areas. Also the Australian Associated Stock Exchanges argue that the combined effects of high company tax and high rates of personal income tax with no relief for company tax paid have turned the individual investor away from the equity market to other forms of investment such as property and fixed interest securities which enjoy more favourable tax treatment. They argue that this lack of neutrality in the present tax structure has thus further undermined interest in the share market, the level of share prices, the liquidity and efficiency of the market, and the ability of companies to raise new equity funds.

It is therefore not surprising that the call for reform in the area is almost unanimous. The call is for closer integration between the tax liability of companies and their shareholders. No significant change in the taxation system can be implemented without some pain. The inertia against significant change in the system is enormous as was witnessed in the indirect tax debate last year. To talk simply of a value added tax or a retail sales tax let alone a general expenditure tax seems to send shudders up the bureacratic spine which regrettably sometimes are adopted by its political masters. Nevertheless, in this instance, government has the advice of Asprey, the advice of Campbell and the experience of the many countries throughout the world that have now implemented at least partial integration of corporate and individual tax. There would appear to be little justification for Australia to continue to lag behind.

There are two accepted methods of achieving the objective. The first is the split rate system where an allowance is made at the company level. In other words, distributed profits are taxed at a lower rate than retained profits. Some countries to adopt such a method include Austria, Finland, West Germany, Japan and Norway. The second is the imputation method where allowance is made at the shareholder level for company tax on distributed profits. The shareholder receives credit for part of the corporation tax paid on distributed profits which is levied at the same rate as on retained profits. This system has been adopted in varying forms in France, Ireland, Italy, United Kingdom, Belgium, Canada and Turkey. Asprey recommended a system of partial imputation not dissimilar to that in operation in Canada. At the time of the report, the Canadian system was that an individual shareholder was entitled to a tax credit of one-third-now I believe one-half-of a dividend received.

Asprey recognised also that, in the longer term, there was a need to go to a more complicated system such as that in existence in the United Kingdom. From 1973, the United Kingdom imputation system provided for a higher rate of corporate tax but that distribution to basic rate taxpayers would not cause extra tax.

Campbell has been much more ambitious. The Campbell committee has recommended that the Government should work towards the introduction of a system of full integration of company and personal tax. No country has yet proceeded as far as full integration although to recommend it is not new. In 1966 the Carter Commission in Canada recommended full integration, as did the Mead Committee in the United Kingdom in 1978. Campbell suggests that an administratively suitable scheme could involve tax being collected from companies at the corporate tax rate and credited against the personal tax liability of shareholders, whose taxation income would include the share of the pre-tax income of the company, that is, the share of both dividends received, and retained earnings grossed up to include the tax withheld by the company.

Implementation of such a scheme would impose significant challenges. It must be stressed, however, that the proposal is not novel. The trend clearly is towards integration. When one looks at the partly integrated systems of France, the United Kingdom, West Germany, Canada and others and reads various academic reports that have recommended it, there is much comfort in saying that now is the time for change. Australia's corporate tax system was introduced in 1940 as a war time revenue measure. It is now in need of reform. There is no better time to introduce that reform than in the forthcoming Budget.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —A comprehensive debate on housing and housing finance took place earlier today in the Senate but I would like to refer to those who can neither 'borrowers nor lenders be' but who are totally dependent upon the Western Australian State Government for housing. I refer to homeless Aboriginal families in crisis in Western Australia. Some of these families are in dire need. They are priority cases and they are acknowledged to be so by the State housing authorities. Many of these families have waited for months and are still waiting for housing. I have been assured by people who are knowledgeable in the field of emergency housing in Western Australia-this is the the disgraceful and repugnant aspect of the problem-that non-Aboriginal families with similar case histories would have been accommodated long ago.

SPEECH.PARA: I should like to refer to four examples from the many of which I am aware. I refer to the case of Elizabeth Jackamarra on whose behalf I approached the State Minister for Housing last year. Many of my colleagues in the State had already approached the Minister for Housing on her behalf. She has two small children. One is a toddler whom she has with her and the other is a four-year old child who is fostered. This woman has no home for herself and her children and, as is customary in Western Australia, a child has been taken away from her and will not be returned until she has a home. Elizabeth lives with another family which has four children. Rose Shaw, another supporting mother with two children, lives in the same house. Her children periodically are institutionalised and frequently have to attend hospital. Her estranged husband visits and creates disturbances at regular intervals. Many letters from the Princess Margaret Hospital for Children support this woman's plea for housing. Both of those women live in a home at Innaloo. That particular home now is a shelter for three families comprising four adults and seven children. The people who are the nominal renters of the home are frightened of eviction. They will be evicted because of overcrowding. Eviction notices have been served in similar circumstances.

Another example is the case of Mr Quentin Colbung who lives at Mount Barker with his wife and three children. He has been sick and is unemployed. He has fallen into rental arrears and has been evicted from his side of a duplex house. He has moved in next door, to the other side of the duplex, with his aged parents, both of whom are sick. One is an epileptic and one has suffered from tuberculosis. That part of the duplex is now overcrowded and all are being threatened with eviction, despite the fact that the side of the house in which the Colbung juniors originally lived is still vacant.

I refer now to the case of Mrs Barbara Taylor who lives at Wundowie, a country town approximately 50 miles east of Perth. She has been threatened with eviction because she is housing her cousins, the Garletts and their four children. Mr Garlett has been unemployed and has been listed by the State Housing Commission for emergency accommodation since November 1981. Mrs Taylor has five children of her own.
