Her children of school age are attending the Wundowie school at present . Wundowie is a country town which recently experienced the failure of a major local industry. This has meant an exodus of many residents who have sought employment elsewhere. This means that there are many houses vacant in the town, one of which could surely be utilised to house the Garletts. If Mrs Taylor is evicted-this is what she fears will happen-she will go to live with her sister who lives in Perth in a two-bedroom State Housing Commission home. Of course, her sister will then be liable to be threatened with eviction because of overcrowding.

The number of families in Western Australia on the Aboriginal housing list was 700 in October 1981. No building program is in existence and the number of people on that list must have increased since then. There has been no significant increase in the welfare rental housing stock in Western Australia over the last couple of years. The insecurity of these families and the fact that they have to move from one relative to another has very severe implications for their health and for their children's education. The incidence of learning difficulties and of minor and major illnesses is compounded by the housing problem. As they move from one school to another the educational chances of the children are jeopardised.

Representations have been made repeatedly to the State Minister for Housing by Federal and State politicians on behalf of these people and other people in the same position. The response, in some cases, has been to list people for emergency housing. We have found that six months later they still have not been housed. In October last year, in desperation, the social work department of the Western Australian Trades and Labour Council wrote to the Commissioner for Community Relations and detailed 12 such cases. The matter has been taken up by the Commissioner with the State Minister. The result has been that action has been held up on some eviction notices which had been issued but the people concerned have no idea of the State Government's intentions. A letter from the social work department of the Trades and Labour Council to the Commissioner for Community Relations stated:

As well, the involvement of the Minister for Housing, the State Ombudsman and the Consultative Committee on Racial Discrimination was often sought. Our Office has been informed that submissions to the State Ombudsman are the only means by which decisions of the Commission can be reviewed-and yet there has been a failure by the Ombudsman to take up the issues such as (i) listing families with the A.H.B. (ii) the 'saturation' policy which prevents the housing of more than 2 Aboriginal families to a block of flats (iii) the policy of approaching Shire Councils before a housing allocation is made to an Aboriginal family to check whether the neighbours on both sides are purchasing homes (iv) the A.H.B. do not control any flat accommodation. It is our understanding that these policies are Cabinet directives, and that while the officers of the State Housing Commission are generally sympathetic to families, they are bound to carry out these racist directives, however reluctantly. The denial of access to the Commonwealth-State funded programmes has been combined with the rundown of the building programs of A.H.B. houses.
The Aboriginal Housing Board, because of the lack of resources, have stated that they cannot meet emergency requirements, and yet families in the most urgent need,-
Families such as those to which I have referred-

often unemployed, with sick and often institutionalized children are referred by the Commission to the Board for accommodation, which at present numbers on the lists means that they must wait years, if they are to be accommodated at all.

Both the Staff of the Aboriginal Housing Board and officers of the State Housing Commission are generally accessible and sympathetic to the plight of these families. However, the policies laid down by the Cabinet restrict their flexibility in housing families in crisis situations.

The State Minister has responded on various occasions and has said that all those people to whom I have referred have been housed before. That is not so. Some of them were housed until their families broke up. In the event of two Aboriginal parents in Western Australia separating, their children are removed to institutions or to foster homes. Families are not reunited until the mothers are housed. Mothers are not housed unless they have their children with them. This is a classic Catch-22 situation. Despite its best efforts, the Office of the Commissioner for Community Relations has yet to receive any indication from Western Australia that the housing problems of these families are on the way to resolution. A 1981 report from the Office of the Commissioner for Community Relations entitled 'Discrimination against Aboriginals in Western Australia' gives examples of the attitude of the Western Australian Government to discrimination on the ground of race. Page 8 of that report states:

. . . the Western Australian Government has adopted a position of non- cooperation with the Commissioner for Community Relations that has called into question the applicability of Commonwealth law to Western Australia. In a letter dated 23 May 1980 the Hon. W. R. B. Hassel wrote to the Commissioner for Community Relations:
'The Government of the State of Western Australia is not a matter over which you have, or ought to have, the slightest jurisdiction' . . .

Quite apart from its intransigence and its racially biased housing policies, the Western Australian Government shows itself again to the nation and to the world as harsh, punitive and lacking in compassion. We in Western Australia endlessly hear about Aboriginal family inadequacy and about delinquency and alcoholism. On the other hand we also hear about the need for people to be responsible for their own health and well-being. Such high-sounding sentiments are pious and platitudinous coming from those who have in it their power to provide such a basic essential as adequate housing and who decline to do so on the basis of the colour of the skin of the client. The Western Australian Government should be urged to review immediately its Aboriginal housing policies. It should be provided with sufficient funds from Commonwealth sources, to the point at which there is simply no excuse for denying housing to anybody in need. Another publication of the Commissioner for Community Relations, dated November/January 1982, states:
In the absence of any positive action by the State government in Western Australia there is an urgent need to develop the educational aspect of complaint handling work.
I suggest that the development of the educational aspect should start with the State Cabinet.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
OFF-SHORE INSTALLATIONS (MISCELLANEOUS AMENDMENTS) BILL 1982

This Bill is the main part of a package of Bills to extend taxing and control laws to rigs used in exploring or exploiting the non-living natural resources of the seabed of Australia's continental shelf.
The package includes provisions extending the control and taxing aspects of customs, excise and sales tax Acts and the controls available under immigration and quarantine laws.

For Constitutional reasons, amendments proposed to be made to the various taxing Acts will be the subject of separate Bills in the package. Certain collection and control provisions associated with those taxing provisions are, however, included in this Bill.

Honourable Senators, it has been the Government's long-standing policy that the treatment to be accorded these off-shore activities should be no different, in principle, from the treatment accorded similar resources ventures being undertaken within Australia.

The petroleum exploration and recovery activities taking place in Bass Strait and elsewhere around Australia for upwards of 15 years have been governed by the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967. In that period, the only extension to off- shore activities of Commonwealth law outside the ambit of that Act was the application in 1968 of relevant income tax legislation.

These measures have now become necessary as a result of developments on the north-west shelf of Western Australia. The previous practice was for all overseas sourced rigs, ships, equipment and materials for the off-shore operations to be imported in the normal way through Australian ports.
The massive scale of the north-west shelf developments, however, requires that a number of giant platforms be brought direct to the places on the shelf at which they are to operate.

During the operation of the rigs there will necessarily be a constant flow of service craft, personnel and goods between the installations and the Australian mainland. There may be occasional movement between places overseas and an installation once attached.

It is essential that these important activities should not provide an avenue for the entry into Australia of prohibited imports such as drugs, of exotic diseases or of illegal immigrants. The Government attaches considerable importance to the maintenance of Australia's security in matters of customs, quarantine and immigration.

The package of Bills provides a proper legislative basis for the exercise of customs, excise, immigration and quarantine powers to remove any degree of danger of illicit activities at these remote sites. The powers are necessary both for the arrival of those installations and for subsequent contacts between the installations and places overseas.
Under the amendments proposed by the Bill, a person wishing to bring an installation direct from overseas to its operating site will be required to obtain prior permission.

Where permission is granted it will be subject to the applicant's compliance with specified conditions. The conditions will ensure that the arrival of the installation and its attachment will be supervised by officers until customs, immigration and quarantine clearance is given.

Generally, these Bills provide that installations attached to the Australian seabed will be deemed to be places in Australia. However the amendments to the Quarantine Act provide that an overseas installation shall be deemed to be part of Australia on attachment only if it has previously been given pratique. This will only be given if the Quarantine Officer on his prior inspection is satisfied that it is disease free.

By the device of treating installations as part of Australia, movement between the Australian mainland and installations which have been attached and cleared may be allowed to proceed without substantial hindrance. However quarantine controls may, if necessary, also be applied to this movement.

Contact between an attached installation and places overseas will be controlled . This means that anything which comes from overseas for delivery to an installation must first enter Australia through a first port of entry. At first ports of entry there are adequate facilities for the customs, immigration and quarantine examination of vessels and goods which would not generally be available at installations. Goods that are found to be a health risk can be treated or destroyed and prohibited imports can be seized.

The customs and quarantine amendments provide for goods from overseas to be permitted to be brought directly to an installation. This discretion is considered desirable to permit the operator of an installation to obtain goods quickly from overseas. Such goods might be mechanical parts which may be necessary to repair some equipment and which would not usually present a customs or health risk. The discretion will be used sparingly and as a general rule vessels will be required to first call at normal ports of entry.

The discretionary arrangements if used may present some risks of avoidance of controls. Accordingly, the Bill proposes provisions to give officers powers and functions that are, in respect of off-shore installations, equivalent to those now given to them by existing legislation in respect of vessels, goods and persons at points of entry into, or exit from, Australia.

Powers under the Immigration (Unauthorised Arrivals) Act 1980 now apply to certain ships when they enter Australian waters and to certain aircraft when they land in Australia. For the purposes of that Act, 'Australian waters' do not extend beyond the outer limits of the territorial sea. The powers under that Act will be extended to those ships when brought to an Australian installation outside Australian waters, as so defined, and to those aircraft that land at any Australian installation.

The powers I have mentioned include the power to board installations and search or examine them for goods on board for customs, immigration or quarantine purposes. If, for example, there are any goods on board which could carry disease to mainland Australia, these may be ordered into quarantine and treated or destroyed as appropriate. Prohibited imports may also be seized and customs control exercised over dutiable goods on board.

It is also necessary to ensure that there is proper authority for the application of the taxing provisions of customs, excise and sales tax law. This will be achieved by further Bills in this package.

A very important result of applying the customs laws to these operations will be the legislative protection of the right of Australian industry to share in the development opportunities to the same extent as now applies in relation to undertakings within Australia.

The granting of concessional by-laws in respect of equipment and materials manufactured outside Australia for use with off-shore installations will be dependent on suitable equivalent goods of Australian manufacture not being reasonably available.

By Parts VIII and IX of this Bill, which will amend Sales Tax Assessment Acts ( Nos. 1 and 5) 1930, together with a group of sales tax Bills that I will introduce shortly, it is also proposed to extend the application of the sales tax law to off-shore installations of the kind that I have earlier described.
In practice, the sales tax law in respect of the importation of goods is closely associated with the customs law.
Administrative efficiency in the collection of sales tax on importation of goods is achieved by giving a Collector of Customs power to collect sales tax at the same time as customs duty is collected.

Parts VIII and IX and the associated sales tax Bills will amend the sales tax law in conformity with the proposed amendments of the customs law, thereby achieving desirable uniformity in the application of these laws to off-shore installations and removing the scope for anomalies which could exist if the two laws operated differently. The amendments to both laws will have a common date of commencement.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT (OFF-SHORE INSTALLATIONS) BILL 1982
The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Customs Tariff Act 1966 as part of the package of Bills proposing extension of the Commonwealth taxing and control powers to off-shore operations.

The Bill proposes that an overseas installation, and goods on board, shall be deemed to be imported when the installation is attached to the Australian seabed . Where such an installation is first brought to a place in Australia from which it is to be taken for attachment to the seabed, the installation and goods on board are to be taken as imported on arrival of the installation at that place.

Goods brought direct from overseas on an installation are also to be deemed to be imported on their arrival. Likewise, goods taken from an installation to a place overseas are to be deemed to have been exported.
The Bill also proposes amendments to the Principal Act to identify when an installation is imported.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
CUSTOMS TARIFF (ANTI-DUMPING) AMENDMENT (OFF-SHORE INSTALLATIONS) BILL 1982
This Bill is part of the package of Bills proposing extension of the Commonwealth's taxing and control powers to off-shore operations.

The purpose of the Bill is to amend the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975 to ensure that an overseas installation that is attached to the Australian seabed, goods that are brought with an installation and goods subsequently brought direct from overseas to such an installation, receive the same treatment as regard anti-dumping measures as is accorded to equipment or goods imported into Australia in the normal way.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
EXCISE TARIFF AMENDMENT (OFF-SHORE INSTALLATIONS) BILL 1982
This Bill is part of the package of Bills proposing extension of the Commonwealth's taxing and control powers to off-shore operations.
The purpose of the Bill is to amend the Excise Tariff Act 1921 to extend the application of that Act to the production of excisable products at off-shore installations.

Under existing legislation petroleum products produced from off-shore wells are regarded as coming within the ambit of the Excise Acts when the product is brought to a shore-based installation at which subsequent processes are performed.

The proposed provisions will not result in variation of any present liability to excise duty. They, taken with a complementary amendment to the Excise Act 1901, will authorize excise officers to have access to installations and to examine processes and recording systems.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
SALES TAX AMENDMENT (OFF-SHORE INSTALLATIONS) BILLS (Nos 1 to 9) 1982
These Bills are a further part of the package of Bills to extend the application of certain controls and taxation measures to off-shore installations .
The sales tax Acts do not currently impose tax on transactions or acts involving goods which are outside geographical Australia but within the area of the continental shelf.

The measures proposed by these Bills, together with the associated measures contained in other Bills in this package, will have the effect that any off- shore installation will be given, from the date of its attachment to the continental shelf, the status of a place in Australia. This will mean that any transaction or act affecting goods on such an installation which would be taxable if the goods were in geographical Australia will, in future, also be taxable.

The amendments will apply to installations brought to the continental shelf directly from overseas and to installations taken there from Australia. They will apply to the latter whether or not the installations were themselves originally imported into Australia.

In their practical effect, the amendments will not subject to sales tax an installation itself insofar as it is for use in the mining industry in carrying out mining operations or in the treatment of products of those operations because such an installation is, in these circumstances, exempt from tax under other provisions.

However, certain attachments to or parts of an installation, for example, attachments or parts used for the comfort, entertainment or recreation of persons living on an installation could be subject to sales tax.
Attachments or parts of this kind which would be taxable include cinema equipment, inbuilt or fixed sporting equipment, floor coverings and kitchen equipment.
A memorandum containing more detailed explanations of the technical aspects of these Bills is being made available to honourable senators.
I commend these Bills to the Senate.
SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT (OFF-SHORE INSTALLATIONS) BILL 1982

This Bill to amend the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act 1935 is the last of the package of Bills designed to implement the proposal to extend the application of the Customs, excise, immigration, quarantine and sales tax laws to off-shore installations.
The amendments proposed by this Bill will have the same effect as, and will complement, the amendments proposed to be made by the Sales Tax Amendment (Off- shore Installations) Bills (Nos 1 to 9).
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having roamed, as is customary in a first reading debate, all over the compass, we now return, in the second reading debate, to the precise subject matter of this very large package of Bills concerned with off-shore installations. There are in fact 14 Bills in the package which deal with subjects as disparate as sales tax and quarantine. It is rather reminiscent of the Statute Law Revision Bills with their extraordinary miscellany of different subjects, but the important difference here is that a single theme unites all the Bills; that is, they apply to Australia's off-shore installations. Therefore it is appropriate that these Bills be dealt with together. The general purpose of the package, to the extent that one can identify anything so precise, is to ensure that the treatment of off-shore installations-by which I mean drilling platforms and rigs-is, for a variety of legislative purposes, the same as that accorded similar installations associated with resource ventures on Australian soil. A specific legislative impact is made by this package of Bills in the following areas: Customs, excise, sales tax, immigration and quarantine. The general effect of the Bills, if one can summarise it, is to deem that installations attached to the Australian seabed be regarded as places in Australia for these various legislative purposes so that the installations in question and the people associated with their operation attract the burdens and exemptions which attach to Australian soil-based installations.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition supports all these Bills for several reasons. Firstly, the principle that resource ventures on the Australian continental shelf should be undifferentiated for taxation, immigration and quarantine purposes from similar ventures on the continent is, of course, scarcely arguable. Equity, legislative effectiveness and the assertion of Australian sovereignty demand that result. In particular, as the incorporated second reading speech of the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) on the Off-shore Installations (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1982 states, this is in fact necessary to give legislative protection to the rights of Australian industry to share in the development opportunities off-shore in the same way as those rights exist on the continent of Australia.

Secondly, at least one specific development-that is, the huge expansion of exploration and production in the remote North West Shelf-has made these Bills necessary. Again, as the second reading speech on the main Bill in the package indicates, the practice in the past has been for all overseas-sourced rigs, ships, equipment and materials for off-shore operations to be imported through existing Australian ports, by virtue of which they attracted the application of the various Customs, quarantine, immigration and taxation laws. But now, however , in the context of the North West Shelf, the scale and location of those developments are such that rigs and goods associated with them are being brought direct to their operating locations without coming through Australian ports. This applies particularly to the giant production platforms of the Woodside project which it is proposed will be imported directly from Japan.

Thirdly-indicating why we support these measures as quite rational and sensible legislation-it is obvious that these more distant off-shore activities would provide rather splendid potential for the avoidance of various obligations and controls imposed by various substantive legislative codes which these Bills amend. I refer to such things as drug laws, laws with respect to exotic diseases and laws about illegal immigration. They are the kind of examples given by the Minister and they highlight the point in issue. There is also the question of avoidance of Customs and excise duties and sales tax which must, in the current climate of raging tax avoidance with which we are all unfortunately familiar, be regarded as something of a certainty unless the off-shore gaps are filled. Again this legislation seeks to do just that.

So much for all the nice things to say about the legislation; now for the qualifications. The first category of qualifications relates to some specific matters dealing with this legislation which were raised by my colleague Mr John Brown, the shadow Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs in the House of Representatives and which I need to refer to again only briefly. The first such qualification relates to the need in practice-whatever the legislation might say -for adequate surveillance facilities and personnel to ensure that the various objectives I have referred to relating to the protection against people avoiding various legal obligations are in fact achieved.

Legislation here, as elsewhere, is likely to be quite useless unless adequate enforcement machinery is established on the ground. Here I suppose one must say 'on the sea'. A further specific point relates to the manifest inadequacy of a number of the penalties provided for in this massive legislative provision. We in the Opposition record a protest here, as we did recently in regard to the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill dealing with the transfer pricing method of international tax avoidance. The penalties in many instances seem quite inadequate having regard to the financial magnitude of the operations involved, the potential benefits which are involved to participants in those projects, the difficulties of an obvious kind of surveillance and also the seriousness of some of the kinds of avoidance or potential avoidance of obligations which are here involved. Mr Brown, the member for Parramatta, gave some illustrations of that in his speech in the other place, and I do not think there is any need to reiterate them here.

So far as specific qualifications are concerned, I refer again to the particular problem of Customs control, a problem which was highlighted recently by the notorious Moore-MacKellar affair and by what that affair brought to light about maladministration and staff shortages within the Bureau of Customs. Clearly legislative sanctions, legislative controls, are not going to amount to a row of beans in the context of these off-shore installations, as elsewhere, unless the legislation is matched by detailed attention to practical operational effectiveness. Perhaps more importantly than any of these kinds of qualifications, I want to take the occasion of the appearance of these Bills to emphasise that our support of them is not to be taken as indicating the faintest weakening of our opposition to the so called off-shore settlement-the coastal waters legislation, the off-shore sovereignty legislation-which was passed by this Parliament in 1980 in the purported exercise of legislative authority, to some extent conferred upon the Commonwealth under section 51 (xxxviii) of the Constitution. On the contrary, the Australian Labor Party remains as implacably opposed as ever to that settlement and the abdication of the Commonwealth sovereignty over coastal waters and the seabed which it involved. I shall say a little more about that matter in a moment.

I point out that these Bills do not amount to anything more by way of an abdication of Commonwealth sovereignty. If anything, it is the reverse to the extent that it is something of an exercise of Commonwealth authority over various miscellaneous areas and an extension of that Commonwealth authority off- shore that is involved in these Bills. But what is essentially important when we are considering the whole development of Australia's coastal waters and the off- shore seabed is not that Commonwealth legislative power be exercised with respect to these essentially ancillary matters. What is absolutely crucial in our view-very much in my view-is that the Commonwealth retains its authority, on behalf of the national interest as a whole, to deal with not the ancillary matters but the vital matters, matters relating to the exploration and development of mineral and energy resources and all the fiscal and other measures and arrangements, including trade arrangements, that go with that development.

When I spoke in the Senate on 31 May 1980 on the introduction of the major off- shore constitutional settlement legislation, I described the coastal waters and off-shore legislation as an act of collective constitutional vandalism by the Commonwealth and the States concerned, including, I acknowledge, some Labor States. Nothing which has transpired in the intervening two years has made me think twice about that description. On the contrary, I would strongly reassert the vital importance of national control in the national interest of off-shore resources and the equally firm intention of the Opposition as soon as we win the next Federal election-clearly that is not very far away-to take steps, as I believe it constitutionally and legally can, to unwind the so-called settlement by repealing, to the extent that it can, the packaged legislation of the past and enacting Commonwealth legislation to re-establish national sovereignty and effective national control over the sea and seabed.

Let me restate very briefly-I do not want to merely go over ground that should by now be familiar-the reasons why it is, in our view, so much in the national interest that the Commonwealth should retain sovereignty in this area and why we continue to object so fiercely to the abdication of Commonwealth sovereignty that had been so hard fought for over so many decades, culminating in famous High Court indecision in the off-shore sovereignty case in 1975. The points, put at their briefest, are four in number.

In the first place, the re-establishment of Commonwealth sovereignty is essential if we are to seriously pursue and implement anything in the nature of a national energy policy. Secondly, it is only by national sovereignty, national control over off-shore resources, that we can avoid the all too ever apparent dangers of competitive warfare so to speak between the States regarding development projects, the competition for investment capital and all the irrational allocation of resources and infrastructure that are associated with that.

Thirdly, there is the very acute question of environmental management and pollution control. There is need for control on a macro-not simply a micro-scale when talking about projects of this magnitude and this potential for disaster in terms of their environmental impact. There is a need for national uniformity; there is a need for national consistency; there is a need for the application of Commonwealth resources, Commonwealth expertise and Commonwealth motivation to maintain the off-shore environment. That need is not equally lacking in every State around the perimeter of this nation. I readily acknowledge there is a growing degree of sensitivity in a number of areas about the need for effective environmental protection in the off-shore as indeed the on-shore area. But there are, equally, governments around this nation of ours-I need not stop for very long to point out which ones they are-which are manifestly, conspicuously, traditionally and notoriously insensitive to the environmental needs of our national heritage, of the nation as a whole.

Fourthly, in this litany of shortly stated reasons why it is crucial to maintain and re-establish national sovereignty over off-shore resources, I point to the international obligations of Australia in relation to its territorial waters. We are party to a number of treaties in matters as disparate as the protection of migratory birds and other endangered species around the world which have to do with the territorial sea and, to some extent, to what goes on underneath the surface of that water. We do have international obligations and it is clear-it has been clear for many years-that the States, particularly some individual States, cannot be relied upon to legislate in a way that gives effect to those international obligations.

The Commonwealth's international obligations, Australia's international obligations, must not be jeopardised by the necessary involvement of the States, by an allocation of functions between the Commonwealth and the States in this area, which leaves our capacity to perform international obligations at the mercy of the lowest common denominator of sensitivity in this respect-in other words, at the mercy of the kind of approach to international obligations that has been for so long manifest in the performance of the Queensland and Western Australian governments. There are constitutional uncertainties which I discussed at length when I spoke on this matter two years ago-on 21 May-about the dismantling of the settlement at this stage. But that, of course, would scarcely distinguish this issue from a whole range of other issues which concern our much traversed, much time worn and now gravely inadequate Constitution.

I want to make it clear that my preoccupations in this respect are not, despite the jibes that I expect will be forthcoming in a few minutes from Senator Chaney or whoever is carrying the can for the Commonwealth, about centralist preoccupations. There are many aspects of the management of the coastal waters and even the seabed that are, quite properly, the preserve of the States and should remain so. There is no policy reason-certainly there is no legal reason- why State laws should not continue to operate in respect of such matters as pleasure boating, wharves, jetties, harbours, beach protection, dredging, dumping and the regulation of certain fisheries, such as abalone and scallop fisheries. There is no reason legally why, in the absence of the kind of legislation that has been implemented in the coastal waters package, the States should not continue to legislate in those areas. To the extent that such legislation is within a State's extraterritorial competence, in that the subject matter of the legislation demonstrates some kind of connection with what is known legally as the peace, order and good government of the State, and to the extent that that legislation is not inconsistent with any explicit Commonwealth legislation that might also be operating in that area, there is no constitutional or any other barrier on State laws operating in that area in the sorts of matters I have mentioned.

There is no question in anything I have said-I do not want it to be misunderstood as a suggestion to that effect-of the Commonwealth wanting to move in, muscle everybody else out of the way and exercise total control over territorial waters, the seabed and all the installations and everything else associated with them simply for the sheer hell of it. We acknowledge that there are all sorts of good, legal and practical administrative and public policy reasons why, to a very significant extent, the management and administration of the coastal waters, the off-shore seabed, the fisheries and everything else associated with them should be divided between the different levels of government. The point which we make and which we keep reiterating is that in the central issue of energy and resource policy as it relates to coastal waters and, more particularly, to the seabed and the wealth of mineral and energy resources lying beneath the seabed there must be Commonwealth sovereignty; in the national interest national sovereignty must be re-established.

Issues such as foreign affairs, defence and the management of the national economy are quintessentially matters for the national government. They are almost universally acknowledged to be such by most people, with the conspicuous exception of the occasional State politician such as Mr Hassell, whom I spoke to on these matters in Western Australia the other day. The national public interest can, in fact, be served in these areas only by the application of national level rules and standards. There will always be contrary views, I suppose, from some of the more fundamentalist brethren in some of the States, but it is acknowledged, and it has always been acknowledged, that certain areas of public policy responsibility are entirely appropriately matters for the Commonwealth acting on behalf of the nation as a whole. I simply argue and the Labor Party simply argues that matters to do with off-shore mineral and energy resources and with basic questions of off-shore sovereignty should properly be within the domain of the Commonwealth in exactly the same way as are defence, foreign affairs and the control of the national economy. We believe that that approach is consistent with the thinking of most Australians on this subject. This is, I suppose, a refrain which the Senate will have to get used to hearing from the Labor Party whenever this off-shore question is debated, as it periodically is.

I conclude by saying that our support of the present legislation, uncontroversial and unexceptionable as it is, does not alter our continuing belief that only when the existing so-called settlement is unwound and sovereignty over off-shore resources and coastal waters reverts to the Commonwealth will we once again have something resembling a rational approach to the division of responsibility in these crucial areas of Australian public policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating a package of six Bills designed to extend taxing and control laws to drilling platforms and rigs exploring the seabed of Australia. They are designed essentially to keep out prohibited imports such as drugs and also to prevent the entry of exotic diseases and illegal immigrants. They are designed to operate through a series of Customs and excise laws and migration and quarantine requirements. I am very happy to say that the Australian Democrats support all of these Bills. We see them as being sensible, practical, clear and very necessary if the Australian continental shelf is to be satisfactorily explored. In passing, I mention in contrast to being complimentary, that some of the language in the Bills is a little difficult to understand. For instance, one memorable provision in the Customs Tariff Amendment (Off-shore Installations) Bill 1982 states:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) For the purposes of the Customs Acts, where an overseas installation becomes attached to the Australian seabed, the installation shall, subject to sub-section (4), be deemed to be part of Australia.

I am not sure how this piece of legislation would operate in the case, for instance, of floating rigs. Perhaps the Minister at the table, the Minister for Social Security, Senator Chaney, could explain that. I understand that many rigs overseas are semi-submersible. One is tempted to ask: When do such rigs become a part of Australia? Is it when they are actually drilling into the seabed or when they are anchored? That is a minor point, but we find some of the language a little hard to understand.

We have one or two minor misgivings about the Bill. The main one is we believe that the safety zone, as defined, is very small. A collision between an off- shore rig and a large ship could be catastrophic. It would create massive pollution and could well result in damage to the rig and to the ship. The cost could run into tens of millions of dollars. On that basis, the fines imposed for breaches are relatively trivial. I make that point bearing in mind that in Bass Strait there have been instances in which merchant ships have strayed to within a few hundred metres of drilling rigs operating there. There have been some very near misses.

We are also concerned that Australia has not a sufficiently efficient type of coastal surveillance; that such surveillance as exists is completely inadequate. The Australian Democrats have advocated for many years that Australia should establish what is commonly called in other countries a brown water navy. We should increase quite substantially the number of small ships that are capable of surveillance. They should be armed with modern weapons such as surface-to- surface guided missiles and could carry a variety of armaments. The package of armaments could well include medium calibre guns, point defence weapons, helicopters and anti-submarine weapons.

The present structure of our defence forces is ill-suited to the task of carrying out extensive maritime surveillance. Even the new Fremantle class ships are too small to perform effectively in heavy weather for extended periods. They are grossly underarmed and not really capable of achieving continual coastal surveillance. The concept of a brown water navy has been applied in the United States for many years and has been performed very satisfactorily in that country . I understand that in the Soviet Union a similar concept is applied.

Another shortcoming of these Bills is that they do not at any stage involve the encouragement of Australian industry, which can be developed quite significantly if it attempts to meet the needs of off-shore resource exploration. Even a nationally owned enterprise such as the Bendigo Ordnance Factory has already demonstrated a great capability to perform difficult and complex heavy engineering tasks. We feel that the Government should give serious consideration to encouraging this sort of heavy engineering in this country. We believe that it is a national priority. We have a very large sea bed to explore. It is obviously a growth area of the future. I mention to the Government dries that they should be aware that most countries have some sort of incentive for heavy engineering. They consider that this is a national priority and a great national asset. Other countries encourage heavy engineering by a variety of means-some by tariffs, some by bounties, some by subsidies, some by export incentives and some , often, by direct government participation. I suggest that the Government could well give consideration to this aspect of off-shore exploration.

Finally, we are also concerned that the Bills take no note of the monitoring of the production from oil rigs. We have already had the experience in Bass Strait of it proving to be beyond the technical capability of the Victorian Government to monitor satisfactorily production from the oil rigs in that State. This has already cost the Victorian Government up to $100m in lost revenue. It has been relying on foreign consulting engineers. Surely both the State Government and the Federal Government must be concerned that it is high time we developed a technology and our own technological engineers capable of carrying out in a satisfactory way the necessary monitoring of the production from our oil rigs. I hope the Minister can answer the comparatively minor queries that I have outlined. We welcome these Bills, commend the Government on their drafting and wish them a speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate for its support of the Bills which was expressed by Senator Evans when he said that the legislation was uncontroversial and unobjectionable, and by Senator Siddons who said that it was sensible, practical and clear. Indeed, I think the legislation is non-controversial in that it simply ensures that activities which are carried on off-shore on our continental shelf are subject to the normal sorts of controls that I think one would expect, bearing in mind that they are activities which are under the control of Australia. Notwithstanding Senator Siddons's description of the Bills as sensible, practical and clear, he raised a number of queries, as did Senator Evans, which I will address.

SPEECH.PARA: Only one general question of principle was raised. That was by Senator Evans, who again pointed out that he is most unhappy with the general off-shore settlement. I am rather sorry that my colleague the Attorney-General (Senator Durack), who is sitting in the Senate at the moment, does not have the conduct of these Bills because he would be able to address these issues of the off-shore settlement at very great length. On this occasion I think we will have to give that a miss. I just note that even Senator Evans concedes that there are good, practical reasons for a division between the various levels of government. The difference which he brought out towards the close of his spech was that he was of the view that there should be clear Commonwealth control over any resource development and wealth production from these areas. He gave in very brief form some reasons for that. I agree that there is a very fundamental difference between us on that point. I do not wish to vest him with the gift of prophecy-he suggested that I would be on my feet complaining on this issue within a matter of minutes-but I must say that I think the prospect of yet another significant area of economic control being vested solely in the Commonwealth is something which he knows would be starkly resisted in various parts of Australia. It is one of the genuine points of difference which lie between the Government and the Opposition. The Government would see its off-shore settlement as a triumph for the principles of a co-operative approach to federalism. The Australian Labor Party would see it as being a real blow to its own ambitions to see more centralist control in these regions. There is nothing shameful in that difference, but it is a difference between us. In view of the fact that Senator Evans seems to be quite keen to get into government, I have to say to him that it is a difference which I am quite happy to have him make apparent as often as possible.

To turn quickly to the specific points which were raised-without necessarily picking them up in the precise order in which they were made in the debate-I note that Senator Evans was concerned about a number of matters. He was concerned about the manpower resources which are available to Customs to deal with the additional responsibilities which Customs will receive under this legislation. The position is that apart from the initial installation phase, when considerable direct overseas involvement is anticipated, the manpower requirements are not expected to be very extensive. However, there will be a need for additional attendance and patrol activity at the site of installation and of the traffic between the installation and the mainland. However, the number of installations having direct contact overseas is not expected to be very large. I can assure the Senate that it will be considerably larger than it would have been if we had the sort of centralist control of these resources which Senator Evans wants. That would result in very little activity at all in these areas. There will almost certainly be found to be a need to revise the format of coastal surveillance generally.

As far as surveillance is concerned, the Government has decided, as a result of its consideration of the review of the need for civil coastal surveillance in 1981, that Customs should not engage in coastal surveillance generally but should depend on the Australian Coastal Surveillance Centre for its needs in that direction. Customs will continue to depend upon that organisation for coastal surveillance and will concentrate on response action according to the nature of the sightings reported.

Senator Evans also raised the question of the inadequacy of penalties. Like a number of other matters which he raised, this was canvassed in the other place. He was concerned about the penalties but seemed to overlook the fact that substantial additional penalties are contained in the forfeiture provisions. So one is looking not merely at the question of monetary penalties under this legislation but also at the forfeiture powers which are contained within the Bills. The other matters which were raised by Senator Evans do not need to be canvassed since he seems to have lost interest.

I now turn to the matters raised by Senator Siddons. He was concerned about the technical question concerning floating rigs. As I am advised, the position concerning such rigs is that they do require to be fixed in order to operate. They do not float at large. They are anchored to the seabed. It is when the rig is affixed that it becomes part of Australia in the terms of this legislation. So, the sorts of rigs which are the concern of Senator Siddons are, I am told, covered by this legislation.

Senator Siddons was also concerned about the need to encourage Australian industry. He might be consoled by the fact that, as at 31 January 1982, Woodside Petroleum Ltd had let contracts for $784m in connection with the North West Shelf project. Of this figure, $529m, or 67.5 per cent, was let to Australian companies.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to hear it.

—I think that would be a matter of satisfaction to all honourable senators. It does indicate that there is a direct benefit to Australian industry in the activities which are being undertaken in that very remote part of Australia off the North West Shelf. As far as the processing of products in Australia is concerned, it is the Government's policy to encourage raw materials processing in Australia where this would be economically feasible and consistent with sound industrial development. In relation to the North West Shelf, the first phase of the project involves the supply by pipeline of 10 million cubic metres per day of natural gas to the Western Australian market. At least one group of companies is conducting a preliminary study into the use of part of this gas as petrochemical feedstock for a plant in Western Australia. The export approvals which have been given for the second phase of the project account for some 53 per cent of the estimated reserves and three fields on the North West Shelf, leaving significant opportunities for the establishment of local industries based on processing the remainder of the reserves.

SPEECH.PARA: The other matter which I think was of concern to Senator Siddons was the matter of the safety zone and the limited distance of 500 metres which was indicated as being the relevant distance. One can understand an objection to that, bearing in mind that it takes a long time for a ship to stop and that there are various other things one might be concerned about. But under international law and convention the powers referred to may only be exercised in respect of foreign vessels within Australia's territorial sea and contiguous zone; that is, up to 12 nautical miles from the coast. The 12-mile limit is not applicable to artificial islands and the powers are not exercisable on the high seas. Under the Convention on the Continental Shelf provision is made whereby contracting parties have some limited rights within a 500-metre safety zone around installations. In other words, the legislation takes advantage of the maximum available to us under that Convention. In this legislation the Government is seeking to go as far as it can in protecting Australia's interests. It is not open to us to move further, as Senator Siddons suggested might be wise. I thank the Senate for its very speedy consideration of this significant legislation and I commend the legislation to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without amendment, requests or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN MEAT AND LIVE-STOCK CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 6 May, on motion by Senator Durack:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —With the approval of the Senate I suggest that this Bill, the Export Control Bill 1982 and the Export Control (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1982 be dealt with in a cognate debate.
—There being no objection, that course will be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —These three related Bills have been prompted by the export meat substitution scandal of last year. They provide for tighter procedures for and control of export establishments and higher penalties for breaches of regulations and for fraud. The first Bill listed, the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Amendment Bill, also amends the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Act in a number of ways not related directly to the export meat substitution scandal. Among the procedures or controls which have been tightened is the fact that it will now be an offence falsely to describe goods on the documentation accompanying the goods. The unauthorised possession of an official export inspection stamp will be an offence. Automatic right of entry for inspectors to all registered premises is provided for.

SPEECH.PARA: Taken in total, all of these changes, apparently, must be extraordinarily complex, because the Government decided to engage counsel to represent the Minister at the royal commission which flowed from the export inspection scandal . I quote from a letter that Senator Sir John Carrick sent to me following a question without notice on 10 March as to why counsel was engaged. He wrote:
It was decided to engage counsel because it is essential that the substantial changes now being made to Commonwealth meat inspection be brought to the attention of the Royal Commission.

No other reason was stated in Senator Carrick's letter for counsel having been engaged. Apparently, in the Government's judgment, these changes are so complex that it is worth $75,000 to have them adequately explained to a royal commission .

The procedures as stipulated in the Bill seem to be acceptable, but lingering doubts must remain about the capacity effectively to administer those procedures of a very slack Department of Primary Industry and an even slacker Minister. The events of the last week suggest that despite all that has happened in the last couple of years, including a major Senate inquiry, administration within the Department of Primary Industry is still very slack, and of course tolerated by a slack Minister. We learned this week that on 19 April the Australian Dairy Corporation discovered that Reserve Bank of Australia funds were being misused by a number of dairy companies. On 5 and 6 May a board meeting was held, and I understand that the matter was discussed at that meeting. Yet, if we are to believe the Minister, it was not until 19 May that he found out about it. The Government has a representative on the Board of the Australian Dairy Corporation , which met on 5 and 6 May, and as far as I know Mr Wallace was present at that meeting. But, if we are to believe the Minister, the Minister was not told of something as important as this for another two weeks; indeed not told, presumably, until it was known that the Business Review weekly was about to publish the story.

If all that is correct, it seems that despite the Senate inquiry, Mr Wallace and the Minister have the same negligent attitude towards their responsibility for the conduct of the Australian Dairy Corporation that was disclosed in the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. If the Department of Primary Industry is still suspect in that area, grave doubts must arise as to whether it remains suspect in the inspection service area.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the suspension of the sitting I was questioning the administrative ability of the Department of Primary Industry, given its continuing condition, as revealed by the Australian Dairy Corporation's latest scandal and in particular the apparent failure of the Government's representative on the Board of the Corporation to report until 19 May-at least that is the Minister's version of when he found out about it-the substance of discussions at a Board meeting on 5 May and 6 May about the misuse of Reserve Bank funds. Those points must cast some doubt upon the capacity or ability of the Department to administer effectively the new, tightened rules concerning export inspection procedures.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Macklin has forecast an intention to move a number of amendments in the Committee stage to the Export Control Bill and the Export Control (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill. The Labor Party is willing to support some of them, but it will not support at least two of them. I will not go into the details at this stage.

The Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Amendment Bill seeks to amend the principal Act in ways that are not directly related to export inspection procedures or the export meat substitution scandal. The amendments in that Bill seek to provide the Corporation with the potential to become a sole trader with the power to restrict the number of exporters who will be licensed in specific markets and, subject to ministerial approval, gives the Corporation the power to trade in futures. It also provides that, on the proclamation of the Act as amended, all existing export licences will be cancelled and re-issued by the Corporation. I should indicate at this stage that the Opposition will not be opposing any of those amendments.

On the question of the Corporation's power to restrict licences for single markets, we are not opposing this provision, but it seems to me that the Corporation, given its general power to withhold licences, would have always had the power to do this. Even if that is so, I guess the power will be more explicit following the amendments proposed by the Government. At least in the preferred markets of the United States, Japan and Canada, the Corporation exercised power which restricted the number of exporters who could sell in those markets. Also, it has always had the power to cancel export licences, a power which was exercised, I think for the first time, following the meat export substitution scandals.

The presumed intention of the amendments to the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Act is to assist the beef industry. It is unfortunately true that the beef industry is currently in a moderately depressed condition. Agricultural history in Australia generally suggests that a condition of depression fosters the emergence of quacks dispensing hocus-pocus. It seems to be happening again. The latest manifestation of this is Sir William Gunn's panacea for the beef industry which, according to the Press, was a plan to extract $100m from a bankrupt industry to spend in nebulous ways.

Following those Press reports, I obtained a copy of the Gunn proposal from the Australian Cattle Council. The printed version has no reference to the $100m which had been widely reported in the Press. What actually is in the printed proposal is a lot of motherhood statements-some nebulous, naive and, in some cases, nonsensical statements. One of the more naive statements-I do not appear to have the document with me but I remember what it said-drew an analogy between the sugar and wool industries and the beef industry. It said that sugar and wool had managed to maintain stable prices and asked why beef could not do the same. A fairly obvious reason which should have occurred even to Sir William Gunn is that sugar and wool are non-perishable products. Therefore, it is technically feasible and often economically justifiable to store them for quite long periods until market conditions change. Beef is not such a product. It is perishable. It cannot be stored economically for long periods. Technically, deep refrigeration for long periods adversely affects quality.

Beneath all that overburden, one particularly dangerous proposal appears, I think, on page 20 of the paper. It is a proposal that there be a pooling system for beef so that returns to producers would be equalised throughout the year. This, so the document said, would induce farmers to market their stock when it was in prime condition instead of in response to prices. The outcome of this, of course, would be that producers would happily slide into bankruptcy, secure in the knowledge that they were producing a prime product. The suggestion that producers should be, as an act of deliberate policy, insulated from price signals from the market and encouraged not to sell when prices were high but to sell when stock was in prime condition is mind-boggling.

Over the years Sir William Gunn has been a fertile source of economic quackery. As Australian Wool Board Chairman in the 1960s, in conjunction with the International Wool Secretariat, which he still reveres in his latest paper, he put forward the original proposition that if wool production increased wool prices would rise. I cannot find anybody in the wool industry today who is willing to support that notion. It is reminiscent of Germany in 1946 when nobody was left but the anti-nazis. Nevertheless, that ludicrous proposition that an increase in supply would push prices up became the conventional wisdom of the 1960s and the early 1970s.

I have just had given to me-I think I should refer to it for the sake of the record-precisely what was written in Sir William Gunn's paper 'Proposal to Stabilize the Beef Cattle Industry'. With respect to the pooling system he said:
A pooling system could allow producers to bring their cattle to market at their prime, instead of in response to a price change.
As I say, even for someone with Sir William Gunn's record it is amazing--

TALK.START.PARA: —An appalling record--
—Appalling that somebody could propose--
—Of inaccuracy and of shooting from the hip and the lip.

—I acknowledge Senator Rae's interjection so that it may be recorded. It is appalling that anybody could seriously propose that as an act of deliberate policy one should set up arrangements which could prevent producers responding to price changes. I hope the latest piece of Gunn economic quackery does not gain the popular acceptance of the quack notion of the 1960s that increased wool production would cause wool prices to rise. Sir William Gunn is living testimony to the fact that chronic economic illiteracy plus, I might add, in his case involvement in a string of bankrupt enterprises do not necessarily preclude people from achieving guru status, at least when they are facing an uncritical audience.

SPEECH.PARA: I might express yet again my disappointment that such palpable nonsense has been not only seriously reported in the agricultural Press but also seriously reported by some agricultural writers in the metropolitan daily Press and that nowhere has there been the sort of dismissal or ridicule that the suggestions of the so-called proposal actually deserve. Of course, it does not give anyone any joy that the beef industry along with, I might add, agriculture generally is at present in a moderately depressed condition. The solution to those problems, however, does not lie in the promotion of snake oil remedies of this type. We believe that although the amendments to the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Act which the Government has proposed will not achieve miracles they may achieve some marginal improvements at least ultimately in the condition of the industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this cognate debate I wish to refer mainly to the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation and make just a couple of comments at the second reading stage on the export control legislation. I will also be speaking to the amendments which I propose to move at the Committee stage.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Amendment Bill seeks to strengthen the control of the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation of Australia's export meat trade in line with the problems in meat substitution that we have had in the past year or at least that have come to public attention in the last year. I think the interesting part of the Bill in terms of the meat trade is the opportunity the Government has given the Corporation to adopt the role of sole trader and also to limit the number of licences for trade with particular overseas markets. Also there is the possibility, subject to ministerial control, that the Corporation will be able to trade in futures. I think that is a very interesting innovation although, of course, it is already occurring in many of our other rural areas. The Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Amendment Bill raises a problem faced by the meat industry as a whole. I should like to refer to what I think is a pertinent comment made by Mr Ian Park, who is the President of the Cattlemen's Union. He said that the recent beef scandal was one of the best things ever to occur to the beef industry. That seems a very odd comment, but Mr Park was making it in the context of saying that at last public and political attention has been focussed upon the meat marketing and export trade. To that extent I think that people in the meat trade are, in some offhanded way, grateful that at last others have taken notice of their problems and are coming to grips with some of the real issues faced by that rural industry.

I am concerned, however, that the Corporation still seems to be taking a fairly hesitant view, particularly in relation to what it sees as its role. I think most people acknowledge that Australia has certain natural advantages in its beef trade. I refer particularly to the quality of its meat. In many ways we must take an aggressive stance to overcome some of the very real problems that have occurred. I should like now to mention a problem faced by my own State concerning the selling methods within the meat trade. There have been some extremely interesting innovations overseas. For example, I refer to video auctions of beef. The Queensland Meat Industry Organisation and Marketing Authority is investigating concepts such as carcass auctions and direct selling by classifications. All of these methods of selling are, of course, directed at solving the problems of saleyards-problems such as bruising, double handling, stress and inability to reduce prices offered on a specified sale day. I think that all those incidences are fairly well known by the industry. I believe the industry is seeking to readjust to cope with them. For example, in Queensland in the last year 21 saleyards have closed down. The nine biggest saleyards now handle more than 60 per cent of sales in Queensland. I think that is an inevitable movement given the state of the beef industry.

I believe that when we look at the current statistics for the industry- unfortunately this is a picture that we know only too well by looking at most of our rural industries-we find not a moderately depressed situation as Senator Walsh called it but rather a devastating situation. Beef production in Australia has dropped more than 20 per cent from 2.9 million tonnes in 1977-78 to 2.3 million tonnes in 1980-81. Our national herd is down from 33.4 million in 1976 to about 25 million today. I do not think anybody is looking at rebuilding that national herd. Cattle prices-this certainly applies to my State and, I believe, it applies nationally-are down about 40 per cent in real terms. Most honourable senators will be aware of the meatworks situation in their own States. In Queensland more than 20 meatworks have closed down in the last three years. I think these problems are borne out when one looks at the situation faced by major meat companies in Australia. I shall quote some figures in order to give an indication of the real problems faced by meat companies. Last year Tancred Bros Pty Ltd had a 2.9 per cent return on invested funds; Metro Industries Ltd had a 9.5 per cent return; Australian Bacon had a 7.3 per cent return; and J. C. Hutton Pty Ltd, Protean (Holdings) Ltd and F. J. Walker Ltd each had a nil return.

The problems of those companies are reflected in the employment opportunities in that field. We have seen over the past year over 10,000 meat workers lose their jobs. Meat retail outlets have been slashed and, for the first time, every section of the beef industry in Australia is depressed. Unfortunately, if one looks outside Australia for some relief it is hard at the moment to see where it might come from. For example, the United States market does not show any signs of recovery at present. Japan is also in difficulties. Certainly, when one looks at their domestic production, which is growing each year, one could not, except in terms of lean meat, look towards further developing export markets in those countries. There is also the concern that the United States is becoming much more aggressive in this area and is seeking some offsetting exports to balance its enormous trade deficit.

The European Economic Community, which is rapidly becoming the bane of almost every agricultural and rural producer in this country, is continuing to increase production. I believe that Australia is finding it extremely difficult to cope with the types of methods that the EEC is employing. At this time our markets basically are in the United States, Canada, Japan and Korea. The Bureau of Agricultural Economics is looking, in general rural terms, at a further decline in this financial year.

With that rather bleak picture, we welcome the introduction by the Government of this measure which will enable the Corporation, if it wishes to make use of the added powers which it has been given, particularly as sole trader, to move to a much more aggressive and successful marketing of beef in Australia. I believe that was the intention of the Government. I think all honourable senators will certainly hope that the Corporation will use to the full extent those additional powers that the Government is offering.

I wonder whether we might raise the question of the difference in terms of government control of the Corporation which, although funded by producers, is still very heavily controlled by the Government and whether we might seek a different relationship between the Government and the Corporation in terms of accountability. I am not quite sure whether that marketing organisation is best operating under the types of controls that it has at the moment. I think that most of the people operating in the beef area believe that there has been a lot to be desired in its performance. They will all be looking quite anxiously at how the Corporation handles its increased powers under this Bill. I also believe they will look at the Government and its intentions in terms of what type of priority it wishes to give to beef production in this country.

I shall speak briefly, because of the pressure of time, to the Export Control Bill and raise one issue that I believe is still of concern, that is, the issue raised by the Law Reform Commission in its report on criminal investigation, and particularly the item in relation to warrants. I shall quote paragraph 192 of the second report of the Law Reform Commission. I think it sets out the problem that still exists in this area. Having raised the issue of warrants the Law Reform Commission said:

It is nonetheless perfectly obvious that the powers conferred are all of them quite extraordinarily wide in their scope. There is no requirement in any of them that before the powers are exercised an independent judicial mind should consider the circumstances of the particular case, weighing the public interest as against that of the individual concerned. Nor is there any effective way in which any of these powers once exercised can be the subject of ex post facto judicial review.
A little later in that chapter, in paragraph 196, the Commission made this point :

The power to search and seize is undoubtedly a very necessary one for police to have. It has great destructive potential so far as the right to privacy and civil liberties generally are concerned. The power must therefore be capable of justification on every single occasion on which it is used.
The Commission raises that issue not so much about the police in general but particularly about Customs. It went on to say:

On this view, the continued existence of general search warrants cannot be countenanced. In the Commission's view such provisions should long ago have disappeared from the Commonwealth and Territorial statute books. We recommend that their demise be delayed no longer.
The recommendation in paragraph 207 relates specifically to customs. It states:
The Commission's recommendation here is that the power to detain and search suspected persons, or vehicles, should be restricted in its application to ' customs areas' . . .

This refers to one of the amendments which I will move in the Committee stage, that is, precisely what is the Government's intention about registered premises. However I will refer to that matter at a later stage. I believe that the points raised by the Law Reform Commission still have to be answered by the Government. Those problems still exist. I think everybody is mindful of the extreme difficulties in the Customs area in ensuring that we have effective seizure and search, that Customs officers have such powers as to enable an effective deterrent to be mounted, particularly against the importation of drugs, while at the same time providing the privacy and civil liberties that we consider to be absolutely fundamental and necessary in a democratic community. I believe this matter was addressed quite clearly by the Law Reform Commission when it sought a middle path. The Government is still reluctant to come to grips with that thorny problem. This legislation does not do that. One would hope that at some stage in the near future the Government will have a complete review of problems relating to seizure which have to be faced by Customs officers and that this chamber will have a chance to debate them more fully than is possible when dealing with this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Amendment Bill 1982 as well as the Export Control ( Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1982 and the Export Control Bill 1982. My remarks will be general. They will relate particularly to the Australian Meat and Live- stock Corporation so they can be considered as directed specifically to the amending Bill although I hope the relevance of a couple of things I say will be apparent in relation to the other Bills. In the last 12 months we have had a number of debates in the Senate on meat and I welcome the opportunity to speak on the amendments to the AMLC Bill. I remind the Senate that the Act we are amending was passed by the Senate in 1977. At the time a number of industry groups voiced strong disapproval of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Bill and the deficiencies they saw in it.

SPEECH.PARA: I was one who attempted to put to the Government certain views on the setting up of the AMLC and what I believe its powers and duties ought to be. I welcome the fact that after five years the Government has now faced the fact that in relation to Australian beef a number of countries have single buying authorities . For many years a number of Australian beef producers have been telling governments this and saying that it is all very well to talk about free enterprise and free trade and hold them up as ideals, but the facts are that it becomes a very one-sided exercise in the beef industry when trading with certain nations. That is not so in our trade with the United States of America. Trade with a country such as Japan is a very sore point with Australian beef producers . I speak with particular feeling because half of the beef produced in my State of Queensland is export beef destined for countries such as the United States of America and Japan, our first and second most important markets.

The system of buying by Japan has long been a subject of considerable grievance to Australian and, in particular, Queensland beef producers. A very large amount of the beef produced in Queensland is not meant to be high quality restaurant beef. It comes from land which has only within the last two decades been utilised for the growing of beef and the quality of beef that it produces is not on the whole suitable for high class restaurant trade. It is meant to be hamburger beef in the case of the United States and beef suitable for such things as curries in the case of Japan. However, because of very protective and restrictive attitudes on the part of certain purchasing countries, notably Japan , the amount of beef that we can land cheaply in such countries is restricted.

In January 1977 I had the opportunity to visit Japan at a time when there was a four-Minister ministerial delegation there talking trade. I was there with a back bench delegation. The subject of the Australian ministerial delegation earned very much Press in the time we were there and was drawing the attention of the ordinary Japanese citizen. As our delegation moved about and came into contact with average Japanese people, not government spokesmen or members of the Diet, those people expressed to us overwhelmingly a desire to have access to Australian beef. For the type of beef that they wanted, not the kobe beef but the beef that ordinary Japanese consumers could have in their homes, Australian beef was ideally suited. However, because of the particular meat buying and trading practices in Japan, that beef was firstly very expensive and secondly was available only in small amounts. So without a doubt I felt that there was a desire on the part of Japanese consumers, for example, to have access to more Australian beef because that was expressed in clear, simple and direct terms to us as Australian representatives. On the other side of the coin, in Australia we have maintained an attitude that we have been able to leave our beef export trade up to individual marketeers; that those who are registered as exporters of beef have the right to go out into the world to deal with whomever they will however they will.

The bitterness of the beef crash in Queensland has not gone. When there was an upturn in the beef industry about four years ago I heard many smug comments from within that industry and from within this Parliament about how the militant attitudes that had emerged during the beef crash would disappear. 'Just wait and see', we were all told, 'Once the beef prices go up, they will all forget their complaints. They will forget that they wanted a different marketing system. They will forget that they criticised the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Bill'. Well, they have not forgotten. The lessons of the beef crash in Queensland and in similar areas such as the Northern Territory and northern Western Australia are not forgotten. Thousands of decent, honest people were forced out of the industry because of the woefully inadequate structure, standards and marketing of Australian beef had obtained at the time of the crash . Those standards and structures could in no way address themselves to the problem. The beef producers have not forgotten their friends and, indeed, in many cases, members of their families who were forced into bankruptcy and who walked off their properties. Militancy remains. Criticism of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Amendment Bill, of the AMLC itself, of its powers and of the way it conducts itself remains. The questions remain. The question of trading and export entitlements remains.

Five years ago I asked the Government to address itself to the question of a single selling right for the AMLC, as was then strongly requested by a very large number of beef processors.
