Finally, the Government has addressed itself to that. There are still other areas at which the Government must look very seriously. The question of export entitlements will remain a difficult area until the beef producer-the person who starts the process and without whom the industry cannot exist at all, without whom we would earn no export money-is satisfied that the system of trading and export credits does not just cream off from his price.

At the moment we are at a patchy stage in the beef industry. Sometimes it is not bad; sometimes it is very depressing. The industry's structure and marketing procedures must still undergo a lot of review, a lot of firm government action. I hope that this Government and governments of the future will not wait for further disasters before they take some action, will not wait until the situation is beating them over the head for several years before they move in the obvious directions.

Who benefits from the present situation? A number of very important factors are involved in our beef industry. A large number of people within its different sectors are affected by downturns or periods of prosperity. There is the processor-the entrepreneur who buys and puts the beef through his processing works. There are all of the people employed in the large meat processing works- and they are large. There is the exporter, in whose hands rests the fate of the export industry-a very large section of the beef industry. There is, of course, as I have mentioned, the producer. At all stages, in looking at beef marketing arrangements, governments should be conscious of all those people.

One of the excuses used by the Government in 1977 for not being more resolute with the opportunity that it had to restructure the Australian beef industry was that sectors of the industry could not agree with one another; that there were even disagreements within those sectors. I suggest that in part that was a lame excuse; in part it was true. But had leadership been shown from outside it could have resolved a number of those problems. That leadership still has not come. I do not think that it has come from the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation . The worker needs to understand that his wages and the factor which they build into the cost of meat, particularly to the domestic consumer, can be critical in the acceptance of meat as a product. The processor has to understand that the producer is not there for his benefit only, not there to be manipulated, to be played off, one against the other. The exporter has to understand that if the Australian beef industry appears to have no long term security, he will have no long term security. The producer must know how he is viewed by those other three sectors of the industry. That is still not clear. The producer clearly wants co- operation with the worker, the processor and the exporter, because without them he is nowhere. They are essential to his livelihood. But he feels powerless.

In August of last year shortly after the meat substitution scandal broke I called on the Government to appoint a royal commission into the scandal. One week later, and quite coincidentally, I left to be a guest of the United States Government in that country. Because this scandal had broken before I left, naturally I spent the greater part of my time in the United States, particularly in Washington, which is where I spent most of my time, talking to members of the House of Representatives and the Senate on the subject of the Australian meat trade. I talked to Congressman Gibbon, Chairman of the Agriculture Committee, which then had the Farm Bill before it. That member of Congress had a very firm view on the Farm Bill. He did not believe that the demands being made by the American cattle producers to put unreasonable controls on imports of beef into the United States should be agreed to. When I say 'unreasonable' I am being kind . If those controls had been imposed they would be an effective virtual ban on the import of meat into the United States. I think that under those circumstances I am not being unkind to my American colleagues when I say that their demands were unreasonable.

I encountered many vigorous, dedicated opponents of the importation of Australian meat into the United States. During my time there I welcomed with great enthusiasm and relief the news of the announcement by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) that there would be a royal commission into the meat substitution scandal. I welcomed the terms of that inquiry because I believed them to be complete and to the point. They gave me, an Australian legislator at the coal face in the United States talking to American legislators, a very good basis for discussion and reassurance. I look forward as do many others, to the outcome of that royal commission report.

I was astonished when I returned to Australia to read a report in our newspapers, published in the week after my return, which credited to an executive member of the National Cattlemen's Association-the United States organisation which represents beef producers in that country-the view that Australians had nothing to fear from the meat substitution scandal, that, in fact, the Australian Press had overplayed the thing altogether and that it was not a big issue in the United States. It was a major issue. Americans I met who had nothing to do with industry, trade or legislation all knew that kangaroo and horse meat was arriving in their country from Australia. But any Australians who had read those reports and taken them at face value would therefore have been astonished when the Farm Bill was passed by Congress. That decision was subsequently overturned and at the moment our position appears reasonably secure , but only on a short term basis. Let nobody underestimate the strength of the Opposition within Congress in the United States to importing Australian meat.

One of the things I therefore welcome about these Bills is a move towards the setting of uniform standards in the marking and marketing of beef, towards giving to somebody the responsibility for making sure that when a carton of meat is presented as a certain product it does contain that product. We should ensure not only that it contains beef instead of kangaroo meat, but also that if it is claimed to contain fillet steak it contains fillet steak and not chuck steak. Accusations of substitution of the latter kind have been made all too often against our meat processing industry by various consumers, not the least of which are international airlines, which take meat on when they are in Australia. Some of the people who have had responsibility for the marketing of our meat have done us a grave disservice over and over again for years now.

I referred early in my speech to a monopoly situation in relation to certain purchasing countries. I am a member of a party and a government which support the free enterprise principles as the most effective way of assuring certain social objectives. However, let us never confuse free market conditions with the rule of the jungle. I note that the second reading speech states:

The current system of meat trading, based on free market principles and involving some 260 private operators licensed to export meat and livestock, operates reasonably well in normal trading circumstances.

Apparently the Minister does not now include as a normal trading circumstance trading with a country where there is a single buyer. Five years ago the Government did. I am pleased that it has been persuaded that that is no longer a normal trading circumstance if one is measuring it by free enterprise trading principles. In that context I think it is valuable to look at the words of Andrew Robb, the Executive Director of the Cattle Council of Australia, to a recent convention of the Livestock and Grain Producers Association. Mr Robb looked at this argument that has been used against orderly marketing by producers, government and all sorts of people on the grounds that we must not upset the free enterprise system. Mr Robb said:
Much of our marketing system-whether responsible for marketing either livestock or meat products-reflects a trading climate long gone, a system very outdated.

Significant sections of this sector have been bound by deep conservatism, extreme reluctance to change and a blind faith in the status quo which, for the sake of confusion, is invariably termed free enterprise.
I'm afraid I see little to resemble the elements of competition and excellence of true free enterprise:
In the arrival at saleyard auction of the one carload of buyers;
in the existence of one meatworks within hundreds of miles and no reliable basis for comparing prices elsewhere;
in the use of a single buying position by overseas countries to force a scramble of price cutting by our exporters;
in the consistent failure of some operators to provide the quality ordered by our customers, and
in the failure of our marketing system as a whole to achieve anywhere near the sophistication of merchandising in many other fields.

Our ability to compete is further hamstrung by a union movement which still fails to see any connection between the loss of 10,000 meatworker jobs over recent years and an internationally unique industrial award. An award which effectively limits the utilisation of our multi-million dollar meatworks to around one-third capacity, so adding literally millions to slaughter costs.

There is no doubt in my mind about our inability to master the trading climate confronting us unless major changes continue to be effected in relation to meat and livestock marketing and industrial co-operation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—Those are the words of Andrew Robb, the Executive Director of the Cattle Council of Australia. I recommend the speech, which was made on 13 May 1982, to Senator Siddons. I suspect that he received a copy of it in his mail at Parliament House this week. I think that Mr Robb put the position particularly succinctly. There was nothing new in that. He put the position well but it is not new. That is what sections of the beef industry have been saying for years about the system of marketing in Australia both for the domestic consumer and for export. The Cattlemen's Union, an organisation that people confidently predicted, firstly, would not last two years when it started and, secondly, would wither and die once the price of beef went up at all, was saying those things and was desperately trying to attract public and political attention five years ago and before when the beef recession first started. I hope those words do not have to be repeated for very much longer.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation well in its venture as a single trader on the export market. I hope very much that it will take its role and its responsibility extremely seriously and put every professional resource that it can muster into that exercise. We have been used and abused as a meat trading nation by many of our buyers for several years now. It is catastrophic for many producers, past and present, that this has been allowed to continue for so long. What of the future? Who can say? I hope that Mr Jones, the present Chairman of the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation, will bend his undoubted talents to the tasks set for him by the Government. He has not been a supporter of the single trading authority of the AMLC, in the past. I hope he has genuinely changed his mind. Whether he has or not, it is now the charter of the Corporation and it must meet the challenge put to it.

We cannot allow this industry which presently earns us hundreds of millions of dollars a year and export credit-it earns that not at its peak; it could earn us much more indeed-to flounder along for want of professional support in marketing . We cannot allow it to wonder about the method of trading in the export area. We certainly cannot allow it to doubt the resolve of government to keep it in its proper place as a major export earning industry for Australia. We cannot allow the people in it to doubt that governments, present and future, will do anything other than keep faith with the producers, meatworkers, processors and exporters and the whole network of the beef trade industry to make sure that this remains the critically important industry it is in so many of our lowly populated, underdeveloped areas of Australia. I commend the Bills to the Senate. I see them as a worthwhile step. I hope they are the first of a series of steps to give our beef industry the strength and support that it deserves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In discussing the matters related to the meat industry and the export of its products I think we should have some regard to some of the plans which are at present being mooted for new proposals to overcome some of the very real problems which have existed in that industry. One of the people who have received considerable publicity recently for certain proposals, as Senator Walsh indicated when speaking earlier tonight, is Sir William Gunn. I believe it is important for us to have some regard to the track record of Sir William Gunn when we consider the proposals he is putting forward. I would describe the track record as being one of a man who has behaved in a way which indicates that he has put forward positive statements which have been ill- considered, ill-advised and inadequately researched.

SPEECH.PARA: I use as one example an experience I have had and that is that on, I understand , 6 December last year Sir William Gunn chose to hold a Press conference in Melbourne and to tell the media representatives who attended, amongst other things, what unforgivable behaviour a Senate committee had been involved in. In fact, I would like to read very briefly a report of that Press conference which has not been denied by Sir William, although he has had the opportunity to do so and has had it drawn to his attention. The heading in the Advertiser newspaper of 8 December 1981 was: 'Treatment was ''unforgivable'' '. The article stated:
The Rae Committee's treatment of the former chairman of the Australian Dairy Corporation, Mr Tony Webster, was unforgivable, according to Sir William Gunn.

Sir William, long-time wool industry leader and IWS chairman, said last week he did not think Mr Webster had done anything wrong, nor anything that would not have been approved of in a private enterprise atmosphere.

'If this is the kind of thing the Rae committee is going to do, blacken people who have done an outstanding job for an industry, all because of a few thousand dollars on an expense account, then we will soon have no-one who will lead or even want to sit on the boards (of statutory authorities)', Sir William said.
Already, some of the non-producer members of such boards were 'getting a bit jack of it' and wondered what they were doing sitting on boards likely to be exposed to the Rae committee.

'The committee (the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, headed by Senator Peter Rae) is making the organisations nervous and they are becoming too cautious,' Sir William said.
Having had that drawn to my attention, I wrote to Sir William Gunn. My letter was dated 23 December 1981, and it reads as follows:
Dear Sir William,

I understand that at a press conference which you held in Melbourne on or about 6th December, you made statements which were reported inter alia in the Adelaide 'Advertiser', a copy of which report I enclose.

I do not choose to debate with you the question of moral and ethical standards in relation to business behaviour, but do believe that if you are going to make the statements which you were reported as having made, you should at least get your facts straight.
You are quoted as stating that my Committee's behaviour was unforgivable in relation to the treatment given to Mr Tony Webster.
You state that the Committee's actions were, in this case, to 'blacken people who have done an outstanding job for an industry, all because of a few thousand dollars on an expense account'.
The facts are:
1. The Auditor-General raised the expense account issue.
2. The Minister ordered the investigation by the Auditor-General under Section 63P of the Audit Act and later the police inquiry.
3. The Committee stated to the Senate at the commencement of its inquiry, through the hearings, and in its Report, Chapter 1.9 that:

'The Committee has studiously avoided seeking evidence which may have impinged upon the matters which were the subject of police investigation. The Committee was conscious that the Minister for Primary Industry had stated his intention to make a full report to the Parliament after the completion of the police investigations.'
4. Mr Webster, when giving evidence to the Committee was not asked--
I emphasise that 'was not asked'-
and did not give evidence in relation to the expense account issues being investigated by the Federal Police.
5. The Committee did not refer to those matters in its Report.

6. It was the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Nixon, who made a statement to the House of Representatives relating to Mr Webster and the results of the Auditor-General's and Police inquiry which the successive Ministers had caused to be undertaken.

7. It was the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Anthony, and the Minister for Communications, Mr Sinclair, who made references to Mr Webster during the parliamentary debate. Those statements caused me, as Chairman of the Senate Committee, to state in the Senate my concern that Mr Webster was not being fairly treated by those Country Party Ministers.

All of this information would have been available to you had you chosen, before making your outburst, to check the Committee's Report and the Hansards of the Committee's inquiry, the House of Representatives, and the Senate.
Your statements were totally without foundation, they were untrue, and they are defamatory of me and my Committee.

To have criticised the Committee for what they did would be one thing, and I do not object to healthy debate. For you to use the language which you did, claiming to justify it upon the basis of what, in fact, the Committee very carefully refrained from doing, and which should and must have been known to you , can only lead me to believe that you have deliberately attempted to mislead the press conference, and for some reason unknown to me, have set out to defame the Committee. It is a possible conclusion that this is part of the concerted plan, as it is not the only instance on which this totally untrue allegation has been made. Whether you are party to, or merely a victim of that planned exercise , is a matter in relation to which I leave you to comment.

If there is some other explanation, then I will be prepared to consider it. However, at the very least, I require a full and public apology from you to both the Committee and to me. That apology should be given the same publication as was the original statement.
I look forward to hearing from you as to the steps which you propose to take and any exculpatory factors which should be taken into account.

I have had no response to that letter. I have nothing but contempt for a man who is so without intestinal fortitude that when he has been demonstrably shown to be wrong he does not even have the decency to respond by saying: 'I am sorry; I did not check my facts'.

The fact is that I defended Mr Webster in this chamber against absolutely unfounded attacks which were made upon him in the House of Representatives. It is ironical in the extreme that I personally and the Committee which I chaired should be attacked by the likes of Sir William Gunn for doing the very thing which the Committee very carefully refrained from doing and which it went out of its way to ensure that it did not do. This man is parading around Australia at the moment pretending to be the leader of a new scheme to get Australia out of its problems but demonstrably, from his whole track record and, in particular, the things to which I have just referred, he has made the following cardinal errors: Firstly, of attacking without checking his facts; secondly, of accepting self-serving scuttle-butt as objective and reliable when it should not be accepted; thirdly, of not being prepared to admit that he was wrong, that he had made a demonstrable error; and fourthly, of proceeding in a pigheaded way notwithstanding the facts. Such a man has an intrinsic credibility problem. Before his latest plan is given credibility people should have regard to his track record, not only what I have just mentioned but also the fact that I did not sue him for defamation because I did not believe money would be well spent in obtaining a judgment. I will put it that way and take it no further.

TALK.START.PARA: —A nod is as good as a wink, Senator.

—Thank you, Senator Mulvihill. The problems in the meat industry are serious. The solution proposed by Sir William Gunn may be seriously put and it may be as ingenious, ill-researched and lacking in foundation and credibility as the attack which he made upon me and my Committee and some of the other activities in which he engaged earlier in his unfortunate record. A man who said at a Press conference in Melbourne that it is perfectly all right to fiddle an expense account-that is what he said-and who said on the AM program today that the payment of bribes where you have to pay bribes is perfectly acceptable is a man whom I believe Australia can judge on his own utterances.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a group of Bills-the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Amendment Bill, the Export Control Bill and the Export Control (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill. I use language a little loosely because I think the debate has been a little wider than the subject matter of the Bills. However, I note from the rather wide debate which has occurred that there is substantial support from all parties on these measures. I think the Opposition, the Australian Democrats and Government supporters have all spoken in favour of these measures. That being the case, I do no more than remind the chamber that the purpose of the Export Control Bill is merely to establish a new and comprehensive legislative base for export inspection and control responsibilities within the portfolio of the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon). The Export Control (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill introduces amendments which are consequential to the introduction of the Export Control Bill. The Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Amendment Bill strengthens the Corporation's control over Australia' s export trade and in particular enables the Corporation, in very specific circumstances, to adopt the role of a sole trader or to limit the number of licensees that may trade with a particular overseas market. I thank honourable senators for their support on this Bill and I commend it to the Senate for speedy passage.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.
Progress reported.

DEBATE.TITLE: EXPORT CONTROL BILL 1982EXPORT CONTROL (MISCELLANEOUS AMENDMENTS) BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 6 May, on motion by Senator Durack:
That the Bills be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.
Ordered that the Bills be considered separately.
EXPORT CONTROL BILL 1982
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats amendments, as circulated, are as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 7, clause 10, sub-clause (3), paragraph (a), leave out the paragraph.
(2) Page 7, clause 10, sub-clause (3), paragraph (b), line 15, leave out 'other '.
(3) Page 7, clause 10, sub-clause (3), paragraph (e), after 'premises', insert 'entered in accordance with this section'.
(4) Page 7, clause 10, sub-clause (3), paragraph (g), after 'premises', insert 'entered in accordance with this section'.
(5) Page 7, clause 10, sub-clause (3), paragraph (h), after 'premises', insert 'entered in accordance with this section'.
(6) Page 7, clause 10, sub-clause (3), paragraph (j), after 'premises', insert 'entered in accordance with this section'.
(7) Page 7, clause 10, sub-clause (5), lines 30 and 31, leave out 'other than registered premises'.
(8) Page 8, clause 11, after sub-section (3), add the following sub-clauses:
'(4) An application may be made to the Secretary by the owner of any goods, matters or things seized under sub-section (1) for the release to the owner of those goods, matters or things.
'(5) An application may be made to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for a review of a refusal by the Secretary of an application made under sub-section (4 ).

'(6) For the purpose of sub-section (5), where the Secretary has not acceded to an application under sub-section (4) within 10 days after that application has been made, he shall be deemed to have refused that application.'.
I seek leave to move the amendments in three groups: Firstly, amendments Nos (1) , (2) and (7); secondly, amendments Nos (3), (4), (5) and (6); and thirdly amendment No. (8).
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 7, clause 10, sub-clause (3), paragraph (a), leave out the paragraph.
(2) Page 7, clause 10, sub-clause (3), paragraph (b), line 15, leave out 'other '.
(7) Page 7, clause 10, sub-clause (5), lines 30 and 31, leave out 'other than registered premises'.

I believe that Senator Tate wishes to speak, so I will be brief. Amendments Nos 1, 2 and 7 refer to registered premises. Whereas in the actual definition registered premises are indeed premises to be registered, nowhere else in the Bill can one manage to discover any interesting facts about them, which I believe leads one to wonder just what is in fact going on with them. For example , why are the premises to be registered, what are they to be registered for, how are they to be registered, what advantages accrue as a result of that registration and why should they be able to be entered without a warrant?

A reference in paragraph 207 of the Law Reform Commission's criminal investigation report No. 2 suggests that the power to detain and search suspected persons or vehicles should be restricted in its application to customs areas, which would be defined to include ports, wharves, dock-side warehouses, customs halls, airport aprons and their environs. I seek from the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) an answer as to what precisely is the intention of the Government to register premises and whether that relates to the Law Reform Commission's reference to customs areas. The important questions are as to why they are to be entered without warrant and what is the intention of the Government in putting such an item in this Bill. I must admit that I have really raised these questions because I am puzzled about precisely what is going on.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is not supporting amendments Nos. 1, 2 and 7 which Senator Macklin has moved. Essentially the requirement is for a search warrant for the entry of registered premises. There are two reasons for our decision not to support the amendments. Firstly, if a premise is registered and therefore has conferred upon it some sort of privilege , it seems to be logical that it ought to be subject to inspection to make sure it is abiding by the conditions under which that privilege is granted. Secondly, given the recent proven malpractice which has occurred in some meat export establishments, it seems to be an unacceptable interference with the efficiency of the inspection service to require a search warrant for entry to premises.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, I want to point out to honourable senators that the Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills considered these provisions of the Export Control Bill 1982 and the Australian Meat and Live- stock Corporation Amendment Bill 1982. Indeed, it alerted honourable senators, by means of Alert Digest No. 6, to the fact that under clause 10 an authorised officer could enter registered premises in the way that has been outlined by Senator Macklin. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee was particularly concerned that forcible entry may be effected by an authorised officer. Therefore, it wrote to Senator Chaney as the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry in this place. The Committee received a reply from Senator Chaney which indicated to the Committee-I will not go into the reply in detail because honourable senators can read the Scrutiny of Bills Committee's report No. 7-that to achieve forcible entry a further separate provision would be required and that that was not a danger under the present legislative provisions. Therefore, the Committee took the view that it would not press the matter any further. At that stage, I was Acting Chairman of the Committee. I replied to Senator Chaney-I want to put this on the record of this place-at that time. I think it was the first occasion on which the Scrutiny of Bills Committee had received such a response from a Minister to an Alert Digest entry. Having received his explanation, at the conclusion of my letter I said:

SPEECH.PARA: May I say that I very much appreciate the obvious trouble to which you have gone in responding to the Alert Digest, and I believe it is the realisation of the hope of those who supported the establishment of the Committee.
Indeed, I thank the Minister and the officers who assisted him for responding so quickly to the Committee's concern at that stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Tate for his comments. Senator Tate may or may not have seen the personal note that I appended to my original letter. I wrote it in some trepidation. The Standing Committee on Scrutiny of Bills is a new committee and I was not sure how it would receive views from the Executive Government in the course of its deliberations. I wrote a personal note to the Chairman of the Committee, Senator Alan Missen, who was then absent, in words to the effect that if it was out of order he might like to return it to me. I am pleased that the Committee thought that this was a benign act and not an intimidatory one. The letter I wrote set out the reasoning behind the Government's belief that, as a matter of policy, there ought to be a power to enter registered premises. The actual registration of premises is a matter which is to be governed by regulation. Clearly, when one looks at the objects of the legislation, to provide for the control and export of certain goods and for related purposes-one is looking at premises which are registered for purposes related to the export of goods. If people are to seek permission to enter into the export trade and we are to have a system of inspectors who will ensure that conditions are met-one has to bear in mind, as Senator Walsh has said, the recent history of this matter-it seems to be a matter of logic that inspectors should have right of entry to premises which have been brought forward specifically as premises which are to be registered for this purpose. Inspectors who are to make sure that the premises comply with requirements should have a right of entry. Paragraph (b) of clause 10 (3) states that an authorised officer may enter any other premises with the consent of the occupier or in pursuance of a warrant. But the Government suggests that it is reasonable and is not an undue trespass on liberty to have permission to enter registered premises-not to make forcible entry but to enter registered premises without a warrant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the explanation that the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) has given goes part way towards meeting what is set out in my amendments. I wonder whether it would have been possible to give more detail in the Bill itself. I believe that, elucidatory information being given elsewhere in the Bill, the provision giving the right of entry to registered premises is not necessarily a good provision. I do not believe that the provision allowing regulations to be made in this respect is terribly appropriate either. However, I accept fully that what the Minister has put forward is appropriate. I presume that a person seeking the registration of premises implicitly gives permission for the premises to be entered. Therefore, what is proposed in the Bill seems to be a perfectly reasonable proposition. For that reason, and in light of the Minister's reply, it is probably best if I do not press my amendments. Therefore I seek leave to withdraw the amendments I have moved.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; amendments withdrawn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Page 7, clause 10, sub-clause (3), paragraph (e), after 'premises', insert 'entered in accordance with this section'.
(4) Page 7, clause 10, sub-clause (3), paragraph (g), after 'premises', insert 'entered in accordance with this section'.
(5) Page 7, clause 10, sub-clause (3), paragraph (h), after 'premises', insert 'entered in accordance with this section'.
(6) Page 7, clause 10, sub-clause (3), paragraph (j), after 'premises', insert 'entered in accordance with this section'.
Amendments Nos. 3 to 6 are of a technical nature. They refer to clause 10 (3), about which previous discussion took place. That sub-clause states:

For the purposes of performing the function of an authorized officer under this section or exercising a power of an authorized officer under section 11, an authorized officer may, with such assistance as he thinks necessary-

Then there is a list-paragraphs (a) to (k)-of what he may do. For example, paragraph (a) refers to entering registered premises. A problem arises in relation to the possibility, presumably, under paragraph (g) whereby an officer may inspect and examine any premises and, under paragraph (e), search any premises. It would be assumed-I seek reassurance on this point; this is the reason these amendments have been put forward-that the powers in relation to the searching, inspection, examination and securing of such premises could be done only pursuant to the powers of entry set out elsewhere in this section. It is not clear that this is necessarily the case. I seek the advice of the Minister in relation to that matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will oppose these amendments, not on the grounds that it has any objection in principle to the point asserted by Senator Macklin, but simply because it is not necessary to insert those words to achieve the objective. The reference to premises in clause 10 (3) (e) relates to a search which does not give rise to any independent right of entry, in the view of the Government. In other words, one is not looking at a situation in which one could illegally enter and then claim the protection of clause 10 (3) (e). The entry provisions are in paragraph (a), which we previously dealt with. An officer may enter registered premises or other premises with the consent of the occupier or in pursuance of a warrant. No one has any objection to that. The later provisions relate to what an officer may do after entry and do not amount to a separate authority for entry.

SPEECH.PARA: It is on that basis that I oppose the amendment and request Senator Macklin again to take the course that he recently followed. Were we in a position in which the Export Control Bill was going back to the House of Representatives anyway, I might take the view that it does not really matter because the amendment, at worst, is redundant; it makes explicit what is presently implicit. On previous occasions when dealing with amendments of this sort I have agreed, when they simply make the meaning doubly clear, that the objective be attained. I ask the Committee not to follow that course in this case because of the delay which would be occasioned and which I do not believe is warranted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make an explanation. I stated during the debate at the second reading stage that the Opposition would support some of the amendments which Senator Macklin moved. The reasons for that stated intention of support were those which Senator Chaney has given; that is, as we saw them, the proposed amendments made explicit what in my layman's opinion was implicit in the original Bill. Evidently that layman's opinion is confirmed by professional opinion. However, I have since taken note of the fact that if these amendments, acceptable in principle though they are, were to be carried tonight the enactment of the Export Control Bill would be delayed until the Budget session of the Parliament. For those reasons we have decided not to support the amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (8) Page 8, clause 11, after sub-section (3), add the following sub-clauses:
'(4) An application may be made to the Secretary by the owner of any goods, matters or things seized under sub-section (1) for the release to the owner of those goods, matters or things.
'(5) An application may be made to the Administrative Appeal Tribunal for a review of a refusal by the Secretary of an application made under sub-section (4 ).

'(6) For the purpose of sub-section (5), where the Secretary has not acceded to an application under sub-section (4) within 10 days after that application has been made, he shall be deemed to have refused that application.'.

The last of the amendments is Amendment No. 8, which relates to the seizure of goods and the right of appeal in relation to the seizure of goods. I have sought to provide a right of appeal where the Secretary refuses to give up, within the 60 days set out in the Bill, goods which have been seized. The problem that I see here does not relate so much to larger organisations-that amount of time may not unduly concern them-but rather to smaller businesses from which the seizure of certain goods could very well be the end of that business or, if not the end, seriously damage a person's livelihood.
In many cases there may be only a one-off importation of particular goods for a business and that delay could be sufficient to take that business to the wall.

At that point one could well ask: Why has a person not been given the ability to make an appeal? One possible reply is that an appeal may take 60 days before it is heard. I do not think that that is necessarily so. At least there is not a necessary connection between that time and the time to make an appeal against the seizure of the goods. I seek the Minister's explanation as to why the Government has considered that 60 days is perfectly adequate and how it proposes to meet the problem faced by a small business when possibly the majority of the goods needed for its operation are seized.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Despite the courteous exchange of correspondence between the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) and the Senate Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills there was eventually no meeting of minds. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee is of the same view as Senator Macklin, namely, that we have a situation here in which the seizure of goods for up to 60 days without an appeal against the refusal of the Secretary to return those goods could create a situation in which the business could be very severely impaired or even completely put to the wall, to use Senator Macklin's colloquial expression. The Committee alerted honourable senators and indeed the Executive, as it turned out, to this possibility in the Alert Digest. After receiving a reply from the Minister the Committee undertook a further investigation and found that its point of view was the same as that which had been adopted by the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances in its thirtieth report to the Parliament relating to a Norfolk Island ordinance. In that case a health inspector could remove any item from a hairdressing establishment-this is some way apart from the problem with which we are confronted in this legislation but the analogy holds-and hold it for up to 14 days, once again without any right of appeal to the owner of the hairdressing establishment to recover that item, an item which the Regulations and Ordinances Committee thought could be essential to carrying on the business.

SPEECH.PARA: The Regulations and Ordinances Committee recognised, as we recognise, that this power would probably not be exercised in an arbitrary manner, but nevertheless the danger is there. The Secretary may-indeed he is not required to give any reason why he is refusing to return the seized item from, for example, a meatworks or prescribed premises-for reasons which are completely inaccessible, refuse to return those items that have been seized and thus bring about the severe impairing of a commercial undertaking and maybe its destruction. Therefore the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, in its report No. 7, alerts honourable senators to the fact that this provision might well be regarded as unduly trespassing on or interfering with rights and liberties. I would like to press the matter further but, given the fact that we are in an untenable position, to amend this provision would be to defer the passage of this most important legislation because the House of Representatives cannot receive it from us for its consideration. Therefore we are forced to make our comments and resume our seats. However, we hope that in a more leisurely moment, when both Houses are sitting in the next session, this matter can be addressed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope that we will deal with this amendment not because of any undue pressure but because the logic of the position, I believe, supports its defeat and the maintenance of the status quo. I will take just a couple of minutes to explain why I think that is so. I first draw from Senator Tate's remarks the confirmation that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee is looking at areas where there is a possibility that provisions may unduly trespass on individual rights and liberties. That involves in each case an exercise of judgment and I have been grateful for the way in which the Committee has exercised its responsibilities so far in simply drawing to the attention of the Senate possibilities which require consideration.

SPEECH.PARA: It is well known that in many cases we do things which certainly affect the rights and liberties of the subject. Frequently, for example, in legislation we reverse the onus of proof. On hundreds of occasions, I suppose, I have taken prosecutions under section 220 of the Health Act in Western Australia, which puts the onus on the defendant to show, once certain things have been established, that food is of the nature, substance and quality demanded by the purchaser. There was a reversal of onus because in the enforcement of the rules of hygeine, pure food laws and so on it was seen that the defendant was in the best position to provide the evidence. The onus of proof was reversed. I do not believe that that unduly trespassed on individual rights and liberties. Commonwealth legislation in the same way is full of such provisions. We are asked to look at them and ask whether they are justified in the circumstances.

Here we are dealing with legislation which concerns a major Australian industry , an industry which we are painfully and recently aware can be besmirched by the actions of a tiny minority. It is a serious business for Australia and we are looking at the situation in which there can be great public risk. The Senate Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills has, I think, very properly drawn our attention to this and said: 'Well, look. Is it possible to reduce the disadvantages which can be suffered?' It draws some comfort from the views of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances on an ordinance affecting Norfolk Island but there is a distinction, I think, between those two ordinances which is evident in the report of the Committee. That distinction is that the Norfolk Island ordinance involves the inspector directly enforcing the provisions. In other words, the Regulations and Ordinances Committee was concerned about the lack of any control over a man who was directly exercising the power to enforce what was contained in the ordinance. In this case we are looking at a situation in which authorised officers are trying to ascertain whether there have been breaches of the law. They are engaged in an exercise which, if it seems that the law has been breached, will take us into the courts to establish that a breach has in fact occurred.

I agree that there can be difficulties here for defendants or for persons whose goods are seized. I am not denying that for a moment. I am asking whether the difficulty is beyond that which should reasonably be imposed in these circumstances. We have examined the position and taken advice from our professional advisers to see whether they think that the provision could be reduced in some way. For example, could the time of the seizure or the time in which some action must be taken be reduced? I refer to the advice that was given . We looked, for example, at the proposition of perhaps a 30-day provision with the power for it to be extended by a court. Our advice is that any period less than 60 days could well be inadequate for proper investigation to be carried out to enable a determination whether a prosecution should be instituted.

When we look at the structure of the clause itself, which is not a direct enforcement section but a prelude to court proceedings or the discovery of a breach which is different from the Norfolk Island situation, and when we look at the significance of this trade and at the now, unfortunately, established fact that the actions of a small number of people can do such major harm to the reputation of the industry and potentially great economic harm to Australia, I think that the disadvantages in the section appear to be warranted. I would suggest that in all these things it is a matter of judgment. To my mind the judgment in this case is one that the Senate can make without feeling it is unduly trespassing on the rights and liberties of the subject.
Amendment negatived.
Bill agreed to.
EXPORT CONTROL (MISCELLANEOUS AMENDMENTS) BILL 1982
Bill-by leave-taken as a whole and agreed to.
Bills reported without amendment or requests; report adopted.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN MEAT AND LIVE-STOCK CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL 1982

Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.
Bill (on motion by Senator Chaney) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 5 May, on motion by Senator Sir John Carrick:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1982 is not opposed by the Opposition, although we will move an amendment which, while drawing to the attention of this chamber shortcomings in the legislation, will not prevent its passage. Since 1976 I have been the Opposition spokesman on health in this chamber. In that time I have witnessed five attempts by the Government to introduce a health insurance scheme and health program which works . All these schemes have failed, as the Opposition had said they would. They have all needed amendments to cope with inequities and ambiguities, as this schemes does, and as this legislation attempts to do. Even so, the scheme, like its predecessors, is headed for failure. The basic problem has always been that the Government has, in designing health programs and health insurance schemes, tried to perform the impossible. It has tried to placate the health insurance funds which supported it at election time with money and manpower-a greedy approach, I suggest, of 'If you will scratch my back I will scratch yours'-which resulted in the insertion in the legislation of sections which led to notorious rip-offs and anti-social behaviour on the part of people running some of these funds.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, the Government has tried to cope with and listen to the extremists on the right of the medical profession, those who particularly abound in such organisations as the General Practitioners Society in Australia and the Australian Association of Surgeons, groups which I must add by no means represent a majority of the medical profession. These people are members of the same groups which in the past have started such organisations as the Workers Party and the Progress Party. They are vigorous supporters of all the right-wing and extremist causes, such as support for South Africa and apartheid, but above all they believe that the free market system is the best means of providing medical services in Australia. Indeed, why should they not do so? It is this market in which they and only they, the providers of services, know what is going on and over which they therefore are in a position to have full control. They have a monopoly of supply and information in the delivery of medical services, which causes so many of our problems.

Those of us on this side of the chamber who have pointed out the fallacy and the danger of such a situation in health are pleased that at least it seems that at last the Government agrees with us. The problems facing the profession in the practice of medicine and in the control of the delivery of health services were put by Senator Sir John Carrick in introducing this Bill in words which could well have been used by Opposition senators in the past five years. On page 1847 of the Senate Hansard of 5 May it is stated:

In commercial terms, medical practitioners are in a virtually unique position. The financial structure of their practices is largely underwritten by the medical benefits scheme which is publicly financed through both taxation and medical benefits fund contributions. Furthermore, most patients are generally not in a position to question the correctness of medical accounts.
Or the correctness of medical procedures. The speech continued:
The operation of the medical benefits scheme is therefore very heavily dependent upon the trustworthiness of medical practitioners.

We cannot have a free market situation in health. The seller-in this case, the doctor-has all the knowledge and the buyer is not in a position to know, nor in most cases to have any idea of the justification or the costs of the procedures per- formed. Yet we have had repeatedly brought out in this chamber the old canard that by controlling the patient we will control the services delivered and therefore we will control the cost. This legislation at least recognises that this is nonsense.

The Bill has differing and unrelated purposes, as have all omnibus Bills of this type. It provides for the inclusion of the mumps vaccine in the nation's vaccination program, a procedure which the Opposition certainly will agree to. Apart from being a dangerous and very inconvenient disease in some circumstances the success of such a vaccination scheme would make life much easier for all post-pubertal boys who seem to have great anxiety about the incidence of this disease in the community. Therefore, of course the Opposition does not oppose this. The Bill also provides for the tightening up of provisions dealing with medical fraud and makes the operation of committees which look at the medical overservicing in this community more effective. The Opposition does not oppose these provisions but believes that they could be improved and that in the future they will have to be improved. The legislation introduces a series of amendments to the Health Insurance Act and the National Health Act to cover certain technical anomalies in the present system.

Most interest in this legislation is directed to those sections which deal with fraud and overservicing. There was a time in this place when any mention of fraudulent behaviour, or even of overservicing, by members of the medical profession was greeted with screams of 'doctor bashing' by my Tasmanian colleague Senator Walters who I notice is on the list of speakers tonight. I hope that tonight she will at least recognise that there is some overservicing, that there is some fraudulent behaviour by doctors, that we have to do something about that and that the Government is attempting to do something about it. The Government and the Australian Medical Association recognise that this occurs. It has been claimed that some 2,500 doctors, or 10 per cent of the doctors in this country, were in some way defrauding the Government or overservicing and that 900, or 4 per cent, were involved in major fraud. This may seem a small number. It recognises the fact that most of my medical colleagues do not indulge in such practices. Such practices did not start with the introduction of Medibank, as some people are wont to claim. Medibank, in tightening up the procedures, certainly made detection of such fraud easier and drew attention to its occurrence in a way that had not been done before.

The only certain way, I suggest, of reducing the level of this anti-social and criminal behaviour is, firstly, by increasing to as near as possible to 100 per cent the possibility of detection of fraud and, secondly, by making the penalties for the same sufficient to be a deterrent. Insofar as this legislation is a move in the right direction, we welcome it. We believe it could have gone further, hence our amendment. But within the present system it is certainly an improvement on what has gone before. To overcome fraud there has been an administrative tightening up of the procedures for recording accounts and item numbers. The profile procedures of the Department of Health will be more effective than they have been in the past. The penalty of ineligibility for medical benefits for three years after two offences of fraud are committed is a potent one if it can be applied without too much difficulty because of technicalities in the courts or too many delays in the courts' procedures. It is worth pointing out that the Department's discussion paper, which we acquired through various means earlier this year and which has received considerable publicity, stated:

In comparing the extent of fraud perpetrated by members of the medical profession, and the extent perpetrated by the public, the latter pales to insignificance. An independent observer could not fail to be concerned about both the success rate of medical profession vis a vis public prosecutions and the relative weight of penalties imposed on members of the medical profession vis a vis members of the public.

So we have a problem. The problem is, first of all, detecting the fraud; secondly, securing conviction; and thirdly, applying reasonable penalties. A colleague in another place, Dr Neal Blewett, and other members of this Parliament have pointed out the difference in attitude of people in this Parliament and the community toward that very small number of people who defraud the social security system, sometimes unintentionally, of very small amounts and to the greater percentage who defraud the medical health insurance system for very much larger amounts. Those who continuously cry from the roof-tops and from the tree-tops about problems created by the supporting parents benefit or unemployment benefit frequently remain mute in regard to the much greater fraud perpetrated by the otherwise socially respectable people who indulge in it in these cases. They get away with it not only because of community attitudes but also because of the complexity of the cases, the number of items involved, the inadequacy of the investigating procedures and the extraordinary rulings by some of the courts. I refer to the Queensland case, which is known to some of us, whereby the court ruled that a doctor did not have to attend a patient to perform a service in a clinical situation.

I suggest that many of these difficulties will remain because we are dealing with a complex area of white collar crime where the normal processes of the law are sometimes inefficient and sometimes inappropriate. The individual cases can be proceeded with difficulty but they can be proceeded with successfully. But they must be proceeded with on an individual basis. The total enormity of someone's malpractices, in fact, may not be obvious to those who have to sit in judgment in this situation. It is for that reason that we favour the production of generalised and technological evidence from the computer files to allow some measure of the magnitude of the crime to be presented to the courts. We believe this should be done after the conviction but before the sentence. We believe, of course, that the person charged should be allowed to refute or rebut the evidence in that situation. It is an unusual procedure; it is not a unique procedure, but it is a procedure which we believe is worth considering in this situation, hence its addition in our amendment. Such a proposal may be a change but, as I have said, it is not new. It has been suggested by the Government's advisers and we believe the Government should have given it more thought.

Another possibility which apparently has not been considered by the Government is to use the method of involving small but varying numbers of consumers-that is patients-in spot checks to verify the procedures for which they, the health funds and the taxpayers have to be billed. This method is used in Canada. It is used in some countries in Western Europe and not only acts as a means of detecting fraud but also, we believe, acts as a means of deterring fraud, hence our inclusion of it in the amendment. The amendment does not prevent the passage of the Bill but we believe it draws the attention of this chamber and of the public to ways which will have to be, to say the least, considered and which will have to be looked at in the future.

The increased powers over the activities of health funds, which are also part of this legislation, are needed but I believe they also do not go far enough. We still remain with the system whereby those who contribute to these funds, which are licensed and allegedly regulated by the Government, in the belief that they are protecting themselves from the costs of health care and who do so because, under the present system, they are in fact more or less compelled to, have no guarantee that the funds will continue in service. They have no guarantee that they will have any protection if the funds collapse. Despite the changes in this legislation we still have the situation in which we could have a repeat of the collapse of the Druids scheme which occurred in Tasmania and affected people largely from the region of Tasmania from which I came. In that area there have been very severe economic effects on patients, hospitals and doctors. Yet those who were responsible for the management of that fund and who abused the trust with which the contributors had put their money in the fund, in fact, have got off scot-free. I dare say that unless the reports on that organisation are released publicly they will continue to get off scot-free.

Although we do not oppose the passage of this legislation because of the improvements it makes in this difficult area, we believe it is only one step along the road to overcoming the very real problems which face patients, taxpayers and contributors to health funds in this community. It is only one step towards overcoming the problems faced by that small group of people who will continue to defraud the system. Until recently there was a great reluctance to recognise that small group of people. Also we believe that further legislation will be necessary to ensure that the health funds under this system are working efficiently and that the people who contribute to them are protected .

Finally, in the long run whatever changes are made to this health insurance scheme and the system of health care delivery will not be effective in providing equity and justice to the people who deserve it. They will not be effective in providing a health insurance scheme which is available to all at a reasonable cost. They will not be effective in providing a health scheme in which people will be completely free from the fear of the costs of health care, as people are in some other countries. They will not be successful because the basic premise on which Government and the present Minister operate, even though the Government has modified it, is one in which the Minister and his colleagues believe that the most appropriate way to deliver health care is in some sort of free market situation, as though it were a bazaar in which people could barter for their services. As long as that attitude persists-it is an attitude which has long been dropped in most Western civilisations-we shall have a health scheme that is ineffective.

For the small benefits and improvements that this legislation provides, we are grateful, and I am sure that the community will be grateful. But in the long run we shall need a sixth scheme, a scheme which is much better than the present one . As I say, we do not oppose the legislation. I move the amendment in the hope that it will draw the Government's attention to the difficulties that it still faces. I move:
At end of motion, add ', but the Senate is of the opinion that the following additional measures are necessary to combat medical fraud:
(a) elimination of technical ambiguities hampering the courts;

(b) provisions for admitting generalised evidence to the courts after conviction on specific charges but prior to sentencing, with full opportunity for the convicted practitioner to counter the evidence, and
(c) adoption of verification procedures through medical consumers'.
I have no reason to delay the Senate further tonight, or to delay the legislation further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the nice things about belonging to a party, the Australian Democrats, which forms neither the Government nor the official Opposition is that one does not get oneself locked into a position of having either to oppose viciously some legislation for the sake of opposing it, or, if one intends to support it, to do so in the rather churlish double negative of not opposing it and then spending three-quarters of one's speech complaining on matters of philosophy surrounding the legislation. In the interests of getting the Senate up as quickly as possible tonight, and in the rather cowardly self-interest of not wishing to get caught in the crossfire which is inevitable between Senators Walters and Grimes, it is my intention not to canvass various matters of philosophy with regard to health policy. I shall not canvass the question of the 'user pays' principle versus the idea that the community ought to pay for the health of the inhabitants of this country. I shall not decide whether it is a large or a small minority of doctors who are abusing the system. I shall not canvass the question whether Medibank, Marks I to VII, or Medicare, son of Medibank, or any other sort of private system is really the best way of running health care in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: What I should like to do tonight, instead, is to adopt the rather novel approach of directing my attention and that of the Senate to the legislation before us. It is, in fact, not the same piece of legislation which was first introduced on 25 March of this year to the House of Representatives by the present Minister for Transport and Construction (Mr Hunt), who made the second reading on that day. The Bill as it is before us intends to establish the same principles as the Bill that appeared on 25 March. It is just that it does it in a slightly more streamlined way and in a way which does not contravene individual liberties to the extent that the original Bill-inadvertently, I am sure-seemed to do.

As Senator Grimes has already pointed out, at some length, there are basically four elements to the Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1982 as already amended by the Government in the lower House. Three of the amendments are relatively minor. There is provision for the availability of free vaccine for immunisation against the disease of mumps. This aim is proposed to be achieved by combining the measles-mumps vaccine in those cases in which the single measles vaccine is provided. Since men are the ones who run around getting themselves so terribly upset about the possibility of catching mumps I am astounded, since the Parliament and the bureaucracy are largely made up of men, that we have not had this piece of legislation introduced before now. I suggest it is highly likely, since the majority of doctors in the community are men, that there will be more occasions on which the doctor will suggest to the mother of a boy that he be immunised against measles-mumps than that same doctor will suggest that the daughters in the same family be immunised against rubella.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are really wrong medically, you know. You really are.

—I certainly hope I am. I understand that governments, both State and Federal, are taking a great deal of interest in advertising rubella injections, and for that I commend them. I am not casting any aspersions at all on the aims of the Government or the Department of Health. I am simply making what is, I think, a perfectly accurate statement and that is that human nature being what it is many male doctors do forget the problems that many women and girls suffer from. Perhaps it is a little cynical but I do not think it is any the less true for that. The second minor amendment in this Bill refers to administrative streamlining concerning the issue of health care cards to people in the low income category which makes simpler the process by which there is continued eligibility for a disadvantaged person. The third provision provides for time limits to be imposed on the lodgement of claims for Commonwealth medical benefits, and there is a variety of good reasons for doing this.

SPEECH.PARA: The fourth provision is the most important. It is the one that Senator Grimes spent most of his time discussing and the one that I will spend the majority of these comments canvassing. This part of the legislation turns its attention to the community concern that has been engendered recently through the media across the country about what is commonly described as medical fraud, particularly by medical practitioners, through the benefits system. The Bill before us contains measures which, it is hoped, will provide a very strong deterrent for such abuse . In fact the Bill as it now stands probably provides a better means of deterrent than the original Bill did. I am not a member of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills and I have not taken as great an interest in it as my colleague Senator Macklin. I note that Mr Fife, the Minister who presented the amendments in another place, made the comment in his speech in the Committee stage on this amendment that the Government has been receptive to representations received on this matter. It pleases me to note that not only did the criticisms on the original clause come from groups such as the Australian Medical Association, which again is to be commended for its interest in the question of the medical practitioner fraud, but also from the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. I take this opportunity to commend that Committee for the wok that it has done. Mr Fife said:
It has now been decided that in view of problems that could be caused by the operation of the provisions as presently constructed--
He was referring to the original piece of legislation-

different procedures whereby patients of the disqualified practitioner could be advised of the particulars and effects of the disqualifications, should be adopted. It is felt that the provisions as presently drafted could infringe a person's rights to have his or her previous dealings with the medical practitioner remain confidential. Under the amendment now proposed the Minister for Health will be given the power to direct a convicted practitioner not to render any professional services to which a disqualification applies unless he has first taken steps to advise the person concerned of the particulars and effects of the practitioner's disqualification.

In view of Senator Grimes's somewhat unnecessary comments earlier tonight, I will quote from the comments made by Dr Blewett in another place following Mr Fife's comments about the amendment. Dr Blewett said:
The Opposition strongly supports the amendment.
It is nice to see the official Opposition strongly supporting something instead of just not opposing it. Dr Blewett said:

It raises an extremely difficult issue which occurs in all such cases as the one with which we are now dealing. We are all committed to a firm sanction against doctors who commit fraud. At the same time, we have the problem of guarding the rights and interests of the patients. It is very difficult to secure this kind of balance.

Indeed it is. It is something that the Australian Medical Association recognised . That organisation has been conferring on the matter of doctors' fraud for, to the best of my knowledge, the last five years. As recently as 3 February, the current President of the AMA, Dr Lionel Wilson, made a public statement which appeared in most newspapers in this country calling upon the Commonwealth Government to overhaul the system of dealing with suspected offenders because the current methods for dealing with fraud and overservicing by doctors have proved, in his words, totally inadequate. In making that statement, Dr Wilson offered the Association's full support in such an overhaul.

I noticed in today's newspapers bold headlines again accusing private hospitals and some of the doctors associated with them of fraud. The headlines are not likely to engender any increased confidence in some sections of the medical profession in the community. That, if for no other reason, is sufficient justification for this Government, or any other government for that matter, taking steps to do something about it. Everybody who speaks on this subject points out that only a minority of doctors are tarring the whole profession with a very unpleasant brush.

TALK.START.PARA: —Too many of them.
—I have not gone around counting them, Senator Georges. There may be too many of them; there are certainly some of them.
—It is before the Public Accounts Committee at the moment and it is much more widespread than is generally known.
—Order, Senator Georges. Senator Haines has the floor.

—It is also a topic which has come up before the Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes. We are all concerned that people in positions of trust such as doctors and lawyers can, as a group and as a profession, be called into disrepute simply because of the self-aggrandisement and self-interest of a few who have not only lost touch with reality in their all-consuming race for increased wealth and status, but also lost touch with people. It is bad for the profession and it is bad for the community. The Australian Democrats are, therefore, prepared openly and with some pleasure to support the Government, not only for its original piece of legislation and for the intentions shown in that legislation but also for having the commonsense and the good grace to amend its own legislation when it was found wanting by community groups and by the Senate Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition's amendment to the second reading motion is another one of those pious sorts of platitudes. We certainly agree with it. The amendment implies that the legislation is all right but it does not go far enough. Certainly we would like to see the elimination of the technical ambiguities which are at present hampering the courts. We would like to see provisions for admitting generalised evidence to the courts, allowing, of course, full opportunity for the practitioner to counter the evidence. We would like to see the adoption of verification procedures through medical consumers. All of those things are devoutly to be wished. I wonder how high they are on the priority list of the Opposition should it eventually come into government. Therefore, in essence the Democrats support this legislation. We support its intention. We support the contents of the Bill and we wish it a speedy passage through the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are considering amendments to both the Health Insurance Act and the National Health Act. The major emphasis of the legislation, as both previous speakers have indicated, is the strong deterrent to that group of medical practitioners who would indulge in medical benefit fraud. The President of the Australian Medical Assocation, Mr Lionel Wilson, has joined with the Government in its concern that a small minority of AMA members tarnish the image of the vast majority of their colleagues. Therefore the AMA supports the aim of the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite what Senator Haines said, I found Senator Grimes's speech most refreshing. It was the first time I have heard Senator Grimes refer to the fact that only a small number of doctors are engaging in medical benefits frauds. I am sorry that the Commonwealth does not have the power to deregister this group of doctors. As the majority of people would know, the States have this power. The AMA has no teeth in the matter. As a matter of fact, only 65 per cent of doctors belong to the AMA. The AMA has absolutely no power to deregister doctors or to take any punitive action whatsover. It only has the right to say to a doctor that he can no longer be a member of the Association. That does not stop a doctor practising. That has no detrimental effect on a doctor's practice at all. The AMA has no power and it is for this reason that the AMA has joined with the Commonwealth and supports the aim of the Bill.

As I said, I am extremely sorry that the powers of the Commonwealth do not extend to deregistration. Consequently, we have taken the only action that I believe is open to us. The complicated court system demands that every occurrence where a doctor defrauds a patient or a medical benefits scheme must be ticked off and a Federal court can penalise a doctor for only that item. The legislation before us tonight provides that a doctor has to be proven guilty of medical benefit fraud on only two occasions. Once a doctor is found guilty on two occasions his services will not be able to attract medical benefit payments for up to three years.

As Senator Haines has indicated, to protect a patient from being disadvantaged the doctor is required, prior to giving professional service, to hand to a patient a notice saying that has been convicted of fraud and that no medical benefit payment will be made for his service. If that patient is under the care of another person that person must be informed. If a patient is unable to read then the doctor must take action to inform that patient. As I understand it, there will certainly be no need for the Government to police this. I am sure that if a doctor has not handed a patient such a notice, as soon as that patient tries to obtain his medical benefit payment and finds out that no medical benefit is payable for the service the patient will scream and certainly let us know that the doctor has not done what he should have done. A penalty will be imposed on the doctor in that situation. There are rights of appeal in the normal way to the High Court of Australia. There is also a method of appeal to the Minister for Health for a review of a disqualification if a doctor believes he has grounds for such a review. The Minister has the power to reduce the penalty.

The Bill also provides for the publishing and laying before each House of the Parliament of details of a doctor's disqualification. This will enable the public in general to have knowledge of such disqualification. These penalties, of course, are over and above that which the courts may impose. As has been said tonight, other amendments to the National Health Act provide free vaccine for immunisation against mumps and measles. A measles-mumps vaccine will replace the measles vaccine at a cost of $1.5m to the Commonwealth Government. This Bill contains technical amendments concerning continuity for those who receive a health benefit card. It was found necessary to do that. There is a need for the individual name of a doctor to be shown on accounts and receipts before medical benefits can be paid. This will prevent an attempt to use company names. It will also ensure the individual responsibility of the doctor to the patient and identify the doctor performing a service for a patient.

The Bill also makes provision for time limits on lodgment of claims for medical benefits, so doing away with unnecessarily large costs such as have been incurred by funds in tracing claims. Again, this Bill gives the Minister for Health powers to direct registered funds concerning management practice. I should like to refer to some provisions which cover this aspect. In the case of a registered organisation the Minister is given power to direct that organisation, if it is carrying on business other than the business of that organisation, to cease that practice. The Minister also may give a registered organisation a direction with respect to the management of its business. These provisions are extremely wide. Senator Grimes said tonight that they do not go as far as he would like them to go. Yet we find that the Minister has the power to give any registered fund a direction in respect of the management of its business. How much further can the legislation go? I do not think that the Minister's power can be widened. The Minister also has the power to direct that funds cease to carry out any business that is not associated directly with health care.

I note that these powers of direction give to the Minister do not fall into the same area as other direction of power given to the Minister in the primary Bill. In section 73BE the Minister is given power to direct funds in many respects. The Minister has had to exercise that power given to him in the primary Bill in the open. He has had to present the matter to both Houses of the Parliament. He has had to lay it on the table for 15 sitting days, giving the Parliament the power to scrutinise what the Minister had been doing. That is not so in clause 43 of the Bill.

I drew this matter to the attention of Senator Peter Baume when he was the responsible Minister, the new Minister for Health (Mr Carlton) and, indeed, the Government. I have been given assurances by the Government that in August when we return to this place, rather than reassemble members of the House of Representatives now to amend the Bill, an amendment will be put forward enabling any direction that the Minister may give to the funds to be brought before both chambers and laid on the table for 15 sitting days and providing the power of disallowance, so that the Parliament can scrutinise what the Minister is doing.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are too kind to the House of Representatives. You should bring them back now.

—I have a great tendency to care for taxpayers' money and I believe that the cost of bringing the House of Representatives back now would be a waste of that money. I am quite sure that Senator Colston would agree that it is not necessary. I refer now to another area that also needs amendment.
