These new directions are not able to be reviewed by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Should a fund feel that the Minister has made a wrong decision it has no power to appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. I am told that it is debatable whether that fund would have a right to appeal to the Federal Court of Australia. I would prefer the funds to be able to approach the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, and I will approach the Government on that issue also in August when I come back.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Grimes assured the Senate that I had always said that doctors were exemplary-far from it. As I said earlier, Senator Grimes has always said that doctors are crooks, that their profession ought to be nationalised and that there is no room for free enterprise in this field. He indicated that he believed that the fraud that doctors indulge in at the moment has been going on for a long time and that it was not commenced under Medibank. When Labor brought in Medibank the AMA warned that it was too open ended and that there was very little control over it. Honourable senators will remember that at that time the AMA was violently opposed to that great open ended bulk billing system. It certainly opened up the area of fraud. If Senator Grimes is correct in saying that this practice has been going on for a long while, why on earth did Senator Grimes's Government not prosecute the doctors for fraud in 1974 or 1975? I wonder why it did not because at this stage the Labor Party is saying that it is about time this Government took some action. I am surprised that the Opposition did not take some action in 1975. Senator Grimes's speech was against private enterprise; it was for nationalising medicine. This policy is in line with the Australian Labor Party's philosophy and should not surprise anyone.

I return to the main purpose of the Bill. As I said earlier, I am sorry the Commonwealth power is not broad enough to include deregistration provisions. I only hope the various States take up their responsibility in this area. In the meantime, I believe the Commonwealth has done what it can and I wish this Bill a speedy passage.
Debate (on motion by Senator Peter Baume) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Peter Baume)-by leave-agreed to:
That Standing Order 68 be suspended to enable new business to be commenced after 10.30 p.m. this day.
Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In debating the Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1982 I intend to speak principally on a matter about which I have some concern and apparently, from the line of debate that has been pursued already, a great number of honourable senators have concern. This matter is medical fraud. Certainly the size of medical fraud in Australia at the moment seems to be extreme. I will quote from the second reading speech of the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume), which gives some indication of the size of the fraud. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: It is now possible to estimate, from statistics compiled by my Department, that the extent of fraud and overservicing by some members of the medical profession is of the order of at least $100 million a year in medical benefits, of which about half is attributable to fraud and half to overservicing. My references to fraud relate to such matters as making claims for services that were not provided, whereas my references to overservicing relate to the provision of services which were not reasonably necessary.

That quotation from the Minister's second reading speech gives an indication of the extent of the fraud. If it is of this size it is essential that it be tackled. I do not believe that there is any question that it is of that size. Some of my colleagues believe it is even higher. I hold that whilst we have a fee for service system we will not eliminate fraud or overservicing. It is my contention that only when we have a total salary service-I cannot see that happening for many years-will fraud and overservicing be a minor problem. However if it amounts to $100m a year it is a great problem that we have to tackle. Earlier Senator Grimes mentioned a discussion paper which was circulated in the Department of Health. I would like to go through part of that discussion paper because initially it mentions the $100m that was referred to by the Minister in his second reading speech. Perhaps it is from that discussion paper or some other paper which was circulated within the Department of Health that the figure in the second reading speech was taken. The discussion paper which was circulated and which was mentioned earlier is titled 'Legal problems and possible solutions associated with prosecutions related to the Health Insurance Act'. I will refer to some earlier comments in that paper which indicate the extent of medical fraud in Australia. The paper states:

Fraud against the Health Insurance Act typically involves amounts ranging from the low thousands to several hundreds of thousands of dollars, perhaps millions. Almost invariably, these amounts are comprised exclusively of multiple similar instances of $10-$50 frauds over several years.
It further states:

Although it has not been possible to arrive at a definitive estimate of the total amount of fraud of this type, the Department of Health has estimated through its Fraud and Overservicing Detection System (FODS), that at least $100m a year is involved in fraud and overservicing and that fraud may be responsible for up to half of that amount.

I reiterate that if the fraud is of that size-there is no reason to suggest that it is not of that size or higher-it is a significant problem and the fee for service system that we have must be tightened up. The discussion paper indicates the number of medical practitioners involved. It states:
The detection system provides an accurate basis upon which to initiate further investigations . . .
Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: THE ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.
Question resolved in the negative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator COLSTON

TALK.START.PARA: —The paper states:

INTERJECT.PARA: The detection system provides an accurate basis upon which to initiate further investigations of particular practitioners. Currently the system indicates that there are of the order of 2,500 doctors who require further investigation of whom around 900 would be high priority.

If 2,500 medical practitioners require further investigation and about 900 of them are high priority, those figures in themselves might seem reasonably high, but I imagine that as a proportion of the medical practitioners who are in private practice in Australia it is fairly low. Even though it may be low, it is significant that so many doctors require further investigation.
Senator Peter Baume-It doesn't mean they are all guilty, does it? It means they require investigation.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator COLSTON

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly it does not mean that they are guilty. In fact, the majority of them would probably be cleared when the investigations were concluded, but there would probably be a very good reason why it was thought that investigation was required. We are looking at a fairly small proportion of medical practitioners out of the total medical practitioners who are in private practice and of that small proportion there is probably an even smaller proportion who are guilty of fraud. But even so, it indicates that the problem is a significant one if we reconsider that $100m a year that I mentioned earlier .

INTERJECT.PARA: The discussion paper to which I am referring has five separate sections. There is an introductory section; the second section discusses certain technical, legal and policy difficulties; the third section canvasses the difficulties of impressing courts of the magnitude of some frauds. One can quite readily understand that if some medical practitioner is taken to court for fraudulent behaviour it is more likely that a greater part of the fraudulent behaviour that he has been engaging in is not brought before the court. The fourth section discusses legislation to ensure that an offending medical practitioner does not continue with fraudulent behaviour and the fifth is a conclusion and summary of recommendations.

This evening I will refer only to the fourth section. It deals with possible legislation to punish further those medical practitioners who are convicted of fraud. Some of the assumptions in this section are questionable, but others are plausible. I will quote from the section which introduces this area of possible legislation to ensure that offending medical practitioners do not continue with similar behaviour. I mention too that throughout this paper the word 'doctor' is used. I will quote that although I would prefer to use the term 'medical practitioner' because most are not doctors in the true sense of the word and probably have just two bachelor's degrees.
Senator Peter Baume-Declare your interest, Senator.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator COLSTON

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not declaring my interest because my doctorate would probably not help anybody to get over a sore toe but the Minister's doctorate would do a lot more than that. The introductory part of section 4 of the paper states:

INTERJECT.PARA: Given that the penalty imposed rarely, if ever, reflects the extent of the suspected fraud, the doctor is not discouraged from abuse of the system.

Indeed, his experience in court will only have acquainted him with the deficiencies of the enforcement procedures; with the probable consequence that he will only become more devious and clever in his future abuse of the system. Such doctors are literally in the position of 'laughing all the way to the bank' , for they know that even if they are caught again, the gains far exceed any penalties.

After that introductory section, which mentions the difficulty of knowing what to do with medical practitioners who are convicted of fraud, the discussion paper goes on to propose a number of options, one of which is deregulation. That is quite difficult to achieve because it is a State matter. It was also mentioned by Senator Walters earlier. However, because it is such a difficult matter, the paper does not pursue it further.

Five other options are mentioned-and this is the nub of what I raise this evening-in providing legislation to ensure that offending medical practitioners do not continue similar activities after having been convicted of fraud. Option (i) is to legislate to provide, on conviction, disqualification of a doctor's services in regard to eligiblity for medical benefits. This would apply for a set period and would include the provision of legal protection for the Department in advertising this fact. The second option would also give the Minister for Health power to reduce the period and extend on specific grounds, for example, there being only one doctor in the region. In exercising such a power the Minister would be required to publish a statement of reasons. Basically the Government's position is identical with this second option. Option (iii) provided:

. . . legislate to provide that for a specific period (as specified in the legislation, or as imposed by the court, or determined by the Minister) the Department to be enabled to adjust a doctor's claims to conform to an acceptable pattern.

Thus, if a medical practitioner were convicted of fraud and option (iii) were used, the Department of Health, for a certain period, would be able to adjust the claims of a medical practitioner so that an acceptable pattern emerged. Option (iv) was option (iii) except that in addition the doctor would be required to bill directly for all services. Therefore all claims would be directed to the Department rather than through the funds and then to the Department. This would allow immediate monitoring and control. The discussion paper quite pertinently points out that if this option were considered it would be necessary to devise a mechanism in order to adjust payments with a registered organisation when insured patients were involved. Therefore, under option (iv), which included option (iii), the Department of Health would be able to adjust a medical practitioner's claims to an acceptable pattern. In addition, the medical practitioner would be required to bill directly for all services. This means that the Department would be able to keep a very strict control on what that medical practitioner was doing.

Option (v), which apparently was not accepted, and probably would not be by most honourable senators, entailed a mandatory gaol sentence for a second conviction in respect of services rendered after a first conviction. The paper concluded:
The solution favoured here is option . . . (ii)

As I mentioned earlier, option (ii) is basically the stance which was taken by the Government and embodied in the legislation that we have before us. I expect that the Minister obtained similar advice when the legislation came before him.

I ask why option (ii) was favoured. In the paper to which I refer there is no summary of points for and against the various options. There is no summing up to determine the best course of action. In military parlance, I suppose there was no real appreciation of the various options. If the Minister, and thus the Cabinet, received bald advice that the solution favoured is option (ii) it seems to me that the advice was defective unless points for and against those various options were given.

I would have favoured option (iv). Option (iv) was that for a specific period the Department of Health would be able to adjust the claims of medical practitioners to conform to an acceptable pattern and, in addition, that the medical practitioner would be required to direct bill for all services so that the Department would be able to keep a strict control over the services that the medical practitioner was providing. Had option (iv), which embodied option (iii) as well, been put into effect, it would have meant that the medical practitioner 's work would really be under a microscope. There would have been an effective curb on his or her ability to defraud again. It would have meant that a court conviction would not have been followed by a further penalty which effectively took away the livelihood of the medical practitioner.

I probably run the risk of appearing to wear my heart on my sleeve but I stress that the vast majority of medical practitioners are like any other people in society. They have families to care for and houses to build. One wonders what would happen to their families if their income were suddenly withdrawn. All we have to do to find out what members of the public think of medical practitioners is to ask them: 'What is your opinion of your own GP?'. Their own GPs are invariably described as very good people who help them and who would never defraud the government and it is all those other GPs who are said to be the fraudulent ones. In other words, if people know a general practitioner they have a high regard for him or her. It is only because of the publicity that some fraudulent medical practitioners gain that we have an opinion in society that all medical practitioners are like them.
Senator Collard-Like senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like members of parliament, yes. As I have said, I would have favoured option (iv), perhaps followed by option (ii). If further fraud took place after the imposition of the lesser penalty of option (iv), perhaps option (ii), which is a very strict option indeed, could be imposed. The Minister in summing up may be able to outline why consideration was not given to option (iv) . I say, in conclusion, that the financial extent of medical fraud in Australia seems to be great and therefore it is necessary, whilst we have a fee-for- service system operating in this country, to have some effective form of fraud control. For this reason, despite the fact that I have some misgivings, the Opposition does not oppose the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for the support they have given to the Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1982. I am grateful for the comments that have been made during the debate. The Bill has four main groups of features and honourable senators have discussed them. I will refer briefly to some of the matters which were raised during the debate. I refer to the question of the measles- mumps vaccine raised by Senator Haines only to make the point that both these illnesses, because they are common, are regarded as minor illnesses. In fact, both of them are very severe and serious illnesses of childhood. For example, the sequelae of measles are serious. In up to one per cent of children there is permanent central nervous system damage following an attack of measles. There is every reason to use vaccination methods which are available to try to control these illnesses. It has nothing to do with the sex of the potential patient. I am glad that honourable senators have given their support to that provision in the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Most of the discussion has centred around the provisions to control and combat overservicing and fraud by medical practitioners. A number of points have been made and I wish to comment on a couple of them. Senator Colston has asked, quite reasonably, in view of the options before the Government, why we came out in favour of one option and not another. In fact, the Government had before it a more detailed appreciation. The discussion that occurred within the Government examined the appreciation of each of the options. Every option, including option four, was considered. I believe Senator Colston was correct when he said that option two, the option that was picked up and embodied in this legislation, is a more severe option for the offending doctor than option four would be. It is a conscious decision of the Government that it should respond in this matter with the utmost severity. Because of the points that have been made by honourable senators during this debate, because of the seriousness with which these offences are viewed, it was considered that option two, the severe option, is the one which is most appropriate in this circumstance. I say again to Senator Colston that the other options were considered. The points of view which he has set out were carefully gone over. On a balance of judgment the Government adopted a slightly different position but did so, I think, following many of the same thought processes and with much the same appreciation that Senator Colston had.

A comment was made during the debate to the effect that the courts are sometimes deficient because they treat offenders leniently. Doctors who have been brought before the courts on charges related to health insurance matters are seen to get away with the proverbial slap on the wrist. Honourable senators will realise that the Bill now before the Senate has a particular quality which should be noted closely; that is, that it does not matter any more how lenient the courts might be in terms of the penalty they impose in relation to offences. It does not matter whether the courts impose a fine of $5 for two offences or whether they impose a sentence of 12 months' gaol. Convictions on two matters will be enough to bring a doctor within the ambit of the operations of this Bill . The Bill sets out administrative penalties which are a reflection of the Government's concern. These will be quite independent of anything imposed by the courts in pursuance of their own duties.

Of course, honourable senators are also correct when they draw attention to the desirability of the States taking action within their own areas of competence by way of examining the registration or registerability of doctors who have been found to be cheating against the public interest. There is no other way of looking at it. I speak as a medical practitioner; I declare my interest. Anyone who cheats against the health insurance system is cheating not only his profession and his patients, but also a wider public.

A couple of matters were raised by Senator Walters to which I think quite specific response is required. Senator Walters drew attention to clause 43 of the Bill and I would like to take this opportunity to inform honourable senators of the Government's intention in relation to clause 43. This clause will insert proposed new section 73BEA into the National Health Act to give to the Minister for Health the power to give directions to registered organisations with respect to their management practices. It is being enacted in an effort principally to deter registered organisations from engaging in undesirable management practices . The Minister will be able, where he has reasonable grounds for believing that an organisation is carrying on or proposes to carry on business other than the business of a registered health insurance organisation, to direct the organisation to refrain from doing so. He will be given-this is Senator Walters' s point of concern-a general power to give an organisation a direction with respect to the management of its business as a registered organisation.

Senator Walters's concern was about the capacity a Minister has in giving such directions. The Bill does not provide specifically for these powers to be subject to review. However, the Government has given further consideration to the matter and it now intends to introduce legislation during the Budget sittings of Parliament that will amend the National Health Act to require the tabling in both Houses of Parliament of directions made under these powers and to provide for the disallowance of those directions by either House of Parliament. That is to say, any directions will be subject to the scrutiny of the Parliament; they will remain within the purview of the Parliament.

Senator Walters also had a concern about the extent to which directions which are not disallowed can be contested. Directions issued under the proposed new section are not appealable to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal as are directions issued under another section-73BE. However, the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 provides for application to be made to the Federal Court for review of administrative decisions. I think Senator Walters expressed some doubt about whether the directions made under this proposed new section-I think it is clause 43 of this Bill-would be able to be taken to the Federal Court. It is thought that a registered organisation that is aggrieved by a decision made under the proposed new section 73BEA may make such an application to the Federal Court. No provision has been made for the directions under the proposed new section to be appealable to the AAT because they would not relate to health insurance matters but to undesirable inducements to attract new contributors, to the inefficient conduct of health insurance or to unrelated business activities. It is our understanding that the Federal Court would probably make the decision on whether it would hear any such appeal. However, in relation to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal I will undertake to bring the matter raised by Senator Walters to the attention of the Minister for Health (Mr Carlton) for his further consideration.

That leaves me to discuss only the matter of the amendment which has been moved by Senator Grimes on behalf of the Opposition. The amendment has three parts. The first part refers to the 'elimination of technical ambiguities hampering the courts'. Essentially, the matters the amendment tries to cover relate to the administration of justice. The Opposition surely would not be suggesting that some form of judicial discrimination should be applied to medical benefits fraud that is not applied to other matters which come before the courts. Paragraph (b) of the amendment reads:

. . . provisions for admitting generalised evidence to the courts after conviction on specific charges but prior to sentencing, with full opportunity for the convicted practitioner to counter the evidence . . .

Again we think that this is an inappropriate amendment to be moving at this stage. We think it is an inappropriate proposition. Fundamentally, it seeks to have the courts give consideration to matters when coming to sentence a person which have not been established by evidence before the court during the trial. In fact the proposition seems to us to be inconsistent with what many of us would consider to be the best course of justice.

The third limb of the amendment asks for the adoption of verification procedures through medical consumers. We are all medical consumers, and that, of course, means patients. The Government supports the concept of this part of the amendment. The Government has already positively encouraged the day to day operation of the medical benefits scheme in a way which makes the patient-the consumer in terms of the amendment-aware of the cost of services that he recieves. All this is not to say that the Government is satisfied with all the legal aspects of the prosecution of doctors for medi-fraud. It is exactly for that reason that the Government has introduced these novel and extremely strong administrative measures against what has been called medi-fraud in the Press. These measures virtually exercise to the limit the Commonwealth's constitutional powers in this area. Furthermore, the Government is already committed to undertaking negotiations with the States for them to pay close attention to the matters for which the States have sole responsibility-notably the deregistration of doctors.

I thank honourable senators for the support that they have given to this legislation and its aims, which are to improve the operation of both the Health Insurance Act and the national health arrangements. The Government will oppose the amendment for the reasons I have indicated. I commend the Bill to the Senate .
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: INTERNATIONAL FUND FOR AGRICULTURAL DEVELOPMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 May, on motion by Senator Peter Baume:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of this Bill is to authorise a further payment of $8,965,000 to the International Fund for Agricultural Development. The Opposition supports this Bill. It was due to the initiative of a former colleague, Ken Wriedt, as the then Minister for Primary Industry, who led the Australian delegation to the 1974 World Food Conference and others, that an organisation such as this was founded in order to respond to the needs of the least developed countries. IFAD is a United Nations-related fund and is based in Rome. It is unique in its system of voting. The developed countries, the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries and the developing countries have an equal voice in management. IFAD does not represent a duplication of the Food and Agriculture Organisation, which does not get involved with major project work, but in some senses it cuts across World Bank operations. IFAD is particularly sensitive to the needs of the least developed countries and provides funds in the form of grant-aid to such countries as Chad.

SPEECH.PARA: In Australia, the policy aspects of the Fund, such as its place in regard to North-South issues, are handled by the Economic Division of the Department of Foreign Affairs. The mechanics of the Fund are handled by the Australian Development Assistance Bureau. The Treasury has not always looked favourably on the Fund because of what it considers to be its poor management. However, the Fund has taken some time to get started and, in general terms, its management seems reasonable. The Opposition believes that it is in Australia's interests as a member of the international community to continue to support the International Fund for Agricultural Development by contributing the amount proposed by the Bill. The Opposition wishes it a speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats also support the International Fund for Agricultural Development Bill and wish it a speedy passage, but we are concerned about some aspects of the Government's aid program which I wish to mention specifically at this stage. The agreed aim of the International Fund for Agricultural Development-known as IFAD-is to mobilise financial resources from donor countries to be made available as loans on concessional terms for agricultural development in developing member states. Funds are directed primarily to projects specifically designed to introduce, expand or improve food production systems.

SPEECH.PARA: Certainly the need for the activities supported by the Fund has not diminished in recent years. In the 1978 annual report, the most recent available, the governing council of the Fund estimated that 20 per cent of the population in Africa, Asia and Latin America were at risk of starvation, which is a strong word. Yet the rate of growth of food production was recorded as being grossly inadequate. Of course there was also an accelerating loss of fertile land through overuse and erosion, which has amomious portents for the future. According to that report only a few developing countries reach an annual growth target of 4 per cent. In most countries it had been 2 per cent or less and in some it had been negative. The report stated that, if such trends were not reversed, by 1985 the gap between food needs and food availibilities in the developing countries would be larger than the 85 million tonnes predicted at the 1974 World Food Conference, at which, as Senator Sibraa has said, this Fund was founded, and the number of people suffering from malnutrition would grow even larger than the current alarming figures.

In the second reading speech the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) said that the Fund's activities are focused on the poorest nations and the poorest sections of rural populations. The Australian Democrats are concerned whether this ideal is being achieved and can be maintained, whether the poorest sections of the poorest nations where the need is greatest are receiving the benefit that they should have. Funds are channelled to projects which are, in most cases, government controlled or administered, and the social, cultural and political structures in most countries are such that in the first instance benefits would flow to those which are equipped with enough basic expertise to utilise the type of assistance provided. In many cases this turns out to be those with the larger landholdings. It is the vast mass of the very poor that concerns us, and believe me, a definite control of direction is necessary to help the poor. In multilateral programs such as this one as well as in its bilateral programs Australia should contribute not only money but also professional support in policy and technological areas if we are to achieve the Minister's laudable objective to direct aid to the people who need it most and most importantly to assist them in developing the expertise to help themselves.

For a long time our capacity to provide such assistance has been minimal. In recent years Australia has begun to make a worthwhile contribution through the Australian Universities International Development Program and to some extent through the Australian Development Assistance Bureau. The recent establishment of the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research was long overdue, but it is welcome as it will enable Australia, it is hoped, to make a more significant contribution of technological expertise than we have been able to do in the past. Here again this will happen only if its sense of the greatest need is accurate.

It must be a matter of great regret that the efforts to improve the Australian Development Assistance Bureau's performance have suffered a set-back with the appointment of its Director last April to the position of Executive Director of the World Food Program. Mr Ingram's departure for Rome was of course in one sense laudable because it was a welcome recognition of Australia's growing efforts in this field. However, the final point I wish to make is that the Government's gross neglect of ADAB as an organisation is inexcusable in the circumstances of our support through this kind of measure. It is not enough merely to throw money at things. According to our information, the top ten executive positions at ADAB are vacant and the Government seems to be in no hurry to fill them. I intend no reflection on the people who occupy those positions in an acting capacity when I say that an organisation of any kind, and especially one in this position with long term objectives, must be severely handicapped in its planning and decision-making capacity if this situation continues. The Democrats, as I said, support the Government in this bill, but question the Government's real commitment to meaningful assistance to developing countries unless it remedies quickly that situation I have mentioned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate for the speedy passage of the International Fund for Agricultural Development Bill. As has been said, under this Bill, Australia will contribute to the replenishment in the same proportion as our share of category I contributions in the initial mobilisation of resources, that is 1.74 per cent. As is Australia's normal practice with international financial institutions, payment will be made on the basis of lodging non-negotiable, non-interest bearing promissory notes. When lodged, the promissory notes will allow the IFAD to commit funds to new developmental projects with actual draw-downs occurring over an extended period of years. It is essential that this Bill be passed at this stage. We thank the Senate for the speedy passage of it. I think I can assure the Senate that the objectives of the fund are to help to increase agricultural production in developing countries. I feel it can be claimed that the work that has been done under this fund up to date has been directed primarily in that direction. I thank the Senate for its support.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.
Senate adjourned at 11.8 p.m. until Tuesday, 17 August 1982, at 3 p.m., or such other day and/or hour as may be fixed in accordance with the resolution of the Senate agreed to this day.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 19 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are the North Magdelaine, South Magdelaine, and Dianne Bank Cays, and Chilcott and South-West Islets, located about 270 nautical miles east of Cairns, under the control of the Commonwealth Government as part of the Coral Sea Islands Territory.
(2) Have any mineral claims been pegged on these cays; if so, when and by whom.
(3) Is the Commonwealth Government considering the declaration of land masses in this area as reserves or national parks.
(4) If the Commonwealth does declare part or all of this area reserve or national park, will any or all of the companies concerned be able to claim compensation from the Government.

(5) Is the Commonwealth considering granting some form of lease in this area which would permit mining and drilling activities to be undertaken; if so, would the companies concerned be in a position to make considerable financial gain from mining and drilling themselves or from disposal of the leases to other interested parties.
(6) Who are the directors and registered shareholders of the companies concerned, what are the addresses of the companies concerned and what is their nominal and paid-up capital.
(7) If the Commonwealth does propose to grant leases in this vicinity, where will application for granting of these leases be made and will they be open for public submission.

(8) Is the Minister aware of reports (Mr John Weeks, Cairns Post, 20 July 1981, page 1) that the trawler Impulse (Registered No. FQKM), was sighted pegging claims in June in this area; if so, did the vessel carry the necessary survey certificate to carry passengers for reward, assuming the trawler was chartered for this work.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) My colleague the Minister for Science and Technology has made available correspondence which he has received from Mr J. Weeks of Cairns in which Mr Weeks advises that on a visit in June last he found evidence of pegging for mineral claims in some of these areas. The matter was also reported in some detail in the Cairns Post. I understand that the pegging was on behalf of different companies but by the same agents.

(3) After consultation with appropriate Commonwealth authorities and with the Queensland Government, notices of reports recommending declaration of two National Nature Reserves in the area have been published. These call for comment from interested persons by 31 May 1982 and are the necessary first step under the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975 for declaration of reserves.
(4) I understand that no rights are created by the pegging.
(6) I have no information on this matter.
(7) See my answer to (5).

(8) The vessel was sighted at anchor at South-West Islet on 3 June 1981. At the time it held a Fishing Vessel Survey Certificate issued by the Queensland Department of Harbours and Marine. The law of Queensland and of the Commonwealth make it an offence to take a vessel to sea from a port without a survey certificate appropriate to the voyage and the class of operations in which the vessel is then engaged.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 24 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Is there, as claimed by Alastair Fischer 'Aspects of the Voting System for the Senate', Politics (dated May 1981) a weakness in the random sampling method employed in Senate vote counting in that where the winning margin for the last elected candidate is small (say less than 500 votes) there is an approximately 1 in 10,000 chance that the wrong candidate has been elected; if so, what is the Government's attitude to his suggestion that the Commonwealth Electoral Act be amended to provide for sampling to be dispensed with where the winning margin proves to be narrow.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Electoral Office has advised me that the precise probability of electing the 'wrong' candidate because of sampling error at a specific Senate election depends, among other things, on the particular preference orderings expressed in the votes at that election. For that reason such a probability cannot be accurately specified in advance.

The possibility of the election of a 'wrong' candidate has been recognised ever since the system of proportional representation was introduced in 1948. However, the Labor Government at that time argued (House of Representatives Hansard, 16 April 1948, pp. 966-7) that 'the Tasmanian system, while suitable where the number of votes is comparatively small and all such votes are concentrated at one centre, is not readily capable of being efficiently worked by too remote a control. In order to employ that system at a Senate election, it would first be necessary to assemble the whole of the ballot-papers for the State at one centre . . .[that would] delay completion, involve risks of loss in transit, and increase costs heavily . . .'.

I am advised also that, put in more concrete terms, Mr Fischer's calculations suggest that in the long run a 'wrong' candidate will be elected in some State about once every 1,250 years and that as Mr Fischer himself has pointed out, to date there is no possibility that this has occurred.

Examined in this way I do not believe that Mr Fischer's calculations gave rise to any real concern about the way in which the Senate count is conducted or that they justify an amendment of the Commonwealth Electoral Act.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 24 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How effective is crime detection in the case of persons who purloin repatriation pension cheques.
(2) Why were investigations terminated against the person who stole a cheque of this type addressed to Aimee S. Caines, 12 Canonbar Street, Nyngan, and cashed this cheque at Nyngan Bowling Club.
(3) Did the late Mrs Caines write to the Commissioner of Federal Police in Sydney and not receive a reply.
(4) Did an Assistant Commissioner McConaghy then claim this case was one for the State Police; if so, has it been handed over to them for appropriate action.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The effectiveness of crime detection in the case of stolen repatriation cheques or any other crimes against Commonwealth law varies according to the circumstances and the amount of evidence available to the investigating detectives. For the six months ended 30 June 1981, 5,702 offences were reported to the Australian Federal Police (AFP) involving the theft of cheques issued by the Departments of Social Security and Veterans' Affairs. Of these 2,431 were cleared by the following means-
Unfounded-43
By charge-731
Reported for prosecution-521
Other appropriate action-1,136.

(2) The AFP investigation into the theft of a cheque for $39.80 addressed to the late Mrs A. S. Caines was discontinued because no suspect could be identified (the cheque was not endorsed) and there was insufficient evidence to justify further inquiries.
(3) Yes. While it would have been courteous to provide an acknowledgment, I am advised the letter did not need any reply.
(4) Yes. In the light of the circumstances outlined in the answer to (2) above, no action was taken to refer the case to the New South Wales Police.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McClelland Sen The Hon D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 24 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the workshop section of the Light Transport Division in Sydney been curtailed in its activities, particularly, the McElhone Street depot.
(2) How many people were employed in the workshop as at 31 January 1981, compared with 31 January 1982.
(3) Is the Light Transport Section now sending cars out to City Ford for servicing.
(4) When did this practice commence, how many cars have been sent for servicing to City Ford and/or others since that date.
(5) Has a 'C service' been charged for by City Ford at the rate of $480 compared with a previous costing in the Light Transport Workshop of about $90 for the same sort of service.
(6) How much in total has been paid to City Ford and/or others for servicing of Commonwealth cars.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The workshop activity in the Light Transport Division has not been reduced. However, the actitivy at McElhone Street has been reduced slightly as a consequence of a decrease in demand for vehicle servicing at that depot.

(2) As at 31 January 1981 there were 63 people employed in the Branch workshops and of these 10 were employed at McElhone Street, As at 31 January 1982 there were 63 people employed in the Branch workshop and of these 8 were employed at McElhone Street.

(3) and (4) It has always been the practice to contract 'overflow work' to contractors. However, during January and February the staffing level within the Branch workshop was temporarily low because of personnel availing themselves of recreation leave. In the early part of January one employee only was available for duty at McElhone Street and it was necessary to send vehicles to a contractor, City Ford, for servicing work that included repairs as part of the overall work to be performed. During January 41 vehicles and February 35 vehicles were sent to City Ford from McElhone Street Depot for service and repair work. No other contractor was used by that Depot.
(6) The amount that has been paid to all contractors by the Sydney Workshops for repair work that includes servicing is:
These amounts relate to work performed by contractors on all types of vehicles, not only passenger cars. Payment for servicing passenger cars only is not readily available.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 25 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What action has been taken by the Australian Federal Police on a report submitted by the Department of Veterans' Affairs involving action against a person who purloined a repatriation cheque addressed to Aimee S. Caines, 12 Canonbar Street, Nyngan, on 19 September 1979, and subsequently cashed it at Nyngan Bowling Club (see answer to Question on Notice No. 1906, Senate Hansard page 906, 17 March 1982).
(2) Do the Australian Federal Police decline to pursue any investigation in cases of this nature where the value of the cheque is less than $100.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am advised the Australian Federal Police did investigate the theft of this cheque. The investigation was terminated because no suspect could be identified (the cheque was not endorsed) and there was insufficient evidence to justify continuing the inquiries. I understand that the late Mrs Caines was issued with a duplicate cheque and thus was not disadvantaged.
(2) I am advised, no.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs , upon notice, on 20 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: What is the (a) number; and (b) location; of all atomic tests carried out in the southern hemisphere since 1 January 1960.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Since 1 January 1960 only France has carried out nuclear tests in the southern hemisphere. Most of these tests have been conducted at Mururoa Atoll in French Polynesia, but in the period 1966-1976 some tests were carried out on nearby Fangataufa Atoll.

The French government does not release detailed information about its nuclear test program. Information about the numbers of nuclear explosions conducted by nuclear-weapons states is, however, available in publications of the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute (SIPRI). According to the 1981 SIPRI Yearbook (page 382), in the period from 1966, when France started testing in the Pacific, to 1974, when France announced that it would no longer conduct atmospheric testing, 41 atmospheric tests took place. In addition, in the years since 1974, France is thought to have carried out more than fifty underground tests in the South Pacific.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 22 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Which Ministers have been featured in government-funded advertisements for: (a) television; (b) radio; and (c) newspapers, since January, 1976.
(2) Which government policies have been promoted in these advertisements.
(3) What has been the cost of: (a) producing; and (b) broadcasting and printing advertisements.
(4) Which advertising agencies have been used, together with an indication of the advertisements which they created.
(5) How much in total has each agency been paid for creative, production and placement work.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Ministers have been featured in government-funded advertising since January 1976 on the following occasions:
February-March 1977
(1) The then Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations.

(2) Two radio advertisements directed to employers to inform them of the Commonwealth Rebate for Apprentice Full-time Training scheme were produced. One featured a statement spoken by the then Minister and the other spoken by the then President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions expressed support for action by employers.
(3) (a) Approximately $500.

(4) Lucas Advertising Pty Ltd (Melbourne) created the two radio advertisements, one of which featured the then Minister. Media placement and accounting was arranged through both the Barry Banks Blakeney Pty Ltd (Melbourne) and Fortune ( Aust.) Pty Ltd (Sydney) agencies.

(5) The services of the agencies in creation, production and placement work were paid for from the private funds of the Australian Government Advertising Advisory Council. Details of such payments from that Council are, by precedent, considered to be private commercial information.
October-November 1977
(1) The then Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations.

(2) Four different television commercials encouraging employers to provide additional employment and training opportunities, especially for young people, were produced and placed with the media. Each commercial urged employers to contact a Commonwealth Employment Service office for information about the CRAFT apprenticeship assistance scheme. Three of the commercials featured employers, each of whom was introduced by the then Minister. The fourth commercial, which featured the then Minister only in the opening frames, showed factory shop floor activity and also urged employers to contact a CES office.
(3) (a) Approximately $60,000.

(4) All four television commercials were created and produced by the Monahan Dayman Adams advertising agency in Melbourne. Television media placement was arranged through the John Clemenger Pty Ltd (Melbourne) and Fortune (Aust.) Pty Ltd (Sydney) agencies.

(5) The services of the agencies in creation, production and placement work were paid for from the private funds of the Australian Government Advertising Advisory Council. Details of such payments from that Council are, by precedent, considered to be private commercial information.
June 1978
(1) The Minister for Defence but with equal and joint featuring of the then President of the ACTU.

(2) In both newspaper and television advertisements this campaign introduced the activities of the Committee for Employer Support for the Reserve Forces ( CESRF), activity directed at achievement of employers' encouragement of their employees who join the Defence Force Reserves. This advertising was not associated with any specific Government policy.
The television commercial was also broadcast extensively by stations as a free community service activity by them.

(4) Doyle Dane Bernbach (Sydney) created and produced the newspaper and television advertisements which featured the Minister and the then President of the ACTU. Placement of media was arranged through the Fortune (Aust.) Pty Ltd ( Sydney) and Berry Currie Advertising Pty Ltd (Sydney) agencies.

(5) Any payments to the agencies for creation, production and placement work associated with this advertising were made from the private funds of the Australian Government Advertising Advisory Council. Details of such payments are , by precedent, considered to be private commercial information. In keeping with the co-operative spirit of the work of the Committee for Employer Support for the Reserve Force, Doyle Dane Bernbach provided its services voluntarily in 1978 to create and produce the advertising at cost.
February 1980
(1) The then Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs.

(2) In a newspaper advertisement and a television commercial, the then Minister encouraged employers to employ more apprentices and young people under the School to Work Transition Scheme. Statements in the advertisements urged employers to contact the Commonwealth Employment Service to obtain details of job training and assistance schemes.

(4) The newspaper and television advertising which featured the then Minister was created and produced by the Monahan Dayman Adams Pty Ltd (Melbourne) agency. Media placement was arranged through the John Clemenger Pty Ltd (Melbourne), Hayes Cowcher Dailey Pty Ltd (Melbourne), Fortune (Aust.) Pty Ltd (Sydney), and Berry Currie Advertising Pty Ltd (Sydney) agencies.

(5) The services of the agencies in creation, production and placement work were paid for from the private funds of the Australian Government Advertising Advisory Council. Details of such payments from that Council are, by precedent, considered to be private commercial information.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 22 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal decided to publish a series of periodical newsletters, to partly replace the comprehensive annual report which is presently published.
(2) What information will be provided in these newsletters, and what by way of an annual report.
(3) How frequently will the newsletter appear.

(4) Will the Minister give an assurance that there will be no reduction in the amount of information provided to the public and to Parliament in any changes of the above, or any changes in reporting which are contemplated.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal has decided to publish a series of periodical newsletters to inform the public on matters dealt with by the Tribunal during the particular period covered by the newsletter and thereby better inform the public of the day to day activities of the Tribunal. The Tribunal is required under the provisions of section 28 (1) of the Broadcasting and Television Act 1942 to furnish a report on the operations of the Tribunal each year and will therefore continue to publish an annual report. Consideration is being given to altering the format of the annual report to place more emphasis on matters that have been dealt with by the Tribunal during the particular year.

(2) It is proposed that the newsletter will provide information on decisions made by the Tribunal during the particular period and other matters of interest to the public eg. research undertaken by the Tribunal.
As indicated in the answer to question 1, the Tribunal is obliged to publish an annual report on its operations for the year under review. This will continue.
(3) The newsletter will be published at regular intervals.

(4) With the introduction of the newsletter, the Tribunal anticipates that there will be an overall increase in the amount of information provided by the Tribunal to the public and to Parliament regarding its operations each year.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: North Australian Film Corporation Pty Ltd

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 27 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What assistance is given by the Federal and the Queensland State governments to the company known as North Australian Film Corporation Pty Ltd.
(2) Have specific amounts been made available by the Commonwealth Government for the production of: (a) A Crocodile Man; (b) Big Fish-Down Under; and (c) The Greatest Reef.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am advised that the Australian Film Commission, the statutory authority whose functions include the encouragement by the provision of financial assistance or otherwise of the making of Australian films, provides no assistance to the Corporation. The Commission has no information on assistance provided by State Government to the Corporation.

In accordance with sections 124ZAB and 124ZAC of the Income Tax Assessment Act it is open to the Corporation to apply to the Minister for certificates stating that particular films are 'qualifying Australian films'. The secrecy provision of the Act precluded disclosure of any information regarding applications which may have been made by the Corporation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 5 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Australian film director, Mr Peter Weir, been filming in the Philippines his latest film The Year of Living Dangerously, and was he forced to leave that country on 24 hours notice after threats from Muslim extremists.
(2) Does Australia provide aid to the Philippines on a continuing basis in various areas to the extent that it is the 4th largest recipient of Australian assistance.

(3) Will the Minister lodge a protest with his counterpart in the Philippine Government over that country's failure to provide any protection for this Australian film crew who were forced to flee the country for fear of their lives after being apparently welcomed by the Marcos Government to work there.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian film director, Mr Peter Weir, and his film crew were in the Philippines during March 1982 making the film The Year of Living Dangerously. During filming in the Philippines several anonymous threats were received, which I understand Mr Weir felt could not be ignored even if the risk was assessed to be low. As the filming schedule had been virtually completed it was decided to shorten the crew's stay in the Philippines by one week. I am advised that this move was only precautionary and that all concerned with the film were grateful to the Philippine Government and the film community for the excellent co- operation they had received.
(2) Yes.
(3) In view of the circumstances outlined in reply to question (1), the Australian Government will not be making representations to the Philippine Government on this matter.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 November 1981 (Hansard, page 2492) Senator Martin asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, a question without notice concerning the granting to Poland of most favoured nation status in terms of trade and tariffs with Australia and the strengthening of Australian Trade Commission representation in Warsaw.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following additional information to the reply I gave to the honourable senator's question:

The bilateral trade agreement between Poland and Australia contains a most favoured nation clause in standard terms in accordance with the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT). This remains in force. Since the question was asked, however, the Australian Trade Commissioner and his staff have been withdrawn from Warsaw. I should emphasise that this withdrawal was undertaken as a result of a pragmatic assessment of declining trade prospects in Poland, and does not represent a downgrading of trade relations. The Australian Trade Commissioner based in Vienna makes regular visits to Warsaw in the course of his duties.

The imposition of martial law in Poland on 13 December 1981 has altered the way in which the Government views bilateral relations with Poland. There is at present little prospect for the early lifting of martial law and this is a matter for profound regret. During my visit to Poland in November 1981, the Polish Government made a request for additional economic assistance which I undertook to have considered on my return to Australia. After the imposition of martial law, the Government, however, decided to take a number of practical measures to demonstrate to the Polish martial law authorities that we are not prepared to conduct normal relations with them in present circumstances.

As set out in my Press statement issued after Cabinet on 19 January 1982, the Government deferred consideration of Poland's request for further economic assistance, and made it clear that the roll-over provisions of the existing credit facility were open to Government discretion. At the same time, the Government set three basic preconditions for the re-establishment of normal relations with Poland; the complete lifting of martial law, the release of all detainees, and an early return to circumstances in which the people of Poland can find their own solution to their internal economic and political difficulties on the basis of consensus and reconciliation.
Any consideration of further ways to assist Poland and improve bilateral relations is out of the question in present circumstances.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 April 1982 (Hansard, page 1351) Senator Mulvihill asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, a question without notice concerning the Northern Territory Fisheries Act.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following additional information in answer to the question:

It should be made clear that fisheries is one of the matters coming within the executive authority of Northern Territory Ministers as provided in Section 35 of the Northern Territory (Self-Government) Act 1978.

It is understood that Mr Justice Gallop of the Northern Territory Supreme Court did not in fact invalidate the Fisheries Act. It was a particular declaration made under Section 13 of that Act which was declared invalid.

Section 13 of the Fisheries Act allows the Administrator, by notice in the Northern Territory Gazette, to declare any waters specified in the notice to be closed . . . against the taking of fish of a specified species. It is understood that a notice under this Section which appeared in the Northern Territory Gazette purported to declare 'all waters' to be closed against the taking of barramundi and threadfish salmon. The notice did not specify with any certainty which waters were closed.
It would appear that what is required is a new notice in the Northern Territory Gazette. As indicated above, this is a matter for the Northern Territory Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 April 1982 (Hansard, page 1658) Senator Tate asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, a question without notice concerning the use of Hutt River passports by international travellers.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following additional information to the reply I gave to the honourable senator's question:

I am aware of the claim that a Hutt River 'diplomatic passport' was used by a television producer to get through Customs and Immigration in Beirut. I am unaware how many of these documents have been issued by Mr Casley or to whom they have been issued. They are not of course genuine passports. A genuine passport is a document issued by a sovereign state to a person who is a subject of that state. It is the accepted international means of identification and evidence of nationality and of the holder's right as a subject to the protection of the state which issued it as well as the preparedness of that state to extend protection. Since the self-styled Hutt River Province is not a state (in international law) clearly the documents printed and distributed by Mr Casley do not meet these criteria.

The use of Hutt River Province 'passports' would facilitate the movements of terrorists and drug runners only as long as other countries are prepared to accept them as valid travel documents. I do not believe the abuse of these ' passports' should have any impact on Australia's relations with the Middle East region.

In 1976, my Department advised all overseas posts that any inquiries from governments regarding the activities of Mr Casley should be advised that the Australian Government does not recognise the Hutt River Province and any assertions to the contrary are false.
The Australian Government will take whatever steps are necessary to protect its international status and role in combating international terrorism and drug running.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 6 May 1982 (Hansard, page 1917) Senator Watson asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology aware that the Australian Academy of Science, which prepares educational material for some 1,500 Australian secondary schools, will no longer be able to meet this commitment as its current grant has been reduced by inflation? As this material makes an important contribution to school science education and, in the long run, to the future of science in Australia, is the Academy to rely on donations and bequests to continue with this work and future participation with international scientific unions?
The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

I wish to point out that a general purpose grant-in-aid of $296,000 was provided to the Australian Academy of Science by the Government in 1981-82. The Academy has been advised that it is at liberty to utilise this grant in accordance with its own priorities. The Government does not accept any obligation to underwrite any specific activity of the Academy at any specific level.
The Government is currently examining the Academy's proposal for a grant-in- aid for 1982-83 and this will be announced in the budget context.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 20 May 1982 (Hansard, page 2223) Senator Macklin asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I preface my question with the information that Mr W. W. Sweetland has recently headed an inquiry into the long term future of Christmas Island. I am informed that a report has now been completed. Given the possible effects of the Government's fertiliser subsidy amendment legislation on the sale of Christmas Island rock, which is before the Senate at the moment, will the Minister give an undertaking that the report will be released immediately?
The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided me with the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The report prepared by Mr Sweetland following his inquiry into the continued viability of the Christmas Island phosphate industry was tabled in the Parliament on 20 February 1980 by the Minister for Administrative Services. He announced the Government's decisions on the recommendations relating to phosphate issues on 5 March 1981. Subsequently, Mr Sweetland was engaged to study the prospects for the development of alternative industries and activities on Christmas Island. The report on that study is not yet available- it has not yet been printed, nor has it been considered by the Government.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Martyr Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 9 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What funding, direct or indirect, is attributable to the Commonwealth Government for the in vitro fertilisation (the so-called test tube baby) programmes being undertaken by some medical practitioners and research groups in Australia.
(2) What is the extent of this funding and under what specified ethical safeguards and scrutiny, and for how long, has it been provided.

(3) What guidelines, if any, have the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) adopted to regulate medical and associated research in Australia involving fertilised human ova, human fetuses or embryos and human fetal tissue.

(4) What members of the NHMRC or its consultant groups have been involved in such research and what grants have they received from the Council or otherwise directly or indirectly from the Commonwealth Government.
(5) What guidelines regulating medical and associated research involving fertilised human ova, human fetuses or embryos and human fetal tissue are in force in the United Kingdom and New Zealand.

(6) Does the Government or the Minister for Health intend to act in regard to the recommendation in paragraph 46 of Report Number 7, Human Tissue Transplants, of the Law Reform Commission that there should be urgent legal consideration of the use of human fetal tissue in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The Government is not providing any direct funding for the in vitro fertilisation programs being conducted by the Queen Victoria Medical Centre, the Royal Women's Hospital, Melbourne and King Edward Memorial Hospital, Perth. It is recognised, however, that some of the costs of these programs are derived from hospital and university budgets. Medical benefits are also attracted by various clinical procedures forming part of the in vitro fertilisation technique . Government funding is involved to some extent, but the precise level cannot be determined.

So far as research involving in vitro fertilisation is concerned, the National Health and Medical Research Council (NH and MRC) is providing support for three research projects. These projects are being undertaken at the Queen Victoria Medical Centre (2) and the Royal Women's Hospital (1) at a cost of $200,000 over the next three years.
The NH and MRC has supported in vitro fertilisation research in a modest way since 1979, with funding of $33,000, $34,000 and $55,000 being provided for 1979 , 1980 and 1981 respectively.
To secure NH and MRC funding, research projects must achieve a high standard of scientific merit and obtain approval from the ethics committee of the institution at which the research is conducted.

(3) The NH and MRC has not, at present, specific guidelines concerning the ethical aspects of research involving fertilisation of human ova, human fetuses or human embryos. It does, however, have a statement on human experimentation which is the basic guideline used by ethics committees in institutions in determining approval of research protocols.

The NH and MRC has recently established a working party on ethics in medical research whose terms of reference include a revision of the statement on human experimentation in the light of developments with in vitro fertilisation research.
(4) No members of the NH and MRC or its consultative committees have been involved in such research.

(5) In the United Kingdom, the Medical Research Council (MRC) has requested researchers supported by it to abide by the recommendations of the advisory group appointed by the Secretary of State for Social Services, entitled: 'The Use of Fetuses and Fetal Material for Research'-the Peel report. The basic recommendations have been incorporated in a suggested code of practice and the MRC has issued additional guidelines on 'Supervision of the Ethics of the Use of Fetuses and Fetal Material for Research'. I have arranged for a copy of the report and the MRC guidelines to be placed in the Parliamentary Library.

In New Zealand, research is conducted in accordance with the Medical Research Council guidelines on human experimentation 1972 and the Human Tissue Act 1964. Copies of this material will also be placed in the Parliamentary Library.
(6) The Attorney-General has referred the question of the use of human fetal tissue in research to the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Administrative Appeals Tribunal: Invalid Pension Appeals

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 14 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many appeals to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal are awaiting decision?
(2) Of that number, how many are social security matters?
(3) Of the social security appeals, how many concern invalid pensions?
(4) What is the current delay between the lodging of an invalid pension appeal and the publication of the decision?
(5) What is the current delay between a request to the Department of Social Security for reasons and the provision of those reasons?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Administrative Appeals Tribunal maintains statistics on a quarterly basis. The last quarter for which statistics are available is the quarter ended on 31 March 1982.
(1) As at 31 March 1982, 1199 applications for review made to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal were undetermined.
(2) Of these, 591 were applications for the review of decisions made under the Social Services Act 1947.
(3) Of the 591 social security applications, 423 concerned cancellation of, or refusal to grant, an invalid pension.

(4) It is not practicable to give a figure for the current delay between the lodging of an application for review of a decision relating to an invalid pension and the publication of the decision of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal on that application. Cases are heard by the Tribunal when the parties are ready to proceed.

I am informed that the longest standing invalid pension application before the Tribunal on 31 March 1982 was lodged on 19 March 1981. This application has been before the Tribunal on two occasions, and each time has been deferred at the request of the parties to enable further medical evidence to be brought before the Tribunal. After a hearing before the President of the Tribunal on 10 March 1982 the hearing of the application was adjourned with liberty to either party to apply to bring the hearing on at 48 hours notice to the other party.

(5) It is assumed that the reference to 'reasons' is a reference to the statement which the Department is required to lodge with the Tribunal, under section 37 of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975, when it receives notice of an application to the Tribunal for review of a decision. The obligation imposed by section 37 is to lodge such a statement within 28 days after receiving notice of the application.

The Administrative Appeals Tribunal does not have available to it records of the dates on which the Department receives notices of applications to the Tribunal for review of social security decisions.

The Registrar of the Tribunal has provided me with figures which show that, on the basis of section 37 statements lodged with the Tribunal by the Department of Social Security in the month ending 31 March 1982, the average period between the date on which notice of an application was sent by the Tribunal to the Department and the date on which the section 37 statement was lodged with the Tribunal was 129 days.

I am informed there have been delays in particular cases in the Melbourne and Sydney Registries of the Tribunal in forwarding notices of applications to the Department of Social Security. The Registrar of the Tribunal has taken action to overcome delays in the future.

The Minister for Social Security has outlined in the Senate on three occasions considerations bearing upon the time being taken to furnish documents to the Tribunal pursuant to section 37 of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act (16 September 1981, Hansard, page 750; 27 April 1982, Hansard, page 1505; 28 April 1982, Hansard, pages 1583-4).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice , on 15 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did a survey reported in the Sydney Morning Herald on 21 September 1981 find that of 2,000 people surveyed 72 per cent were opposed to sending troops to the Sinai.

(2) Will the Government give an assurance that a force will not be sent to the Middle East; if not, does this indicate that the Government is prepared to ignore overwhelming opposition to Australia's involvement in the Sinai.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 21 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When will the Government announce its decision on the request by the Government of the United States of America for Australian troops to join a Sinai Peacekeeping Force.
(2) Is the Government aware of a recent national poll which showed 72 per cent of Australians were opposed to sending troops to the Sinai.

(3) Has the Government considered the implications of recent events tending to destabilise the Middle East, and their effects on Australian troops if involved in an American Peacekeeping Force in the Sinai.
(4) Does the government see any parallels between the US request to send Australian troops to the Sinai and their request in the 1960s to send troops to Vietnam.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government announced its decision on the Sinai Peacekeeping Force on 22 October 1981.
(2), (3) and (4) I refer the honourable senator to my statement in the House of Representatives on 22 October 1981.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 10 November 1981.

QUESTION.PARA: To what extent do foreign corporations, with public sector involvement in their own country, operate in Australia. What are the main corporations, what is the extent of their public ownership and what is the extent of their ownership and control of Australian (1) resource development, (2) manufacturing industry, (3) finance institutions, (4) rural industry.
