ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Provision of Aids for Disabled People Program

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 18 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What form of monitoring is built in to the Provision of Aids for Disabled People Program (PADP) and in particular, are the States required to report on:
(a) the number and nature of requests that cannot be met because of lack of funds; if so, what are the details for each State;
(b) the number and nature of requests that cannot be met because the items required are not on the prescribed list; if so, what are the details for each State;
(c) the guidelines or priority system established by the State Health Commissions or individual hospitals; and
(d) the imposition of financial limits on individual allocations by some hospitals.
(2) Are there any plans to extend the eligibility to nursing home patients to increase their independence and improve their quality of life, even if the aid will not enable them to be discharged.
(3) Has consideration been given to authorising occupational therapists and physiotherapists as official prescribers, since they are almost always involved in the prescribing process.

(4) How do potential beneficiaries, especially those who are not attending hospital, find out about the PADP scheme; and what are the plans for publicising the scheme ''widely in the community'' as the Minister promised early in 1981.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a), (b), (c) and (d) Administrative arrangements applicable to the Program of Aids for Disabled People (PADP) are such that the Commonwealth's role relates to the provision of funds, broad policy development, and overall program administration from the national standpoint. Day-to-day administration of the program and the development of detailed administrative procedures are the responsibility of the State and Territory health authorities and the lodgment centres which operate under their supervision. Within these arrangements the State and Territory authorities are required to provide the Commonwealth with statistics regarding the numbers and costs of aids issued under each of the ten approved categories. There is no formal requirement for the States and Territories to provide the type of information listed in the honourable senator' s question. However, in accordance with its overall administrative role, my Department is in regular contact with the State and Territory administering authorities concerning operational matters and expenditure trends.

(2) The principal aim of PADP is to enable people with disabilities to live more independently in a domestic (i.e. non-institutional) setting in the community. PADP assistance is available to residents of nursing homes and other institutions in cases where the aid is provided in connexion with the recipient' s discharge from the nursing home, etc., into the community. There are no plans to extend PADP to cover residents of institutions beyond this provision.

(3) My Department recognises that, in addition to medical practitioners, other categories of health professionals have an important role in the operation of PADP. Although the Commonwealth has not formally documented explicit requirements regarding the involvement of allied health professionals, it is expected that the State and Territory health authorities will make arrangements for such involvement where appropriate and practicable. However, it is not intended that the list of authorised prescribers for PADP be extended to include other than medical practitioners.

(4) Some 27,000 registered medical practitioners throughout Australia have been circularised with details of the program. Furthermore, there has been considerable liaison with both professional and non-government organisations in the health/welfare field concerning PADP. Nevertheless, the question of additional publicity, brochures, etc., will be considered in the context of ongoing review of the program as it develops.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 11 March 1982.

QUESTION.PARA: 1. What material and equipment currently in use in the Minister's Department are known to contain polychlorinated biphenyls (PCB).
2. Is the Minister aware of the dangers associated with the use of PCB's.
3. What methods of storage or disposal are used for material and equipment containing PCB's when those items become redundant or useless.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 11 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the United States of America Environmental Protection Agency announced its intent to cancel all agricultural and domestic uses of the organo-chlorine compounds chlordane and heptachlor, on the grounds that these substances have carcinogenic properties; if so, although these compounds are gazetted as ' hazardous pesticides' in Australia, why are they still readily available for sale on supermarket and garden shop shelves.
(2) Are there any recorded cases of injury, death or foetal abnormality occurring in Australia as a result of the use of chlordane and heptachlor.
(3) Will the Minister consider instituting an inquiry into the dangers posed by the use of these compounds.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The uses of chlordane and heptachlor for agricultural and domestic purposes in the United States of America are being phased out by the Environmental Protection Agency because of their persistence in the environment, rather than for any carcinogenic or other health hazard. The use of chlordane and heptachlor for termite control by subterranean injection has not been phased out be the Agency. Chlordane and heptachlor are used in Australia mainly by pest control operators on ants, termites etc. around building sites. Some States have a limited range of registered agricultural uses. Chlordane and heptachlor are included in Schedule 6 of the Uniform Poisons Standard of the National Health and Medical Research Council (NH & MRC). This Schedule includes substances or preparations of a poisonous nature which must be readily available to the public for domestic, agricultural, pastoral, horticultural, veterinary, photographic or industrial purposes or for the destruction of pests. As such, these substances would be available at appropriate commercial outlets.

(2) The honourable senator will appreciate that it is next to impossible to record all cases of injury by any agent. Chlordane and heptachlor have not been implicated as agents causing foetal abnormalities. There may have been cases of death or injury due to accidental or deliberate poisoning as can, and does, occur with any toxic substance but my Department does not have specific records of these.

(3) The NH and MRC maintains a constant review of both substances and presently considers existing restrictions adequate. If the honourable senator has evidence to warrant further investigation I would be pleased to present this to the NH and MRC expert committees for evaluation.

(2) If no 'more satisfactory voluntary code' for health has been formulated, what steps has the Minister taken, or will he take, to implement the conditional recommendation of the Senate Committee that the National Therapeutic Goods Committee draw up proposals (which do not require full disclosure of the drug but do set out adequate standards of advertising) to be enforced by legislation for controlling the promotion of prescription medication, bearing in mind the Committee's deadline of six months for the voluntary code after the appearance of the Report (June 1981).

As a result, proposals have been put forward for a series of changes to be made in relation to reminder advertisements to the NMMC's Code relating to ethical advertising. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 24 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Minister for Health consider an allocation of at least $50,000 to the Queensland Institute of Medical Research either in the forthcoming Budget, or sooner, for research to develop a dengue fever vaccine and also to detect the possible presence of the more virulent South-east Asian strain.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth Government supports medical research through the National Health and Medical Research Council. Should the Queensland Institute of Medical Research wish to receive funding for research to develop a dengue fever vaccine, it could approach the Council with details of the work proposed and request funding. Such an application would then be considered in conjunction with other applications for grant support.

In relation to a dengue fever vaccine, the honourable senator may have in mind recent advances in recombinant DNA technology and molecular biology which have opened up new possibilities for vaccine production. Notwithstanding this, there remain major difficulties in the development of an effective dengue vaccine, and further basic research is necessary. It must be noted that there is no virulent South-east Asian strain, and I assume the honourable senator is referring to the severe forms of infection-dengue haemorrhagic fever and dengue shock syndrome.

I would stress the need meanwhile for the continuation of vector control measures which are the present basis for the control of dengue. I am aware that dengue fever has recently appeared in Queensland after an absence of 17 years, and since the only available method of stopping the spread of the disease is through these vector control programs, the Commonwealth is providing financial support in this area.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 22 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: What are the conditions under which a woman on supporting mother's benefit can become eligible for Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme (TEAS) payment; if she is eligible for TEAS, is her supporting mother's benefit pension reduced, and by how much.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Department of Social Security provides supporting parent's benefit to sole parents of either sex who have the care of dependent children. A recipient of supporting parent's benefit is eligible for benefits under the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme (TEAS), as are other applicants, provided that he or she is a full-time student undertaking an approved course, meets the scheme's conditions relating to previous study and progress in present course, and satisfies the means test. In the case of a sole parent, the maximum allowance of $2583pa ($49.67 a week) is payable where the income of the parent from all other sources, including social security benefits, does not exceed $5100pa or $98.00 per week. Where income from other sources exceeds $5100, the TEAS allowance is reduced on a pro-rata basis to the point where no TEAS is payable if other income exceeds $9667 in the year of study. If eligible for TEAS an additional allowance of $10 a week for each dependent child would be payable under TEAS.

The maximum rate of supporting parent's benefit for a person with one child is $87.70 per week; a sole parent in receipt of maximum TEAS and with no other income would receive supporting parent's benefit of $72.85 per week, that is, the TEAS benefits would cause a reduction in the supporting parent's benefit of $14.85 a week. Naturally the latter amount would vary depending on a number of factors such as the amount of income from other sources, the level of TEAS entitlement and the number of dependent children.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Northern Territory Department of Health Bulletin

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 22 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware that the Northern Territory Department of Health bulletin has now ceased publication and that the Bulletin has been abolished because of the need to reduce costs.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 September 1981 (Hansard, page 890) Senator Sibraa asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, refers to two questions asked last week by Senators Bjelke- Petersen and Townley concerning Zimbabwe and the presence there of North Korean military instructors. As the Australian High Commissioner to Zimbabwe was recently in Canberra reporting to the Minister and he also recently briefed the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence on this matter as well as on the biased anti-Zimbabwe Press reports which were being reprined in the Australian media, will the Minister bring down a statement on current events in Zimbabwe and Southern Africa for the information of honourable senators? Will the Minister not agree that Zimbabwe, a non-aligned country, whose armed forces are currently being predominantly trained by British instructors, is entitled to invite instructors from other countries, including Australia, to train its armed forces?
The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

You referred to the military assistance being proved by North Korea to help train the Zimbabwe Army. Senator Guilfoyle confirmed that the Government of Zimbabwe had accepted an offer of assistance from the Democratic People's Republic of Korea, and that this was intended to train and equip a brigade of the defence forces of Zimbabwe.

As you quite correctly pointed out, the Zimbabwe armed forces are being predominantly trained by a British militay training team, under an arrangement which has operated since Zimbabwe attained independence in April 1980. I agree that it is a decision for Zimbabwe itself whether to invite instructors from other countries to train its armed forces. In announcing its decision to accept the North Korean offer, the Government of Zimbabwe said this was consistent with Zimbabwe's policy of non-alignment. I would repeat Senator Guilfoyle's observation that we hope the North Koreans are approaching their task in the same light. The question of providing Australian military training assistance to Zimbabwe is not under consideration.

The task of restructuring and integrating into one force the three armies which operated in Zimbabwe prior to independence-Mr Mugabe's ZANLA, Mr Nkomo's ZIPRA and the former Rhodesian security forces-is obviously crucial for the future stability of Zimbabwe, and from the outset Mr Mugabe has accorded it high priority. This task is clearly not an easy one, and it will take some time to achieve complete confidence among three such previously antagonistic groups. However considerable progress has been made to date, and this is a cause for encouragement.

You also asked if I would bring down a statement on current events in Zimbabwe and southern Africa. I believe the Government's policies towards southern Africa, and the conduct of its relations with Zimbabwe, are widely known and understood. I do not think it necessary at this particular time to table a statement specifically on current developments in the region. I will, however, keep this under review.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 16 February 1982 Hansard, page 7 Senator Archer asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning the testing of road accident casualties for the presence of alcohol or cannabis.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

I am aware of the study to which the honourable senator refers. This was conducted on a series of motor vehicle drivers admitted to Hornsby Ku-ring-gai Hospital as casualties in the latter half of 1981. Of 94 persons tested 23 per cent showed evidence of cannabis products in their urine, and 8 per cent also showed alcohol. This, of course, appears to be an alarming finding. However, the real significance of the finding is not known. The number of drivers who have used cannabis throughout New South Wales and Australia may be much higher or much lower. The significance for the causation of motor traffic accidents of presence of cannabis metabolites in the urine is quite unknown as cannabis metabolites continue to be excreted for weeks after the last use of cannabis. What this study does is reinforce the need for further studies to allow confident assertions to be made concerning whether cannabis use is an important factor in traffic accidents in Australia.

Given the present difficulties in interpreting the data, I could not recommend the introduction of routine tests on all accident victims. Neither could I recommend comparable penalties for alcohol and cannabis when there are no data linking cannabis levels to levels of risk on the road (such as there are for alcohol). Rather, I support the development of a well-designed research program , as recommended by the House of Representatives Road Safety Committee report on Alcohol Drugs and Road Safety.

Notwithstanding that the major recommendations of the report are currently under consideration by the Government, I can inform the honourable senator that the Commonwealth Minister for Transport, at the meeting of the Australian Transport Advisory Council held on 26 February 1982, submitted proposals for a national media campaign which is being considered by the States, supported a national program of random breath testing, and indicated Government support for increased research into the effects of alcohol and drugs on road safety.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 February 1982 hansard, page 233) Senators Childs asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning the use of 2-nitropropane.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

I am aware of the importation and use in Australia of this substance. The United States National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health found no tumours or other changes in rats exposed to 27 ppm or rabbits exposed to 207 ppm of 2-nitropropane for six months. Liver tumors were observed in all ten rats killed after six months of exposure to 207 ppm of 2-nitropropane. In a later bioassay metastatic liver cancers were observed in rats exposed for six months at 200 ppm and held unexposed for six months. According to preliminary data of the same study, male rats exposed to 100 ppm also developed liver tumours. At the end of 22 months no malignancies or significant changes were observed in the livers of the male or female rats exposed at 25 ppm. 2- nitropropane is widely used in solvent systems for coating, printing inks and adhesives, and is used in food processing for fractionation of a partially saturated vegetable oil. While it has not been demonstrated to be a severe threat, it is being treated as a potential health threat to exposed workers and its use in water tanks in Western Australia is currently under investigation by the health authorities in that State.

Guidance on the measures to be taken with carcinogens is provided in the National Health and Medical Research Council (NH and MRC) publications 'Model Carcinogenic Substances Regulations and Recommendations' for Laboratory Workers Handling Carcinogenic Chemicals. Concerning 2-nitropropane, this is the subject of an International Hazard Alert. A scientific group of the NH and MRC, the body designated to receive notification of Alerts, has taken action to ensure that information on 2-nitropropane is widely disseminated to government agencies and industrial groups to take appropriate action.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 March 1982 (Hansard, page 700) Senator MacGibbon asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: In view of the decision by National Semiconductor Corporation not to proceed for the time being with the facility in Canberra to produce silicon chips, will the Government, as a matter of great urgency, encourage those companies at present operating in Australia to set up a facility on a free enterprise basis to produce custom designed chips? Such components are now the fundamental building blocks of our national defence capability and the ability to produce them in Australia cannot be delayed any longer.
The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Government's decision to invite the National Semiconductor Corporation ( Natsemi) to examine the feasibility of establishing a silicon wafer fabrication plant in the Australian Capital Territory and its willingness to provide land and buildings in return for certain undertakings from Natsemi reflected the Government's continuing commitment to promoting private sector investment and employment opportunities in the Territory. Recognising the importance of microelectronics technology to the future of Australian industry, the Government sought undertakings from Natsemi concerning technology transfer, training and preferential supply of components to Australian users. The objective in seeking those undertakings was to assist the development of downstream industries using semi-conductors whether they are supplied by Natsemi or other semi-conductor manufacturers.

Assistance for the microelectronics industry is provided through a variety of measures, most of which are available to manufacturing industry generally. These include tariffs on competing imports, industrial research and development incentives, government purchasing preference afforded to goods of Australian origin that meet certain high technology guidelines or are judged to be of strategic defence significance, offset requirement for government purchases and export incentives. Direct assistance has also been provided in the form of loans by the Department of Defence to firms for purchase of specialised plant and equipment. Some of these measures are under review at present in the context of the Government's consideration of the reports by the Industries Assistance Commission on Certain Budgetary Assistance to Industry and Export Incentives. The Government is also considering a report by Australian Science and Technology Council which discusses assistance to the microelectronics industry.

Custom microelectronic devices are being produced in Australia, mostly by two firms, for specialised uses such as medical equipment, alarm systems, and communication. These firms have benefitted from the Government assistance measures as well as gaining a significant level of on going orders from the Department of Defence for specialised microelectronic devices. Despite these orders the firms have spare capacity available to meet higher levels of demand.

The Government also supports the development of microelectronic technology research in Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization, the Defence Science and Technology Organisation and tertiary institutions. The joint Commonwealth Special Research Centre in microelectronics at the Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology and the University of New South Wales was established recently under the Commonwealth Program for Promotion of Research Excellence.

Further, it is proposed to send a reference to the Industries Assistance Commission shortly on assistance to the local industry producing automatic data processing equipment and parts. The scope and timing of the reference are currently under consideration.
In considering the need for further support it should be noted that at the present time there exists adequate capacity to meet the current Australian demand for custom microelectronic components.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 20 May 1982 (Hansard, page 2213) Senator MacGibbon asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Support the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Can the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Support say whether the industry rationalisation policy of 1976 remains in force with the Department of Defence Support? If it is still the policy of the Department, now can such a system be modified to pemit competitive tendering to contain costs? Since there have been significant exceptions to this doctrine why is the policy being selectively applied?
The Minister for Defence Support has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
The aircraft industry rationalisation policy which the Government announced in 1976 remains in force. There have however been three cases of significant deviation from that policy.

In two cases, cost and efficiency considerations have led to ongoing work on aircraft or components being undertaken by the same company which originally produced those same items for the Royal Australian Air Force.
In the third case, airframe work was won in commercially competitive bidding.

Each of these three instances of variation in the disposition of work as compared with what would have been expected under the Government's rationalisation policy has been approved by the predecessors of the present Ministers for Defence and for Defence Support.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 May 1982 (Hansard, page 2324) Senator Ryan asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, without notice:

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 March 1982 (Hansard page 858) Senator Bjelke-Peterson asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. Her question concerned the extent of the damage to Cavendish bananas from Panama disease in South Africa and Taiwan.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minster for Primary Industry has now supplied me with the following additional information:

Panama disease is caused by a soil-borne fungus which enters banana plants through their roots. There is no evidence of any other mode of entry. Some species of bananas, such as Lady Finger, are very susceptible to the disease, but in recent years, the Dwarf Cavendish species which has previously been immune, has been affected by the disease in South Africa and Taiwan.

The disease has been present in small localized areas in South Africa for over 20 years, but since 1977, it has been spreading slowly and has attacked the Dwarf Cavendish species. This breakdown in resistance has been ascribed to an as yet unknown complex of soil factors. A great deal of work has been done in South Africa to contain or eliminate the disease, including soil treatments and quarantine measures, but it is now generally accepted in that country that it is not controllable by agronomic treatments, phytosanitary measure or the application of soil fungicides. However, a research programme has been mounted in South Africa to define the extent of the disease and to identify possible ways of combatting the fungus, although scientists in that country are not optimistic that a viable control method will be found.

Information obtained from Taiwan, indicates that Cavendish bananas in that Country are not susceptible to Panama disease, but a new strain of the pathogen was discovered in 1967-68, and I am informed that some 400 acres of Cavendish bananas have been affected by this new strain.

So far as the Australian infection is concerned, I can confirm that their has been a minor outbreak of Panama disease in the Wamuran Basin in southern Queensland which is affecting Cavendish bananas, but I understand the Queensland Department of Primary Industries has the situation under control. I am informed that it is not unusual for Cavendish bananas to succumb to the disease in extreme stress conditions, and this may account for the present outbreak. The Queensland authorities have not yet been able to determine whether the present outbreak has been caused by a new strain of the disease, but I understand that they are maintaining contact with the agricultural authorities in South Africa and Taiwan on the effectiveness of their control measures.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 March 1982 (Hansard, page 921-922) Senator Thomas asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry in the Senate. His question concerned the export of livestock.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied the following additional information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

At the outest, let me say quite categorically that there has been no change in the Government's support for the live sheep export trade. We are well aware of the benefits to sheep producers and to associated industries which have resulted from this trade.

The letter in question requested the exporter to be discriminating in the type of livestock he exported. I am aware of no evidence that the exercise of such discrimination would have required a reduction in the number of sheep exported from Australia in a given period.

When the letter was written in January I was concerned at the evidence that increasing numbers of light-weight lambs were being included in shipments of sheep for overseas. I am not convinced that this trend was in the overall interests of the live sheep export trade and accordingly I suggested to live sheep exporters and the Sheepmeat Council of Australia that the export of light -weight lambs should be avoided as much as possible.

The Government is concerned to preserve the continuity of Australia's overseas trade by enhancing this country's reputation as an efficient and reliable exporter. I am sure that there would be widespread acceptance of the need for the live sheep trade to be conducted to the highest standards of animal husbandry and in conformity with the specifications of export contracts.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Closer Economic Relationship with New Zealand

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 March 1982 Hansard, page 931) Senator Harradine asked me a question, without notice, concerning discussions between Australia and New Zealand on closer economic relations. I indicated to Senator Harradine that I would refer his question to the Minister for Primary Industry to see whether any additional information sould be provided.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister has supplied me with the following details:

In seeking a closer economic relationship (CER), the Governments of Australia and New Zealand are committed to ensuring equitable treatment for industries in both countries. In this regard the question of how to deal with New Zealand export incentives has been very much to the forefront in the negotiations.

In the particular case of horticultural products the aim has been to negotiate a package of measures which would achieve a freeing-up of the trade on a basis which was fair to both sides. In addition to reductions in tariffs and progressive liberalisation of New Zealand import restrictions, we have sought the speedy phasing out of New Zealand export incentives. We will also institute a fast track anti-dumping arrangement which would facilitate the handling of legitimate complaints under our anti-dumping legislation. Details of these arrangements are still being finalised.

In the case of dairy products, discussions have been held between the dairy industries of the two countries with the aim of arriving at mutually acceptable arrangements for incorporating dairy products in a closer economic relationship . The industries have now released a Memorandum of Understanding which outlines the proposed arrangements. The Government will, of course, need to look at the agreement in the context of the total CER package. However, it does conform to the principles for such an agreement which I outlined to the Australian Agricultural Council earlier this year.

The Government has made it clear that no final decisions on CER will be taken until there has been full consultation with all interested parties including the State Governments and industries. A special meeting of the Australian Agricultural Council will be convened to discuss specific concerns of the States before any final decisions are taken.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 March 1982 (Hansard, page 923) Senator Siddons asked me as the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: 1. Is he aware that Victoria is the only State of the Commonwealth that does not have a broadcasting channel available for religious broadcasting; and
2. Can some arrangements be made for a broadcasting channel to be made available for religious broadcasting in Melbourne.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provide me with the following answers:

ANSWER.PARA: 1. Public radio stations 2CBA-FM Sydney and 7HFC-FM Hobart specialise in regligious broadcasting and several commercial stations are licensed to churches or church-related organisations. I am not aware of such a station- commerical or public-in Victoria.

2. Commerical stations are not generally bound to follow particular formats or to specialise in particular areas of programming. There is provision for special purpose public stations, as indicated in (1), and organisations interested in religious broadcasting apply for licences when invited. One such organisation did apply to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal in 1978, but the Tribunal did not grant it a licence. It should be noted that the Minister, when inviting applications, establishes general specifications only; he would not designate any licence as for the special purpose of religious broadcasting.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —on 21 April 1982 (Hansard, page 1353) Senator McIntosh asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I preface it by reminding the Minister that the Australian Government joined with the Pacific nations at the South Pacific Forum, the South Pacific Commission and also at the recent Commonwealth Heads of Government meeting in condemning nuclear dumping and testing in the Pacific region. Is the Minister aware that the Australian yacht Pacific Peacemaker, which was protesting at the French nuclear testing at Moruroa Atoll, was impounded by the French authorities at Papeete in Tahiti. Is the Minister aware that the captain and crew of the Pacific Peacemaker claim that their yacht was deliberately rammed by a French vessel and that film of this incident is now being processed in Australia? I ask the Minister: If the ramming of the vessel is substantiated by a court of marine enquiry, will the Government be prepared to seek an apology from the French about the whole incident and also support a claim to be lodged by the owners of the vessel for proper compensation for damage caused to the yacht?
The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

I am aware that the Pacific Peacemaker was arrested and detained in Papeete. It is clear from the statement of the captain of the Pacific Peacemaker, Mr Ethell, that the purpose of his presence in French waters was to protest against French nuclear testing on Moruroa Atoll.
The Australian Consulate in Noumea unsuccessfully attempted to get in touch with Mr Ethell and Mr Ethell made no request for assistance to the Australian Government.

The French authorities in Tahiti have confirmed that Mr Ethell was fined 20, 000 CFP (approximately Australian $175) and that upon payment of the fine Mr Ethell and the Pacific Peacemaker would be free to depart Tahiti. The fine has now been paid and the Pacific Peacemaker has set sail for Hawaii, with Mr Ethell, his four children and one other Australian on board. The Australian Consul-General in Noumea was able to speak with Mr Ethell in Papeete prior to his departure, and Mr Ethell said he had been well treated during his stay in Tahiti. Mr Ethell has been assured by marine authorities that the French authorities would not be taking further action. The question of any possible compensation is one for Mr Ethell to pursue. So far as we are aware he has not indicated an intention to do so.
The Government of France is well aware of Australia's continued opposition to its nuclear testing program in the South Pacific.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 April 1982 (Hansard, page 1345) Senator Button asked me, as Minister representing the Prime Minister, a question without notice concerning arrangements made for Customs clearances when the Prime Minister, using his Boeing 707, flies directly into Canberra from overseas. Other questions concerned declarations of goods for inspection on the Prime Minister's return to Canberra after the Commonwealth Heads of Government Regional Meeting in September 1980.

ANSWER.PARA: The Prime Minister has supplied the following information for answer to the honourable senator's question:

An Australian customs and quarantine passanger statement is distributed to each passenger on the aircraft. Completed forms are presented to the Customs officer on arrival. Checks are made by Customs or quarantine officers as appropriate with persons who have given a 'yes' answer to any question. Customs officers may decide on a random and intuitive basis to examine the luggage of any persons on the flight.
These procedures were followed on the return to Australia on 10 September 1980 by each passenger on the aircraft. I am not aware of what goods, if any, were declared.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: International Narcotics Control Board: Report on Cannabis

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 April 1982 (Hansard, page 1506) Senator Walters asked me as the then Minister for Health a question without notice concerning the distribution of information contained in the report of the International Narcotics Control Board.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information to supplement the answer I gave then:

It is in the interests of drug abuse prevention that accurate information be readily available to the public. The National Information Service on Drug Abuse , within my Department, produces a regular publication entitled the Technical Information Bulletin (TIB). The TIB provides a comprehensive coverage of recent Australian and overseas news and research on all aspects of drugs of dependence and is distributed free of charge to a broad cross section of people, including key people in the community such as the judiciary, police and the media as well as those in health, education and related fields. Relevant extracts from the report of the International Narcotics Control Board, along with the findings of other bodies as to the effects of cannabis, will be considered for inclusion in a future issue of the TIB.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 4 May 1982 (Hansard, page 1771) Senator Evans asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology a question without notice concerning progress with preparing a formal agreement between the Australian Government and National Aeronautics and Space Administration covering the flying of a blood experiment of Dr Leopold Dintenfass in the space shuttle.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following information in relation to that question:
It is correct that the Dintenfass experiment has been rescheduled from early 1983 to the early 1984 space shuttle flight.

The question of liability for damage in the event of a shuttle crash has been of particular significance in these discussions. Dr Dintenfass has been kept informed of progress on this matter.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 20 May 1982 (Hansard, page 2213) Senator Archer asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: In view of the continuing weakness in the world tin market and the importance of tin to a number of Australian communities, particularly in Tasmania, what is the Government doing to improve the situation at present?
The Minister for Trade and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

There is little that the Government can do directly to counter the effect on the Australian tin mining industry of the weakness in the world tin market. The weakness is a result of the general downturn in world economic activity, some excess of production over demand, a build up of stocks of tin metal and the disposal of tin by the United States Government from surplus strategic stocks.

However, the adverse effects on the Australian industry have been moderated by the operation of the International Tin Agreement of which Australia is a member along with other tin producing countries and a number of consuming countries. Following a sharp fall in world prices last February prices have been prevented from falling further by the purchase of substantial quantities of tin under the buffer stock arrangements in the Tin Agreement.

Australia and other member countries have provided finance, in accordance with the terms of the Agreement to cover the purchase of some 27,000 tonnes of tin and the International Tin Council has also arranged bank loans to provide further funds for buffer stock operations. In addition, the International Tin Council decided last month that producer members of the Agreement should introduce export controls to limit the amount of current tin production being placed on the world market. There can be little doubt that tin prices would have virtually collapsed without the action under the International Tin Agreement.

As regards sales of tin from United States strategic stocks, these sales have a price depressing effect particularly in times of weak demand and have the potential to destabilise the world market. I made representations to the United States Special Trade Representative (Mr Brock) on 16 April 1982 suggesting that , in the current difficult situation the United States should temporarily cease sales of the surplus stockpile tin. Whilst this suggestion was not accepted the level of sales has been greatly reduced compared with that in the latter part of 1981.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 4 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a Press report in the Australian of Monday, April 26, which states that 'Queensland health authorities fear that a fatal form of dengue fever could break out in the State's north, possibly killing hundreds of people'.
(2) Is the 'killer' variety of this disease, known as dengue haemorrhagic fever and responsible for about 50,000 deaths a year in Asia.
(3) Have Queensland health authorities estimated that up to five million dollars would have to be spent over five years to remove the threat to Australia .

(4) Does the Commonwealth match State governments in the affected areas on a dollar for dollar basis in a co-ordinated attempt to eradicate dengue fever and prevent the introduction of the haemorrhagic variety; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) I assume the honourable senator is referring to a severe form of the disease, viz. dengue haemorrhagic fever and dengue shock syndrome, when he refers to the 'killer' variety of the disease in which there is mortality especially among children. From South East Asia, 20,632 deaths were notified in the 25 years from 1956 to 1980. These figures almost certainly grossly understate the actual occurrence of the disease in these countries due to difficulties in the reporting systems.

(3) Commonwealth and State officers maintain a close contact concerning the spread of arbo virus disease throughout Australia. This contact has also been maintained with Queensland health authorities during the recent dengue outbreak in Queensland.

The $5m mentioned in the honourable senator's question and said to be required for mosquito eradication in Queensland appears to represent comments quoted in the newspaper report and does not represent the views of the Queensland State Health Department.

Eradication of Aedes aegypti which is the particular mosquito vector of dengue fever could be achieved by a more modest expenditure on public health and public awareness programs conducted in local areas. The removal of discarded cans and drums, old tyres, and plastic food containers, particularly ice cream containers , and similar household items in which mosquitoes breed would quickly eliminate the problem.

(4) Funds are not provided by the Commonwealth to match State government funding on a dollar for dollar basis specifically to eradicate dengue fever. However, under the Australian Encephalitis Control Program, funding along these lines has been provided since 1974-75. The basis of the Australian Encephalitis Control Program is the control of mosquito vectors and consequently benefit is derived not only in relation to Australian Encephalitis but also in relation to a wider range of arbo virus diseases. In 1981-82 Queensland applied for, and received funding for the first time, under the program, for a mosquito control program based in the Townsville area. Queensland's proposal for Commonwealth funding for 1982-83 under the program is being considered in the budgetary context.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 April 1982 (Hansard, page 1504) Senator Townley asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, without notice:

If the Minister is not aware of the details of this matter-something which affects the whole world-will he ascertain that this is the actual situation, discuss the matter in Cabinet and make the Government's attitude known to this Parliament and to the United States?
The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

I refer the attention of the honourable senator to a reply given by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle on 6 May 1982 in answer to Question No. 2123 which sets out the Government's attitude to the matters he has raised.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 22 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did HMAS Bataan transport Britain's Lord Fraser, RN, to board the USS Missouri in Tokyo Bay on September 2, 1945, for the signing of the surrender, if so, how does this tally with the Minister's agreement with Senator Macklin that the Bataan and three other Australian warships, Shropshire, Hobart and Warramunga arrived in Tokyo after the signing of the surrender.
(2) Did servicemen from these warships, while on shore leave during this period , visit Nagasaki and photograph the devastation.
(3) What was the name and location of the submarine base south of Tokyo that the Bataan visited within three weeks of arriving in Tokyo.
(4) Will the Minister reassure the Senate that these sailors were not exposed to serious radiation levels, during this voyage.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Information on the movement of ships of the Royal Australian Navy is not held by my Department. However, I have been informed that the ships Bataan, Shropshire, Hobart and Warramunga entered Tokyo Bay on 31 August 1945. It is not known whether Admiral Sir Bruce Fraser O.S.C., was on board the Bataan. Japan had surrendered prior to this date although the official documents had not been signed and my reply to Senator Macklin in the Senate on 14 October 1981 (Hansard , page 1164) did not refer to the signing of the surrender.
(2) Records do not confirm this, although it is possible they did so.
(3) Yokosuka. Eleven miles south of Tokyo.

(4) Yes. On 21 April 1980 my predecessor answered a question on notice about the likely effects of radiation on Australian service personnel in Japan (House of Representatives Hansard, page 2042). Although that question dealt predominantly with the British Commonwealth Occupation Forces in 1946, part 3 of the question relates to nuclear radiation in the Hiroshima and Nagasaki areas.

The answer to that part of the question provides quite detailed information on both immediate and residual radiation but states, in part, that fallout from the atomic bombs dropped was limited to the Koi-Taksu area of Hiroshima and the Nishiyama area of Nagasaki. It further points out that both cities were engulfed in flames which precluded entry in the hypocentre for many hours and that a technical report-Arakawa E.T. (1962), 'Residual Radiation in Hiroshima and Nagasaki, ABCC Technical Report, 02-62'-stated that, allowing for the rapid decay of radiation, 'very few individuals, if any, received significant amounts of residual radiation from external sources.'

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 11 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will cigarette manufacturers be required to print tar and nicotine content on cigarette packets as from August 1982; if so, will all cigarettes on the market be tested by the Government before labelling takes place.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 April 1982 (Hansard, page 1349) Senator Evans asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Will the inquiry, whatever its nature, result in a public report? Will it deal with questions of not only internal departmental or administrative behaviour, but also ministerial behaviour and, in particular, the remaining central question in issue as to how Mr Moore was able to create the impression in the minds of his senior officers that the set in question was a black and white one in October 1981 when, according to him, the question of whether it was black or white or colour simply did not arise until April 1982?

I refer the honourable senator to the statement made in the House on 27 April 1982 by the Honourable N. A. Brown, M.P., then Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 4 May 1982 (Hansard, page 1765) Senator McIntosh asked me as the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: In view of the Government's announced reductions in expenditure on defence installations and the follow-on destroyer program, is it still the Governments intention to home port two destroyers and two submarines at HMAS Stirling in Western Australia by 1986?
The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

There has been no change to the plan to home port two destroyers at HMAS Stirling (response to Senator Martyr, Hansard, page 1496 of 22 April 1982 is relevant) and there are no plans at present to home port submarines there.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 6 May 1982 (Hansard, page 1907) Senator Mulvihill asked me as the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Can the Minister tell me whether the Public Service Board has at last responded to meet the tremendous demands that will be made on departmental staff in order to maintain adequate processing of migrant applications.
The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Public Service Board advised the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs on 7 May 1982 that the Department's 1981-82 staff ceiling has been increased by 26, of which 25 were for the new migrant entry policy. This increase was quickly distributed around the Department's regional offices and recruitment action set in motion to obtain the necessary staff as soon as possible.
